verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 1:1
verses.text: Homilies of St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 1:2
verses.text: John Chrysostom,  archbishop of constantinople,  on the  second epistle of St.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 1:3
verses.text: paul the apostle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 1:4
verses.text: to the  corinthians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:1
verses.text: Homily I.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:3
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:4
verses.text: ,  Paul, an Apostle of Jesus Christ through the will of God, and Timothy our brother, unto the Church of God, which is at Corinth, with all the saints which are in the whole of Achaia: grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:5
verses.text: Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of mercies and God of all comfort; Who comfort us in all our affliction, that we may be able to comfort them that are in any affliction through the comfort wherewith we ourselves are comforted of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:6
verses.text: It is meet to enquire, first, why to the former Epistle he adds a second: and what can be his reason for thus beginning with the mercies and consolation of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:7
verses.text: Why then does he add a second Epistle? Whereas in the first he had said, "I will come to you, and will know not the word of them which are puffed up, but the power;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:8
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:9
verses.text: ) and again towards the end had promised the same in milder terms, thus, "I will come unto you when I shall have passed through Macedonia; for I do pass through Macedonia; and it may be that I shall abide, or even winter with you;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:10
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:12
verses.text: ) yet now after along interval, he came not; but was still lingering and delaying even though the time appointed had passed away; the Spirit detaining him in other matters of far greater necessity than these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:13
verses.text: For this reason he had need to write a second Epistle, which he had not needed had he but a little out-tarried his time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:14
verses.text: But not for this reason only, but also because they were amended by the former; for him that had committed fornication whom before they applauded and were puffed up about, they had cut off and separated altogether.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:15
verses.text: And this he shows where he says, "But if any hath caused sorrow, he hath caused sorrow not to me, but in part (that I press not too heavily) to you all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:16
verses.text: Sufficient to such a one is this punishment which was inflicted by the many".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:17
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:18
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:20
verses.text: ) And as he proceeds, he alludes again to the same thing when he says, "For behold that ye were made sorry after a godly sort, what earnest care it wrought in you, yea, what clearing of yourselves, yea, what indignation, yea, what fear, yea, what longing, yea, what zeal, yea, what avenging! In every thing ye approved yourselves to be pure in this matter".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:21
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:22
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:23
verses.text: ) Moreover, the collection which he enjoined, they gathered with much forwardness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:24
verses.text: Wherefore also he says, "For I know your readiness of which I glory on your behalf to them of Macedonia, that Achaia hath been prepared for a year past".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:25
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:26
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:27
verses.text: ) And Titus too, whom he sent, they received with all kindness, as he shows when he says again, "His inward affection is more abundantly toward you, whilst he remembereth the obedience of you all, how with fear and trembling ye received him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:28
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:29
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:30
verses.text: ) For all these reasons he writes the second Epistle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:31
verses.text: For it was right that, as when they were in fault he rebuked them, so upon their amendment he should approve and commend them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:32
verses.text: On which account the Epistle is not very severe throughout, but only in a few parts towards the end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:33
verses.text: For there were even amongst them Jews who thought highly of themselves, and accused Paul as being a boaster and worthy of no regard; whence also that speech of theirs; "His letters are weighty, but his bodily presence is weak, and his speech of no account:" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:34
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:35
verses.text: ) meaning thereby, when he is present he appears of no account, (for this is the meaning of, "his bodily presence is weak,") but when he is away he boasts greatly in what he writes, (for such is the signification of "his letters are weighty".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:36
verses.text: ) Moreover, to enhance their own credit these persons made a pretence of receiving nothing, to which he also alludes where he says, "that wherein they glory, they may be found even as we".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:37
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:38
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:39
verses.text: ) And besides, possessing also the power of language, they were forthwith greatly elated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:40
verses.text: Wherefore also he calls himself "rude in speech," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:41
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:42
verses.text: ) showing that he is not ashamed thereof; nor deems the contrary any great acquisition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:43
verses.text: Seeing then it was likely that by these persons some would be seduced, after commending what was right in their conduct, and beating down their senseless pride in the things of Judaism, in that out of season they were contentious to observe them, he administers a gentle rebuke on this subject also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:44
verses.text: Such then, to speak summarily and by the way, appears to me the argument of this Epistle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:45
verses.text: It remains to consider the introduction, and to say why after his accustomed salutation he begins, as he does, with the mercies of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:46
verses.text: But first, it is necessary to speak of the very beginning, and inquire why he here associates Timothy with himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:47
verses.text: For, he saith, "Paul an Apostle of Jesus Christ through the will of God, and Timothy our brother".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:48
verses.text: In the first Epistle he promised he would send him; and charged them, saying, "Now if Timothy come, see that he be with you without fear".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:49
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:50
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:51
verses.text: ) How then is it that he associates him here in the outset with himself? After he had been amongst them, agreeably to that promise of his teacher, "I have sent unto you Timothy who shall put you in remembrance of my ways which be in Christ," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:52
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:53
verses.text: ) and had set everything in order, he had returned back to Paul; who on sending him, had said, "Set him forward on his journey in peace that he may come to me, for I expect him with the brethren".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:54
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:55
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:56
verses.text: )  Since then Timothy was restored to his teacher, and after having with him set in order the things in Asia, (for, says he, "I will tarry at Ephesus until Pentecost,"  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:57
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:58
verses.text: ;) had crossed again into Macedonia; Paul not unreasonably associates him hereafter as abiding with himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:59
verses.text: For then he wrote from Asia, but now from Macedonia.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:60
verses.text: Moreover, thus associating him he at once gains increased respect for him, and displays his own exceeding humility: for Timothy was very inferior to himself, yet doth love bring all things together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:61
verses.text: Whence also he everywhere makes him equal with himself; at one time saying, "as a child serveth a father so he served with me;" (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:62
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:63
verses.text: ) at another, "for he worketh the work of the Lord, as I also do;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:64
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:65
verses.text: ) and here, he even calleth him, "brother;" by all making him an object of respect to the Corinthians amongst whom he had been, as I have said, and given proof of his worth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:66
verses.text: "To the Church of God which is at Corinth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:67
verses.text: Again he calleth them "the Church," to bring and bind them all together in one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:68
verses.text: For it could not be one Church, while those within her were sundered and stood apart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:69
verses.text: "With all the saints which are in the whole of Achaia.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:70
verses.text: In thus saluting all through the Epistle addressed to the Corinthians, he would at once honor these, and bring together the whole nation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:71
verses.text: But he calls them "saints," thereby implying that if any be an impure person, he hath no share in this salutation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:72
verses.text: But why, writing to the mother city, does he address all through her, since he doth not so everywhere? For instance, in his Epistle to the Thessalonians he addressed not the Macedonians also; and in like manner in that to the Ephesians he doth not include all Asia; neither was that to the Romans written to those also who dwell in Italy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:73
verses.text: But in this Epistle he doth so; and in that to the Galatians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:74
verses.text: For there also he writeth not to one city, or two, or three, but to all who are scattered every where, saying, "Paul an Apostle, (not from men neither through man, but through Jesus Christ, and God the Father, Who raised Him from the dead,) and all the brethren which are with me, unto the Churches of Galatia.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:75
verses.text: Grace to you and peace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:76
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:77
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:79
verses.text: ) To the Hebrews also he writes one Epistle to all collectively; not distinguishing them into their several cities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:80
verses.text: What then can be the reason of this? Because, as I think, in this case all were involved in one common disorder, wherefore also he addresses them in common, as needing one common remedy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:81
verses.text: For the Galatians were all of them infected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:82
verses.text: So too were the Hebrews, and so I think these (Achaians) also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:83
verses.text: So then having brought the whole nation together in one, and saluted them with his accustomed greeting, for, saith he, "Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ:" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:84
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:85
verses.text: ) hear how aptly to the purpose in hand he begins, "Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of mercies and God of all comfort".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:86
verses.text: (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:87
verses.text: ) Do you ask, how is this aptly to the purpose in hand? I reply, Very much so; for observe, they were greatly vexed and troubled that the Apostle had not come to them, and that, though he had promised, but had spent the whole time in Macedonia; preferring as it seemed others to themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:88
verses.text: Setting himself then to meet this feeling against him, he declares the cause of his absence; not however directly stating it, as thus; "I know, indeed, I promised to come, but since I was hindered by afflictions forgive me, nor judge me guilty of any sort of contempt or neglect towards you:" but after another manner he invests the subject at once with more dignity and trustworthiness, and gives it greatness by the nature of the consolation, so that thereafter they might not so much as ask the reason of his delay.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:89
verses.text: Just as if one, having promised to come to one he longed for, at length arriving after dangers innumerable, should say, "Glory to Thee, O God, for letting me see the sight so longed for of his dear countenance! Blessed be Thou, O God, from what perils hast Thou delivered me!" for such a doxology is an answer to him who was preparing to find fault, and will not let him so much as complain of the delay; for one that is thanking God for deliverance from such great calamities he cannot for shame drag to the bar, and bid clear himself of loitering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:90
verses.text: Whence Paul thus begins, "Blessed be the God of mercies," implying by the very words that he had been both brought into and delivered from mighty perils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:91
verses.text: For as David also doth not address God every where in one way or with the same titles; but when he is upon battle and victory, "I will love Thee, he saith, O Lord my strength; the Lord is my buckler:" when again upon delivery from affliction and the darkness which overwhelmed him, "The Lord is my light and my salvation;" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:92
verses.text: xxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:93
verses.text: ) and as the immediate occasion suggests, he names Him now from His loving-kindness, now from His justice, now from His righteous judgment:—in like way Paul also here at the beginning describeth Him by His loving-kindness, calling Him "the God of mercies," that is, "Who hath showed me so great mercies as to bring me up from the very gates of death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:94
verses.text: And thus to have mercy is the peculiar and excellent attribute of God, and the most inherent in His nature; whence he calleth Him the "God of mercies".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:95
verses.text: And observe, I pray you, herein also the lowly-mindedness of Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:96
verses.text: For though he were in peril because of the Gospel he preached; yet saith he not, he was saved for his merit, but for the mercies of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:97
verses.text: But this he afterwards declareth more clearly, and now goes on to say, "Who comforteth us in all affliction".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:98
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:99
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:100
verses.text: ) He saith not, "Who suffereth us not to come into affliction:" but, "Who comforteth in affliction".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:101
verses.text: For this at once declareth the power of God; and increaseth the patience of those afflicted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:102
verses.text: For, saith he, "tribulation worketh patience".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:103
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:104
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:105
verses.text: ) And so also the prophet, "Thou hast set me at large when I was in distress".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:106
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:107
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:108
verses.text: ) He doth not say, "Thou hast not suffered me to fall into affliction," nor yet, "Thou hast quickly removed my affliction," but, whilst it continueth, "Thou hast set me at large:" (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:109
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:111
verses.text: ) that is, "hast granted me much freedom and refreshment".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:112
verses.text: Which truly happened also in the case of the three children, for neither did He prevent their being cast into the flame, nor when so cast, did He quench it, but while the furnace was burning He gave them liberty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:113
verses.text: And such is ever God's way of dealing; as Paul also implies when he says, "Who comforteth us in all affliction".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:114
verses.text: But he teaches something more in these words: Do you ask what? Namely, that God doeth this not once, nor twice, but without intermission.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:115
verses.text: For He doth not one while comfort, another not, but ever and constantly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:116
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "Who comforteth," not, "Who hath comforted," and, "in all affliction," not, "in this or that," but, "in all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:117
verses.text: "That we may be able to comfort them which are in any affliction through the comfort wherewith we ourselves are comforted of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:118
verses.text: See you not how he is beforehand with his defence by suggesting to the hearer the thought of some great affliction; and herein also is his modesty again apparent, that he saith not for their own merits was this mercy showed, but for the sake of those that need their assistance; "for," saith he, "to this end hath He comforted us that we might comfort one another".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:119
verses.text: And hereby also he manifesteth the excellency of the Apostles, shewing that having been comforted and breathed awhile, he lieth not softly down as we, but goeth on his way to anoint, to nerve, to rouse others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:120
verses.text: Some, however, consider this as the Apostle's meaning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:121
verses.text: "Our consolation is that of others also:" but my opinion is that in this introduction, he is also censuring the false Apostles, those vain boasters who sat at home and lived in luxury; but this covertly and, as it were, incidentally, the leading object being to apologise for his delay.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:122
verses.text: "For," he would say, "if for this end we were comforted that we might comfort others also, do not blame us that we came not; for in this was our whole time spent, in providing against the conspiracies, the violence, the terrors which assailed us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:123
verses.text: "For as the sufferings of Christ abound unto us, even so our comfort also aboundeth through Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:124
verses.text: Not to depress the disciples by an aggravated account of his sufferings; he declareth on the other hand that great and superabundant was the consolation also, and lifteth up their heart not hereby alone, but also by putting them in mind of Christ and calling the sufferings "His," and prior to the consolation deriveth a comfort from the very sufferings themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:125
verses.text: For what joy can I have so great as to be partaker with Christ, and for His sake to suffer these things? What consolation can equal this? But not from this source only does he raise the spirits of the afflicted, but from another also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:126
verses.text: Ask you what other? In that he saith, "abound:" for he doth not say, "As the sufferings of Christ" are "in us," but as they "abound," thereby declaring that they endure not His sufferings only, but even more than these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:127
verses.text: For, saith he, "not whatsoever He suffered, that have we suffered; "but even more," for, consider, "Christ was cast out, persecuted, scourged, died," but we, saith he, "more than all this," which even of itself were consolation enough.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:128
verses.text: Now let no one condemn this speech of boldness; for he elsewhere saith, "Now I rejoice in my sufferings, and fill up on my part that which is lacking of the afflictions of Christ in my flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:129
verses.text: (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:130
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:131
verses.text: ) Yet neither here nor there is it from boldness or any presumptousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:132
verses.text: For as they wrought greater miracles than He according to that saying of His, "he that believeth on Me shall do greater works than these," (John xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:133
verses.text: ) but all is of Him that worketh in them; so did they suffer also more than He, but all again is of Him that comforteth them, and fitteth them to bear the evils that betide them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:134
verses.text: With which respect Paul aware how great a thing he had said, doth again remarkably restrain it by adding, "So our comfort also aboundeth through Christ;" thus at once ascribing all to Him, and proclaiming herein also His loving-kindness; for, he saith not, "As our affliction, such our consolation;" but "far more;" for, he saith not, "our comfort is equal to our sufferings," but, "our comfort aboundeth," so that the season of struggles was the season also of fresh crowns.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:135
verses.text: For, say, what is equal to being scourged for Christ's sake and holding converse with God; and being more than match for all things, and gaining the better of those who cast us out, and being unconquered by the whole world, and expecting hence such good things "as eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither have entered into the heart of man!" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:136
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:137
verses.text: ) And what is equal to suffering affliction for godliness' sake, and receiving from God consolations infinite, and being rescued from sins so great, and counted worthy of the Spirit, and of being sanctified and justified, and regarding no man with fear and trembling, and in peril itself outshining all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:138
verses.text: Let us then not sink down when tempted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:139
verses.text: For no self-indulger hath fellowship with Christ, nor sleeper, nor supine person, nor any of these lax and dissolute livers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:140
verses.text: But Whoso is in affliction and temptation, this man standeth near to Him, whoso is journeying on the narrow way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:141
verses.text: For He Himself trode this; whence too He saith, "the Son of Man hath not where to lay His head".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:142
verses.text: So then grieve not when thou art in affliction; considering with Whom thou hast fellowship, and how thou art purified by trials; and how great gain is thine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:143
verses.text: For there is nothing miserable save the offending against God; but this apart, neither afflictions nor conspiracies, nor any other thing hath power to grieve the right-minded soul: but like as a little spark, if thou cast it into a mighty deep, thou presently puttest it out, so doth even a total and excessive sorrow if it light on a good conscience easily die away and disappear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:144
verses.text: Such then was the spring of Paul's continual joy: because in whatever was of God he was full of hope; and did not so much as take count of ills so great, but though he grieved as a man yet sank not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:145
verses.text: So too was that Patriarch encompassed with joy in the midst of much painful suffering; for consider, he forsook his country, underwent journeyings long and hard; when he came into a strange land, had "not so much as to set his foot on".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:146
verses.text: (Acts vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:147
verses.text: ) Then again a famine awaited him which made him once more a wanderer; after the famine again came the seizure of his wife, then the fear of death, and childlessness, and battle, and peril, and conspiracies, and at the last that crowning trial, the slaying of his only-begotten and true son, that grievous irreparable sacrifice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:148
verses.text: For think not, I pray you, that because he readily obeyed, he felt not all the things he underwent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:149
verses.text: For though his righteousness had been, as indeed it was, inestimable, yet was he a man and felt as nature bade.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:150
verses.text: But yet did none of these things cast him down, but he stood like a noble athlete, and for each one was proclaimed and crowned a victor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:151
verses.text: So also the blessed Paul, though seeing trials in very snow-showers assailing him daily, rejoiced and exulted as though in the mid-delights of Paradise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:152
verses.text: As then he who is gladdened with this joy cannot be a prey to despair; so he who maketh not this his own is easily overcome of all; and is as one that hath unsound armor, and is wounded by even a common stroke: but not so he who is well encased at all points, and proof against every shaft that cometh upon him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:153
verses.text: And truly stouter than any armor is joy in God; and whoso hath it, nothing can ever make his head droop or his countenance sad, but he beareth all things nobly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:154
verses.text: For what is worse to bear than fire? what more painful than continual torture? truly it is more overpowering in pain than the loss of untold wealth, of children, of any thing; for, saith he, "Skin for skin, yea, all that a man hath will he give for his life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:155
verses.text: (Job ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:156
verses.text: ) So nothing can be harder to bear than bodily pain; nevertheless, because of this joy in God, what even to hear of is intolerable, becomes both tolerable and longed for: and if thou take from the cross or from the gridiron the martyr yet just breathing, thou wilt find such a treasure of joy within him as admits not of being told.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:157
verses.text: And doth any one say, What am I to do; for now is no time of martyrdom? What sayest thou? Is now no time of martyrdom? Never is it not a time; but ever is it before our eyes; if we will keep them open.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:158
verses.text: For it is not the hanging on a cross only that makes a Martyr, for were this so, then was Job excluded from this crown; for he neither stood at bar, nor heard Judge's voice, nor looked on executioner; no, nor while hanging on tree aloft had his sides mangled; yet he suffered worse than many martyrs; more sharply than any stroke did the tale of those successive messengers strike, and goad him on every side: and keener the gnawings of the worms which devoured him in every part than thousand executioners.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:159
verses.text: Against what martyr then may he not worthily be set? Surely against ten thousand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:160
verses.text: For in every kind of suffering he both wrestled and was crowned; in goods, and children, and person, and wife, and friends, and enemies, and servants, (for these too even did spit in his face,) in hunger and visions and pains and noisomeness; it was for this I said he might worthily be set, not against one nor two nor three, but against ten thousand Martyrs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:161
verses.text: For besides what I have mentioned, the time also maketh a great addition to his crown; in that it was before the Law, before Grace, he thus suffered, and that, many months, and each in its worst form; and all these evils assailed him at once.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:162
verses.text: And yet each individual evil by itself intolerable, even that which seemeth most tolerable, the loss of his goods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:163
verses.text: For many have patiently borne stripes, but could not bear the loss of their goods; but rather than relinquish any part of them were content even to be scourged for their sake and suffer countless ills; and this blow, the loss of goods, appeared to them heavier than all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:164
verses.text: So then here is another method of martyrdom for one who bears this loss nobly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:165
verses.text: And doth any ask, How shall we bear it nobly? When thou hast learned that by one word of thanksgiving thou shalt gain more than all thou hast lost.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:166
verses.text: For if at the tidings of our loss we be not troubled, but say, "Blessed be God," we have found far more abundant riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:167
verses.text: For truly such great fruit thou shalt not reap by expending all thy wealth on the needy, by going about and seeking out the poor, and scattering thy substance to the hungry, as thou shalt gain by the same word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:168
verses.text: And so neither Job do I admire so much in setting wide his house to the needy, as I am struck with and extol his taking the spoiling of his substance thankfully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:169
verses.text: The same in the loss of children it happeneth to see.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:170
verses.text: For herein, also, reward no less than his who offered his son and presented him in sacrifice shalt thou receive, if as thou seest thine die thou shalt thank the God of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:171
verses.text: For how shalt such an one be less than Abraham? He saw not his son stretched out a corpse, but only looked to do so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:172
verses.text: So if he gain in the comparison by his purpose to slay and his stretching forth his hand to take the knife, (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:173
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:174
verses.text: ) yet doth he lose in that the child is lying dead here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:175
verses.text: And besides, he had some comfort in the prospect of a good work done, and the thought that this so excellent achievement was the work of his own fortitude, and that the voice he heard came from above made him the readier.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:176
verses.text: But here is no such thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:177
verses.text: So that he had need have a soul of adamant, who can bear with calmness to see a child, his only one, brought up in affluence, in the dawn of fair promise, lying upon the bier an outstretched corpse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:178
verses.text: And should such an one, hushing to rest the heavings of nature, be strengthened to say the words of Job without a tear, "The Lord gave, the Lord hath taken away;" (Job i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:179
verses.text: ) for those words' sake alone, he shall stand with Abraham himself and with Job be proclaimed a victor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:180
verses.text: And if, staying the wailings of the women and breaking up the bands of mourners, he shall rouse them all to sing glory to God, he shall receive above, below, rewards unnumbered; men admiring, angels applauding, God crowning him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:181
verses.text: And sayest thou, How is it possible for one that is man not to mourn? I reply, If thou wilt reflect how neither the Patriarch nor Job, who both were men, gave way to any thing of the kind; and this too in either case before the Law, and Grace, and the excellent wisdom of the laws we have: if thou wilt account that the deceased has removed into a better country, and bounded away to a happier inheritance, and that thou hast not lost thy son but bestowed him henceforward in an inviolable spot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:182
verses.text: Say not then, I pray thee, I am no longer called "father," for why art thou no longer called so, when thy son abideth? For surely thou didst not part with thy child nor lose thy son? Rather thou hast gotten him, and hast him in greater safety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:183
verses.text: Wherefore, no longer shalt thou be called "father" here only, but also in heaven; so that thou hast not lost the title "father," but hast gained it in a nobler sense; for henceforth thou shalt be called father not of a mortal child, but of an immortal; of a noble soldier; on duty continually within the palace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:184
verses.text: For think not because he is not present that therefore he is lost; for had he been absent in a foreign land, the title of thy relationship had not gone from thee with his body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:185
verses.text: Do not then gaze on the countenance of what lieth there, for so thou dost but kindle afresh thy grief; but away with thy thought from him that lieth there, up to heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:186
verses.text: That is not thy child which is lying there, but he who hath flown away and sprung aloft into boundless height.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:187
verses.text: When then thou seest the eyes closed, the lips locked together, the body motionless, Oh be not these thy thoughts, "These lips no longer speak, these eyes no longer see, these feet no longer walk, but are all on their way to corruption!" Oh say not so: but say the reverse of this, "These lips shall speak better, and the eyes see greater things, and the feet shall mount upon the clouds; and this body which now rotteth away shall put on immortality, and I shall receive my son back more glorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:188
verses.text: But if what thou seest distress thee, say to thyself the while, This is only clothing and he has put it off to receive it back more precious; this is an house and it is taken down to be restored in greater splendor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:189
verses.text: For like as we, when purposing to take houses down, allow not the inmates to stay, that they may escape the dust and noise; but causing them to remove a little while, when we have built up the tenement securely, admit them freely; so also doth God; Who taking down this His decaying tabernacle hath received him the while into His paternal dwelling and unto Himself, that when it hath been taken down and built anew He may then return it to him more glorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:190
verses.text: Say not then, "He is perished and shall no more be;" for these be the words of unbelievers; but say, "He sleepeth and will rise again," "He is gone a journey and will return with the King".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:191
verses.text: Who sayeth this? He that hath Christ speaking in him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:192
verses.text: "For," saith he, "if we believe that Jesus died and rose again" and revived, "even so them also which sleep in Jesus will God bring with Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:193
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:194
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:195
verses.text: ) If then thou seek thy son, there seek him where the King is, where is the army of the Angels; not in the grave; not in the earth; lest whilst he is so highly exalted, thyself remain grovelling on the ground.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 2:196
verses.text: If we have this true wisdom, we shall easily repel all this kind of distress; and "the God of mercies and Father of all comfort" comfort all our hearts, both those who are oppressed with such grief and those held down with any other sorrow; and grant us deliverance from all despair and increase of spiritual joy; and to obtain the good things to come; whereunto may all we attain, through the grace and loving-kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom unto the Father, together with the Holy Spirit, be glory, power, honor, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:1
verses.text: Homily II.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:3
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:4
verses.text: ,  Whether we be afflicted, it is for your comfort and salvation, which worketh in the patient enduring of the same sufferings which we also suffer: and our hope for you is steadfast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:5
verses.text: Having spoken of one, and that the chief ground of comfort and consolation, namely, having fellowship by sufferings with Christ: he layeth down as second this which he now mentions, namely, that the salvation of the disciples themselves was procured thereby.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:6
verses.text: "Faint not, therefore, he says, nor be confounded and afraid because we are afflicted; for this same thing were rather a reason for your being of good cheer: for had we not been afflicted, this had been the ruin of you all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:7
verses.text: How and wherein? For if through lack of spirit and fear of danger we had not preached unto you the word whereby ye learned the true knowledge, your situation had been desperate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:8
verses.text: Seest thou again the vehemence and earnest contention of Paul? The very things which troubled them he uses for their comfort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:9
verses.text: For, saith he, the greater the intensity of our persecutions, the greater should be the increase of your good hope; because the more abundant also in proportion is your salvation and consolation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:10
verses.text: For what hath equal force of consolation with this of having obtained such good things through the preaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:11
verses.text: Then that he may not seem to be bringing the encomium round to himself alone, see how he maketh them too to share these praises.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:12
verses.text: For to the words, "Whether we be afflicted, it is for your comfort and salvation:" he adds, "which worketh in the patient enduring of the same sufferings which we also suffer".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:13
verses.text: (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:14
verses.text: ) Afterwards, indeed, he states this more clearly, thus saying, "As ye are partakers of the sufferings, so also are ye of the consolation;" but here also meanwhile he alludes to it in the words, "the same sufferings," so making what he says include them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:15
verses.text: For what he saith is this, "Your salvation is not our work alone, but your own as well; for both we in preaching to you the word endure affliction, and ye in receiving it endure the very same; we to impart to you that which we received, ye to receive what is imparted and not to let it go".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:16
verses.text: Now what humility can compare with this, seeing that those who fell so far short of him he raiseth to the same dignity of endurance? for he saith, "Which worked in the enduring of the same sufferings;" for not through believing only cometh your salvation, but also through the suffering and enduring the same things with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:17
verses.text: For like as a pugilist is an object of admiration, when he doth but show himself and is in good training and hath his skill within himself, but when he is in action, enduring blows and striking his adversary, then most of all shineth forth, because that then his good training is most put in action, and the proof of his skill evidently shown; so truly is your salvation also then more especially put into action, that is, is displayed, increased, heightened, when it hath endurance, when it suffereth and beareth all things nobly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:18
verses.text: So then the work of salvation consisteth not in doing evil, but in suffering evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:19
verses.text: Moreover he saith not, "which worketh," but, "which is wrought," to show that together with their own willingness of mind, grace also which wrought in them did contribute much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:20
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:21
verses.text: "And our hope for you is steadfast".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:22
verses.text: That is, though ye should suffer ills innumerable, we are confident that ye will not turn round, either upon your own trials or upon our persecutions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:23
verses.text: For so far are we from suspecting you of being confounded on account of our sufferings that even when yourselves are in peril, we are then confident concerning you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:24
verses.text: Seest thou how great had been their advance since the former Epistle? For he hath here witnessed of them far greater things than of the Macedonians, whom throughout that Epistle he extolleth and commendeth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:25
verses.text: For on their the Macedonians' account he feared and saith, "We sent," unto you, "Timothy…to establish you, and to comfort you concerning your faith, that no man be moved by these afflictions, for yourselves know that hereunto we are appointed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:26
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:27
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:29
verses.text: ) And again: "For this cause when I could no longer forbear, I sent to know your faith, lest by any means the tempter hath tempted you: and our labor should be in vain".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:30
verses.text: (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:31
verses.text: ) But of these the Corinthians he saith nothing of this kind, but quite the contrary, "Our hope for you is steadfast".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:32
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:34
verses.text: "Or whether we be comforted, it is for your consolation and salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:35
verses.text: Knowing that as ye are partakers of the sufferings, so also are ye of the comfort".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:36
verses.text: That for their sakes the Apostles were afflicted, he showed when he said, "whether we be afflicted, it is for your consolation and salvation:" he wishes also to show that for their sakes also they were comforted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:37
verses.text: He said this indeed even a little above, although somewhat generally, thus; "Blessed be God, Who comforteth us in all our afflictions, that we may be able to comfort them which are in any affliction".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:38
verses.text: He repeats it here too in other words more clearly and more home to their needs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:39
verses.text: "For whether we be comforted," says he, "it is for your comfort".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:40
verses.text: What he means is this; our comfort becometh your refreshment, even though we should not comfort you by word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:41
verses.text: If we be but a little refreshed, this availeth for encouragement to you; and if we be ourselves comforted, this becometh your comfort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:42
verses.text: For as ye consider our sufferings your own, so do ye also make our comfort your own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:43
verses.text: For surely it cannot be that, when ye share in worse fortune with us, ye will not share in the better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:44
verses.text: If then ye share in everything, as in tribulation so in comfort, ye will in no wise blame us for this delay and slowness in coming, because that both for your sakes we are in tribulation and for your sakes in comfort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:45
verses.text: For lest any should think this a hard saying, "for your sakes we thus suffer," he adds, "for your sakes also we are comforted," and "not we alone are in peril; for ye also," saith he, "are partakers of the same sufferings".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:46
verses.text: Thus then, by admitting them to be partakers in the perils and ascribing to them the cause of their own comfort, he softeneth what he saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:47
verses.text: If then we be beset by craft, be of good cheer; we endure this that your faith may grow in strength.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:48
verses.text: And if we be comforted, glory in this also; for we enjoy this too for your sakes, that thereby ye may receive some encouragement by sharing in our joy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:49
verses.text: And that the comfort he here speaks of is that which they enjoyed not only from being comforted by themselves, (the Apostles) but also from knowing them (the Apostles) to be at rest, hear him declaring in what follows next, "Knowing that as ye are partakers of the sufferings, so also are ye of the comfort".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:50
verses.text: For as when we suffer persecution, ye are in distress as though yourselves so suffering; so are we sure that when we are comforted, ye think the enjoyment also your own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:51
verses.text: What more humble-minded than this spirit? He who so greatly surpasseth in perils, calleth them "partakers," who endured no part of them whatever; whilst of the comfort he ascribeth the whole cause to them, not to his own labors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:52
verses.text: Next, having spoken before only generally of troubles, he now maketh mention of the place too where they (Ben.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:53
verses.text: he) endured them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:54
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:55
verses.text: "For we would not, Brethren, have you ignorant concerning our affliction which befell us in Asia".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:56
verses.text: "These things we speak," saith he, "that ye may not be ignorant of what befell us; for we wish, yea have earnestly endeavored, that ye should know our affairs:" which is a very high proof of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:57
verses.text: Of this even in the former Epistle he had before given notice, where he said, "For a great door and effectual is opened to me at Ephesus, and there are many adversaries".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:58
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:59
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:61
verses.text: ) Putting them then in mind of this, and recounting how much he suffered, he saith, "I would not have you ignorant of our affliction which befell us in Asia".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:62
verses.text: And in his Epistle to the Ephesians too he said the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:63
verses.text: For having sent Tychicus to them, he gives this as the reason of his journey: whence he saith, "But that ye also may know my affairs, and how I do, Tychicus, the beloved brother and faithful minister in the Lord, shall make known to you all things; whom I have sent unto you for this very purpose, that ye may know our state, and that he may comfort your hearts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:64
verses.text: (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:65
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:67
verses.text: ) And in other Epistles also he doeth the very same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:68
verses.text: Nor is it superfluous, but even exceedingly necessary: both because of his exceeding affection for the disciples, and because of their continued trials; wherein the knowledge of each other's fortunes was a very great comfort; so that if these were calamitous, they might be prepared both to be energetic and to be safer against falling; or if these were good, they might rejoice with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:69
verses.text: He here, however, speaketh as well of being delivered from trials as of being assaulted by them, saying, "We were weighed down exceedingly, beyond our power".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:70
verses.text: Like a vessel sinking under some mighty burden.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:71
verses.text: He may seem to have said, only one thing here "exceedingly" and "beyond our power:" it is, however, not one but two; for lest one should object, "What then? granting the peril were exceeding, yet it was not great to you;" he added, it both was great and surpassed our strength, yea, so surpassed it, "That we despaired even of life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:72
verses.text: That is, we had no longer any expectation of living.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:73
verses.text: What David calleth "the gates of hell, the pangs" and "the shadow of death," this he expresseth by saying, "We endured peril pregnant with certain death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:74
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:75
verses.text: "But we had the answer of death in ourselves, that we should not trust in ourselves, but in God which raiseth the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:76
verses.text: What is this, "the answer of death?" The vote, the judgment, the expectation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:77
verses.text: For so spake our affairs; our fortunes gave this answer, "We shall surely die".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:78
verses.text: To be sure, this did not come to the proof, but only as far as to our anticipations, and stopped there: for the nature of our affairs did so declare, yet the power of God allowed not the declaration to take effect, but permitted it to happen only in our thought and in expectation: wherefore he saith, "We had the answer of death in ourselves," not in fact.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:79
verses.text: And wherefore permitted He peril so great as to take away our hope and cause us to despair? "That we should not trust in ourselves," saith he, "but in God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:80
verses.text: These words Paul said, not that this was his own temper.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:81
verses.text: Away with such a thought, but as attuning the rest by what he saith of himself, and in his great care to speak modestly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:82
verses.text: Whence also further on he saith, "There was given to me a thorn in the flesh, (meaning his trials,) lest I should be exalted overmuch".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:83
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:84
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:85
verses.text: ) And yet God doth not say that He permitted them for this, but for another reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:86
verses.text: What other? That His strength might be the more displayed; "For," saith he, "My grace is sufficient for thee, for My power is made perfect in weakness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:87
verses.text: (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:88
verses.text: ) But, as I said, he no where forgetteth his own peculiar character, classing himself with those who fall short exceedingly and stand in need of much discipline and correction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:89
verses.text: For if one or two trials suffice to sober even ordinary men, how should he who of all men had most cultivated lowliness of mind his whole life long and had suffered as no other man did, after so many years and a practice of wisdom worthy of the heavens, be in need of this admonition? Whence it is plain that here too, it is from modesty and to calm down those who thought highly of themselves and boasted, that he thus speaks, "That we should not trust in ourselves, but in God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:90
verses.text: And observe how he treateth them tenderly here also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:91
verses.text: For, saith he, these trials were permitted to come upon us for your sakes; of so great price are ye in God's sight; for "whether we be afflicted," saith he, "it is for your consolation and salvation;" but they were "out of measure" for our sake, lest we should be high minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:92
verses.text: "For we were weighed down exceedingly, beyond our power, that we should not trust in ourselves, but in God that raiseth the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:93
verses.text: He again putteth them in mind of the doctrine of the Resurrection whereon he said so much in the former Epistle, and confirmeth it from the present circumstance; whence he added,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:94
verses.text: "Who delivered us out of so great deaths".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:95
verses.text: He said not, "from so great dangers," at once showing the insupportable severity of the trials, and confirming the doctrine I have mentioned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:96
verses.text: For whereas the Resurrection was a thing future, he showeth that it happeneth every day: for when God lifteth up again a man who is despaired of and hath been brought to the very gates of Hades, He showeth none other thing than a resurrection, snatching out of the very jaws of death him that had fallen into them: whence in the case of those despaired of and then restored either out of grievous sickness or insupportable trials, it is an ordinary way of speaking to say, We have seen a resurrection of the dead in his case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:97
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:99
verses.text: "And we have set our hope that He will also still deliver us; ye also helping together on our behalf by your supplication, that for the gift bestowed upon us by the means of many, thanks may be given by many persons on our behalf".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:100
verses.text: Since the words, "that we should not trust in ourselves," might seem to be a common charge and an accusation that pointed to some amongst them; he softeneth again what he said, by calling their prayers a great protection and at the same time showing that this our life must be throughout a scene of conflict.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:101
verses.text: For in those words, "And we have set our hope that He will also still deliver us," he predicts a future sleet of many trials: but still no where aught of being forsaken, but of succor again and support.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:102
verses.text: Then, lest on hearing that they were to be continually in perils they should be cast down, he showed before the use of perils; for instance, "that we should not trust in ourselves;" that is, that he may keep us in continual humility, and that their salvation may be wrought; and many other uses besides; the being partakers with Christ; ("for," saith he, "the sufferings of Christ abound in us;") the suffering for the faithful; ("for," saith he, "whether we be afflicted, it is for your comfort and salvation;") the superior lustre this last (i-e:, their salvation) should shine with; "which," saith he, "worketh" in you "in the patient enduring of the same sufferings;" their being made hardy; and besides all these, that of seeing the resurrection vividly portrayed before their eyes: for, "He hath delivered us out of so great death;" being of an earnest mind and ever looking unto Him, "for," saith he, "we have set our hope that he will deliver" us; its rivetting them to prayers, for he saith, "ye also helping together on our behalf by your supplication".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:103
verses.text: Thus having shown the gain of affliction and then having made them energetic: he anointeth once more their spirits for the combat, and animates them to virtue by witnessing great things of their prayers, for that to these God had granted Paul; as he saith, "Ye helping together on our behalf by prayer".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:104
verses.text: But what is this: "That for the gift bestowed upon us by means of many, thanks may be given by many on our behalf? He delivered us from those deaths," saith he, "ye also helping together by prayer;" that is, praying all of you for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:105
verses.text: For "the gift bestowed upon us," that is, our being saved, He was pleased to grant to you all, in order that many persons might give Him thanks, because that many also received the boon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:106
verses.text: And this he said, at once to stir them up to prayer for others, and to accustom them always to give thanks to God for whatever befalleth others, showing that He too willeth this exceedingly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:107
verses.text: For they that are careful to do both these for others, will much more for themselves show an example of both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:108
verses.text: And besides this, he both teacheth them humility and leadeth on to more fervent love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:109
verses.text: For if he who was so high above them owneth himself to have been saved by their prayers: and that to their prayers himself had been granted as a boon of God, think what their modesty and disposition ought to have been.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:110
verses.text: And observe, I pray you, this also; that even if God doeth any thing in mercy, yet prayer doth mightily contribute thereunto.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:111
verses.text: For at the first he attributed his salvation to His mercies; for "The God of mercies," he says, Himself "delivered us," but here to the prayers also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:112
verses.text: For on him too that owed the ten thousand talents He had mercy after that he fell at His feet; (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:113
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:115
verses.text: ) although it is written, that "being moved with compassion, He loosed him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:116
verses.text: And again to the "woman of Canaan," it was after that long attendance and importunity of hers, (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:117
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:118
verses.text: ) that He finally granted the healing of her daughter, even though of His mercy He healed her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:119
verses.text: Hereby then we learn that even though we are to receive mercy, we must first make ourselves worthy of the mercy; for though there be mercy, yet it seeketh out those that are worthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:120
verses.text: It will not come upon all without distinction; those even who have no feeling; for He saith, "I will have mercy on whom I have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I have compassion".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:121
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:122
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:123
verses.text: ) Observe at least what he saith here, "Ye also helping together by prayer".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:124
verses.text: He hath neither ascribed the whole of the good work to them lest he should lift them up, nor yet deprived them of all share whatever in it, in order to encourage them and animate their zeal, and bring them together one to another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:125
verses.text: Whence also he said, "He also granted to you my safety".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:126
verses.text: For ofttimes also God is abashed by a multitude praying with one mind and mouth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:127
verses.text: Whence also He said to the prophet, "And shall not I spare this city wherein dwell more than six score thousand persons?" (Jonah iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:128
verses.text: ) Then lest thou think He respecteth the multitude only, He saith, "Though the number of Israel be as the sand of the sea, a remnant shall be saved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:129
verses.text: (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:130
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:131
verses.text: ) How then saved He the Ninevites? Because in their case, there was not only a multitude, but a multitude and virtue too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:132
verses.text: For each one "turned from" his "evil way".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:133
verses.text: (Jonah iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:134
verses.text: ; iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:135
verses.text: ) And besides, when He saved them, He said that they discerned not "between their right hand and their left hand:" whence it is plain that even before, they sinned more out of simpleness than of wickedness: it is plain too from their being converted, as they were, by hearing a few words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:136
verses.text: But if their being six score thousand were of itself enough to save them, what hindered even before this that they should be saved? And why saith He not to the Prophet, And shall I not spare this city which so turneth itself? but bringeth forward the score thousands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:137
verses.text: He produceth this also as a reason over and above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:138
verses.text: For that they had turned was known to the prophet, but he knew not either their numbers or their simpleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:139
verses.text: So by every possible consideration he is desirous to soften them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:140
verses.text: For even greatness of number hath power, when there is virtue withal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:141
verses.text: And truly the Scripture elsewhere also showeth this plainly, where it saith, "But prayer was made earnestly of the Church unto God for him:" (Acts xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:142
verses.text: ) and so great power had it, even when the doors were shut and chains lay on him and keepers were sleeping by on either side, that it led the Apostle forth and delivered him from them all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:143
verses.text: But as where there is virtue, greatness of number hath mighty power; so where wickedness is, it profiteth nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:144
verses.text: For the Israelites of whom He saith that the number of them was as the sand of the sea, perished every one, and those too in the days of Noe were both many, yea, numberless; and yet this profited them nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:145
verses.text: For greatness of number hath no power of itself, but only as an adjunct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:146
verses.text: Let us then be diligent in coming together in supplication; and let us pray for one another, as they did for the Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:147
verses.text: For so we both fulfil a commandment, and are "anointed" unto love: (and when I say love, I speak of every good thing:) and also learn to give thanks with more earnestness: for they that give thanks for the things of others, much more will they for their own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:148
verses.text: This also was David wont to do, saying, "Magnify the Lord with me, and let us exalt His name together;" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:149
verses.text: xxxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:150
verses.text: ) this the Apostle too doth every where require.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:151
verses.text: This let us too labor in; and let us show forth unto all the beneficence of God that we may get companions in the act of praise: for if when we have received any good from men, by proclaiming it forth we make them the readier to serve us: much more shall we, by telling abroad the benefits of God, draw Him on to more good-will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:152
verses.text: And if when we have received benefits of men we stir up others also to join us in the giving of thanks, much more ought we to bring many unto God who may give thanks for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:153
verses.text: For if Paul who had so great confidence toward God doth this, much more is it necessary for us to do it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:154
verses.text: Let us then exhort the saints to give thanks for us; and let us do the same ourselves for one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:155
verses.text: To priests especially this good work belongs, since it is an exceeding privilege.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:156
verses.text: For drawing near, we first give thanks for the whole world and the good things common to all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:157
verses.text: For even though the blessings of God be common, yet doth the common preservation include thine own; so that thou both owest common thanksgivings for thine own peculiar blessing, and for the common blessings shouldest of right render up thine own peculiar praise: for He lighted up the sun not for thee alone, but also for all in common; but nevertheless thou for thy part hast it whole.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:158
verses.text: For it was made so large for the common good; and yet thou individually seest it as large as all men have seen it; so that thou owest a thanksgiving as great as all together; and thou oughtest to give thanks for what all have in common and likewise for the virtue of others; for on account of others, too, we receive many blessings: for had there been found in Sodom ten righteous only, they had not suffered what they did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:159
verses.text: So then let us give thanks also for the confidence of others toward God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:160
verses.text: For this custom is an ancient one, planted in the Church from the beginning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:161
verses.text: Thus Paul also giveth thanks for the Romans, (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:162
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:163
verses.text: ) for the Corinthians, ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:164
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:165
verses.text: ) for the whole world, ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:166
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:167
verses.text: ) And tell me not, "The good work is none of mine;" for though it be none of thine, yet even so oughtest thou to give thanks that thy member is such an one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:168
verses.text: And besides, by thy acclamation thou makest it thine own, and sharest in the crown, and shalt thyself also receive the gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:169
verses.text: On this account it is that the laws of the Church command prayer also to be thus made, and that not for the faithful only, but also for the Catechumens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:170
verses.text: For the law stirreth up the faithful to make supplication for the uninitiated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:171
verses.text: For when the Deacon saith, "Let us pray earnestly for the Catechumens," he doth no other than excite the whole multitude of the faithful to pray for them; although the Catechumens are as yet aliens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:172
verses.text: For they are not yet of the Body of Christ, they have not yet partaken of the Mysteries, but are still divided from the spiritual flock.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:173
verses.text: But if we ought to intercede for these, much more for our own members.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:174
verses.text: And even therefore he saith, "earnestly let us pray," that thou shouldest not disown them as aliens, that thou shouldest not disregard them as strangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:175
verses.text: For as yet they have not the appointed prayer, which Christ brought in; as yet they have not confidence, but have need of others' aid who have been initiated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:176
verses.text: For without the king's courts they stand, far from the sacred precincts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:177
verses.text: Therefore they are even driven away whilst those awful prayers are being offered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:178
verses.text: Therefore also he exhorteth thee to pray for them that they may become members of thee, that they may be no longer strangers and aliens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:179
verses.text: For the words, "Let us pray," are not addressed to the priests alone, but also to those that make up the people: for when he saith, "Let us stand in order: let us pray;" he exhorteth all to the prayer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:180
verses.text: Then beginning the prayer, he saith, "That the all-pitying and merciful God would listen to their prayers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:181
verses.text: For that thou mayest not say, What shall we pray? they are aliens, not yet united to the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:182
verses.text: Whereby can I constrain the regard of God? Whence can I prevail with Him to impart unto them mercy and forgiveness? That thou mayest not be perplexed with such questions as these, see how he disentangleth thy perplexity, saying, "that the all-pitying and merciful God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:183
verses.text: Heardest thou? "All-pitying God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:184
verses.text: Be perplexed no more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:185
verses.text: For the All-pitying pitieth all, both sinners and friends.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:186
verses.text: Say not then, "How shall I approach Him for them?" Himself will listen to their prayers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:187
verses.text: And the Catechumens' prayer, what can it be but that they may not remain Catechumens? Next, he suggesteth also the manner of the prayer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:188
verses.text: And what is this? "That He would open the ears of their hearts;" for they are as yet shut and stopped up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:189
verses.text: "Ears," he saith, not these which be outward, but those of the understanding, "so as to hear 'the things which eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither have entered into the heart of man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:190
verses.text: '" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:191
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:192
verses.text: ; Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:193
verses.text: liv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:194
