verses.text: ) For they have not heard the untold mysteries; but they stand somewhere at a distance and far off from them; and even if they should hear, they know not what is said; for those mysteries need much understanding, not hearing only: and the inward ears as yet they have not: wherefore also he next invoketh for them a Prophet's gift, for the Prophet spoke on this wise; "God giveth me the tongue of instruction, that I should know how to speak a word in season; for He opened my mouth; He gave to me betimes in the morning; He granted me a hearing ear".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:195
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:196
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:197
verses.text: Sept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:198
verses.text: ) For as the Prophets heard otherwise than the many, so also do the faithful than the Catechumens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:199
verses.text: Hereby the Catechumen also is taught not to learn to hear these things of men, (for He saith, "Call no man master upon the earth, but from above, from heaven, "For they shall be all taught of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:200
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:201
verses.text: liv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:202
verses.text: )  Wherefore he says, "And instil into them the word of truth," so that it may be inwardly learned; for as yet they know not the word of truth as they ought to know.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:203
verses.text: "That He would sow His fear in them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:204
verses.text: But this is not enough; for "some fell by the wayside, and some upon the rock".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:205
verses.text: But we ask not thus; but as on rich soil the plough openeth the furrows, so we pray it may be here also, that having the fallow ground of their minds tilled deep, they may receive what is dropped upon them and accurately retain everything they have heard.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:206
verses.text: Whence also he adds, "And confirm His faith in their minds;" that is, that it may not lie on the surface, but strike its root deep downwards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:207
verses.text: "That He would unveil to them the Gospel of Righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:208
verses.text: He showeth that the veil is two-fold, partly that the eyes of their understanding were shut, partly that the Gospel was hidden from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:209
verses.text: Whence he said a little above, "that He would open the ears of their hearts," and here, "that he would unveil unto them the Gospel of Righteousness;" that is, both that He would render them wise and apt for receiving seed, and that He would teach them and drop the seed into them; for though they should be apt, yet if God reveal not, this profiteth nothing; and if God should unveil but they receive not, there resulteth like unprofitableness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:210
verses.text: Therefore we ask for both: that He would both open their hearts and unveil the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:211
verses.text: For neither if kingly ornaments lie underneath a veil, will it profit at all that the eyes be looking; nor yet that they be laid bare, if the eyes be not waking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:212
verses.text: But both will be granted, if first they themselves desire it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:213
verses.text: But what then is "the Gospel of Righteousness?" That which maketh righteous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:214
verses.text: By these words he leadeth them to the desire of Baptism, showing that the Gospel is for the working not only of the remission of sins, but also of righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:215
verses.text: "That He would grant to them a godly mind, sound judgment, and virtuous manner of life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:216
verses.text: Let such of the faithful attend as are rivetted to the things of this life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:217
verses.text: For if we are bidden to ask these things for the uninitiated: think in what things we ought to be occupied who ask these things for others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:218
verses.text: For the manner of life ought to keep pace with the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:219
verses.text: Whence surely also the order of the prayer shifts from the doctrines of the Gospel to the deportment: for to the words, "that He would unveil to them the Gospel of Righteousness;" it hath added, "that He would give unto them a Godly mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:220
verses.text: And what is this "Godly?" That God may dwell in it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:221
verses.text: For He saith, "I will dwell in them, and walk in them;" (Lev.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:222
verses.text: xxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:223
verses.text: ) for when the mind is become righteous, when it hath put off its sins, it becometh God's dwelling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:224
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:225
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:226
verses.text: ) But when God indwelleth, nothing of man will be left.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:227
verses.text: And thus doth the mind become Godly, speaking every word from Him, even as in truth an house of God dwelling in it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:228
verses.text: Surely then the filthy in speech hath not a Godly mind, nor he who delighteth in jesting and laughter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:229
verses.text: "Sound judgment".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:230
verses.text: And what can it be to have "a sound judgment?" To enjoy the health that pertaineth to the soul: for he that is held down by wicked lusts and dazzled with present things, never can be sound, that is, healthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:231
verses.text: But as one who is diseased lusteth even after things which are unfit for him, so also doth he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:232
verses.text: "And a virtuous mode of life," for the doctrines need a mode of life answerable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:233
verses.text: Attend to this, ye who come to baptism at the close of life, for we indeed pray that after baptism ye may have also this deportment, but thou art seeking and doing thy utmost to depart without it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:234
verses.text: For, what though thou be justified: yet is it of faith only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:235
verses.text: But we pray that thou shouldest have as well the confidence that cometh of good works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:236
verses.text: "Continually to think those things which be His, to mind those things which be His, to practise those things which be His:" for we ask not to have sound judgment and virtuous deportment for one day only, or for two or three, but through the whole tenor and period of our life; and as the foundation of all good things, "to mind those things which be His".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:237
verses.text: For the many "seek their own, not the things which are Jesus Christ's".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:238
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:239
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:240
verses.text: ) How then might this be? (For besides prayer, need is that we contribute also our own endeavors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:241
verses.text: ) If we be occupied in His law day and night.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:242
verses.text: Whence he goeth on to ask this also, "to be occupied in His law;" and as he said above, "continually," so here "day and night".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:243
verses.text: Wherefore I even blush for these who scarce once in the year are seen in church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:244
verses.text: For what excuse can they have who are bidden not simply "day and night" to commune with the law but "to be occupied in," that is, to be for ever holding converse with it, and yet scarce do so for the smallest fraction of their life?  "To remember His commandments, to keep His judgments".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:245
verses.text: Seest thou what an excellent chain is here? and how each link hangs by the next compacted with more strength and beauty than any chain of gold? For having asked for a Godly mind, he telleth whereby this may be produced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:246
verses.text: Whereby? By continually practising it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:247
verses.text: And how might this be brought about? By constantly giving heed to the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:248
verses.text: And how might men be persuaded to this? If they should keep His Commandments: yea rather, from giving heed to the law cometh also the keeping His Commandments; as likewise from minding the things which be His and from having a Godly mind, cometh the practising the things which be His.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:249
verses.text: For each of the things mentioned jointly procureth and is procured by the next, both linking it and being linked by it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:250
verses.text: "Let us beseech for them yet more earnestly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:251
verses.text: For since by length of speaking the soul useth to grow drowsy, he again arouseth it up, for he purposeth to ask again certain great and lofty things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:252
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "Let us beseech for them yet more earnestly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:253
verses.text: And what is this? "That He would deliver them from every evil and inordinate thing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:254
verses.text: Here we ask for them that they may not enter into temptation, but be delivered from every snare, a deliverance as well bodily as spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:255
verses.text: Wherefore also he goeth on to say, "from every devilish sin and from every besetment of the adversary," meaning, temptations and sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:256
verses.text: For sin doth easily beset, taking its stand on every side, before, behind, and so casting down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:257
verses.text: For, after telling us what ought to be done by us, namely, to be occupied in His law, to remember His Commandments, to keep His judgments, he assures us next that not even is this enough, except Himself stand by and succor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:258
verses.text: For, "Except the Lord build the house, they labor in vain that build it;" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:259
verses.text: cxxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:260
verses.text: ) and especially in the case of those who are yet exposed to the devil and are under his dominion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:261
verses.text: And ye that are initiated know this well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:262
verses.text: For call to mind, for instance, those words wherein ye renounced his usurped rule, and bent the knee and deserted to The King, and uttered those awful words whereby we are taught in nothing whatever to obey him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:263
verses.text: But he calleth him adversary and accuser, because he both accuseth God to man and us to God, and us again one to another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:264
verses.text: For at one time he accused Job to God, saying, "Doth Job serve the Lord for nought?" (Job i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:265
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:266
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:267
verses.text: ) at another time God to Job, "Fire came down from heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:268
verses.text: And again, God to Adam, (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:269
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:270
verses.text: ) when He said their eyes would be opened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:271
verses.text: And to many men at this day, saying, that God taketh no care for the visible order of things, but hath delegated your affairs to demons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:272
verses.text: And to many of the Jews he accused Christ, calling Him a deceiver and a sorcerer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:273
verses.text: But perchance some one wisheth to hear in what manner he worketh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:274
verses.text: When he findeth not a godly mind, findeth not a sound understanding, then, as into a soul left empty, he leads his revel thither; when one remembereth not the commandments of God nor keepeth His judgments, then he taketh him captive and departeth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:275
verses.text: Had Adam, for instance, remembered the commandment which said, "Of every tree thou mayest eat:" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:276
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:277
verses.text: ) had he kept the judgment which said, "In the day in which ye eat thereof, then shall ye surely die;" it had not fared with him as it did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:278
verses.text: "That He would count them worthy in due season of the regeneration of the laver, of the remission of sins".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:279
verses.text: For we ask some things to come now, some to come hereafter; and we expound the doctrine of the laver, and in asking instruct them to know its power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:280
verses.text: For what is said thenceforth familiarizes them to know already that what is there done is a regeneration, and that we are born again of the waters, just as of the womb; that they say not after Nicodemus, "How can one be born when he is old! Can he enter into his mother's womb, and be born again?" Then, because he had spoken of "remission of sins," he confirmeth this by the words next following, "of the clothing of incorruption;" for he that putteth on sonship plainly becometh incorruptible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:281
verses.text: But what is that "in due season?" When any is well disposed, when any cometh thereunto with earnestness and faith; for this is the "due season" of the believer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:282
verses.text: "That He would bless their coming in and their going out, the whole course of their life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:283
verses.text: Here they are directed to ask even for some bodily good, as being yet somewhat weak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:284
verses.text: "Their houses and their households," that is, if they have servants or kinsfolk or any others belonging to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:285
verses.text: For these were the rewards of the old Covenant; and nothing then was feared so much as widowhood, childlessness, untimely mournings, to be visited with famine, to have their affairs go on unprosperously.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:286
verses.text: And hence it is, that he alloweth these also fondly to linger over petitions rather material, making them mount by little and little to higher things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:287
verses.text: For so too doth Christ; so too doth Paul, making mention of the ancient blessings: Christ, when He saith, "Blessed are the meek, for they shall inherit the earth;" Paul, when he saith, "Honor thy father and thy mother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:288
verses.text: …and thou shalt live long on the earth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:289
verses.text: "That He would increase their children and bless them, and bring them to full age, and teach them wisdom".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:290
verses.text: Here again is both a bodily and spiritual thing, as for persons yet but too much babes in disposition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:291
verses.text: Then what follows is altogether spiritual, "that He would direct all that is before them unto good;" for he saith not simply, "all that is before them," but, "all that is before them unto good".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:292
verses.text: For often a journey is before a man, but it is not good; or some other such thing, which is not profitable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:293
verses.text: Hereby they are taught in every thing to give thanks to God, as happening for good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:294
verses.text: After all this, he bids them stand up during what follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:295
verses.text: For having before cast them to the ground, when they have asked what they have asked and have been filled with confidence, now the word given raiseth them up, and biddeth them during what follows engage for themselves also in supplication to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:296
verses.text: For part we say ourselves, and part we permit them to say, now opening unto them the door of prayer, (exactly as we first teach children what to say, and then bid them say it of themselves,) saying, "Pray ye, Catechumens, for the angel of peace;" for there is an angel that punisheth, as when He saith, "A band of evil angels," (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:297
verses.text: lxxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:298
verses.text: ) there is that destroyeth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:299
verses.text: Wherefore we bid them ask for the angel of peace, teaching them to seek that which is the bond of all good things, peace; so that they may be delivered from all fightings, all wars, all seditions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:300
verses.text: "That all that is before you may be peaceful;" for even if a thing be burdensome, if a man have peace, it is light.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:301
verses.text: Wherefore Christ also said, "My peace I give unto you" (John xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:302
verses.text: ) for the devil hath no weapon so strong as fighting, and enmity, and war.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:303
verses.text: "Pray that this day and all the days of your life be full of peace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:304
verses.text: Seest thou how he again insisteth that the whole life be passed in virtue? "That your ends be Christian;" your highest good, the honorable and the expedient; for what is not honorable is not expedient either.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:305
verses.text: For our idea of the nature of expediency is different from that of the many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:306
verses.text: "Commend yourselves to the living God and to His Christ;" for as yet we trust them not to pray for others, but it is sufficient to be able to pray for themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:307
verses.text: Seest thou the completeness of this prayer, both in regard of doctrine and of behavior? for when we have mentioned the Gospel and the clothing of incorruption and the Laver of Regeneration, we have mentioned all the doctrines: when again we spoke of a Godly mind, a sound understanding, and the rest of what we said, we suggested the mode of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:308
verses.text: Then we bid them bow their heads; regarding it as a proof of their prayers being heard that God blessed them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:309
verses.text: For surely it is not a man that blesseth; but by means of his hand and his tongue we bring unto the King Himself the heads of those that are present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:310
verses.text: And all together shout the "Amen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:311
verses.text: Now why have I said all this? To teach you that we ought to seek the things of others, that the faithful may not think it no concern of theirs when these things are said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:312
verses.text: For not to the walls surely doth the Deacon say, "Let us pray for the Catechumens".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:313
verses.text: But some are so without understanding, so stupid, so depraved, as to stand and talk not only during the time of the Catechumens, but also during the time of the faithful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:314
verses.text: Hence all is perverted; hence all is utterly lost: for at the very time when we ought most to propitiate God, we go away having provoked Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:315
verses.text: So again in the prayers of the faithful, we are bidden to approach the God that loveth men, for Bishops, for Priests, for Kings, for those in authority, for earth and sea, for the seasons, for the whole world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:316
verses.text: When then we who ought to have such boldness as to pray for others, are scarce awake even whilst praying for ourselves, how can we excuse ourselves? how find pardon? Wherefore I beseech you that laying all this to heart, ye would know the time of prayer, and be lifted up and disengaged from earth, and touch the vault itself of heaven; so that we may have power to make God propitious and obtain the good things promised, whereunto may we all attain, through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ; with Whom unto the Father, together with the Holy Ghost, be glory, might, honor, now and for ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 3:317
verses.text: seems to be used in Diodorus and Polybius for hostile, inimical.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:1
verses.text: Homily III.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:3
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:4
verses.text: For our glorying is this, the testimony of our conscience, that in simplicity and sincerity, not in fleshly wisdom, but in the grace of God, we behaved ourselves in the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:5
verses.text: Here again he openeth to us yet another ground of comfort, and that not small, yea rather, exceeding great, and well fitted to upraise a mind sinking under perils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:6
verses.text: For seeing he had said, God comforted us, and God delivered us, and had ascribed all to His mercies and their prayers, lest he should thus make the hearer supine, presuming on God's mercy only and the prayers of others, he showeth that they themselves had contributed not a little of their own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:7
verses.text: And indeed he showed as much even before, when he said, "For as the sufferings of Christ abound in us, so our consolation also aboundeth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:8
verses.text: (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:9
verses.text: ) But here he is speaking of a certain other good work, properly their own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:10
verses.text: What then is this? That, saith he, in a conscience pure and without guile we behave ourselves every where in the world: and this availeth not a little to our encouragement and comfort; yea, rather, not to comfort merely, but even unto somewhat else far greater than comfort, even to our glorying.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:11
verses.text: And this he said, teaching them too not to sink down in their afflictions, but, if so be they have a pure conscience, even to be proud of them; and at the same time quietly though gently hitting at the false Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:12
verses.text: And as in the former Epistle he saith, "Christ sent me to preach the Gospel, not in wisdom of words, lest the Cross of Christ should be made of none effect:" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:13
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:14
verses.text: ) and, "that your faith should not stand in the wisdom of men, but in the power of God;" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:15
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:16
verses.text: ) so here also, "Not in wisdom, but in the grace of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:17
verses.text: And he hinted also something besides, by employing the words, "not in wisdom," that is, 'not in deceit,' here too striking at the heathen discipline.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:18
verses.text: "For our glorying," saith he, "is this, the testimony of our conscience;" that is, our conscience not having whereof to condemn us, as if for evil doings we were persecuted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:19
verses.text: For though we suffer countless horrors, though from every quarter we be shot at and in peril, it is enough for our comfort, yea rather not only for comfort, but even for our crowning, that our conscience is pure and testifieth unto us that for no evil-doing, but for that which is well-pleasing to God, we thus suffer; for virtue's sake, for heavenly wisdom's, for the salvation of the many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:20
verses.text: Now that previous consolation was from God: but this was contributed by themselves and from the purity of their life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:21
verses.text: Wherefore also he calls it their glorying, because it was the achievement of their own virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:22
verses.text: What then is this glorying and what doth our conscience testify unto us? "That in sincerity," that is to say, having no deceitful thing, no hypocrisy, no dissimulation, no flattery, no ambush or guile, nor any other such thing, but in all frankness, in simplicity, in truth, in a pure and unmalicious spirit, in a guileless mind, having nothing concealed, no festering sore.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:23
verses.text: "Not in fleshly wisdom;" that is, not with evil artifice, nor with wickedness, nor with cleverness of words, nor with webs of sophistries, for this he meaneth by 'fleshly wisdom:' and that whereupon they greatly prided themselves, he disclaims and thrusts aside: showing very abundantly that this is no worthy ground for glorying: and that not only he doth not seek it, but he even rejecteth and is ashamed of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:24
verses.text: "But in the grace of God we behaved ourselves in the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:25
verses.text: What is, "in the grace of God?" Displaying the wisdom that is from Him, the power from Him given unto us, by the signs wrought, by overcoming sages, rhetoricians, philosophers, kings, peoples, unlearned as we are and bringing with us nothing of the wisdom that is without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:26
verses.text: No ordinary comfort and glorying, however, was this, to be conscious to themselves that it was not men's power they had used; but that by Divine grace they had achieved all success.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:27
verses.text: "In the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:28
verses.text: So not in Corinth only, but also in every part of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:29
verses.text: "And more abundantly to you-ward".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:30
verses.text: What more abundantly to you-ward? "In the grace of God we behaved ourselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:31
verses.text: For we showed both signs and wonders amongst you, and greater strictness, and a life unblameable; for he calls these too the grace of God, ascribing his own good works also unto it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:32
verses.text: For in Corinth he even overleapt the goal, making the Gospel without charge, because he spared their weakness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:33
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:34
verses.text: "For we write none other things unto you, than what ye read or even acknowledge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:35
verses.text: For since he spoke great things of himself and seemed to be bearing witness to himself, an odious thing, he again appeals to them as witnesses of what he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:36
verses.text: For, he saith, let no one think that what I say is a boastful flourish of writing; for we declare unto you what yourselves know; and that we lie not ye more than all others can bear us witness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:37
verses.text: For, when ye read, ye acknowledge that what ye know that we perform in our actions, this we say also in our writings, and your testimony doth not contradict our epistles; but the knowledge which ye had before of us is in harmony with your reading.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:38
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:39
verses.text: "As also ye did acknowledge us in part".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:40
verses.text: For your knowledge of us, he saith, is not from hearsay but from actual experience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:41
verses.text: The words "in part" he added from humility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:42
verses.text: For this is his wont, when necessity constraineth him to say any highsounding thing, (for he never doth so otherwise,) as desiring quickly to repress again the elation arising from what he had said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:43
verses.text: "And I hope ye will acknowledge even to the end".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:44
verses.text: Seest thou again how from the past he draws pledges for the future; and not from the past only, but also from the power of God? For he affirmed not absolutely, but cast the whole upon God and his hope in Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:45
verses.text: "That we are your glorying, even as ye also are our's, in the day of our Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:46
verses.text: Here he cuts at the root of the envy that his speech might occasion, by making them sharers and partners in the glory of his good works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:47
verses.text: 'For these stick not with us, but pass over unto you also, and again from you to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:48
verses.text: ' For seeing he had extolled himself, and produced proof of the past and given security for the future; lest his hearers should reflect on him for talking proudly, or, as I have said, be hurried to enviousness, he makes the rejoicing a common one and declares that this crown of praises is theirs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:49
verses.text: For if, he says, we have shown ourselves to be such, our praise is your glory: even as when ye also are approved, we rejoice and leap for joy and are crowned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:50
verses.text: Here also again he displays his great humility by what he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:51
verses.text: For he so levels his expressions, not as a master discoursing to disciples, but as a disciple unto fellow-disciples of his own rank.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:52
verses.text: And observe how he lifts them on high and fills them with philosophy, sending them on to That Day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:53
verses.text: For, he saith, tell me not of the present things, that is, the reproaches, the revilings, the scoffings of the many, for the things here are no great matter, neither the good nor the painful; nor the scoffings nor the praises which come from men: but remember, I pray, that day of fear and shuddering in the which all things are revealed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:54
verses.text: For then both we shall glory in you, and ye in us; when ye shall be seen to have such teachers, who teach no doctrine of men nor live in wickedness nor give men any handle; and we to have such disciples, neither affected after the manner of men nor shaken, but taking all things with readiness of mind, and unseduced by sophistries from what side soever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:55
verses.text: For this is plain even now to those that have understanding, but then to all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:56
verses.text: So that even if we are afflicted now, we have this, and that no light, consolation which the conscience affordeth now, and the manifestation itself then.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:57
verses.text: For now indeed our conscience knoweth that we do all things by the grace of God, as ye also know and shall know: but then, all men as well will learn both our doings and yours: and shall behold us glorified through each other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:58
verses.text: For that he may not appear himself alone to derive lustre from this glorying, he gives to them also a cause of boasting, and leads them away from their present distresses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:59
verses.text: And as he did in respect to the consolation when he said, "We are comforted for your sakes," (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:60
verses.text: ) so he does here also, saying, 'we glory on your account, as ye also on ours,' every where making them partakers of every thing, of his comfort, his sufferings, his preservation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:61
verses.text: For this his preservation he ascribes to their prayers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:62
verses.text: "For God delivered us," he saith, "ye helping together by prayer".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:63
verses.text: In like manner also he makes the gloryings common.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:64
verses.text: For as in that place he says, "Knowing that as ye are partakers of the sufferings, so also of the consolation:" so here too, "we are your glorying, as ye also are ours".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:65
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:66
verses.text: "And in this confidence I was minded to come before unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:67
verses.text: What confidence? 'In relying exceedingly on you, glorying over you, being your glorying, loving you exceedingly, being conscious to myself of nothing evil, being confident that all is spiritual with us, and having you as witnesses of this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:68
verses.text: '  "I was minded to come unto you, and by you to pass into Macedonia".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:69
verses.text: And yet he promised the contrary in his former Epistle, saying thus: "Now I will come unto you when I shall have passed through Macedonia: for I do pass through Macedonia".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:70
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:71
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:72
verses.text: ) How is it then that he here says the contrary? He doth not say the contrary: away with the thought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:73
verses.text: For it is contrary indeed to what he wrote, but not contrary to what he wished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:74
verses.text: Wherefore also here he said not, 'I wrote that I would pass by you into Macedonia; but, 'I was minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:75
verses.text: ' 'For though I did not write on that wise,' he says, 'nevertheless I was greatly desirous, and 'was minded,' even before, to have come unto you: so far was I from wishing to be later than my promise that I would gladly have come before it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:76
verses.text: ' "That ye might have a second benefit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:77
verses.text: What is, a second benefit? 'That ye might have a double benefit, both that from my writings, and that from my presence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:78
verses.text: ' By "benefit" he here means pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:79
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:81
verses.text: "And by you to pass into Macedonia, and to come again from Macedonia unto you, and of you to be set forward on my journey unto Judaea.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:82
verses.text: When I therefore was thus minded, did I show fickleness?"   Here in what follows, he directly does away with the charge arising out of his delay and absence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:83
verses.text: For what he says is of this nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:84
verses.text: "I was minded to come unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:85
verses.text: 'Wherefore then did I not come? Is it as light-minded and changeable?' for this is, "did I show fickleness?" By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:86
verses.text: But wherefore? "Because what things I purpose, I purpose not according to the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:87
verses.text: What is, "not according to the flesh?" I purpose not 'carnally.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:88
verses.text: '  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:89
verses.text: "That with me there should be the yea yea and the nay nay".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:90
verses.text: But still even this is obscure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:91
verses.text: What is it then he says? The carnal man, that is, he that is rivetted to the present things and is continually occupied in them, and is without the sphere of the Spirit's influence, has power to go every where, and to wander whithersoever he will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:92
verses.text: But he that is the servant of the Spirit, and is led, and led about by Him, cannot everywhere be lord of his own purpose, having made it dependent upon the authority thence given; but it so fares with him as if a trusty servant, whose motions are always ruled by his lord's biddings and who has no power over himself nor is able to rest even a little, should make some promise to his fellow-servants, and then because his master would have it otherwise should fail to perform his promise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:93
verses.text: This then is what he means by, "I purpose not according to the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:94
verses.text: I am not beyond the Spirit's governance, nor have liberty to go where I will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:95
verses.text: For I am subject to lordship and commands, the Comforter's, and by His decrees I am led, and led about.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:96
verses.text: For this cause I was unable to come, for it was not the Spirit's will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:97
verses.text: As happened also frequently in the Acts; for when he had purposed to come to one place, the Spirit bade him go to another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:98
verses.text: So that it was not from lightness, that is, fickleness in me that I came not, but that being subject to the Spirit I obeyed Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:99
verses.text: Didst mark again his accustomed logic? That by which they thought to prove that "he purposed according to the flesh," namely, the non-fulfilment of his promise, he uses as the special proof that he purposed according to the Spirit, and that the contrary had been purposing according to the flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:100
verses.text: What then? saith one: was it not with the Spirit that he promised what he did? By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:101
verses.text: For I have already said that Paul did not foreknow every thing that was to happen or was expedient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:102
verses.text: And it is for this reason that he says in the former Epistle, "that ye may set me forward on my journey whithersoever I go;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:103
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:104
verses.text: ) entertaining this very fear that after he had said, 'into Judaea,' he might be compelled to go elsewhither; but now when his intention had been frustrated, he says it, "And of you be set forward on my journey unto Judaea".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:105
verses.text: So much as was of love, he states, namely, the coming to them; but that which had no reference to them, his going, namely, from them into Judaea, he doth not add definitely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:106
verses.text: When however he had been proved wrong, he afterwards says here boldly, "toward Judaea".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:107
verses.text: And this too befel for good, lest any among them should conceive of them (the Apostles, Acts xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:108
verses.text: ) more highly than they deserved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:109
verses.text: For if in the face of these things they wished to sacrifice bulls to them, upon what impiety would they not have driven, had they not given many instances of human weakness? And why marvel if he knew not all things that were to happen, seeing that ofttimes he even in prayers knoweth not what is expedient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:110
verses.text: "For," saith he "we know not what we should pray for as we ought".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:111
verses.text: And that he may not seem to be speaking modestly, he not only saith this, but instances wherein he knew not in prayers what was expedient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:112
verses.text: Wherein then was it? When he entreated to be delivered from his trials, saying, "There was given to me a thorn in the flesh, a messenger of Satan to buffet me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:113
verses.text: Concerning this thing I besought the Lord thrice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:114
verses.text: And he said unto me, My grace is sufficient for thee: for My power is made perfect in weakness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:115
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:116
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:118
verses.text: ) Seest thou how he knew not to ask what was expedient, and so although he asked often he obtained not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:119
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:120
verses.text: "But as God is faithful, our word toward you was not yea and nay".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:121
verses.text: He skillfully overturns a rising objection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:122
verses.text: For one might say, If after having promised, thou hast put off coming, and yea is not yea, and nay nay, with thee, but what thou sayest now thou unsayest afterwards, as thou didst in the case of this Journey: woe is unto us, if all this were the case in the Preaching too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:123
verses.text: Now lest they should have these thoughts and be troubled thereat, he says, "But as God is faithful, our word toward you was not yea and nay".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:124
verses.text: This, saith he, was not the case in the Preaching, but only in our travels and journeyings; whereas whatever things we have said in our preaching, these abide steadfast and unmoveable, (for he calleth his preaching here, "word".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:125
verses.text: ) Then he bringeth proof of this that cannot be gainsaid, by referring all to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:126
verses.text: What he saith is this; 'the promise of my coming was my own and I gave that promise from myself: but the preaching is not my own, nor of man, but of God, and what is of God it is impossible should lie.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:127
verses.text: ' Whereupon also he said, "God is faithful," that is, "true".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:128
verses.text: 'Mistrust not then what is from Him, for there is nought of man in it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:129
verses.text: '   And seeing he had said "word," he adds what follows to explain what kind of word he means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:130
verses.text: Of what kind then is it?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:131
verses.text: "For the Son of God," saith he, "Who was preached among you by us, even by me, and Silvanus, and Timothy, was not yea and nay".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:132
verses.text: For on this account he brings before them the company of the teachers also, as thence too giving credibility to the testimony by those who taught, and not who heard it only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:133
verses.text: And yet they were disciples; however in his modesty he counts them as in the rank of teachers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:134
verses.text: But what is, "was not yea and nay?" I have never, he saith, unsaid what before I said in the Preaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:135
verses.text: My discourse to you was not now this, now that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:136
verses.text: For this is not of faith, but of an erring mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:137
verses.text: "But in Him was the yea".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:138
verses.text: That is, just as I said, the word abideth unshaken and steadfast".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:139
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:140
verses.text: "For how many soever be the promises of God," in Him is the yea, and in Him the Amen, unto the glory of God by us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:141
verses.text: What is this, "how many soever the promises of God?" The Preaching promised many things; and these many things they proffered and preached.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:142
verses.text: For they discoursed of being raised again, and of being taken up, and of incorruption, and of those great rewards and unspeakable goods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:143
verses.text: As to these promises then, he saith that they abide immoveable, and in them is no yea and nay, that is, the things spoken were not now true, and now false, as was the case about my being with you, but always true.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:144
verses.text: And first indeed he contends for the articles of the faith, and the word concerning Christ, saying, "My word" and my preaching, "was not yea and nay;" next, for the promises "for how many soever be the promises, of God, in Him is the yea".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:145
verses.text: But if the things He promised are sure and He will certainly give them, much more is He Himself and the word concerning Him, sure, and it can not be said that He is now, and now is not, but He "always" is, and is the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:146
verses.text: But what is, "In Him is the yea, and the Amen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:147
verses.text: He signifies that which shall certainly be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:148
verses.text: For in Him, not in man, the promises have their being and fulfilment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:149
verses.text: Fear not, therefore; for it is not man so that thou shouldest mistrust; but it is God Who both said and fulfilleth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:150
verses.text: "Unto the glory of God through us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:151
verses.text: What is, "unto His glory through us?" He fulfilleth them by us, that is, and by His benefits towards us unto His glory; for this is "for the glory of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:152
verses.text: But if they be for the glory of God, they will certainly come to pass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:153
verses.text: For His own glory He will not think little of, even did He think little of our salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:154
verses.text: But as it is, He thinketh not little of our salvation either, both because He loveth mankind exceedingly, and because our salvation is bound up with His glory from these things accruing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:155
verses.text: So that if the promises are for His glory, our salvation also will certainly follow; to which also, in the Epistle to the Ephesians, he reverteth continually, saying, "to the maintenance of His glory;" (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:156
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:157
verses.text: ) and every where he layeth down this, and shows the necessity of this result.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:158
verses.text: And in this regard he here saith, that His promises lie not: for they not only save us, but also glorify Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:159
verses.text: Dwell not on this therefore that they were promised by us; and so doubt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:160
verses.text: For they are not fulfilled by us, but by Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:161
verses.text: Yea, and the promises were by Him; for we spoke not to you our own words, but His.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:162
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:164
verses.text: "Now He which stablisheth us with you in Christ, and anointed us, is God; Who also sealed us, and gave us the earnest of the Spirit in our hearts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:165
verses.text: Again, from the past He stablisheth the future.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:166
verses.text: For if it is He that establisheth us in Christ; (i-e:, who suffereth us not to be shaken from the faith which is in Christ;) and He that anointed us and gave the Spirit in our hearts, how shall He not give us the future things?  For if He gave the principles and the foundations, and the root and the fount, (to wit, the true knowledge of Him, the partaking of the Spirit,) how shall He not give the things that come of these: for if for the sake of these those are given, much more will he supply those.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:167
verses.text: And if to such as were enemies he gave these, much more when now made friends will He "freely give" to them those.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:168
verses.text: Wherefore He said not simply "the Spirit," but named "earnest," that from this thou mightest have a good hope of the whole as well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:169
verses.text: For did He not purpose to give the whole, He would never have chosen to give "the earnest" and to waste it without object or result.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:170
verses.text: And observe Paul's candor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:171
verses.text: For why need I say, saith he, that the truth of the promises standeth not in us? The fact of your standing unwavering and fixed is not in us, but this too is of God; "for" saith he, "He who stablisheth us is God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:172
verses.text: It is not we who strengthen you: for even we also need Him that stablisheth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:173
verses.text: So then let none imagine that the Preaching is hazardous in us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:174
verses.text: He hath undertaken the whole, He cared for the whole.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:175
verses.text: And what is, "anointed," and "sealed?" Gave the Spirit by Whom He did both these things, making at once prophets and priests and kings, for in old times these three sorts were anointed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:176
verses.text: But we have now not one of these dignities, but all three preeminently.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:177
verses.text: For we are both to enjoy a kingdom and are made priests by offering our bodies for a sacrifice, (for, saith he, "present your members a living sacrifice unto God;) and withal we are constituted prophets too: for what things "eye hath not seen, nor ear heard," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:178
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:179
verses.text: ) these have been revealed unto us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:180
verses.text: And in another way too we become kings: if we have the mind to get dominion over our unruly thoughts, for that such an one is a king and more than he who weareth the diadem, I will now make plain to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:181
verses.text: He hath many armies, but we again have thoughts exceeding them in number; for it is impossible to number the infinite multitude of the thoughts within us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:182
verses.text: Nor is their multitude all that one is to consider, but also that in this multitude of thoughts, there are many generals, and colonels, and captains, and archers, and slingers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:183
verses.text: What else makes a king? His apparel? But this one too is arrayed in a better and braver robe, which neither doth moth devour nor age impair.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:184
verses.text: A crown too he hath of curious workmanship, that of glory, that of the tender mercies of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:185
verses.text: For saith the Psalmist, "Bless the Lord, O my soul, that crowneth thee with pity and tender mercies".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:186
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:187
verses.text: ciii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:189
verses.text: ) Again, that of glory: "For thou hast crowned him with glory and honor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:190
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:191
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:192
verses.text: ) And "with favor Thou hast crowned us with a shield".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:193
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:194
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:195
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:196
verses.text: ) Again, that of grace: "For thou shalt receive a crown of grace upon thy head".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:197
verses.text: (Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:198
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:199
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:200
verses.text: ) Seest thou this diadem of many wreaths, and surpassing the other in grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:201
verses.text: But let us institute anew and from the beginning a stricter inquiry into the condition of these kings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:202
verses.text: That king hath dominion over his guards, and issues orders to all, and all obey and serve him; but here I show you greater authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:203
verses.text: For the number here is as great or even greater: it remains to inquire into their obedience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:204
verses.text: And bring me not forth those that have ruled amiss, since I too bring those that have been driven from their kingdom and murdered by their very body guards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:205
verses.text: Let us then bring forth these instances, but seek for those of either kind who have ordered well their kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:206
verses.text: And do thou put forward whom thou wilt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:207
verses.text: I oppose unto thee the patriarch against all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:208
verses.text: For when he was commanded to sacrifice his son, consider how many thoughts then rose up against him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:209
verses.text: Nevertheless, he brought all under submission, and all trembled before him more than before a king his guards; and with a look only he stilled them all and not one of them dared so much as mutter; but down they bowed and as unto a king gave place, one and all, though much exasperated and exceeding relentless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:210
verses.text: For even the heads of spears raised upright by many soldiers are not as fearful as were then those fearful thoughts, armed not with spears, but what is harder to deal with than many spears, the sympathy of nature! Wherefore they had power to pierce his soul more than sharpened spear point.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:211
verses.text: For never spear could be so sharp as were the goads of those thoughts, which, sharpened and upraised from beneath, from his affections, were piercing through and through the mind of that righteous man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:212
verses.text: For here there needs time and purpose and a stroke and pain, and then death follows; but there, there needed none of these, so much were the wounds speedier and acuter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:213
verses.text: But still though so many thoughts were then in arms against him, there was a deep calm, and they stood all in fair array; adorning rather than daunting him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:214
verses.text: See him at least stretching out the knife, and set forth as many as thou wilt, kings, emperors, Caesars, yet shalt thou tell of nought like this, have no like mien to point to, so noble, so worthy of the heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:215
verses.text: For that righteous man erected a trophy at that movement over the most arbitrary of tyrannies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:216
verses.text: For nothing is so tyrannical as nature; and find ten thousand tyrannicides, one like this shalt thou never show us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:217
verses.text: For it was the triumph in that moment of an angel, not a man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:218
verses.text: For consider.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:219
verses.text: Nature was dashed to the ground with all her weapons, with all her host: and he stood with outstretched hand, grasping not a crown, but a knife more glorious than any crown, and the throng of angels applauded, and God from heaven proclaimed him conquerer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:220
verses.text: For seeing that his citizenship was in heaven, thence also he received that proclamation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:221
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:222
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:223
verses.text: ) What could be more glorious than this? rather, what trophy could ever be equal to it? For if on occasion of a wrestler's success, not a herald below but the king above should have risen up and himself proclaimed the Olympic Victor, would not this have seemed to him more glorious than the crown, and have turned the gaze of the whole theatre upon him? When then no mortal king, but God Himself, not in this theatre but in the theatre of the universe, in the assembly of the angels, the archangels, proclaimeth his name with uplifted voice shouting from heaven, tell me what place shall we assign to this holy man?   But if you will, let us listen too to the voice itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:224
verses.text: What then was the voice? "Abraham, Abraham, lay not thy hand upon Isaac, neither do thou any thing unto him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:225
verses.text: For now I know that thou fearest God, and hast not spared thy son, thy well-beloved, for My sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:226
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:227
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:229
verses.text: ) What is this? He that knoweth all things before they are, did He now know! And yet even to man the Patriarch's fear of God was evident: so many proofs had he given that his heart was right toward God, as when He said to him, "Get thee out of thy country, and from thy kindred;" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:230
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:231
verses.text: ) when for His sake and the honor due to Him he relinquished to his sister's son his priority; when He delivered him out of so great perils; when He bade him go into Egypt, and on his wife's being taken from him, he repined not, and more instances besides; and as I said, from these things even man would have learned the Patriarch's fear of God, much more than God Who waiteth not for the acts to know the end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:232
verses.text: And how too justified he him, if He knew not? For it is written, "Abraham believed, and it was counted unto him for righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:233
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:234
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:235
verses.text: ; Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:236
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:237
verses.text: )  What then means this, "Now I know?" The Syriac hath, "Now thou hast made known;" that is, to men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:238
verses.text: For I knew of old, even before all those commandments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:239
verses.text: And why, to men even, "now?" for were not those acts enough to prove his mind was right toward God? They were enough indeed, but this one so much greater than them all that they appear nothing beside it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:240
verses.text: As exalting then this good work and showing its superiority to all, He so spake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:241
verses.text: For of things which exceed and surpass all that went before, most men are wont to speak so: for instance, if one receive from another a gift greater than any former one, he often says, "Now I know that such an one loves me," not hereby meaning that he knew not in the time past, but as intending to declare what is now given to be greater than all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:242
verses.text: So also God, speaking after the manner of men, saith, "Now I know," intending only to mark the exceeding greatness of the exploit; not that He "then" came to know either his fear or the greatness of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:243
verses.text: For when He saith, "Come, let Us go down and see," (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:244
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:245
verses.text: ; xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:246
verses.text: ) He saith it not as needing to go down, (for He both filleth all things and knoweth all things certainly,) but to teach us not to give sentence lightly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:247
verses.text: And when He saith, "The Lord looked down from Heaven:" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:248
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:249
verses.text: ) it describeth His perfect knowledge by a metaphor taken from men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:250
verses.text: So also here He saith, "Now I know," to declare this to be greater than all which had preceded it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:251
verses.text: Of this itself too He furnisheth proof by adding, "Because thou sparedst not thy son, thy well-beloved, for My sake; He saith not "thy son" only, but yet more, "thy well-beloved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:252
verses.text: For it was not nature only, but also parental fondness, which having both by natural disposition and by the great goodness of his child, he yet dared in him to spurn.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:253
verses.text: And if about worthless children parents are not easily indifferent, but mourn even for them; when it is his son, his only-begotten, and his well-beloved, even Isaac, and the father himself is on the point of immolating him; who can describe the excessiveness of such philosophy? This exploit outshineth thousands of diadems and crowns innumerable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:254
verses.text: For the wearer of that crown, both death ofttimes assaileth and annoyeth, and before death, assaults of circumstances without number; but this diadem shall no one have strength to take from him that weareth it; no not even after death; neither of his own household, nor of strangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:255
verses.text: And let me point you out the costliest stone in this diadem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:256
verses.text: For as a costly stone, so this comes at the end and clasps it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:257
verses.text: What then is this? the words, "for My sake?" for not herein is the marvel, that he spared not, but that it was "for His sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:258
verses.text: Oh! blessed right hand, of what a knife was it accounted worthy? oh! wondrous knife, of what a right hand was it accounted worthy? Oh! wondrous knife, for what a purpose was it prepared? to what an office did it serve? to what a type did it minister? How was it bloodied? how was it not bloodied? For I know not what to say, so awful was that mystery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:259
verses.text: It touched not the neck of the child, nor passed through the throat of that holy one: nor was crimsoned with the blood of the righteous; rather it both touched, and passed through, and was crimsoned, and was bathed in it, yet was not bathed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:260
verses.text: Perchance I seem to you beside myself, uttering such contradictions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:261
verses.text: For, in truth, I am beside myself, with the thought of the wondrous deed of that righteous man; but I utter no contradictions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:262
verses.text: For indeed the righteous man's hand thrust it in the throat of the lad, but God's Hand suffered it not, so thrust, to be stained with blood of the lad.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:263
verses.text: For it was not Abraham alone that held it back, but God also: and he by his purpose gave the stroke, God by His voice restrained it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:264
verses.text: For the same voice both armed and disarmed that right hand, which, marshalled under God, as if under a leader, performed all things at His beck, and all were ministered at His voice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:265
verses.text: For observe; He said, "Slay," and straightway it was armed: He said, "Slay not," and straightway it was disarmed: for every thing before had been fully prepared.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:266
verses.text: And now God showed the soldier and general to the whole world; this crowned victor to the theatre of the angels; this priest, this king, crowned with that knife beyond a diadem, this trophy-bearer, this champion, this conqueror without a fight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:267
verses.text: For as if some general having a most valiant soldier, should use his mastery of his weapons, his bearing, his ordered movements to dismay the adversary; so also God, by the purpose, the attitude, the bearing only of that righteous man, dismayed and routed the common enemy of us all, the Devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:268
verses.text: For I deem that even he then shrunk away aghast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:269
verses.text: But if any one say, 'And why did he not suffer that right hand to be bathed, and then forthwith raise him up after being sacrificed?' Because God might not accept such bloody offerings; such a table were that of avenging demons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:270
verses.text: But here two things were displayed, both the loving kindness of the Master, and the faithfulness of the servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:271
verses.text: And before, indeed, he went out from his country: but then he abandoned even nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:272
verses.text: Wherefore also he received his principal with usury: and very reasonably.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:273
verses.text: For he chose to lose the name of father, to show himself a faithful servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:274
verses.text: Wherefore he became not a father only, but also a priest; and because for God's sake he gave up his own, therefore also did God give him with these His own besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:275
verses.text: When then enemies devise mischief, He allows it to come even to the trial, and then works miracles; as in the case of the furnace and the lions; (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:276
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:277
verses.text: and vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:278
verses.text: ) but when Himself biddeth, readiness attained, He stayeth His bidding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:279
verses.text: What then, I ask, was wanting further in this noble deed? For did Abraham foreknow what would happen? Did he bargain for the mercy of God? For even though he were a prophet, yet the prophet knoweth not all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:280
verses.text: So the actual sacrifice afterwards was superfluous and unworthy of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:281
verses.text: And if it was fit he should learn that God was able to raise from the dead, by the womb he had learnt this much more marvellously, or rather he learnt it even before that proof, for he had faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:282
verses.text: Do not then only admire this righteous man, but also imitate him, and when thou seest him amid so great uproar and surge of waves sailing as in a calm, take thou in hand in like way the helm of obedience and fortitude.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:283
verses.text: For look, pray, not only at this that he built up the altar and the wood; but remember too the voice of the lad, and reflect what hosts like snow storms assaulted him to dismay him, when he heard the lad say, "My father, where is the lamb?" Bethink thee how many thoughts were then stirred up armed not with iron, but with darts of flame; and piercing into and cutting him through on every side.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:284
verses.text: If even now many, and those not parents, are broken down, and would have wept, did they not know the end: and many, I see, do weep, though they know it; what must it be thought he would feel, who begat, who nurtured him, in old age had him, had him only, him such an one, who sees, who hears him, and is presently about to slay him? What intelligence in the words! What meekness in the question! Who then is here at work? The Devil that he might set nature in a flame? God forbid! but God, the more to prove the golden soul of the righteous man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:285
verses.text: For when indeed the wife of Job speaks, a Devil is at work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:286
verses.text: For of such sort the advice is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:287
verses.text: But this one uttereth nothing blasphemous, but what is both very devout and thoughtful; and great the grace that overspread the words, much the honey that dropped therefrom, flowing from a calm and gentle soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:288
verses.text: Even a heart of stone these words were enough to soften.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:289
verses.text: But they turned not aside, nay, shook not that adamant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:290
verses.text: Nor said he, 'Why callest thou him father, who in a little while will not be thy father, yea, who hath already lost that title of honor?' And why doth the lad ask the question? Not of impertinence merely, not of curiosity, but as anxious about what was proposed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:291
verses.text: For he reflected that had his father not meant to make him a partner in what was done, he would not have left the servants below, and taken him only with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:292
verses.text: For this reason, too, surely, it is that when they were alone, then he asks him, when none heard what was said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:293
verses.text: So great was the judgment of the lad.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:294
verses.text: Are ye not all warmed towards him, both men and women? Doth not each one of you mentally infold and kiss the child, and marvel at his judgment; and venerate the piety which, when he was both bound and laid on the wood, made him not be dismayed nor struggle nor accuse his father as mad; but he was even bound and lifted up and laid upon it, and endured all in silence, like a lamb, yea, rather like the common Lord of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:295
verses.text: For of Him he both imitated the gentleness, and kept to the type.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:296
verses.text: For "He was led like a lamb to the slaughter, and as a sheep dumb before his shearer".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:297
