verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:298
verses.text: liii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:299
verses.text: ) And yet Isaac spake; for his Lord spake also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:300
verses.text: How dumb then? This meaneth, he spake nothing wilful or harsh, but all was sweet and mild, and the words more than the silence manifested his gentleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:301
verses.text: For Christ also said, "If I have spoken evil, bear witness of the evil; but if well, why smitest thou Me?" (John xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:302
verses.text: ) and manifested His gentleness more than if He had held His peace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:303
verses.text: And as this one speaketh with his father from the altar, so too doth He from the Cross, saying, "Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:304
verses.text: What then said the Patriarch? (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:305
verses.text: ) "God will provide Himself a lamb for a burnt-offering, my son".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:306
verses.text: Either uses the names of nature; the former, father; the latter, son; and on either side arduous is the war stirred up, and mighty the storm, and yet wreck no where: for religion triumphed over all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:307
verses.text: Then after he heard of God, he spoke no further word nor was impertinently curious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:308
verses.text: Of such judgment was the child even in the very bloom of youth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:309
verses.text: Seest thou the king, over how many armies, in how many battles which beset him, he hath been victorious? For the barbarians were not so fearful to the city of Jerusalem when they assaulted her oftentimes, as were to this man the thoughts on every side besieging him: but still he overcame all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:310
verses.text: Wouldest thou see the priest also? The instance is at hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:311
verses.text: For when thou hast seen him with fire and a knife; and standing over an altar, what doubtest thou after as to his priesthood? But if thou wouldest see the sacrifice also, lo, here a twofold one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:312
verses.text: For he offered a son, he offered also a ram, yea, more and above all, his own will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:313
verses.text: And with the blood of the lamb he consecrated his right hand, with the sacrifice of his son, his soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:314
verses.text: Thus was he ordained a priest, by the blood of his only-begotten, by the sacrifice of a lamb; for the priests also were consecrated by the blood of the victims which were offered to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:315
verses.text: Wouldest thou see the prophet also? It is written, "Your father Abraham rejoiced to see My day, and he saw it, and was glad".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:316
verses.text: (Levit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:317
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:318
verses.text: ; John viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:319
verses.text: )  So also art thou thyself made king and priest and prophet in the Laver; a king, having dashed to earth all the deeds of wickedness and slain thy sins; a priest, in that thou offerest thyself to God, having sacrificed thy body and being thyself slain also, "for if we died with Him," saith he, "we shall also live with Him;" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:320
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:321
verses.text: ) a prophet, knowing what shall be, and being inspired of God, and sealed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:322
verses.text: For as upon soldiers a seal, so is also the Spirit put upon the faithful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:323
verses.text: And if thou desert, thou art manifest by it to all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:324
verses.text: For the Jews had circumcision for a seal, but we, the earnest of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 4:325
verses.text: Knowing then all this, and considering our high estate, let us exhibit a life worthy of the grace, that we may obtain also the kingdom to come; which may we all obtain through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom, to the Father, together with the Holy Spirit, be glory, power, honor, now and for ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:1
verses.text: Homily IV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:3
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:4
verses.text: But I call God for a witness upon my soul, that to spare you I forbare to come unto Corinth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:5
verses.text: What sayest thou, O blessed Paul? To spare them thou camest not to Corinth? Surely thou presentest us with something of a contradiction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:6
verses.text: For a little above thou saidst that thou therefore camest not, because thou purposest not according to the flesh nor art thine own master, but art led about every where by the authority of the Spirit, and didst set forth thine afflictions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:7
verses.text: But here thou sayest it was thine own act that thou camest not, and not from the authority of the Spirit; for he saith, "To spare you I forbare to come to Corinth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:8
verses.text: What then is one to say? either, that this too was itself of the Spirit, and that he himself wished to come but the Spirit suggested to him not to do so, urging the motive of sparing them; or else, that he is speaking of some other coming, and would signify that before he wrote the former Epistle he was minded to come, and for love's sake restrained himself lest he should find them yet unamended.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:9
verses.text: Perhaps also, after the second Epistle though the Spirit no longer forbade him to go, he involuntarily stayed away for this reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:10
verses.text: And this suspicion is the more probable, that in the first instance the Spirit forbade him: but afterwards upon his own conviction also that this was more advisable, he stayed away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:11
verses.text: And observe, I pray you, how he remembers again his own custom, (which I shall never cease to observe,) of making what seems against him tell in his favor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:12
verses.text: For since it was natural for them to respect this and say, 'It was because thou hatedst us, thou wouldest not come unto us,' he shows on the contrary, that the cause for which he would not come was that he loved them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:13
verses.text: What is the expression, "to spare you?" I heard, he saith, that some among you had committed fornication; I would not therefore come and make you sorry: for had I come, I must needs have enquired into the matter, and prosecuted and punished, and exacted justice from many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:14
verses.text: I judged it then better to be away and to give opportunity for repentance, than to be with you and to prosecute, and be still more incensed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:15
verses.text: For towards the end of this Epistle he hath plainly declared it, saying, "I fear lest when I come, my God should humble me before you, and that I should mourn for many of them that have sinned heretofore, and repented not of the lasciviousness and uncleanness which they committed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:16
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:17
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:19
verses.text: ) This therefore here also he intimates, and he saith it indeed as in his own defence; yet rebuketh them most severely and putteth them in fear; for he implied that they were open to punishment, and will also have somewhat to suffer, unless they be quickly reformed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:20
verses.text: And he says the same thing again at the end of the Epistle thus; "If I come again, I will not spare".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:21
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:22
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:23
verses.text: ) Only there he says it more plainly: but here, as it was the proem, he does not say it so but in a repressed tone; nor is he content even with this, but he softens it down, applying a corrective.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:24
verses.text: For seeing the expression was that of one asserting great authority, (for a man spares those whom he has also power to punish,) in order to relieve it, and draw a shade over what seems harsh, he saith,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:25
verses.text: "Not for that we have lordship over your faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:26
verses.text: That is, I did not therefore say, "To spare you I came not," as lording it over you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:27
verses.text: Again, he said not you, but "your faith," which was at once gentler and truer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:28
verses.text: For him that hath no mind to believe, who hath power to compel?  "But are helpers of your joy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:29
verses.text: For since, saith he, your joy is ours, I came not, that I might not plunge you into sorrow and increase my own despondency; but I stayed away that ye being reformed by the threat might be made glad.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:30
verses.text: For we do every thing in order to your joy, and give diligence in this behalf, because we are ourselves partakers of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:31
verses.text: "For by faith ye stand".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:32
verses.text: Behold him again speaking repressedly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:33
verses.text: For he was afraid to rebuke them again; since he had handled them severely in the former Epistle, and they had made some reformation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:34
verses.text: And if, now that they were reformed, they again received the same reproof, this was likely to throw them back.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:35
verses.text: Whence this Epistle is much gentler than the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:36
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:37
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:38
verses.text: "But I determined for myself that I would not come again to you with sorrow".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:39
verses.text: The expression "again" proves that he had already been made sorry from thence, and whilst he seems to be speaking in his own defence he covertly rebukes them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:40
verses.text: Now if they had both already made him sorry and were about again to make him sorry, consider how great the displeasure was likely to be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:41
verses.text: But he saith not thus, 'Ye made me sorry,' but turns the expression differently yet implying the very same thing thus, 'For this cause I came not that I might not make you sorry:' which has the same force as what I said, but is more palatable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:42
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:43
verses.text: "For if I make you sorry, who then is he that maketh me glad, but he that is made sorry by me?"  What is this consequence? A very just one indeed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:44
verses.text: For observe, I would not, he saith, come unto you, lest I should increase your sorrow, rebuking, showing anger and disgust.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:45
verses.text: Then seeing that even this was strong and implied accusation that they so lived as to make Paul sorry, he applies a corrective in the words, "For if I make you sorry, who then is he that maketh me glad, but he that is made sorry by me?"  What he saith is of this kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:46
verses.text: 'Even though I were to be in sorrow, being compelled to rebuke you and to see you sorry, still nevertheless this very thing would have made me glad.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:47
verses.text: For this is a proof of the greatest love, that you hold me in such esteem as to be hurt at my being displeased with you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:48
verses.text: '  Behold too his prudence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:49
verses.text: Their doing what all disciples do, namely, smarting and feeling it when rebuked, he produces as an instance of their gratifying him; for, saith he, 'No man maketh me so glad as he that giveth heed to my words, and is sorry when he seeth me angry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:50
verses.text: '  Yet what followed naturally was to say, 'For if I make you sorry, who then is he that can make you glad?' But he doth not say this, but turns his speech back again, dealing tenderly with them, and says, 'Though I make you sorry, even herein ye bestow on me a very great favor in that ye are hurt at what I say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:51
verses.text: '  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:52
verses.text: "And I wrote this very thing unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:53
verses.text: What? That for this cause I came not, to spare you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:54
verses.text: When wrote he? In the former Epistle when he said, "I do not wish to see you now by the way?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:55
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:56
verses.text: ) I think not; but in this Epistle when he said, "Lest when I come again, my God should humble me before you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:57
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:58
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:59
verses.text: ) I have written then towards the end this same, saith he, "lest when I come, my God will humble me, and I should mourn for many of them that have sinned heretofore".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:60
verses.text: But why didst thou write? "Lest when I came I should have sorrow from them of whom I ought to rejoice, having confidence in you all, that my joy is the joy of you all?" For whereas he said he was made glad by their sorrow, and this was too arrogant and harsh, again he gave it a different turn and softened it by what he subjoined.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:61
verses.text: For, he saith, I therefore wrote unto you before, that I might not with anguish find you unreformed; and I said this, "lest I should have sorrow," out of regard not to my own interest but yours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:62
verses.text: For I know that if ye see me rejoicing ye rejoice, and if ye behold me sad ye are sad.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:63
verses.text: Observe therefore again the connection of what he said; for so his words will be more easy to understand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:64
verses.text: I came not, he says, lest I should cause you sorrow when finding you unreformed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:65
verses.text: And this I did, not studying my own advantage, but yours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:66
verses.text: For as to myself, when ye are made sorry I receive no little pleasure, seeing that you care so much about me as to be sorry and distressed at my being displeased.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:67
verses.text: "For who is he that maketh me glad, but he that is made sorry by me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:68
verses.text: However, though it be so with myself, yet because I study your advantage, I wrote this same thing to you that I might not be made sorry, herein also again studying not my advantage, but yours; for I know, that were ye to see me sad, ye also would be sorry; as also ye are glad when ye see me rejoicing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:69
verses.text: Observe now his prudence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:70
verses.text: He said, I came not, that I might not make you sorry; although, saith he, this makes me glad.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:71
verses.text: Then, lest he should seem to take pleasure in their pain, he saith, In this respect I am glad inasmuch as I make you feel, for in another respect I am sorry in that I am compelled to make those sorry who love me so much, not only by this rebuke, but also by being myself in sorrow and by this means causing you fresh sorrow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:72
verses.text: But observe how he puts this so as to mingle praise; saying, "from them of whom I ought to rejoice," for these are the words of one testifying kindred and much tender affection; as if one were speaking of sons on whom he had bestowed many benefits and for whom he had toiled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:73
verses.text: If then for this I write and come not; it is with weighty meaning I come not, and not because I feel hate or aversion, but rather exceeding love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:74
verses.text: Next, whereas he said, he that makes me sorry makes me glad; lest they should say 'this then is what thou studiest, that thou mightest be made glad and mightest exhibit to all the extent of thy power;' he added,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:75
verses.text: "For out of much affliction and anguish of heart I wrote unto you with many tears, not that ye should be made sorry, but that ye might know the love which I have more abundantly unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:76
verses.text: What more tenderly affectioned than this man's spirit is? for he showeth himself to have been not less pained than they who had sinned, but even much more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:77
verses.text: For he saith not "out of affliction" merely, but "out of much," nor "with tears," but "with many tears" and "anguish of heart," that is, I was suffocated, I was choked with despondency; and when I could no longer endure the cloud of despondency, "I wrote unto you: not that ye should be grieved, but that ye might know the love," saith he, "which I have more abundantly unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:78
verses.text: And yet what naturally followed was to say, not that ye might be grieved, but that ye might be corrected: (for indeed with this purpose he wrote.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:79
verses.text: ) This however he doth not say, but, (more to sweeten his words, and win them to a greater affection,) he puts this for it, showing that he doth all from love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:80
verses.text: And he saith not simply "the love," but "which I have more abundantly unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:81
verses.text: For hereby also he desires to win them, by showing that he loveth them more than all and feels towards them as to chosen disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:82
verses.text: Whence he saith, "Even if I be not an Apostle unto others, yet at least I am to you;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:83
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:84
verses.text: ) and, "Though ye have many tutors, yet have ye not many fathers;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:85
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:86
verses.text: ) and again, "By the grace of God we behaved ourselves in the world, and more abundantly to you ward;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:87
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:88
verses.text: ) and farther on, "Though the more abundantly I love you, the less I be loved;" and here "Which I have more abundantly unto you;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:89
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:90
verses.text: ) So that if my words were full of anger, yet out of much love and sadness was the anger; and whilst writing the Epistle, I suffered, I was pained, not because ye had sinned only, but also because I was compelled to make you sorry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:91
verses.text: And this itself was out of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:92
verses.text: Just as a father whose legitimate son is afflicted with a gangrene, being compelled to use the knife and cautery, is pained on both accounts, that he is diseased and that he is compelled to use the knife to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:93
verses.text: So that what ye consider a sign of hating you was indeed a sign of excessive love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:94
verses.text: And if to have made you sorry was out of love, much more my gladness at that sorrow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:95
verses.text: Having made this defence of himself, (for he frequently defends himself, without being ashamed; for if God doth so, saying, "O My people, what have I done unto thee?" (Micah vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:96
verses.text: ) much more might Paul,) having, I say, made this defence of himself, and being now about to pass on to the plea for him who had committed fornication, in order that they might not be distracted as at receiving contradictory commands, nor take to cavilling because he it was who both then was angry and was now commanding to forgive him, see how he provided for this beforehand, both by what he has said and what he is going to say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:97
verses.text: For what saith he?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:98
verses.text: "But if any hath caused sorrow, he hath caused sorrow not to me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:99
verses.text: Having first praised them as feeling joy and sorrow for the same things as himself, he then strikes into the subject of this person, having said first, "my joy is the joy of you all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:100
verses.text: But if my joy is the joy of you all, need is that you should also now feel pleasure with me, as ye then were pained with me: for both in that ye were made sorry, ye made me glad; and now in that ye rejoice, (if as I suppose ye shall feel pleasure,) ye will do the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:101
verses.text: He said not, my sorrow is the sorrow of you all; but having established this in the rest of what he said, he has now put forward that only which he most desired, namely, the joy: saying, my joy is the joy of you all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:102
verses.text: Then, he makes mention also of the former matter, saying,  "But if any hath caused sorrow he hath caused sorrow not to me, but in part (that I press not too heavily) to you all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:103
verses.text: I know, he saith, that ye shared in my anger and indignation against him that had committed fornication, and that what had taken place grieved in part all of you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:104
verses.text: And therefore said I "in part," not as though ye were less hurt than I, but that I might not weigh down him that had committed fornication.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:105
verses.text: He did not then grieve me only but you also equally, even though to spare him I said, "in part".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:106
verses.text: Seest thou how at once he moderated their anger, by declaring that they shared also in his indignation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:107
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:108
verses.text: "Sufficient to such a one is this punishment which was inflicted by the many".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:109
verses.text: And he saith not "to him that hath committed fornication," but here again "to such a one," as also in the former Epistle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:110
verses.text: Not however for the same reason; but there out of shame, here out of mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:111
verses.text: Wherefore he no where subsequently so much as mentions the crime; for it was time now to excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:112
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:113
verses.text: "So that contrariwise ye should rather forgive him and comfort him, lest by any means such a one should be swallowed up with his overmuch sorrow".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:114
verses.text: He bids them not only take off the censure; but, besides, restores him to his former estate; for if one let go him that hath been scourged and heal him not, he hath done nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:115
verses.text: And see how him too he keeps down lest he should be rendered worse by the forgiveness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:116
verses.text: For though he had both confessed and repented, he makes it manifest that he obtaineth remission not so much by his penitence as by this free gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:117
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "to forgive him and to comfort him," and what follows again makes the same thing plain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:118
verses.text: 'For' saith he, 'it is not because he is worthy, not because he has shown sufficient penitence; but because he is weak, it is for this I request it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:119
verses.text: ' Whence also he added, "lest by any means such a one should be swallowed up with overmuch sorrow".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:120
verses.text: And this is both as testifying to his deep repentance and as not allowing him to fall into despair.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:121
verses.text: But what means this, "swallowed up?" Either doing as Judas did, or even in living becoming worse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:122
verses.text: For, saith he, if he should rush away from longer enduring the anguish of this lengthened censure, perchance also despairing he will either come to hang himself, or fall into greater crimes afterwards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:123
verses.text: One ought then to take steps beforehand, lest the sore become too hard to deal with; and lest what we have well done we lose by want of moderation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:124
verses.text: Now this he said, (as I have already observed,) both to keep him low, and to teach him not to be over-listless after this restoration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:125
verses.text: For, not as one who has washed all quite away; but as fearing lest he should work aught of deeper mischief, I have received him, he saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:126
verses.text: Whence we learn that we must determine the penance, not only by the nature of the sins, but by the disposition and habit of them that sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:127
verses.text: As the Apostle did in that instance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:128
verses.text: For he feared his weakness, and therefore said, "lest he be swallowed up," as though by a wild beast, by a storm, by a billow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:129
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:130
verses.text: "Wherefore I beseech you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:131
verses.text: He no longer commands but beseeches, not as a teacher but as an equal; and having seated them on the judgment seat he placed himself in the rank of an advocate; for having succeeded in his object, for joy he adopts without restraint the tone of supplication.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:132
verses.text: And what can it be that thou beseechest? Tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:133
verses.text: "To confirm your love toward him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:134
verses.text: That is, 'make it strong,' not simply have intercourse with him, nor any how.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:135
verses.text: Herein, again, he bears testimony to their virtue as very great; since they who were so friendly and so applauded him as even to be puffed up, were so estranged that Paul takes such pains to make them confirm their love towards him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:136
verses.text: Herein is excellence of disciples, herein excellence of teachers; that they should so obey the rein, he so manage their motions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:137
verses.text: If this were so even now, they who sin would not have transgressed senselessly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:138
verses.text: For one ought neither to love carelessly, nor to be estranged without some reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:139
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:140
verses.text: "For to this end also did I write to you, that I might know the proof of you, whether ye are obedient in all things;" not only in cutting off but also in reuniting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:141
verses.text: Seest thou how here again he brings the danger to their doors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:142
verses.text: For as when he sinned, he alarmed their minds, except they should cut him off, saying, "A little leaven leaveneth the whole lump," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:143
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:144
verses.text: ) and several other things; so here too again he confronts them with the fear of disobedience, as good as saying, 'As then ye had to consult not for him, but for yourselves too, so now must ye not less for yourselves than for him; lest ye seem to be of such as love contention and have not human sensibilities, and not to be in all things obedient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:145
verses.text: And hence he saith, "For to this end also did I write to you, that I might know the proof of you, whether ye are obedient in all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:146
verses.text: For the former instance might have seemed to proceed even of envy and malice, but this shows very especially the obedience to be pure, and whether ye are apt unto loving kindness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:147
verses.text: For this is the test of right minded disciples; if they obey not only when ordered to do certain things, but when the contrary also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:148
verses.text: Therefore he said, "in all things," showing that if they disobey, they disgrace not him so much as themselves, earning the character of lovers of contention; and he doth this that hence also he may drive them to obey.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:149
verses.text: Whence also he saith, "For to this end did I write to you;" and yet he wrote not for this end, but he saith so in order to win them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:150
verses.text: For the leading object was the salvation of that person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:151
verses.text: But where it does no harm, he also gratifies them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:152
verses.text: And by saying, "In all things," he again praises them, recalling to memory and bringing forth to view their former obedience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:153
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:154
verses.text: "To whom ye forgive any thing, I forgive also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:155
verses.text: Seest thou how again he assigns the second part to himself, showing them as beginning, himself following.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:156
verses.text: This is the way to soften an exasperated, to compose a contentious spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:157
verses.text: Then lest he should make them careless, as though they were arbiters, and they should refuse forgiveness; he again constrains them unto this, saying, that himself also had forgiven him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:158
verses.text: "For what I also have forgiven, if I have forgiven any thing, for your sakes have I forgiven it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:159
verses.text: For, this very thing I have done for your sakes, he saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:160
verses.text: And as when he commanded them to cut him off, he left not with them the power to forgive, saying, "I have judged already to deliver such an one unto Satan," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:161
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:163
verses.text: ) and again made them partners in his decision saying, "ye being gathered together to deliver him," (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:165
verses.text: ) (thereby securing two most important things, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:166
verses.text: , that the sentence should be passed; yet not without their consent, lest herein he might seem to hurt them;) and neither himself alone pronounces it, lest they should consider him self-willed, and themselves to be overlooked, nor yet leaves all to them, lest when possessed of the power they should deal treacherously with the offender by unseasonably forgiving him: so also doth he here, saying, 'I have already forgiven, who in the former Epistle had already judged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:167
verses.text: ' Then lest they should be hurt, as though overlooked, he adds, "for your sakes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:168
verses.text: What then? did he for men's sake pardon? No; for on this account he added, "In the person of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:169
verses.text: What is "in the person of Christ?" Either he means according to the will of God, or unto the glory of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:170
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:171
verses.text: "That no advantage may be gained over us by Satan: for we are not ignorant of his devices".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:172
verses.text: Seest thou how he both committeth the power to them and again taketh away that by that he may soften them, by this eradicate their self will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:173
verses.text: But this is not all that he provides for by this, but shows also that should they be disobedient the harm would reach to all, just as he did at the outset also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:174
verses.text: For then too he said, "A little leaven leaveneth the whole lump".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:175
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:176
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:177
verses.text: ) And here again, "Lest Satan should get an advantage of us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:178
verses.text: And throughout, he maketh this forgiveness the joint act of himself and them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:179
verses.text: Consider it from the first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:180
verses.text: "But if any," saith he, "have caused sorrow he hath caused sorrow not to me, but in part (that I press not too heavily) to you all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:181
verses.text: Then again, "Sufficient to such a one is this punishment which was" inflicted by the "many".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:182
verses.text: This is his own decision and opinion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:183
verses.text: He rested not however with this decision, but again makes them partners saying, "So that contrariwise ye should rather forgive" him "and comfort" him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:184
verses.text: "Wherefore I beseech you to confirm your love towards him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:185
verses.text: Having thus again made the whole their act, he passes to his own authority, saying, "For to this end did I write unto you, that I might know the proof of you, whether ye are obedient in all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:186
verses.text: Then, again, he makes the favor theirs, saying, "To whom ye forgive anything".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:187
verses.text: Then, his own, "I" forgive "also:" saying, "if I have forgiven anything, it is for your sakes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:188
verses.text: Then both theirs and his, "For," saith he, "if I have forgiven any thing, for your sakes forgave I it in the person of Christ," either that is for the glory of Christ, or as though Christ commanding this also, which was most effectual to prevail with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:189
verses.text: For after this they would have feared not to grant that which tended to His glory and which He willed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:190
verses.text: Then again he signifieth the common harm should they disobey, when he saith, "Lest Satan should get an advantage of us;" well naming it, getting advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:191
verses.text: For he no more takes his own, but violently seizeth ours, for he is reformed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:192
verses.text: And tell me not that this one only becomes the wild beast's prey, but consider this also, that the number of the herd is diminished, and now especially when it might recover what it had lost.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:193
verses.text: "For we are not ignorant of his devices," That he destroys even under the show of piety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:194
verses.text: For not only by leading into fornication can he destroy, but even by the contrary, the unmeasured sorrow following on the repentance for it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:195
verses.text: When then besides his own he taketh ours too, when both by bidding to sin, he destroys; and when we bid repent, violently seizeth; how is not this case getting "advantage?" For he is not content with striking down by sin, but even by repentance he doth this except we be vigilant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:196
verses.text: Wherefore also with reason did he call it getting advantage, when he even conquereth our own weapons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:197
verses.text: For to take by sin is his proper work; by repentance, however, is no more his; for ours, not his, is that weapon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:198
verses.text: When then even by this he is able to take, think how disgraceful the defeat, how he will laugh at and run us down as weak and pitiful, if he is to subdue us with our own weapons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:199
verses.text: For it were matter for exceeding scorn and of the last disgrace, that he should inflict wounds on us through our own remedies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:200
verses.text: Therefore he said, "for we are not ignorant of his devices," exposing his versatility, his craftiness, his evil devices, his malice, his capacity to injure under a show of piety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:201
verses.text: These things then having in mind, let us too never despise any one; nor ever, though we fall into sin, despair; on the other hand, again, let us not be easy-minded afterwards, but, when we transgress, afflict our minds and not merely give vent to words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:202
verses.text: For I know many who say indeed that they bewail their sins, but do nothing of account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:203
verses.text: They fast and wear rough garments; but after money are more eager than hucksters, are more the prey of anger than wild beasts, and take more pleasure in detraction than others do in commendations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:204
verses.text: These things are not repentance, these things are the semblance and shadow only of repentance, not repentance itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:205
verses.text: Wherefore in the case of these persons too it is well to say, Take heed "lest Satan should get an advantage of us, for we are not ignorant of his devices;" for some he destroys through sins, others through repentance; but these in yet another way, by suffering them to gain no fruit from repentance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:206
verses.text: For when he found not how he might destroy them by direct attack, he came another road, heightening their toils, whilst robbing them of the fruits, and persuading them, as if they had successfully accomplished all they had to do, therefore to be neglectful of what remains.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:207
verses.text: That we may not then fruitlessly afflict ourselves, let us address a few words to women of this character; for to women this disorder especially belongs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:208
verses.text: Praiseworthy indeed is even that which now ye do, your fasting and lying on the ground and ashes; but except the rest be added, these are of no avail.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:209
verses.text: God hath showed how He remitteth sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:210
verses.text: Why then forsaking that path, do ye carve another for yourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:211
verses.text: In old time the Ninevites sinned, and they did the things which ye too now are doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:212
verses.text: Let us see however what it was that availed them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:213
verses.text: For as in the case of the sick, physicians apply many remedies; howbeit the man of understanding regardeth not that the sick person has tried this and that, but what was of service to him; such must be also our inquiry here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:214
verses.text: What then was it that availed those barbarians? They applied fasting unto the wounds, yea applied extreme fasting, lying on the ground too, putting on of sackcloth, and ashes, and lamentations; they applied also a change of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:215
verses.text: Let us then see which of these things made them whole.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:216
verses.text: And whence, saith one, shall we know? If we come to the Physician, if we ask Him: for He will not hide it from us, but will even eagerly disclose it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:217
verses.text: Rather that none may be ignorant, nor need to ask, He hath even set down in writing the medicine that restored them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:218
verses.text: What then is this? "God," saith He, "saw that they turned every one from his evil way, and He repented of the evil that He had said He would do unto them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:219
verses.text: (Jonah iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:220
verses.text: ) He said not, He saw their fasting and sackcloth and ashes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:221
verses.text: And I say not this to overturn fasting, (God forbid!) but to exhort you that with fasting ye do that which is better than fasting, the abstaining from all evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:222
verses.text: David also sinned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:223
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:224
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:226
verses.text: ) Let us see then how he too repented.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:227
verses.text: Three days he sat on ashes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:228
verses.text: But this he did not for the sin's sake, but for the child's, being as yet stupefied with that affliction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:229
verses.text: But the sin by other means did he wipe away, by humbleness, contrition of heart, compunction of soul, by falling into the like no more, by remembering it always, by bearing thankfully every thing that befalls him, by sparing those that grieve him, by forbearing to requite those who conspire against him; yea, even preventing those who desire to do this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:230
verses.text: For instance, when Shimei was bespattering him with reproaches without number ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:231
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:233
verses.text: ) and the captain who was with him was greatly indignant, he said, "Let him curse me, for the Lord hath bidden him:" for he had a contrite and humbled heart, and it was this especially which wiped away his sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:234
verses.text: For this is confession, this is repentance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:235
verses.text: But if whilst we fast we are proud, we have been not only nothing profited but even injured.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:236
verses.text: Humble then thine heart, thou too, that thou mayest draw God unto thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:237
verses.text: "For the Lord is nigh unto them that are of a contrite heart".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:238
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:239
verses.text: xxxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:240
verses.text: ) Seest thou not in the gorgeous houses those who are in disgrace; how they answer not again when even the lower servants insult them, but put up with it because of the disgrace with which their fault hath surrounded them? So do thou too: and if any one revile thee, wax not fierce, but groan, not for the insult, but for that sin which cast thee into disgrace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:241
verses.text: Groan when thou hast sinned, not because thou art to be punished, (for this is nothing,) but because thou hast offended thy Master, one so gentle, one so kind, one that so loveth thee and longeth for thy salvation as to have given even His Son for thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:242
verses.text: For this groan, and do this continually: for this is confession.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:243
verses.text: Be not to-day cheerful, to-morrow of a sad countenance, then again cheerful; but continue ever in mourning and self contrition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:244
verses.text: For, "Blessed," saith he, "are they that mourn," that is, that do this perpetually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:245
verses.text: Continue then to do this perpetually, and to take heed to thyself, and to afflict thine heart; as one who had lost a beloved son might mourn.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:246
verses.text: "Rend," saith he, "your hearts, and not your garments".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:247
verses.text: (Joel ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:248
verses.text: ) That which is rent will not lift itself on high; that which hath been broken cannot rise up again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:249
verses.text: Hence one saith, "Rend," and another, "a broken and a contrite heart God will not despise".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:250
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:251
verses.text: li.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:252
verses.text: ) Yea, though thou be wise, or wealthy, or a ruler, rend thine heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:253
verses.text: Suffer it not to have high thoughts nor to be inflated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:254
verses.text: For that which is rent is not inflated, and even if there be something to make it rise, from being rent it cannot retain the inflation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:255
verses.text: So also do thou be humble-minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:256
verses.text: Consider that the publican was justified by one word, although that was not humiliation, but a true confession.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:257
verses.text: Now if this hath power so great, how much more humiliation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:258
verses.text: Remit offences to those who have transgressed against thee, for this too remitteth sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:259
verses.text: And concerning the former He saith, "I saw that he went sorrowful, and I healed his ways;" (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:260
verses.text: lvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:262
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:263
verses.text: ) and in Ahab's case, this appeased the wrath of God: ( Kings xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:264
verses.text: ) concerning the latter, "Remit, and it shall be remitted unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:265
verses.text: There is also again another way which bringeth us this medicine; condemning what we have done amiss; for, "Declare thou first thy transgressions, that thou mayest be justified".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:266
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:267
verses.text: xliii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:268
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:269
verses.text: ) And for one in afflictions to give thanks looseth his sins; and almsgiving, which is greater than all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:270
verses.text: Reckon up therefore the medicines which heal thy wounds, and apply all unremittingly, humbleness, confession, forgetting wrongs, giving thanks in afflictions, showing mercy both in alms and actions, persevering in prayer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:271
verses.text: So did the widow propitiate the cruel and unyielding judge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:272
verses.text: And if she the unjust, much more thou the gentle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:273
verses.text: There is yet another way along with these, defending the oppressed; "for," He saith, "judge the fatherless, and plead for the widow; and come, and let us reason together, and though your sins be as scarlet, I will make them white as snow".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:274
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:275
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:277
verses.text: ) What excuse then can we deserve if with so many ways leading us up to heaven, and so many medicines to heal our wounds, even after the Laver we continue where we were.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 5:278
verses.text: Let us then not only continue so, but let those indeed who have never yet fallen abide in their proper loveliness; yea, rather let them cultivate it more and more, (for these good works, where they find not sins, make the beauty greater:) and let us who in many things have done amiss, in order to the correction of our sins use the means mentioned: that we may stand at the tribunal of Christ with much boldness, whereunto may all we attain through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, together with the Holy Spirit, be glory, and power, and honor, now and ever, world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:1
verses.text: Homily V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:3
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:4
verses.text: ,  Now when I came to Troas for the gospel of Christ, and when a door was opened unto me in the Lord, I had no relief for my spirit, because I found not Titus my brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:5
verses.text: These words seem on the one hand to be unworthy of Paul, if because of a brother's absence he threw away so great an opportunity of saving; and on the other, to hang apart from the context.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:6
verses.text: What then? Will ye that we should first prove that they hang upon the context, or, that he hath said nothing unworthy of himself? As I think, the second, for so the other point also will be easier and clearer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:7
verses.text: How then do these (words) hang upon those before them? Let us recall to mind what those were, and so we shall perceive this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:8
verses.text: What then were those before? What he said at the beginning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:9
verses.text: "I would not have you," saith he, "ignorant concerning our affliction which befell us in Asia, that we were weighed down exceedingly, beyond our power".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:10
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:11
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:12
verses.text: ) Now having shown the manner of his deliverance, and inserted the intermediate matter, he is of necessity led to teach them again that in yet another way he had been afflicted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:13
verses.text: How, and in what way? In not finding Titus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:14
verses.text: (vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:15
verses.text: ; viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:17
verses.text: ) Fearful indeed, and enough to prostrate the soul, is it even to endure trials; but when there is none to comfort and that can help to bear the burden, the tempest becometh greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:18
verses.text: Now Titus is he, whom further on he speaks of as having come to him from them, and of whom he runs through many and great praises, and whom he said he had sent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:19
verses.text: With the view then of showing that in this point also he had been afflicted for their sakes, he said these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:20
verses.text: That the words then in question hang on what went before is from all this plain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:21
verses.text: And I will attempt to prove also that they are not unworthy of Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:22
verses.text: For He doth not say that the absence of Titus impeded the salvation of those who were about to come over, nor yet that he neglected those that believed on this account, but that he had no relief, that is, 'I was afflicted, I was distressed for the absence of my brother;' showing how great a matter a brother's absence is; and therefore he departed thence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:23
verses.text: But what means, "when I came to Troas, for the Gospel?" he saith not simply 'I arrived,' but 'so as to preach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:24
verses.text: ' But still, though I had both come for that and found very much to do, (for "a door was opened unto me in the Lord,") I had, saith he, "no relief," not that for this he impeded the work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:25
verses.text: How then saith he,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:26
verses.text: "Taking my leave of them, I went from thence?"  That is, 'I spent no longer time, being straitened and distressed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:27
verses.text: ' And perhaps the work was even impeded by his absence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:28
verses.text: And this was no light consolation to them too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:29
verses.text: For if when a door was opened there, and for this purpose he had come; yet because he found not the brother, he quickly started away; much more, he saith, ought ye to make allowance for the compulsion of those affairs which lead us and lead us about everywhere, and suffer us not according as we desire either to journey, or to tarry longer amongst those with whom we may wish to remain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:30
verses.text: Whence also he proceeds in this place again to refer his journeyings to God, as he did above to the Spirit, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:31
verses.text: "But thanks be to God, which always causeth us to triumph in Christ, and maketh manifest through us the savor of His knowledge in every place".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:32
verses.text: For that he may not seem as though in sorrow to be lamenting these things, he sendeth up thanks to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:33
verses.text: Now what he saith is this: 'Every where is trouble, every where straitness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:34
verses.text: I came into Asia, I was burdened beyond strength.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:35
verses.text: I came to Troas, I found not the brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:36
verses.text: I came not to you; this too bred in me no slight, yea rather, exceeding great dejection, both because many among you had sinned, and because on this account I see you not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:37
verses.text: For, "To spare you," he saith, "I came not as yet unto Corinth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:38
verses.text: That then he may not seem to be complaining in so speaking, he adds, 'We not only do not grieve in these afflictions, but we even rejoice; and, what is still greater, not for the sake of the rewards to come only, but those too even which are present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:39
verses.text: For even here we are by these things made glorious and conspicuous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:40
verses.text: So far then are we from lamenting, that we even call the thing a triumph; and glory in what happeneth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:41
verses.text: ' For which cause also he said, "Now thanks be unto God, Which always causeth us to triumph," that is, 'Who maketh us renowned unto all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:42
verses.text: For what seemeth to be matter of disgrace, being persecuted from every quarter, this appeareth to us to be matter of very great honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:43
verses.text: ' Wherefore he said not, "Which maketh us seen of all," but, "Which causeth us to triumph:" showing that these persecutions set up a series of trophies against the devil in every part of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:44
verses.text: Then having mentioned along with the author, the subject also of the triumph, he thereby also raiseth up the hearer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:45
verses.text: 'For not only are we made to triumph by God, but also "in Christ;"' that is, on account of Christ and the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:46
verses.text: 'For seeing it behooveth to triumph, all need is that we also who carry the trophy are seen of all, because we bear Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:47
verses.text: For this reason we become observed and conspicuous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:48
verses.text: '   Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:49
verses.text: "And which maketh manifest through us the savor of His knowledge in every place".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:50
verses.text: He said above, "Which always causeth us to triumph".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:51
verses.text: Here he saith "in every place," showing that every place and every time is full of the Apostles' labors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:52
verses.text: And he uses yet another metaphor, that of the sweet savor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:53
verses.text: For 'like as those who bear ointment, so are we,' saith he, 'manifest to all'; calling the knowledge a very precious ointment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:54
verses.text: Moreover, he said not, 'the knowledge;' but "the savor of the knowledge;" for such is the nature of the present knowledge, not very clear nor uncovered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:55
verses.text: Whence also he said in the former Epistle, "For now we see in a mirror darkly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:56
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:57
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:58
verses.text: ) And here he calls that which is such a "savor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:59
verses.text: Now he that perceiveth the savor knoweth that there is ointment lying somewhere; but of what nature it is he knows not yet, unless he happens before to have seen it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:60
verses.text: 'So also we.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:61
verses.text: That God is, we know, but what in substance we know not yet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:62
verses.text: We are then, as it were, a Royal censer, breathing whithersoever we go of the heavenly ointment and the spiritual sweet savor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:63
verses.text: ' Now he said this, at once both to set forth the power of the Preaching, in that by the very designs formed against them, they shine more than those who prosecute them and who cause the whole world to know both their trophies and their sweet savor: and to exhort them in regard to their afflictions and trials to bear all nobly, seeing that even before the Recompense they reap this glory inexpressible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:64
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:65
verses.text: "For we are a sweet savor of Christ unto God, in them that are saved and in them that perish".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:66
verses.text: Whether, saith he, one be saved or be lost, the Gospel continues to have its proper virtue: and as the light, although it blindeth the weakly, is still light, though causing blindness; and as honey, though it be bitter to those who are diseased, is in its nature sweet; so also is the Gospel of sweet savor, even though some should be lost who believe it not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:67
verses.text: For not It, but their own perverseness, worketh the perdition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:68
verses.text: And by this most of all is its sweet savor manifested, by which the corrupt and vicious perish; so that not only by the salvation of the good, but also by the perdition of the wicked is its excellence declared.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:69
verses.text: Since both the sun, for this reason most especially that he is exceeding bright, doth wound the eyes of the weak: and the Saviour is "for the fall and rising again of many," (Luke ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:70
verses.text: ) but still He continueth to be a Saviour, though ten thousand fall; and His coming brought a sorer punishment upon them that believe not, but still it continueth to be full of healing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:71
verses.text: Whence also he saith, "We are unto God a sweet savor;" that is, 'even though some be lost we continue to be that which we are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:72
verses.text: ' Moreover he said not simply "a sweet savor," but "unto God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:73
verses.text: And when we are a sweet savor unto God, and He decreeth these things, who shall henceforth gainsay?  The expression also, "sweet savor of Christ," appears to me to admit of a double interpretation: for he means either that in dying they offered themselves a sacrifice: or that they were a sweet savor of the death of Christ, as if one should say, this incense is a sweet savor of this victim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:74
verses.text: The expression then, sweet savor, either signifieth this, or, as I first said, that they are daily sacrificed for Christ's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:75
verses.text: Seest thou to what a height he hath advanced the trials, terming them a triumph and a sweet savor and a sacrifice offered unto God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:76
verses.text: Then, whereas he said, "we are a sweet savor, even in them that perish," lest thou shouldest think that these too are acceptable, he added,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:77
verses.text: "To the one a savor from death unto death, to the other a savor from life unto life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:78
verses.text: For this sweet savor some so receive that they are saved, others so that they perish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:79
verses.text: So that should any one be lost, the fault is from himself: for both ointment is said to suffocate swine, and light (as I before observed,) to blind the weak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:80
verses.text: And such is the nature of good things; they not only correct what is akin to them, but also destroy the opposite: and in this way is their power most displayed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:81
verses.text: For so both fire, not only when it giveth light and when it purifieth gold, but even when it consumeth thorns, doth very greatly display its proper power, and so show itself to be fire: and Christ too herein also doth discover His own majesty when He "shall consume" Antichrist "with the breath of His mouth, and bring him to nought with the manifestation of His coming".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:82
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:83
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:84
verses.text: )  "And who is sufficient for these things?"  Seeing he had uttered great things, that 'we are a sacrifice of Christ and a sweet savor, and are every where made to triumph,' he again useth moderation, referring all to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:85
verses.text: Whence also he saith, "and who is sufficient for these things?" 'for all,' saith he, 'is Christ's, nothing our own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:86
verses.text: ' Seest thou how opposite his language to the false Apostles'? For they indeed glory, as contributing somewhat from themselves unto the message: he, on the contrary, saith, he therefore glorieth, because he saith that nothing is his own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:87
verses.text: "For our glorying is this, the testimony of our conscience, that not in fleshly wisdom, but in the grace of God, we behaved ourselves in the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:88
verses.text: And that which they considered it a glory to acquire, I mean the wisdom from without, he makes it his to take away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:89
verses.text: Whence also he here saith, "And who is sufficient for these things?" But if none are sufficient, that which is done is of grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:90
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:91
verses.text: "For we are not as the rest, which corrupt the word of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:92
verses.text: 'For even if we use great sounding words, yet we declared nothing to be our own that we achieved, but all Christ's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:93
verses.text: For we will not imitate the false apostles; the men who say that most is of themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:94
verses.text: ' For this is "to corrupt," when one adulterates the wine; when one sells for money what he ought to give freely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:95
verses.text: For he seems to me to be here both taunting them in respect to money, and again hinting at the very thing I have said, as that they mingle their own things with God's; which is the charge Isaiah brings when he said, "Thy vintners mingle wine with water:" (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:96
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:97
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:98
verses.text: ) for even if this was said of wine, yet one would not err in expounding it of doctrine too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:99
verses.text: 'But we,' saith he, 'do not so: but such as we have been entrusted with, such do we offer you, pouring out the word undiluted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:100
verses.text: ' Whence he added, "But as of sincerity, but as of God, in the sight of God speak we in Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:101
verses.text: 'We do not,' saith he 'beguile you and so preach, as conferring a gift on you, or as bringing in and mingling somewhat from ourselves, "but as of God;" that is, we do not say that we confer any thing of our own, but that God hath given all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:102
verses.text: ' For "of God" means this; To glory in nothing as if we had it of our own, but to refer every thing to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:103
verses.text: "Speak we in Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:104
verses.text: Not by our own wisdom, but instructed by the power that cometh from Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:105
verses.text: Those who glory speak not in this way, but as bringing in something from themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:106
verses.text: Whence he elsewhere also turns them into ridicule, saying, "For what hast thou that thou didst not receive? but if thou didst receive it, why dost thou glory as if thou hadst not received it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:107
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:108
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:109
verses.text: ) This is the highest virtue, to refer every thing to God, to consider nothing to be our own, to do nothing out of regard to men's opinion, but to what God willeth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:110
verses.text: For He it is that requireth the account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:111
verses.text: Now however this order is reversed: and of Him that shall sit upon the tribunal and require the account, we have no exceeding fear, yet tremble at those who stand and are judged with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:112
verses.text: Whence then is this disease? Whence hath it broken out in our souls? From not meditating continually on the things of that world, but being rivetted to present things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:113
verses.text: Hence we both easily fall into wicked doings, and even if we do any good thing we do it for display, so that thence also loss cometh to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:114
verses.text: For instance, one has looked on a person often with unbridled eyes, unseen of her or of those who walk with her, yet of the Eye that never sleeps was not unseen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:115
verses.text: For even before the commission of the sin, It saw the unbridled soul, and that madness within, and the thoughts that were whirled about in storm and surge; for no need hath He of witnesses and proofs Who knoweth all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:116
verses.text: Look not then to thy fellow-servants: for though man praise, it availeth not if God accept not; and though man condemn, it harmeth not if God do not condemn.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:117
verses.text: Oh! provoke not so thy Judge; of thy fellow-servants making great account, yet when Himself is angry, not in fear and trembling at Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:118
verses.text: Let us then despise the praise that cometh of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:119
verses.text: How long shall we be low-minded and grovelling? How long, when God lifteth us to heaven, take we pains to be trailed along the ground? The brethren of Joseph, had they had the fear of God before their eyes, as men ought to have, would not have taken their brother in a lonely place and killed him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:120
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:121
verses.text: xxxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:122
verses.text: ) Cain again, had he feared that sentence as he should have feared, would not have said, "Come, and let us go into the field:" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:123
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:124
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:125
verses.text: ) for to what end, O miserable and wretched! dost thou take him apart from him that begat him, and leadest him out into a lonely place? For doth not God see the daring deed even in the field? Hath thou not been taught by what befel thy father that He knoweth all things, and is present at all things that are done? And why, when he denied, said not God this unto him: 'Hidest thou from Me Who am present every where, and know the things that are secret?' Because as yet he knew not aright to comprehend these high truths.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:126
verses.text: But what saith he? "The voice of thy brother's blood crieth unto Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:127
verses.text: Not as though blood had a voice; but like as we say when things are plain and clear, "the matter speaketh for itself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:128
verses.text: Wherefore surely it behoveth to have before our eyes the sentence of God, and all terrors are extinguished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:129
