verses.text: So too in prayers we can keep awake, if we bear in mind with whom we are conversing, if we reflect that we are offering sacrifice and have in our hands a knife and fire and wood; if in thought we throw wide the gates of heaven, if we transport ourselves thither and taking the sword of the Spirit infix it in the throat of the victim: make watchfulness the sacrifice and tears the libation to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:130
verses.text: For such is the blood of this victim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:131
verses.text: Such the slaughter that crimsons that altar.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:132
verses.text: Suffer not then aught of worldly thoughts to occupy thy soul then.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:133
verses.text: Bethink thee that Abraham also, when offering sacrifice, suffered nor wife nor servant nor any other to be present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:134
verses.text: Neither then do thou suffer any of the slavish and ignoble passions to be present unto thee, but go up alone into the mountain where he went up, where no second person is permitted to go up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:135
verses.text: And should any such thoughts attempt to go up with thee, command them with authority, and say, "Sit ye there, and I and the lad will worship and return to you;" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:136
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:137
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:138
verses.text: ) and leaving the ass and the servants below, and whatever is void of reason and sense, go up, taking with thee whatever is reasonable, as he took Isaac.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:139
verses.text: And build thine altar so as he, as having nothing human, but having outstepped nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:140
verses.text: For he too, had he not outstepped nature, would not have slain his child.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:141
verses.text: And let nothing disturb thee then, but be lift up above the very heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:142
verses.text: Groan bitterly, sacrifice confession, (for, saith he, "Declare thou first thy transgressions that thou mayest be justified," Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:143
verses.text: xliii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:144
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:145
verses.text: ), sacrifice contrition of heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:146
verses.text: These victims turn not to ashes nor dissolve into smoke nor melt into air; neither need they wood and fire, but only a deep-pricked heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:147
verses.text: This is wood, this is fire to burn, yet not consume them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:148
verses.text: For he that prayeth with warmth is burnt, yet not consumed; but like gold that is tried by fire becometh brighter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:149
verses.text: And withal observe heedfully one thing more, in praying to say none of those things that provoke thy Master; neither draw near to pray against enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:150
verses.text: For if to have enemies be a reproach, consider how great the evil to pray against them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:151
verses.text: For need is that thou defend thyself and show why thou hast enemies: but thou even accusest them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:152
verses.text: And what forgiveness shalt thou obtain, when thou both revilest, and at such a time when thyself needest much mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:153
verses.text: For thou drewest near to supplicate for thine own sins: make not mention then of those of others, lest thou recall the memory of thine own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:154
verses.text: For if thou say, 'Smite mine enemy,' thou hast stopped thy mouth, thou hast cut off boldness from thy tongue; first, indeed, because thou hast angered the Judge at once in beginning; next, because thou asketh things at variance with the character of thy prayer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:155
verses.text: For if thou comest near for forgiveness of sins, how discoursest thou of punishment? The contrary surely was there need to do, and to pray for them in order that we may with boldness beseech this for ourselves also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:156
verses.text: But now thou hast forestalled the Judge's sentence by thine own, demanding that He punish them that sin: for this depriveth of all pardon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:157
verses.text: But if thou pray for them, even if thou say nothing in thine own sins' behalf, thou hast achieved all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:158
verses.text: Consider how many sacrifices there are in the law; a sacrifice of praise, a sacrifice of acknowledgment, a sacrifice of peace, a sacrifice of purifications, and numberless others, and not one of them against enemies, but all in behalf of either one's own sins or one's own successes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:159
verses.text: For comest thou to another God? To him thou comest that said, "Pray for your enemies".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:160
verses.text: (Luke vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:161
verses.text: , ; Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:162
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:163
verses.text: ) How then dost thou cry against them? How dost thou beseech God to break his own law? This is not the guise of a suppliant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:164
verses.text: None supplicates the destruction of another, but the safety of himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:165
verses.text: Why then wearest thou the guise of a suppliant, but hast the words of an accuser? Yet when we pray for ourselves, we scratch ourselves and yawn, and fall into ten thousand thoughts; but when against our enemies, we do so wakefully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:166
verses.text: For since the devil knows that we are thrusting the sword against ourselves, he doth not distract nor call us off then, that he may work us the greater harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:167
verses.text: But, saith one, 'I have been wronged and am afflicted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:168
verses.text: ' Why not then pray against the devil, who injureth us most of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:169
verses.text: This thou hast also been commanded to say, "Deliver us from the evil one".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:170
verses.text: He is thy irreconcileable foe, but man, do whatsoever he will, is a friend and brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:171
verses.text: With him then let us all be angry; against him let us beseech God, saying, "Bruise Satan under our feet;" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:172
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:173
verses.text: ) for he it is that breedeth also the enemies we have.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:174
verses.text: But if thou pray against enemies, thou prayest so as he would have thee pray, just as if for thine enemies, then against him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:175
verses.text: Why then letting him go who is thine enemy indeed, dost thou tear thine own members, more cruel in this than wild beasts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:176
verses.text: 'But,' saith one, 'he insulted me and robbed me of money;' and which hath need to grieve, he that suffered injury, or he that inflicted injury? Plainly he that inflicted injury, since whilst he gained money he cast himself out of the favor of God, and lost more than he gained: so that he is the injured party.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:177
verses.text: Surely then need is not that one pray against, but for him, that God would be merciful to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:178
verses.text: See how many things the three children suffered, though they had done no harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:179
verses.text: They lost country, liberty, were taken captive and made slaves; and when carried away into a foreign and barbarous land, were even on the point of being slain on account of the dream, without cause or object.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:180
verses.text: (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:181
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:182
verses.text: ) What then? When they had entered in with Daniel, what prayed they? What said they? Dash down Nabuchodonosor, pull down his diadem, hurl him from the throne? Nothing of this sort; but they desired "mercies of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:183
verses.text: (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:184
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:185
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:186
verses.text: ) And when they were in the furnace, likewise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:187
verses.text: But not so ye: but when ye suffer far less than they, and oftentimes justly, ye cease not to vent ten thousand imprecations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:188
verses.text: And one saith, 'Strike down my enemy as Thou overwhelmedst the chariot of Pharaoh;' another, 'Blast his flesh;' another again, 'Requite it on his children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:189
verses.text: ' Recognize ye not these words? Whence then is this your laughter? Seest thou how laughable this is, when it is uttered without passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:190
verses.text: And so all sin then discovereth how vile it is, when thou strippest it of the state of mind of the perpetrator.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:191
verses.text: Shouldest thou remind one who has been angered of the words which he said in his passion, he will sink for shame and scorn himself and wish he had suffered a thousand punishments rather than those words to be his.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:192
verses.text: And shouldest thou, when the embrace is over, bring the unchaste to the woman he sinned with, he too will turn away from her as disgusting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:193
verses.text: And so do ye, because ye are not under the influence of the passion, laugh now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:194
verses.text: For worthy to be laughed at are they, and the words of drunken old gossips; and springing from a womanish littleness of soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:195
verses.text: And yet Joseph, though he had been sold and made a slave, and had tenanted a prison, uttered not even then a bitter word against the authors of his sorrows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:196
verses.text: But what saith he? "Indeed I was stolen away out of the land of the Hebrews;" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:197
verses.text: xl.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:198
verses.text: ) and addeth not by whom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:199
verses.text: For he feels more ashamed for the wickedness of his brethren, than they who wrought them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:200
verses.text: Such too ought to be our disposition, to grieve for them who wrong us more than they themselves do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:201
verses.text: For the hurt passeth on to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:202
verses.text: As then they who kick against nails, yet are proud of it, are fit objects of pity and lamentation on account of this madness; so they who wrong those that do them no evil, inasmuch as they wound their own souls, are fit objects for many moans and lamentations, not for curses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:203
verses.text: For nothing is more polluted than a soul that curseth, or more impure than a tongue that offereth such sacrifices.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:204
verses.text: Thou art a man; vomit not forth the poison of asps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:205
verses.text: Thou art a man; become not a wild beast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:206
verses.text: For this was thy mouth made, not that thou shouldest bite but that thou shouldest heal the wounds of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:207
verses.text: 'Remember the charge I have given thee,' saith God, 'to pardon and forgive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:208
verses.text: But thou beseechest Me also to be a party to the overthrow of my own commandments, and devourest thy brother, and reddenest thy tongue, as madmen do their teeth on their own members.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 6:209
verses.text: ' How, thinkest thou, the devil is pleased and laughs, when he hears such a prayer? and how, God is provoked, and turneth from and abhorreth thee, when thou beseechest things like these? Than which, what can be more dangerous? For if none should approach the mysteries that hath enemies: how must not he, that not only hath, but also prayeth against them, be excluded even from the outer courts themselves? Thinking then on these things, and considering the Subject of the Sacrifice, that He was sacrificed for enemies; let us not have an enemy: and if we have, let us pray for him; that we too having obtained forgiveness of the sins we have committed, may stand with boldness at the tribunal of Christ; to whom be glory for ever, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:1
verses.text: Homily VI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:3
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:4
verses.text: Are we beginning, again to commend ourselves? or need we, as do some, epistles of commendation to you or letters of commendation from you?  He anticipates and puts himself an objection which others would have urged against him, 'Thou vauntest thyself;' and this though he had before employed so strong a corrective in the expressions, "Who is sufficient for these things?" and, "of sincerity…speak we".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:5
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:6
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:8
verses.text: ) Howbeit he is not satisfied with these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:9
verses.text: For such is his character.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:10
verses.text: From appearing to say any thing great of himself he is far removed, and avoids it even to great superfluity and excess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:11
verses.text: And mark, I pray thee, by this instance also, the abundance of his wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:12
verses.text: For a thing of woeful aspect, I mean tribulations, he so much exalted and showed to be bright and lustrous, that out of what he said the present objection rose up against him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:13
verses.text: And he does so also towards the end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:14
verses.text: For after having enumerated numberless perils, insults, straits, necessities, and as many such like things as be, he added, "We commend not ourselves, but speak as giving you occasion to glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:15
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:16
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:17
verses.text: ) And he expresses this again with vehemence in that place, and with more of encouragement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:18
verses.text: For here the words are those of love, "Need we, as do some, epistles of commendation?" but there what he says is full of a kind of pride even, necessarily and properly so, of pride, I say, and anger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:19
verses.text: "For we commend not ourselves again," saith he, "but speak as giving you occasion to glory;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:20
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:21
verses.text: ) and, "Again, think ye that we excuse ourselves unto you? For in the sight of God speak we in Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:22
verses.text: For I fear lest by any means when I come I should not find you such as I would, and should myself be found of you such as ye would not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:23
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:24
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:26
verses.text: ) For to prevent all appearance of a wish to flatter, as though he desired honor from them, he speaketh thus, "I fear lest by any means when I come I should not find you such as I would, and should myself be found of you such as ye would not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:27
verses.text: This however comes after many accusations; But in the beginning he speaketh not so, but more gently.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:28
verses.text: And what is it he saith? He spoke of his trials and his perils, and that every where he is conducted as in procession by God in Christ, and that the whole world knoweth of these triumphs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:29
verses.text: Since then he has uttered great things of himself, he urges this objection against himself, "Are we beginning again to commend ourselves?" Now what he saith is this: Perchance some one will object, 'What is this, O Paul? Sayest thou these things of thyself, and exaltest thyself?' To do away then with this suspicion, he saith, We desire not this, that is, to boast and exalt ourselves; yea, so far are we from needing epistles of commendation to you that ye are to us instead of an epistle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:30
verses.text: "For," saith he,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:31
verses.text: "Ye are our epistle".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:32
verses.text: What means this, "ye are?" 'Did we need to be commended to others, we should have produced you before them instead of an epistle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:33
verses.text: ' And this he said in the former Epistle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:34
verses.text: "For the seal of mine Apostleship are ye".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:35
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:36
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:37
verses.text: ) But he doth not here say it in this manner, but in irony so as to make his question, "Do we need epistles of commendation?" more cutting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:38
verses.text: And in allusion to the false apostles, he added, "as do some, epistles of commendation to you, or letters of commendation from you" to others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:39
verses.text: Then because what he had said was severe, he softens it by adding, "Ye are our epistle, written in our hearts, known of all,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:40
verses.text: "Being made manifest that ye are an epistle of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:41
verses.text: Here he testifieth not only to their love, but also to their good works: since they are able to show unto all men by their own virtue the high worth of their teacher, for this is the meaning of, "Ye are our epistle".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:42
verses.text: What letters would have done to commend and gain respect for us, that ye do both as seen and heard of; for the virtue of the disciples is wont to adorn and to commend the teacher more than any letter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:43
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:44
verses.text: "Written in our hearts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:45
verses.text: That is, which all know; we so bear you about every where and have you in mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:46
verses.text: As though he said, Ye are our commendation to others, for we both have you continually in our heart and proclaim to all your good works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:47
verses.text: Because then that even to others yourselves are our commendation, we need no epistles from you; but further, because we love you exceedingly, we need no commendation to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:48
verses.text: For to those who are strangers one hath need of letters, but ye are in our mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:49
verses.text: Yet he said not merely, "ye are in it," but "written in it," that is, ye cannot slide out of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:50
verses.text: For just as from letters by reading, so from our heart by perceiving, all are acquainted with the love we bear you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:51
verses.text: If then the object of a letter be to certify, "such an one is my friend and let him have free intercourse with you," your love is sufficient to secure all this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:52
verses.text: For should we go to you, we have no need of others to commend us, seeing your love anticipateth this; and should we go to others, again we need no letters, the same love again sufficing unto us in their stead, for we carry about the epistle in our hearts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:53
verses.text: Then exalting them still higher, he even calleth them the epistle of Christ, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:54
verses.text: "Being made manifest that ye are an epistle of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:55
verses.text: And having said this, he afterwards hence takes ground and occasion for a discussion on the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:56
verses.text: And there is another aim in his here styling them His epistle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:57
verses.text: For above as commending him, he called them an epistle; but here an epistle of Christ, as having the Law of God written in them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:58
verses.text: For what things God wished to declare to all and to you, these are written in your hearts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:59
verses.text: But it was we who prepared you to receive the writing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:60
verses.text: For just as Moses hewed the stones and tables, so we, your souls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:61
verses.text: Whence he saith,  "Ministered by us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:62
verses.text: Yet in this they were on an equality; for the former were written on by God, and these by the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:63
verses.text: Where then is the difference?  "Written not with ink, but with the Spirit of the living God; not in tables of stone, but in tables that are hearts of flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:64
verses.text: Wide as the difference between the Spirit and ink, and a stony table and a fleshy, so wide is that between these and those; consequently between themselves who ministered, and him who ministered to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:65
verses.text: Yet because it was a great thing he had uttered, he therefore quickly checks himself, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:66
verses.text: "And such confidence have we through Christ to Godward,"  And again refers all to God: for it is Christ, saith he, Who is the Author of these things to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:67
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:68
verses.text: "Not that we are sufficient of ourselves to account any thing as from ourselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:69
verses.text: See again, yet another corrective.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:70
verses.text: For he possesses this virtue, humility I mean, in singular perfection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:71
verses.text: Wherefore whenever he saith any thing great of himself, he maketh all diligence to soften down extremely and by every means, what he has said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:72
verses.text: And so he does in this place also, saying, "Not that we are sufficient of ourselves to account any thing as from ourselves:" that is, I said not, "We have confidence," as though part were ours and part God's; but I refer and ascribe the whole to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:73
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:75
verses.text: "For our sufficiency is from God; who also made us sufficient as ministers of a new covenant".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:76
verses.text: What means, "made us sufficient?" Made us able and fitting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:77
verses.text: And it is not a little thing to be the bearer to the world of such tables and letters, greater far than the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:78
verses.text: Whence also he added,  "Not of the letter, but of the spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:79
verses.text: See again another difference.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:80
verses.text: What then? was not that Law spiritual? How then saith he, "We know that the Law is spiritual?" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:81
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:82
verses.text: ) Spiritual indeed, but it bestowed not a spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:83
verses.text: For Moses bare not a spirit, but letters; but we have been entrusted with the giving of a spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:84
verses.text: Whence also in further completion of this contrast, he saith,  "For the letter killeth, but the spirit giveth life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:85
verses.text: Yet these things he saith not absolutely; but in allusion to those who prided themselves upon the things of Judaism.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:86
verses.text: And by "letter" here he meaneth the Law which punisheth them that transgress; but by "spirit" the grace which through Baptism giveth life to them who by sins were made dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:87
verses.text: For having mentioned the difference arising from the nature of the tables, he doth not dwell upon it, but rapidly passing it by, bestows more labor upon this, which most enabled him to lay hold on his hearer from considerations of what was advantageous and easy; for, saith he, it is not laborious, and the gift it offers is greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:88
verses.text: For if when discoursing of Christ, he puts especially forward those things which are of His lovingkindness, more than of our merit, and which are mutually connected, much greater necessity is there for his doing so when treating of the covenant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:89
verses.text: What then is the meaning of "the letter killeth?" He had said tables of stone and hearts of flesh: so far he seemed to mention no great difference.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:90
verses.text: He added that the former covenant was written with letters or ink, but this with the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:91
verses.text: Neither did this rouse them thoroughly, He says at last what is indeed enough to give them wings; the one "killeth," the other "giveth life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:92
verses.text: And what doth this mean? In the Law, he that hath sin is punished; here, he that hath sins cometh and is baptized and is made righteous, and being made righteous, he liveth, being delivered from the death of sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:93
verses.text: The Law, if it lay hold on a murderer, putteth him to death; the Gospel, if it lay hold on a murderer, enlighteneth, and giveth him life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:94
verses.text: And why do I instance a murderer? The Law laid hold on one that gathered sticks on a sabbath day, and stoned him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:95
verses.text: (Numb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:96
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:98
verses.text: ) This is the meaning of, "the letter killeth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:99
verses.text: The Gospel takes hold on thousands of homicides and robbers, and baptizing delivereth them from their former vices.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:100
verses.text: This is the meaning of, "the Spirit giveth life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:101
verses.text: The former maketh its captive dead from being alive, the latter rendereth the man it hath convicted alive from being dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:102
verses.text: For, "come unto me, ye that labor and are heavy laden," (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:103
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:104
verses.text: ) and, He said not, 'I will punish you,' but, "I will give you rest".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:105
verses.text: For in Baptism the sins are buried, the former things are blotted out, the man is made alive, the entire grace written upon his heart as it were a table.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:106
verses.text: Consider then how high is the dignity of the Spirit, seeing that His tables are better than those former ones; seeing that even a greater thing is shown forth than the resurrection itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:107
verses.text: For indeed, that state of death from which He delivers, is more irremediable than the former one: as much more so, as soul is of more value than the body: and this life is conferred by that, by that which the Spirit giveth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:108
verses.text: But if It be able to bestow this, much more then that which is less.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:109
verses.text: For, that prophets wrought, but this they could not: for none can remit sins but God only; nor did the prophets bestow that life without the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:110
verses.text: But this is not the marvel only, that it giveth life, but that it enabled others also to do this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:111
verses.text: For He saith, "Receive ye the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:112
verses.text: (John xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:113
verses.text: ) Wherefore? Because without the Spirit it might not be? Yes, but God, as showing that It is of supreme authority, and of that Kingly Essence, and hath the same power with Himself, saith this too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:114
verses.text: Whence also He adds, "Whosesoever sins ye remit, they are remitted; and whosesoever sins ye retain, they are retained".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:115
verses.text: (ibid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:116
verses.text: )   Since then It hath given us life, let us remain living and not return again to the former deadness: for "Christ dieth no more; for the death that He died, He died unto sin once:" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:117
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:119
verses.text: ) and He will not have us always saved by grace: for so we shall be empty of all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:120
verses.text: Wherefore He will have us contribute something also from ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:121
verses.text: Let us then contribute, and preserve to the soul its life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:122
verses.text: And what is life in a soul, learn from the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:123
verses.text: For the body too we then affirm to live, when it moves with a healthy kind of motion; but when it lies prostrate and powerless, or its motions are disorderly, though it retain the semblance of life or motion, such a life is more grievous than any death: and should it utter nothing sane but words of the crazy, and see one object instead of another, such a man again is more pitiable than those who are dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:124
verses.text: So also the soul when it hath no healthiness, though it retain a semblance of life, is dead: when it doth not see gold as gold but as something great and precious; when it thinketh not of the future but crawleth upon the ground; when it doth one thing in place of another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:125
verses.text: For whence is it clear that we have a soul? Is it not from its operations? When then it doth not perform the things proper to it, is it not dead? when, for instance, it hath no care for virtue, but is rapacious and transgresseth the law; whence can I tell that thou hast a soul? Because thou walkest? But this belongs to the irrational creatures as well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:126
verses.text: Because thou eatest and drinkest? But this too belongeth to wild beasts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:127
verses.text: Well then, because thou standest upright on two feet? This convinceth me rather that thou art a beast in human form.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:128
verses.text: For when thou resemblest one in all other respects, but not in its manner of erecting itself, thou dost the more disturb and terrify me; and I the more consider that which I see to be a monster.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:129
verses.text: For did I see a beast speaking with the voice of a man, I should not for that reason say it was a man, but even for that very reason a beast more monstrous than a beast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:130
verses.text: Whence then can I learn that thou hast the soul of a man, when thou kickest like the ass, when thou bearest malice like the camel, when thou bitest like the bear, when thou ravenest like the wolf, when thou stealest like the fox, when thou art wily as the serpent, when thou art shameless as the dog? Whence can I learn that thou hast the soul of a man? Will ye that I show you a dead soul and a living? Let us turn the discourse back to those men of old; and, if you will, let us set before us the rich man in the story of Lazarus, and we shall know what is death in a soul; for he had a dead soul, and it is plain from what he did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:131
verses.text: For, of the works of the soul he did not one, but ate and drank and lived in pleasure only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:132
verses.text: Such are even now the unmerciful and cruel, for these too have a dead soul as he had.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:133
verses.text: For all its warmth that floweth out of the love of our neighbor hath been spent, and it is deader than a lifeless body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:134
verses.text: But the poor man was not such, but standing on the very summit of heavenly wisdom shone out; and though wrestling with continual hunger, and not even supplied with the food that was necessary, neither so spake he aught of blasphemy against God, but endured all nobly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:135
verses.text: Now this is no trifling work of the soul; but a very high proof that it is well-strung and healthful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:136
verses.text: And when there are not these qualities, it is plainly because the soul is dead that they have perished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:137
verses.text: Or, tell me, shall we not pronounce that soul dead which the Devil falls upon, striking, biting, spurning it, yet hath it no sense of any of these things, but lieth deadened nor grieveth when being robbed of its wealth; but he even leapeth upon it, yet it remaineth unmoved, like a body when the soul is departed, nor even feeleth it? For when the fear of God is not present with strictness, such must the soul needs be, and then the dead more miserable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:138
verses.text: For the soul is not dissolved into corruption and ashes and dust, but into things of fouler odor than these, into drunkenness and anger and covetousness, into improper loves and unseasonable desires.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:139
verses.text: But if thou wouldest know more exactly how foul an odor it hath, give me a soul that is pure, and then thou wilt see clearly how foul the odor of this filthy and impure one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:140
verses.text: For at present thou wilt not be able to perceive it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:141
verses.text: For so long as we are in contact habitually with a foul odor, we are not sensible of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:142
verses.text: But when we are fed with spiritual words, then shall we be cognizant of that evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:143
verses.text: And yet to many this seemeth of no importance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:144
verses.text: And I say nothing as yet of hell; but let us, if you will, examine what is present, and how worthy of derision is he, not that practiseth, but that uttereth filthiness; how first he loadeth himself with contumely; just as one that sputtereth any filth from the mouth, so he defiles himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:145
verses.text: For if the stream is so impure, think what must be the fountain of this filth! "for out of the abundance of the heart the mouth speaketh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:146
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:147
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:148
verses.text: ) Yet not for this alone do I grieve, but because that to some this doth not even seem to be reckoned amongst improper things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:149
verses.text: Hence the evils are all made worse, when we both sin, and do not think we even do amiss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:150
verses.text: Wilt thou then learn how great an evil is filthy talking? See how the hearers blush at thy indecency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:151
verses.text: For what is viler than a filthy talker? what more infamous? For such thrust themselves into the rank of buffoons and of prostituted women, yea rather these have more shame than you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:152
verses.text: How canst thou teach a wife to be modest when by such language thou art training her to proceed unto lasciviousness? Better vent rottenness from the mouth than a filthy word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:153
verses.text: Now if thy mouth have an ill-odor, thou partakest not even of the common meats; when then thou hadst so foul a stink in thy soul, tell me, dost thou dare to partake of mysteries? Did any one take a dirty vessel and set it upon the table, thou wouldest have beaten him with clubs and driven him out: yet God at His own table, (for His table our mouth is when filled with thanksgiving,) when thou pourest out words more disgusting than any unclean vessel, tell me, dost thou think that thou provokest not? And how is this possible? For nothing doth so exasperate the holy and pure as do such words; nothing makes men so impudent and shameless as to say and listen to such; nothing doth so unstring the sinews of modesty as the flame which these kindle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:154
verses.text: God hath set perfumes in thy mouth, but thou storest up words of fouler odor than a corpse, and destroyest the soul itself and makest it incapable of motion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:155
verses.text: For when thou insultest, this is not the voice of the soul, but of anger; when thou talkest filthily, it is lewdness, and not she that spake; when thou detractest, it is envy; when thou schemest, covetousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:156
verses.text: These are not her works, but those of the affections and the diseases belonging to her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:157
verses.text: As then corruption cometh not simply of the body, but of the death and the passion which is thus in the body; so also, in truth, these things come of the passions which grow upon the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:158
verses.text: For if thou wilt hear a voice from a living soul, hear Paul saying, "Having food and covering, we shall be therewith content:" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:159
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:160
verses.text: ) and "Godliness is great gain:" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:161
verses.text: ) and, "The world is crucified unto me, and I unto the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:162
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:163
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:164
verses.text: ) Hear Peter saying, "Silver and gold have I none, but such as I have, give I thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:165
verses.text: (Acts iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:166
verses.text: ) Hear Job giving thanks and saying, "The Lord gave, and the Lord hath taken away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:167
verses.text: (Job i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:168
verses.text: ) These things are the words of a living soul, of a soul discharging the functions proper to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:169
verses.text: Thus also Jacob said, "If the Lord will give me bread to eat and raiment to put on".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:170
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:171
verses.text: xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:172
verses.text: ) Thus also Joseph, "How shall I do this wickedness, and sin before God?" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:173
verses.text: xxxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:174
verses.text: ) But not so that barbarian woman; but as one drunken and insane, so spake she, saying, "Lie with me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:175
verses.text: (ibid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 7:176
verses.text: ) These things then knowing, let us earnestly covet the living soul, let us flee the dead one, that we may also obtain the life to come; of which may all we be made partakers, through the grace and love toward men of our Lord Jesus Christ, though Whom and with Whom, to the Father, together with the Holy Ghost, be glory, might, honor, now and for ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:1
verses.text: Homily VII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:3
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:4
verses.text: ,  But if the ministration of death, written and engraven in stones, came with glory, so that the children of Israel could not look steadfastly upon the face of Moses, for the glory of his face; which glory was passing away: how shall not rather the ministration of the Spirit be with glory?  He said that the tables of Moses were of stone, as also they were written with letters; and that these were of flesh, I mean the hearts of the Apostles, and had been written on by the Spirit; and that the letter indeed killeth, but the Spirit giveth life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:5
verses.text: There was yet wanting to this comparison the addition of a further and not trifling particular, that of the glory of Moses; such as in the case of the New Covenant none saw with the eyes of the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:6
verses.text: And even for this cause it appeared a great thing in that the glory was perceived by the senses; (for it was seen by the bodily eyes, even though it might not be approached;) but that of the New Covenant is perceived by the understanding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:7
verses.text: For to the weaker sort the apprehension of such a superiority is not clear; but the other did more take them, and turn them unto itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:8
verses.text: Having then fallen upon this comparison and being set upon showing the superiority in question, which yet was exceedingly difficult because of the dulness of the hearers; see what he does, and with what method he proceeds in it, first by arguments placing the difference before them, and constructing these out of what he had said before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:9
verses.text: For if that ministration were of death, but this of life, doubtless, saith he, the latter glory is also greater than the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:10
verses.text: For since he could not exhibit it to the bodily eyes, by this logical inference he established its superiority, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:11
verses.text: "But if the ministration of death came with glory, how shall not rather the ministration of the Spirit be with glory?"  Now by "ministration of death" he means the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:12
verses.text: And mark too how great the caution he uses in the comparison so as to give no handle to the heretics; for he said not, 'which causeth death,' but, "the ministration of death;" for it ministereth unto, but was not the parent of, death; for that which caused death was sin; but the Law brought in the punishment, and showed the sin, not caused it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:13
verses.text: For it more distinctly revealed the evil and punished it: it did not impel unto the evil: and it ministered not to the existence of sin or death, but to the suffering of retribution by the sinner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:14
verses.text: So that in this way it was even destructive of sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:15
verses.text: For that which showeth it to be so fearful, it is obvious, maketh it also to be avoided.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:16
verses.text: As then he that taketh the sword in his hands and cutteth off the condemned, ministers to the judge that passeth sentence, and it is not he that is his destruction, although he cutteth him off; nay, nor yet is it he who passeth sentence and condemneth, but the wickedness of him that is punished; so truly here also it is not that destroyeth, but sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:17
verses.text: This did both destroy and condemn, but that by punishing undermined its strength, by the fear of the punishment holding it back.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:18
verses.text: But he was not content with this consideration only in order to establish the superiority in question; but he addeth yet another, saying, "written, and engraven on stones".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:19
verses.text: See how he again cuts at the root of the Jewish arrogancy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:20
verses.text: For the Law was nothing else but letters: a certain succor was not found leaping forth from out the letters and inspiring them that combat, as is the case in Baptism; but pillars and writings bearing death to those who transgress the letters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:21
verses.text: Seest thou how in correcting the Jewish contentiousness, by his very expressions even he lessens its authority, speaking of stone and letters and a ministration of death, and adding that it was engraven? For hereby he declareth nothing else than this, that the Law was fixed in one place; not, as the Spirit, was present everywhere, breathing great might into all; or that the letters breathe much threatening, and threatening too which can not be effaced but remaineth for ever, as being engraved in stone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:22
verses.text: Then even whilst seeming to praise the old things, he again mixeth up accusation of the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:23
verses.text: For having said, "written and engraven in stones, came with glory," he added, "so that the children of Israel could not look steadfastly upon the face of Moses;" which was a mark of their great weakness and grovelling spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:24
verses.text: And again he doth not say, 'for the glory of the tables,' but, "for the glory of his countenance, which glory was passing away;" for he showeth that he who beareth them is made glorious, and not they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:25
verses.text: For he said not, 'because they could not look steadfastly upon the tables,' but, "the face of Moses;" and again, not, 'for the glory of the tables,' but, "for the glory of his face".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:26
verses.text: Then after he had extolled it, see how again he lowers it, saying, "which was passing away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:27
verses.text: Not however that this is in accusation, but in diminution; for he did not say, 'which was corrupt, which was evil,' but, 'which ceaseth and hath an end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:28
verses.text: '  "How shall not rather the ministration of the Spirit be with glory?" for henceforth with confidence he extolleth the things of the New Covenant as indisputable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:29
verses.text: And observe what he doth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:30
verses.text: He opposed 'stone' to 'heart,' and 'letter' to 'spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:31
verses.text: ' Then having shown the results of each, he doth not set down the results of each; but having set down the work of the latter, namely, death and condemnation, he setteth not down that of the spirit, namely, life and righteousness; but the Spirit Itself; which added greatness to the argument.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:32
verses.text: For the New Covenant not only gave life, but supplied also 'The Spirit' Which giveth the life, a far greater thing than the life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:33
verses.text: Wherefore he said, "the ministration of the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:34
verses.text: Then he again reverts to the same thing, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:35
verses.text: "For if the ministration of condemnation is glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:36
verses.text: Also, he interprets more clearly the meaning of the words, "The letter killeth," declaring it to be that which we have said above, namely, that the Law showed sin, not caused it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:37
verses.text: "Much rather doth the ministration of righteousness exceed in glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:38
verses.text: For those Tables indeed showed the sinners and punished them, but this not only did not punish the sinners, but even made them righteous: for this did Baptism confer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:39
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:40
verses.text: "For verily that which hath been made glorious hath not been made glorious in this respect, by reason of the glory that surpasseth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:41
verses.text: Now in what has gone before, indeed, he showed that this also is with glory; and not simply is with glory, but even exceedeth in it: for he did not say, "How shall not the ministration of the Spirit be rather in glory?" but, "exceed in glory;" deriving the proof from the arguments before stated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:42
verses.text: Here he also shows the superiority, how great it is, saying, 'if I compare this with that, the glory of the Old Covenant is not glory at all;' not absolutely laying down that there was no glory, but in view of the comparison.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:43
verses.text: Wherefore also he added, "in this respect," that is, in respect of the comparison.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:44
verses.text: Not that this doth disparage the Old Covenant, yea rather it highly commendeth it: for comparisons are wont to be made between things which are the same in kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:45
verses.text: Next, he sets on foot yet another argument to prove the superiority also from a fresh ground.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:46
verses.text: What then is this argument? That based upon duration, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:47
verses.text: "For if that which passeth away was with glory, much more that which remaineth is in glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:48
verses.text: For the one ceased, but the other abideth continually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:49
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:50
verses.text: "Having therefore such a hope, we use great boldness of speech".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:51
verses.text: For since when he had heard so many and so great things concerning the New Covenant, the hearer would be desirous of seeing this glory manifested to the eye, mark whither he hurleth him, even to the world to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:52
verses.text: Wherefore also he brought forward the "hope," saying, "Having therefore such a hope".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:53
verses.text: Such? Of what nature? That we have been counted worthy of greater things than Moses; not we the Apostles only, but also all the faithful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:54
verses.text: "We use great boldness of speech".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:55
verses.text: Towards whom? tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:56
verses.text: Towards God, or towards the disciples? Towards you who are receiving instruction, he saith; that is, we speak every where with freedom, hiding nothing, withholding nothing, mistrusting nothing, but speaking openly; and we have not feared lest we should wound your eyesight, as Moses did that of the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:57
verses.text: For that he alluded to this, hear what follows; or rather, it is necessary first to relate the history, for he himself keeps dwelling upon it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:58
verses.text: What then is the history? When, having received the Tables a second time, Moses came down, a certain glory darting from his countenance shone so much that the Jews were not able to approach and talk with him until he put a veil over his face.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:59
verses.text: And thus it is written in Exodus, (Exod.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:60
verses.text: xxxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:62
verses.text: ) "When Moses came down from the Mount, the two Tables were in his hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:63
verses.text: And Moses wist not that the skin of his countenance was made glorious to behold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:64
verses.text: And they were afraid to come nigh him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:65
verses.text: And Moses called them, and spake unto them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:66
verses.text: And when Moses had done speaking with them, he put a veil over his face.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:67
verses.text: But when he went in before the Lord to speak with Him, he took the veil off until he came out".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:68
verses.text: Putting them in mind then of this history, he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:69
verses.text: "And not as Moses, who put a veil upon his face, so that the children of Israel should not look steadfastly on the end of that which was passing away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:70
verses.text: Now what he says is of this nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:71
verses.text: There is no need for us to cover ourselves as Moses did; for ye are able to look upon this glory which we are encircled with, although it is far greater and brighter than the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:72
verses.text: Seest thou the advance? For he that in the former Epistle said, "I have fed you with milk, not with meat;" saith here, "We use great boldness of speech".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:73
verses.text: And he produces Moses before them, carrying forward the discourse by means of comparison, and thus leading his hearer upwards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:74
verses.text: And for the present he sets them above the Jews, saying that 'we have no need of a veil as he had with those he governed;' but in what comes afterwards he advances them even to the dignity itself of the Lawgiver, or even to a much greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:75
verses.text: Mean time, however, let us hear what follows next.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:76
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:77
verses.text: "But their minds were hardened, for until this day remaineth the same veil in the reading of the Old Covenant, it not being revealed to them that it is done away in Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:78
verses.text: See what he establisheth by this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:79
verses.text: For what happened then once in the case of Moses, the same happeneth continually in the case of the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:80
verses.text: What is said, therefore, is no accusation of the Law, as neither is it of Moses that he then veiled himself, but only the senseless Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:81
verses.text: For the law hath its proper glory, but they were unable to see it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:82
verses.text: 'Why therefore are ye perplexed,' he saith, 'if they are unable to see this glory of the Grace, since they saw not that lesser one of Moses, nor were able to look steadfastly upon his countenance? And why are ye troubled that the Jews believe not Christ, seeing at least that they believe not even the Law? For they were therefore ignorant of the Grace also, because they knew not even the Old Covenant nor the glory which was in it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:83
verses.text: For the glory of the Law is to turn men unto Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:84
verses.text: '   Seest thou how from this consideration also he takes down the inflation of the Jews? By that in which they thought they had the advantage, namely, that Moses' face shone, he proves their grossness and groveling nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:85
verses.text: Let them not therefore pride themselves on that, for what was that to Jews who enjoyed it not? Wherefore also he keeps on dwelling upon it, saying one while, "The same veil in the reading of the old covenant remaineth," it "not being revealed that it is done away in Christ:" another while, that "unto this day when Moses is read," (v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:86
verses.text: ) the same "veil lieth upon their heart; "showing that the veil lieth both on the reading and on their heart; and above, "So that the children of Israel could not look steadfastly upon the face of Moses for the glory of his countenance; which" (v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:87
verses.text: ) glory "was passing away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:88
verses.text: Than which what could mark less worth in them? Seeing that even of a glory that is to be done away, or rather is in comparison no glory at all, they are not able to be spectators, but it is covered from them, "so that they could not steadfastly look on the end of that which was passing away;" that is, of the law, because it hath an end; "but their minds were hardened".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:89
verses.text: 'And what,' saith one, 'hath this to do with the veil then?' Because it prefigured what would be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:90
verses.text: For not only did they not then perceive; but they do not even now see the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:91
verses.text: And the fault lies with themselves, for the hardness is that of an unimpressible and perverse judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:92
verses.text: So that it is we who know the law also; but to them not only Grace, but this as well is covered with a shadow; "For until this day the same veil upon the reading of the old covenant remaineth," he saith, it "not being revealed that it is done away in Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:93
verses.text: Now what he saith is this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:94
verses.text: This very thing they cannot see, that it is brought to an end, because they believe not Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:95
verses.text: For if it be brought to an end by Christ, as in truth it is brought to an end, and this the Law said by anticipation, how will they who receive not Christ that hath done away the Law, be able to see that the Law is done away? And being incapable of seeing this, it is very plain that even of the Law itself which asserted these things, they know not the power nor the full glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:96
verses.text: 'And where,' saith one, 'did it say this that it is done away in Christ?' It did not say it merely, but also showed it by what was done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:97
verses.text: And first indeed by shutting up its sacrifices and its whole ritual in one place, the Temple, and afterwards destroying this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:98
verses.text: For had He not meant to bring these to an end and the whole of the Law concerning them, He would have done one or other of two things; either not destroyed the Temple, or having destroyed it, not forbidden to sacrifice elsewhere.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:99
verses.text: But, as it is, the whole world and even Jerusalem itself He hath made forbidden ground for such religious rites; having allowed and appointed for them only the Temple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:100
verses.text: Then having destroyed this itself afterwards He showed completely even by what was done that the things of the Law are brought to an end by Christ; for the Temple also Christ destroyed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:101
verses.text: But if thou wilt see in words as well how the Law is done away in Christ, hear the Lawgiver himself speaking thus; "A Prophet shall the Lord raise up unto you of your brethren, like unto me; (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:102
verses.text: xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:104
verses.text: ) Him shall ye hear in all things whatsoever He shall command you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:105
verses.text: And it shall come to pass, that every soul which will not hear that Prophet shall be utterly destroyed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:106
verses.text: (Acts iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:108
verses.text: ) Seest thou how the Law showed that it is done away in Christ? For this Prophet, that is, Christ according to the flesh, Whom Moses commanded them to hear, made to cease both sabbath and circumcision and all the other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:109
verses.text: And David too, showing the very same thing, said concerning Christ, "Thou art a Priest after the order of Melchizedek," (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:110
verses.text: cx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:111
verses.text: ;) not after the order of Aaron.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:112
verses.text: Wherefore also Paul, giving a clear interpretation of this, says, "The priesthood being changed, there is made of necessity a change also of the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:113
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:114
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:115
verses.text: ) And in another place also he says again, "Sacrifice and offering thou wouldst not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:116
verses.text: In whole burnt offerings and sacrifices for sin Thou hadst had no pleasure: then said I, Lo, I come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:117
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:118
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:120
verses.text: ) And other testimonies far more numerous than these may be adduced out of the Old Testament, showing how the Law is done away by Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:121
verses.text: So that when thou shalt have forsaken the Law, thou shalt then see the Law clearly; but so long as thou holdest by it and believest not Christ, thou knowest not even the Law itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:122
verses.text: Wherefore also he added, to establish this very thing more clearly;  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:123
verses.text: "But even unto this day, whensoever Moses is read, a veil lieth upon their heart".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:124
verses.text: For since he said that in the reading of the Old Testament the veil remaineth, lest any should think that this that is said is from the obscurity of the Law, he both by other things showed even before what his meaning was, (for by saying, "their minds were hardened," he shows that the fault was their own,) and, in this place too, again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:125
verses.text: For he said not, 'The veil remaineth on the writing,' but "in the reading;" (now the reading is the act of those that read;) and again, "When Moses is read".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:126
verses.text: He showed this however with greater clearness in the expression which follows next, saying unreservedly, "The veil lieth upon their heart".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:127
verses.text: For even upon the face of Moses it lay, not because of Moses, but because of the grossness and carnal mind of these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:128
verses.text: Having then suitably accused them, he points out also the manner of their correction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:129
verses.text: And what is this?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:130
verses.text: "Nevertheless when one shall turn to the Lord," which is, to forsake the Law, "the veil is taken away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:131
verses.text: Seest thou that not over the face of Moses was there that veil, but over the eyesight of the Jews? For it was done, not that the glory of Moses might be hidden, but that the Jews might not see.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:132
verses.text: For they were not capable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:133
verses.text: So that in them was the deficiency, for it caused not him to be ignorant of any thing, but them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:134
verses.text: And he did not say indeed, "when thou shalt let go the Law," but he implied it, for "when thou shalt turn to the Lord, the veil is taken away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:135
verses.text: To the very last he kept to the history.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:136
verses.text: For when Moses talked with the Jews he kept his face covered; but when he turned to God it was uncovered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:137
verses.text: Now this was a type of that which was to come to pass, that when we have turned to the Lord, then we shall see the glory of the Law, and the face of the Lawgiver bare; yea rather, not this alone, but we shall then be even in the same rank with Moses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:138
verses.text: Seest thou how he inviteth the Jew unto the faith, by showing, that by coming unto Grace he is able not only to see Moses, but also to stand in the very same rank with the Lawgiver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:139
verses.text: 'For not only,' he saith, 'shalt thou look on the glory which then thou sawest not, but thou shalt thyself also be included in the same glory; yea rather, in a greater glory, even so great that that other shall not seem glory at all when compared with this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:140
verses.text: ' How and in what manner? 'Because that when thou hast turned to the Lord and art included in the grace, thou wilt enjoy that glory, unto which the glory of Moses, if compared, is so much less as to be no glory at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:141
verses.text: But still, small though it be and exceedingly below that other, whilst thou art a Jew, even this will not be vouchsafed thee; but having become a believer, it will then be vouchsafed thee to behold even that which is far greater than it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:142
verses.text: ' And when he was addressing himself to the believers, he said, that "that which was made glorious had no glory;" but here he speaks not so; but how? "When one shall turn to the Lord, the veil is taken away:" leading him up by little and little, and first setting him in Moses' rank, and then making him partake of the greater things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:143
verses.text: For when thou hast seen Moses in glory, then afterwards thou shalt also turn unto God and enjoy this greater glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:144
verses.text: See then from the beginning, how many things he has laid down, as constituting the difference and showing the superiority, not the enmity or contradiction, of the New Covenant in respect to the old.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:145
verses.text: That, saith he, is letter, and stone, and a ministration of death, and is done away: and yet the Jews were not even vouchsafed this glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:146
verses.text: (Or, the glory of this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:147
verses.text: ) This table is of the flesh, and spirit, and righteousness, and remaineth; and unto all of us is it vouchsafed, not to one only, as to Moses of the lesser then.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:148
verses.text: (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:149
verses.text: ) "For," saith he, "we all with unveiled face reflecting as a mirror the glory of the Lord," not that of Moses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:150
verses.text: But since some maintain that the expression, "when one shall turn to the Lord," is spoken of the Son, in contradiction to what is quite acknowledged; let us examine the point more accurately, having first stated the ground on which they think to establish this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:151
verses.text: What then is this? Like, saith one, as it is said, "God is a Spirit;" (John iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:152
verses.text: ) so also here, 'The Lord is a Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:153
verses.text: ' But he did not say, 'The Lord is a Spirit,' but, "The Spirit is the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:154
verses.text: And there is a great difference between this construction and that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:155
verses.text: For when he is desirous of speaking so as you say, he does not join the article to the predicate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:156
verses.text: And besides, let us review all his discourse from the first, of whom hath he spoken? for instance, when he said, "The letter killeth, but the Spirit giveth life:" (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:157
verses.text: ) and again, "Written not with ink, but with the Spirit of the living God;" (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:158
verses.text: ) was he speaking of God, or of the Spirit? It is very plain that it was of the Spirit; for unto It he was calling them from the letter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:159
verses.text: For lest any, hearing of the Spirit, and then reflecting that Moses turned unto the Lord, but himself unto the Spirit, should think himself to have the worse, to correct such a suspicion as this, he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:160
verses.text: "Now the Spirit is the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:161
verses.text: This too is Lord, he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:162
verses.text: And that you may know that he is speaking of the Paraclete, he added,  "And where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:163
verses.text: For surely you will not assert, that he says, 'And where the Lord of the Lord is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:164
verses.text: ' "Liberty," he said, with reference to the former bondage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:165
verses.text: Then, that you may not think that he is speaking of a time to come, he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:166
verses.text: "But we all, with unveiled face, reflecting as a mirror the glory of the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:167
verses.text: Not that which is brought to an end, but that which remaineth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:168
verses.text: "Are transformed into the same image from glory to glory, even as from the Lord the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:169
verses.text: Seest thou how again he places the Spirit in the rank of God, (vide infra) and raises them up to the rank of the Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:170
verses.text: For he said before, "Ye are the Epistle of Christ;" and here, "But we all with open face".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:171
verses.text: Yet they came, like Moses, bringing a law.
