verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:172
verses.text: But like as we, he says, needed no veil, so neither ye who received it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:173
verses.text: And yet, this glory is far greater, for this is not of our countenance, but of the Spirit; but nevertheless ye are able as well as we to look steadfastly upon it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:174
verses.text: For they indeed could not even by a mediator, but ye even without a mediator can look steadfastly on a greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:175
verses.text: They were not able to look upon that of Moses, ye even upon that of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:176
verses.text: Now had the Spirit been at all inferior, He would not have set down these things as greater than those.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:177
verses.text: But what is, "we reflecting as a mirror the glory of the Lord, are transformed into the same image".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:178
verses.text: This indeed was shown more clearly when the gifts of miracles were in operation; howbeit it is not even now difficult to see it, for one who hath believing eyes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:179
verses.text: For as soon as we are baptized, the soul beameth even more than the sun, being cleansed by the Spirit; and not only do we behold the glory of God, but from it also receive a sort of splendor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:180
verses.text: Just as if pure silver be turned towards the sun's rays, it will itself also shoot forth rays, not from its own natural property merely but also from the solar lustre; so also doth the soul being cleansed and made brighter than silver, receive a ray from the glory of the Spirit, and send it back.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:181
verses.text: Wherefore also he saith, "Reflecting as a mirror we are transformed into the same image from glory," that of the Spirit, "to glory," our own, that which is generated in us; and that, of such sort, as one might expect from the Lord the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:182
verses.text: See how here also he calleth the Spirit, Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:183
verses.text: And in other places too one may see that lordship of His.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:184
verses.text: For, saith he, "As they ministered and fasted unto the Lord, the Spirit said, Separate me Paul and Barnabas".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:185
verses.text: (Acts xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:186
verses.text: ) For therefore he said, "as they ministered unto the Lord, Separate me," in order to show the Spirit's equality in honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:187
verses.text: And again Christ saith, "The servant knoweth not what his lord doeth;" but even as a man knoweth his own things, so doth the Spirit know the things of God; not by being taught them, for so the similitude holdeth not good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:188
verses.text: Also the working as He willeth showeth His authority and lordship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:189
verses.text: This transformeth us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:190
verses.text: This suffereth not to be conformed to this world; for such is the creation of which This is the Author.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:191
verses.text: For as he saith, "Created in Christ Jesus," (Ephes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:192
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:193
verses.text: ) so saith he, "Create in me a clean heart, O God, and renew a right spirit in my inward parts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:194
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:195
verses.text: li.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:196
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:197
verses.text: )   Wilt thou that I show thee this also from the Apostles more obviously to the sense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:198
verses.text: Consider Paul, whose garments wrought: Peter, whose very shadows were mighty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:199
verses.text: (Acts xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:201
verses.text: XX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:202
verses.text: ) For had they not borne a King's image and their radiancy been unapproachable, their garments and shadows had not wrought so mightily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:203
verses.text: For the garments of a king are terrible even to robbers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:204
verses.text: Wouldest thou see this beaming even through the body? "Looking steadfastly," said he, "upon the face of Stephen, they saw it as it had been the face of an angel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:205
verses.text: (Acts vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:206
verses.text: ) But this was nothing to the glory flashing within.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:207
verses.text: For what Moses had upon his countenance, that did these carry about with them on their souls, yea 'rather' even far more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:208
verses.text: For that of Moses indeed was more obvious to the senses, but this was incorporeal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:209
verses.text: And like as fire-bright bodies streaming down from the shining bodies upon those which lie near them, impart to them also somewhat of their own splendor, so truly doth it also happen with the faithful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:210
verses.text: Therefore surely they with whom it is thus are set free from earth, and have their dreams of the things in the heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:211
verses.text: Woe is me! for well is it that we should here even groan bitterly, for that we who enjoy a birth so noble do not so much as know what is said, because we quickly lose the reality, and are dazzled about the objects of sense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:212
verses.text: For this glory, the unspeakable and awful, remaineth in us for a day or two, and then we quench it, bringing over it the winter of worldly concerns, and with the thickness of those clouds repelling its rays.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:213
verses.text: For worldly things are a winter, and than winter more lowering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:214
verses.text: For not frost is engendered thence nor rain, neither doth it produce mire and deep swamps; but, things than all these more grievous, it formeth hell and the miseries of hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:215
verses.text: And as in severe frost all the limbs are stiffened and are dead, so truly the soul shuddering in the winter of sins also, performeth none of its proper functions, stiffened, as it were, by a frost, as to conscience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:216
verses.text: For what cold is to the body, that an evil conscience is to the soul, whence also cometh cowardice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:217
verses.text: For nothing is more cowardly than the man that is rivetted to worldly things; for such an one lives the life of Cain, trembling every day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:218
verses.text: And why do I mention deaths, and losses, and offences, and flatteries, and services? for even without these he is in fear of ten thousand vicissitudes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:219
verses.text: And his coffers indeed are full of gold, but his soul is not freed from the fear of poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:220
verses.text: And very reasonably.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:221
verses.text: For he is moored as it were on rotten and swiftly shifting things, and even though in his own case he experienced not the reverse, yet is he undone by seeing it happen in others; and great is his cowardice, great his unmanliness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:222
verses.text: For not only is such an one spiritless as to danger, but also as to all other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:223
verses.text: And if desire of wealth assail him, he doth not like a free man beat off the assault; but like a bought slave, doth all it bids, serving the love of money as it were a severe mistress.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:224
verses.text: If again he have beheld some comely damsel, down he croucheth at once made captive, and followeth like a raging dog, though it behoveth to do the opposite.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:225
verses.text: For when thou hast beheld a beautiful woman, consider not how thou mayest enjoy thy lust, but how be delivered from thy lust.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:226
verses.text: 'And how is this possible,' saith one? 'for loving is not my own doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:227
verses.text: ' Whose then? tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:228
verses.text: It is from the Devil's malice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:229
verses.text: Thou art quite convinced that that which plotteth against thee is a devil; wrestle then and fight with a distemper.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:230
verses.text: But I cannot, he saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:231
verses.text: Come then, let us first teach thee this, that what happeneth is from thine own listlessness, and that thou at the first gavest entrance to the Devil, and now if thou hast a mind, with much ease mayest drive him off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:232
verses.text: They that commit adultery, is it from lust they commit it, or simply from desire of dangers? Plainly from lust.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:233
verses.text: Do they then therefore obtain forgiveness? Certainly not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:234
verses.text: Why not? Because the sin is their own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:235
verses.text: 'But,' saith one, 'why, pray, string syllogisms? For my conscience bears me witness that I wish to repel the passion; and cannot, but it keepeth close, presses me sore, and afflicts me grievously.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:236
verses.text: ' O man, thou dost wish to repel it, but thou dost not the things repellers should do; but it is with thee just as with a man in a fever, who drinking of cold streams to the fill, should say, 'How many things I devise with the wish to quench this fever, and I cannot; but they stir up my flame the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:237
verses.text: ' Let us see then whether at all thou too dost the things that inflame, yet thinkest thou art devising such as quench.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:238
verses.text: 'I do not,' he saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:239
verses.text: Tell me then, what hast thou ever essayed to do in order to quench the passion? and what is it, in fine, that will increase the passion? For even supposing we be not all of us obnoxious to these particular charges; (for more may be found who are captivated by the love of money than of beauty;) still the remedy to be proposed will be common to all, both to these and to those.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:240
verses.text: For both that is an unreasonable passion, and this, is keener and fiercer than that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:241
verses.text: When then we have proved victorious over the greater, it is very plain that we shall easily subdue the less also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:242
verses.text: 'And how is it,' saith one, 'that if this be keener, all persons are not made captive by the vice, but a greater number are mad after money?' Because in the first place this last desire appears to be unattended with danger: next, although that of beauty be even fiercer, yet it is more speedily extinguished; for were it to continue like that of money, it would wholly destroy its captive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:243
verses.text: Come then, let us discourse to you on this, the love of beauty, and let us see whereby the mischief is increased; for so we shall know whether the fault be ours, or not ours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:244
verses.text: And if ours, let us do everything to get the better of it; whereas if not ours, why do we afflict ourselves for nought? And why do we not pardon, but find fault, with those who are made captive by it? Whence then is this love engendered? 'From comeliness of feature,' saith one, 'when she that woundeth one is beautiful and of fair countenance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:245
verses.text: ' It is said idly and in vain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:246
verses.text: For if it were beauty that attracted lovers, then would the maiden who is such have all men for her lovers; but if she hath not all, this thing cometh not of nature nor from beauty, but from unchaste eyes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:247
verses.text: For it was when by eyeing too curiously, thou didst admire and become enamored, that thou receivedst the shaft.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:248
verses.text: 'And who,' saith one, 'when he sees a beautiful woman, can refrain from commending her he sees? If then admiring such things cometh not of deliberate choice, it follows that love depends not on ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:249
verses.text: ' Stop, O man! Why dost thou crowd all things together, running round and round on every side, and not choosing to see the root of the evil? For I see numbers admiring and commending, who yet are not enamored.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:250
verses.text: 'And how is it possible to admire and not be enamored?' Clamor not, (for this I am coming to speak of,) but wait, and thou shalt hear Moses admiring the son of Jacob, and saying, "And Joseph was a goodly person, and well favored exceedingly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:251
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:252
verses.text: xxxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:253
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:254
verses.text: ) Was he then enamored who speaketh this? By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:255
verses.text: 'For,' saith he, 'he did not even see him whom he commended.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:256
verses.text: ' We are affected, however, somewhat similarly towards beauties also which are described to us, not only which are beheld.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:257
verses.text: But that thou cavil not with us on this point:—David, was he not comely exceedingly, and ruddy with beauty of eyes? (So  Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:258
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:259
verses.text: & xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:260
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:261
verses.text: ) and indeed this beauty of the eyes, is even especially, a component of beauteousness of more despotic power than any.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:262
verses.text: Was then any one enamored of him? By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:263
verses.text: Then to be also enamored cometh not necessarily with admiring.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:264
verses.text: For many too have had mothers blooming exceedingly in beauty of person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:265
verses.text: What then? Were their children enamored of them? Away with the thought! but they admire what they see, yet fall not into a shameful love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:266
verses.text: 'No, for again this good provision is Nature's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:267
verses.text: ' How Nature's? Tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:268
verses.text: 'Because they are mothers,' he saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:269
verses.text: Then hearest thou not that Persians, and that without any compulsion, have intercourse with their own mothers, and that not one or two individuals, but a whole nation? But independent of these, it is hence also evident that this distemper cometh not from bloom of person nor from beauty merely, but from a listless and wandering soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:270
verses.text: Many at least it is certain, oftentimes, having passed over thousands of well-favored women, have given themselves to such as were plainer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:271
verses.text: Whence it is evident that love depends not on beauty: for otherwise, surely, those would have caught such as fell into it, before these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:272
verses.text: What then is its cause? 'For,' saith he, 'if it be not beauty that causeth love, whence hath it its beginning and its root? From a wicked Demon?' It hath it indeed, thence also, but this is not what we are inquiring about, but whether we ourselves too be not the cause.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:273
verses.text: For the plot is not theirs only, but along with them our own too in the first place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:274
verses.text: For from no other source is this wicked distemper so engendered as from habit, and flattering words, and leisure, and idleness, and having nothing to do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:275
verses.text: For great, great is the tyranny of habit, even so great as to be moulded into a necessity of nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:276
verses.text: Now if it be habit's to gender it, it is very evident that it is also habit's to extinguish it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:277
verses.text: Certain it is at least that many have in this way ceased to be enamored, from not seeing those they were enamored of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:278
verses.text: Now this for a little while indeed appears to be a bitter thing and exceedingly unpleasant; but in time it becometh pleasant, and even were they to wish it, they could not afterwards resume the passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:279
verses.text: How then, when without habit one is taken captive at first sight? Here also it is indolence of body, or self-indulgence, and not attending to one's duties, nor being occupied in necessary business.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:280
verses.text: For such an one, wandering about like some vagabond, is transfixed by any wickedness; and like a child let loose, any one that liketh maketh such a soul his slave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:281
verses.text: For since it is its wont to be at work, when thou stoppest its workings in what is good, seeing it cannot be unemployed, it is compelled to engender what is otherwise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:282
verses.text: For just as the earth, when it is not sown nor planted, sends up simply weeds; so also the soul, when it hath nought of necessary things to do, being desirous by all means to be doing, giveth herself unto wicked deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:283
verses.text: And as the eye never ceaseth from seeing, and therefore will see wicked things, when good things are not set before it; so also doth the thought, when it secludes itself from necessary things, busy itself thereafter about such as are unprofitable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:284
verses.text: For that even the first assault occupation and thought are able to beat off, is evident from many things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:285
verses.text: When then thou hast looked on a beautiful woman, and wert moved towards her, look no more, and thou art delivered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:286
verses.text: 'And how shall I be able to look no more,' saith he, 'when drawn by that desire?' Give thyself to other things which may distract the soul, to books, to necessary cares, to protecting others, to assisting the injured, to prayers, to the wisdom which considers the things to come: with such things as these bind down thy soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:287
verses.text: By these means, not only shalt thou cure a recent wound, but shalt wear away a confirmed and inveterate one easily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:288
verses.text: For if an insult according to the proverb prevails with the lover to give over his love, how shall not these spiritual charms much rather be victorious over the evil, if only we have a mind to stand aloof.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:289
verses.text: But if we are always conversing and associating with those who shoot such arrows at us, and talking with them and hearing what they say, we cherish the distemper.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:290
verses.text: How then dost thou expect the fire to be quenched, when day by day thou stirrest up the flame?  And let this that we have said about habit be our speech unto the young; since to those who are men and taught in heavenly wisdom, stronger than all is the fear of God, the remembrance of hell, the desire of the kingdom of heaven; for these are able to quench the fire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:291
verses.text: And along with these take that thought also, that what thou seest is nothing else than rheum, and blood, and juices of decomposed food.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:292
verses.text: 'Yet a gladsome thing is the bloom of the features,' saith one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:293
verses.text: But nothing is more gladsome than the blossoms of the earth, and these too rot and wither.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:294
verses.text: Do not then in this either give heed to the bloom, but pass on further inward in thy thought, and stripping off that beauteous skin in thy thought, scan curiously what lies beneath it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:295
verses.text: For even the bodies of the dropsical shine brightly, and the surface hath nothing offensive; but still, shocked with the thought of the humor stored within we cannot love such persons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:296
verses.text: 'But languishing is the eye and glancing, and beautifully arched the brow, and dark the lashes, and soft the eyeball, and serene the look.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:297
verses.text: ' But see how even this itself again is nothing else than nerves, and veins, and membranes, and arteries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:298
verses.text: Think too, I pray, of this beautiful eye, when diseased and old, wasting with despair, swelling with anger, how hateful to the sight it is, how quickly it perisheth, how sooner even than pictured ones, it is effaced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:299
verses.text: From these things make thy mind pass to the true beauty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:300
verses.text: 'But,' saith he, ' I do not see beauty of soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:301
verses.text: ' But if thou wilt choose, thou shalt see it: and as the absent beautiful may be with the mind admired, though with one's eyes unseen, so it is possible to see without eyes beauty of soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:302
verses.text: Hast thou not often sketched a beauteous form, and felt moved unto the drawing? Image also now beauty of soul, and revel in that loveliness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:303
verses.text: 'But,' saith he, 'I do not see things incorporeal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:304
verses.text: ' And yet we see these, rather than the corporeal, with the mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:305
verses.text: Therefore it is, for instance, that although we see them not, we admire angels also and archangels, and habits of character, and virtue of soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:306
verses.text: And if thou seest a man considerate and moderate, thou wilt more admire him than that beautiful countenance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:307
verses.text: And if thou seest one insulted, yet bearing it; wronged, yet giving way, admire and love such, even though they be striken in age.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:308
verses.text: For such a thing is the beauty of the soul; even in old age it hath many enamored of it, and it never fadeth, but bloometh for ever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:309
verses.text: In order then that we also may gain this beauty, let us go in quest of those that have it, and be enamored of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 8:310
verses.text: For so shall we too be able, when we have attained this beauty, to obtain the good things eternal, whereof may all we partake, through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, with the Holy Spirit, be glory and might, for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:1
verses.text: Homily VIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:3
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:4
verses.text: ,  Therefore seeing we have this ministry, even as we obtained mercy we faint not, but we have renounced the hidden things of shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:5
verses.text: Seeing he had uttered great things and had set himself and all the faithful before Moses, aware of the height and greatness of what he had said, observe how he moderates his tone again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:6
verses.text: For it was necessary on account of the false Apostles to exalt his hearers also, and again to calm down that swelling; yet not to do it away, since this would be a trifler's part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:7
verses.text: Wherefore he manages this in another manner, by showing that not of their own merits was it, but all of the loving-kindness of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:8
verses.text: Wherefore also he says, "Therefore seeing we have this ministry".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:9
verses.text: For nothing more did we contribute, except that we became ministers, and made ourselves subservient to the things given by God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:10
verses.text: Wherefore he said not 'largess,' nor 'supply,' but 'ministry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:11
verses.text: ' Nor was he contented with this even, but added, "as we obtained mercy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:12
verses.text: For even this itself, he saith, the ministering to these things, is of mercy and loving-kindness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:13
verses.text: Yet it is mercy's to deliver from evils, not to give so many good things besides: but the mercy of God includes this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:14
verses.text: "We faint not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:15
verses.text: And this indeed is to be imputed to His loving-kindness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:16
verses.text: For the clause, "as we obtained mercy," take to be said with reference both to the "ministry," and to the words, "we faint not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:17
verses.text: And observe how earnestly he endeavors to lower his own things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:18
verses.text: 'For,' saith he, 'that one who hath been counted worthy of such and so great things, and this from mercy only and loving-kindness, should show forth such labors, and undergo dangers, and endure temptations, is no great matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:19
verses.text: Therefore we not only do not sink down, but we even rejoice and speak boldly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:20
verses.text: ' For instance, having said, "we faint not," he added,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:21
verses.text: "But we have renounced the hidden things of shame, not walking in craftiness, nor handling the word of God deceitfully".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:22
verses.text: And what are "the hidden things of shame?" We do not, he saith, profess and promise great things, and in our actions show other things, as they do; wherefore also he said, "Ye look on things after the outward appearance;" but such we are as we appear, not having any duplicity, nor saying and doing such things as we ought to hide and veil over with shame and blushes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:23
verses.text: And to interpret this, he added, "not walking in craftiness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:24
verses.text: For what they considered to be praise, that he proves to be shameful and worthy of scorn.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:25
verses.text: But what is, "in craftiness?" They had the reputation of taking nothing,, but they took and kept it secret; they had the character of saints and approved Apostles, but they were full of numberless evil things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:26
verses.text: But, saith he, "we have renounced" these things: (for these are what he also calls the "hidden things of shame;" being such as we appear to be, and keeping nothing veiled over.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:27
verses.text: And that not in this our life only, but also in the Preaching itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:28
verses.text: For this is, "nor handling the word of God deceitfully".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:29
verses.text: "But by the manifestation of the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:30
verses.text: Not by the countenance and the outward show, but by the very proof of our actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:31
verses.text: "Commending ourselves to every man's conscience".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:32
verses.text: For not to believers only, but also to unbelievers, we are manifest; lying open unto all that they may test our actions, as they may choose; and by this we commend ourselves, not by acting a part and carrying about a specious mask.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:33
verses.text: We say then, that we take nothing, and we call you for witnesses; we say that we are conscious of no wickedness, and of this again we derive the testimony from you, not as they (sc.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:34
verses.text: false Apostles) who, veiling over their things, deceive many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:35
verses.text: But we both set forth our life before all men; and we lay bare the Preaching, so that all comprehend it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:36
verses.text: Then because the unbelievers knew not its power, he added, this is no fault of ours, but of their own insensibility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:37
verses.text: Wherefore also he saith,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:39
verses.text: "But if our Gospel is veiled, it is veiled in them that are lost; in whom the God of this world hath blinded the eyes of the unbelieving".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:40
verses.text: As he said also before, "To some a savor from death unto death, to others a savor from life unto life," (ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:41
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:42
verses.text: ) so he saith here too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:43
verses.text: But what is "the God of this world?" Those that are infected with Marcion's notions, affirm that this is said of the Creator, the just only, and not good; for they say that there is a certain God, just and not good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:44
verses.text: But the Manichees say that the devil is here intended, desiring from this passage to introduce another creator of the world besides the True One, very senselessly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:45
verses.text: For the Scripture useth often to employ the term God, not in regard of the dignity of that so designated, but of the weakness of those in subjection to it; as when it calls Mammon lord, and the belly god.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:46
verses.text: But neither is the belly therefore God, nor Mammon Lord, save only of those who bow down themselves to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:47
verses.text: But we assert of this passage that it is spoken neither of the devil nor of another creator, but of the God of the Universe, and that it is to be read thus; "God hath blinded the minds of the unbelievers of this world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:48
verses.text: For the world to come hath no unbelievers; but the present only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:49
verses.text: But if any one should read it even otherwise, as, for instance, "the God of this world;" neither doth this afford any handle, for this doth not show Him to be the God of this world only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:50
verses.text: For He is called "the God of Heaven," (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:51
verses.text: cxxxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:53
verses.text: ) yet is He not the God of Heaven only; and we say, 'God of the present day;' yet we say this not as limiting His power to it alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:54
verses.text: And moreover He is called the "God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob;" (Exod.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:55
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:57
verses.text: ) and yet He is not the God of them alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:58
verses.text: And one may find many other like testimonies in the Scriptures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:59
verses.text: How then "hath" He "blinded" them? Not by working unto this end; away with the thought! but by suffering and allowing it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:60
verses.text: For it is usual with the Scripture so to speak, as when it saith, "God gave them up unto a reprobate mind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:61
verses.text: For when they themselves first disbelieved, and rendered themselves unworthy to see the mysteries; He Himself also thereafter permitted it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:62
verses.text: But what did it behove Him to do? To draw them by force, and reveal to those who would not see? But so they would have despised the more, and would not have seen either.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:63
verses.text: Wherefore also he added,  "That the light of the Gospel of the glory of Christ should not dawn upon them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:64
verses.text: Not that they might disbelieve in God, but that unbelief might not see what are the things within, as also He enjoined us, commanding not to "cast the pearls before the swine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:65
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:66
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:67
verses.text: ) For had He revealed even to those who disbelieve, their disease would have been the rather aggravated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:68
verses.text: For if one compel a man laboring under ophthalmia to look at the sunbeams, he the rather increases his infirmity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:69
verses.text: Therefore the physicians even shut them up in darkness, so as not to aggravate their disorder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:70
verses.text: So then here also we must consider that these persons indeed became unbelievers of themselves, but having become so, they no longer saw the secret things of the Gospel, God thenceforth excluding its beams from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:71
verses.text: As also he said to the disciples, "Therefore I speak unto them in proverbs, (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:72
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:73
verses.text: ) because hearing they hear not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:74
verses.text: But what I say may also become clearer by an example; suppose a Greek, accounting our religion to be fables.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:75
verses.text: This man then, how will he be more advantaged? by going in and seeing the mysteries, or by remaining without? Therefore he says, "That the light should not dawn upon them," still dwelling on the history of Moses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:76
verses.text: For what happened to the Jews in his case, this happeneth to all unbelievers in the case of the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:77
verses.text: And what is that which is overshadowed, and which is not illuminated unto them? Hear him saying, "That the light of the glorious Gospel of Christ who is the Image of God, should not dawn upon them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:78
verses.text: Namely, that the Cross is the salvation of the world, and His glory; that this Crucified One himself is about to come with much splendor; all the other things, those present, those to come, those seen, those not seen, the unspeakable splendor of the things looked for.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:79
verses.text: Therefore also he said, "dawn," that thou mayest not look for the whole here, for that which is here given is only, as it were, a little dawning of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:80
verses.text: Therefore, also above as indicating this, he spoke of "savor;" (c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:81
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:82
verses.text: ) and again, "earnest," (c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:83
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:84
verses.text: ) showing that the greater part remaineth there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:85
verses.text: But nevertheless all these things have been hidden from them; but had been hidden because they disbelieved first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:86
verses.text: Then to show that they are not only ignorant of the Glory of Christ, but of the Father's also, since they know not His, he added, "Who is the Image of God?" For do not halt at Christ only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:87
verses.text: For as by Him thou seest the Father, so if thou art ignorant of His Glory, neither wilt thou know the Father's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:88
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:89
verses.text: "For we preach not ourselves, but Christ Jesus as Lord, and ourselves as your servants for Jesus' sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:90
verses.text: And what is the nature of the connexion there? What hath this in common with what has been said? He either hints at them as exalting themselves, and persuading the disciples to name themselves after them: as he said in the former Epistle, "I am of Paul and I of Apollos;" or else another thing of the gravest character.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:91
verses.text: What then is this? Seeing that they waged fierce war against them, and plotted against them on every side; 'Is it,' he says, 'with us ye fight and war? Nay but with Him that is preached by us, "for we preach not ourselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:92
verses.text: I am a servant, I am but a minister even of those who receive the Gospel, transacting every thing for Another, and for His glory doing whatsover I do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:93
verses.text: So that in warring against me thou throwest down what is His.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:94
verses.text: For so far am I from turning to my own personal advantage any part of the Gospel, that I will not refuse to be even your servant for Christ's sake; seeing it seemed good to Him so to honor you, seeing He so loved you and did all things for you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:95
verses.text: ' Wherefore also he saith, "and ourselves your servants for Christ's sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:96
verses.text: Seest thou a soul pure from glory? 'For in truth,' saith he, 'we not only do not take to ourselves aught of our Master's, but even to you we submit ourselves for His sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:97
verses.text: '  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:98
verses.text: "Seeing it is God that said, Light shall shine out of darkness, who shined in your hearts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:99
verses.text: Seest thou how again to those who were desirous of seeing that surpassing glory, I mean that of Moses, he shows it flashing with added lustre? 'As upon the face of Moses, so also hath it shined unto your hearts,' he saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:100
verses.text: And first, he puts them in mind of what was made in the beginning of the Creation, sensible light and darkness sensible, showing that this creation is greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:101
verses.text: And where commanded He light to shine out of darkness? In the beginning and in prelude to the Creation; for, saith he, "Darkness was upon the face of the deep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:102
verses.text: And God said, Let there be light, and there was light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:103
verses.text: Howbeit then indeed He said, "Let it be, and it was:" but now He said nothing, but Himself became Light for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:104
verses.text: For he said not, 'hath also now commanded,' but "hath" Himself "shined".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:105
verses.text: Therefore neither do we see sensible objects by the shining of this Light, but God Himself through Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:106
verses.text: Seest thou the invariableness in the Trinity? For of the Spirit, he says, "But we all with unveiled face reflecting in a mirror the glory of the Lord, are transformed into the same image from glory to glory even as from the Lord the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:108
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:109
verses.text: ) And of the Son; "That the light of the glorious Gospel of Christ, Who is the Image of God, should not dawn upon them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:111
verses.text: ) And of the Father; "He that said Light shall shine out of darkness shined in your hearts, to give the light of the knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:112
verses.text: For as when he had said, "Of the Gospel of the glory of Christ," he added, "Who is the Image of God," showing that they were deprived of His glory also; So after saying, "the knowledge of God," he added, "in the face of Christ,' to show that through Him we know the Father, even as through the Spirit also we are brought unto Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:113
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:114
verses.text: "But we have this treasure in earthen vessels, that the exceeding greatness of the power may be of God, and not from ourselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:115
verses.text: For seeing he had spoken many and great things of the unspeakable glory, lest any should say, 'And how enjoying so great a glory remain we in a mortal body?' he saith, that this very thing is indeed the chiefest marvel and a very great example of the power of God, that an earthen vessel hath been enabled to bear so great a brightness and to keep so high a treasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:116
verses.text: And therefore as admiring this, he said, "That the exceeding greatness of the power may be of God, and not from ourselves;" again alluding to those who gloried in themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:117
verses.text: For both the greatness of the things given and the weakness of them that receive show His power; in that He not only gave great things, but also to those who are little.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:118
verses.text: For he used the term "earthen" in allusion to the frailty of our mortal nature, and to declare the weakness of our flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:119
verses.text: For it is nothing better constituted than earthenware; so is it soon damaged, and by death and disease and variations of temperature and ten thousand other things easily dissolved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:120
verses.text: And he said these things both to take down their inflation, and to show to all that none of the things we hold is human.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:121
verses.text: For then is the power of God chiefly conspicuous, when by vile it worketh mighty things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:122
verses.text: Wherefore also in another place He said, "For My power is made perfect in weakness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:123
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:124
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:125
verses.text: ) And indeed in the Old Testament whole hosts of barbarians were turned to flight by gnats and flies, wherefore also He calleth the caterpillar His mighty force; (Joel ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:126
verses.text: ) and in the beginning, by only confounding tongues, He put a stop to that great tower in Babylon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:127
verses.text: And in their wars too, at one time, He routed innumerable hosts by three hundred men; at another He overthrew cities by trumpets; and afterwards by a little and poor stripling, David, He turned to flight the whole army of barbarians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:128
verses.text: So then here also, sending forth twelve only He overcame the world; twelve, and those, persecuted, warred against.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:129
verses.text: Let us then be amazed at the Power of God, admire, adore it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:130
verses.text: Let us ask Jews, let us ask Greeks, who persuaded the whole world to desert from their fathers' usages, and to go over to another way of life? The fisherman, or the tentmaker? the publican, or the unlearned and ignorant? And how can these things stand with reason, except it were Divine Power which achieveth all by their means? And what too did they say to persuade them? 'Be baptized in the Name of The Crucified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:131
verses.text: ' Of what kind of man? One they had not seen nor looked upon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:132
verses.text: But nevertheless saying and preaching these things, they persuaded them that they who gave them oracles, and whom they had received by tradition from their forefathers, were no Gods: whilst this Christ, He Who was nailed to the wood, drew them all unto Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:133
verses.text: And yet that He was indeed crucified and buried, was manifest in a manner to all; but that He was risen again, none save a few saw.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:134
verses.text: But still of this too they persuaded those who had not beheld; and not that He rose again only, but that He ascended also into Heaven, and cometh to judge quick and dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:135
verses.text: Whence then the persuasiveness of these sayings, tell me? From nothing else than the Power of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:136
verses.text: For, in the first place, innovation itself was offensive to all; but when too one innovates in such things, the matter becomes more grievous: when one tears up the foundations of ancient custom, when one plucks laws from their seat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:137
verses.text: And besides all this, neither did the heralds seem worthy of credit, but they were both of a nation hated amongst all men, and were timorous and ignorant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:138
verses.text: Whence then overcame they the world? Whence cast they out you, and those your forefathers who were reputed to be philosophers, along with their very gods? Is it not quite evident that it was from having God with them? For neither are these successes of human, but of some divine and unspeakable, power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:139
verses.text: 'No,' saith one, 'but of witchcraft.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:140
verses.text: ' Then certainly ought the power of the demons to have increased and the worship of idols to have extended.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:141
verses.text: How then have they been overthrown and have vanished, and our things the reverse of these? So that from this even it is manifest that what was done was the decree of God; and not from the Preaching only, but also from the title of life itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:142
verses.text: For when was virginity so largely planted every where in the world? when contempt of wealth, and of life, and of all things besides? For such as were wicked and wizards, would have effected nothing like this, but the contrary in all respects: whilst these introduced amongst us the life of angels; and not introduced merely, but established it in our own land, in that of the barbarians, in the very extremities of the earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:143
verses.text: Whence it is manifest that it was the power of Christ every where that effected all, which every where shineth, and swifter than any lightning illumeth the hearts of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 9:144
verses.text: All these things, then, considering, and accepting what hath been done as a clear proof of the promise of the things to come, worship with us the invincible might of The Crucified, that ye may both escape the intolerable punishments, and obtain the everlasting kingdom; of which may all we partake through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ; to Whom be glory world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:1
verses.text: Homily IX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:3
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:4
verses.text: ,  We are pressed on every side, yet not straitened; perplexed, yet not unto despair; pursued, yet not forsaken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:5
verses.text: He still dwells upon proving that the whole work is to be ascribed to the power of God, repressing the highmindedness of those that glory in themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:6
verses.text: 'For not this only,' saith he, 'is marvelous, that we keep this treasure in earthen vessels, but that even when enduring ten thousand hardships, and battered on every side, we still preserve and lose it not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:7
verses.text: Yet though there were a vessel of adamant, it would neither have been strong enough to carry so vast a treasure, nor have sufficed against so many machinations; yet, as it is, it both bears it and suffers no harm, through God's grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:8
verses.text: ' For, "we are pressed on every side," saith he, "but not straitened".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:9
verses.text: What is, "on every side?"  'In respect of our foes, in respect of our friends, in respect of necessaries, in respect of other needs, by them which be hostile, by them of our own household.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:10
verses.text: ' "Yet not straitened".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:11
verses.text: And see how he speaks contrarieties, that thence also he may show the strength of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:12
verses.text: For, "we are pressed on every side, yet not straitened," saith he; "perplexed, yet not unto despair;" that is, 'we do not quite fall off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:13
verses.text: For we are often, indeed, wrong in our calculations, and miss our aim, yet not so as to fall away from what is set before us: for these things are permitted by God for our discipline, not for our defeat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:14
verses.text: '  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:15
verses.text: "Pursued, yet not forsaken; smitten down, yet not destroyed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:16
verses.text: For these trials do indeed befal, but not the consequences of the trials.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:17
verses.text: And this indeed through the power and Grace of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:18
verses.text: In other places indeed he says that these things were permitted in order both to their own humble-mindedness, and to the safety of others: for "that I should not be exalted overmuch, there was given to me a thorn," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:19
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:20
verses.text: ; ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:21
verses.text: ) he says: and again, "Lest any man should account of me above that which he seeth me to be, or heareth from me;" and in another place again, "that we should not trust in ourselves:" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:22
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:23
verses.text: ) here, however, that the power of God might be manifested.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:24
verses.text: Seest thou how great the gain of his trials? For it both showed the power of God, and more disclosed His grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:25
verses.text: For, saith He, "My grace is sufficient for thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:26
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:27
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:28
verses.text: ) It also anointed them unto lowliness of mind, and prepared them for keeping down the rest, and made them to be more hardy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:29
verses.text: "For patience," saith he, "worketh probation, and probation hope".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:30
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:31
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:32
verses.text: ) For they who had fallen into ten thousand dangers and through the hope they had in God had been recovered, were taught to hold by it more and more in all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:33
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:34
verses.text: "Always bearing about in the body the dying of the Lord Jesus, that the life also of Jesus may be manifested in our body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:35
verses.text: And what is the "dying of the Lord Jesus," which they bare about? Their daily deaths by which also the resurrection was showed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:36
verses.text: 'For if any believe not,' he says, 'that Jesus died and rose again, beholding us every day die and rise again, let him believe henceforward in the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:37
verses.text: ' Seest thou how he has discovered yet another reason for the trials? What then is this reason? "That his life also may be manifested in our body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:38
verses.text: He says, 'by snatching us out of the perils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:39
verses.text: So that this which seems a mark of weakness and destitution, this, I say, proclaims His resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:40
verses.text: For His power had not so appeared in our suffering no unpleasantness, as it is now shown in our suffering indeed, but without being overcome.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:41
verses.text: '  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:42
verses.text: "For we which live are also delivered unto death for Jesus' sake, that the life also of Jesus may be manifested in us in our mortal flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:43
verses.text: For every where when he has said any thing obscure, he interprets himself again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:44
verses.text: So he has done here also, giving a clear interpretation of this which I have cited.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:45
verses.text: 'For therefore, "we are delivered,"' he says, 'in other words, we bear about His dying that the power of His life may be made manifest, who permitteth not mortal flesh, though undergoing so great sufferings, to be overcome by the snowstorm of these calamities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:46
verses.text: ' And it may be taken too in another way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:47
verses.text: How? As he says in another place, "If we die with him, we shall also live with Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:48
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:49
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:50
verses.text: ) 'For as we endure His dying now, and choose whilst living to die for His sake: so also will he choose, when we are dead, to beget us then unto life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:51
verses.text: For if we from life come into death, He also will from death lead us by the hand into life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:52
verses.text: '  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:53
verses.text: "So then death worketh in us, but life in you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:54
verses.text: Speaking no more of death in the strict sense, but of trials and of rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:55
verses.text: 'For we indeed,' he says, 'are in perils and trials, but ye in rest; reaping the life which is the fruit of these perils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:56
verses.text: And we indeed endure the dangerous, but ye enjoy the good things; for ye undergo not so great trials.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:57
verses.text: '   Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:58
verses.text: "But having the same spirit of faith, according to that which is written, I believed, and therefore did I speak; we also believe, and therefore also we speak; that He which raised up the Lord Jesus, shall raise up us also by Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:59
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:60
verses.text: cxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:61
verses.text: )  He has reminded us of a Psalm which abounds in heavenly wisdom, and is especially fitted to encourage in dangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:62
verses.text: For this saying that just man uttered when he was in great dangers, and from which there was no other possibility of recovery than by the aid of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:63
verses.text: Since then kindred circumstances are most effective in comforting, therefore he says, "having the same Spirit;" that is, 'by the same succor by which he was saved, we also are saved; by the Spirit through which he spake, we also speak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:64
verses.text: ' Whence he shows, that between the New and Old Covenants great harmony exists, and that the same Spirit wrought in either; and that not we alone are in dangers, but all those of old were so too; and that we must find a remedy through faith and hope, and not seek at once to be released from what is laid upon us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:65
verses.text: For having showed by arguments the resurrection and the life, and that the danger was not a mark of helplessness or destitution; he thenceforward brings in faith also, and to it commits the whole.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:66
verses.text: But still of this also, he furnishes a proof, the resurrection, namely, of Christ, saying, "we also believe, and therefore also we speak".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:67
verses.text: What do we believe? tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:68
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:70
verses.text: "That He which raised up Jesus, shall raise up also, and shall present us with you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:71
verses.text: For all things are for your sakes, that the grace, being multiplied through the many, may cause the thanksgiving to abound unto the glory of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:72
verses.text: Again, he fills them with lofty thoughts, that they may not hold themselves indebted to men, I mean to the false Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:73
verses.text: For the whole is of God Who willeth to bestow upon many, so that the grace may appear the greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:74
verses.text: For your sakes, therefore, was the resurrection and all the other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:75
verses.text: For He did not these things for the sake of one only, but of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:76
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:77
verses.text: "Wherefore we faint not; but though our outward man is decaying, yet the inward man is renewed day by day".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:78
verses.text: How does it decay? Being scourged, being persecuted, suffering ten thousand extremities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:79
verses.text: "Yet the inward man is renewed day by day".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:80
verses.text: How is it renewed? By faith, by hope, by a forward will, finally, by braving those extremities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:81
verses.text: For in proportion as the body suffers ten thousand things, in the like proportion hath the soul goodlier hopes and becometh brighter, like gold refined in the fire more and more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:82
verses.text: And see how he brings to nothing the sorrows of this present life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:83
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:85
verses.text: "For the light affliction," he saith, "which is for the moment, worketh more and more exceedingly an eternal weight of glory; while we look not at the things which are seen, but at the things which are not seen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:86
verses.text: Having closed the question by a reference to hope, (and, as he said in his Epistle to the Romans, "We are saved by hope, but hope that is seen is not hope;" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:87
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:88
verses.text: ) establishing the same point here also,) he sets side by side the things present with the things to come, the momentary with the eternal, the light with the weighty, the affliction with the glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:89
verses.text: And neither is he content with this, but he addeth another expression, doubling it and saying, "more and more exceedingly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:90
verses.text: Next he also shows the mode how so great afflictions are light.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:91
verses.text: How then light? "While we look not at the things that are seen, but at the things that are not seen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:92
verses.text: So will both this present be light and that future great, if we withdraw ourselves from the things that are seen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:93
verses.text: "For the things that are seen are temporal".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:95
verses.text: ) Therefore the afflictions are so too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:96
verses.text: "But the things that are not seen are eternal".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:97
verses.text: Therefore the crowns are so also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:98
verses.text: And he said not the afflictions are so, but "the things that are seen;" all of them, whether punishment or rest, so that we should be neither puffed up by the one nor overborne by the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:99
verses.text: And therefore when speaking of the things to come, he said not the kingdom is eternal; but, "the things which are not seen are eternal," whether they be a kingdom, or again punishment; so as both to alarm by the one and to encourage by the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:100
verses.text: Since then "the things that are seen are temporal, but the things that are not seen are eternal," let us look to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:101
verses.text: For what excuse even can we have, if we choose the temporal instead of the eternal? For even if the present be pleasurable, yet it is not abiding; whilst the woe it entails is abiding and irremissible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:102
verses.text: For what excuse will they have who have been counted worthy of the Spirit and have enjoyed so great a gift, if they become of grovelling mind and fall down to the earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:103
verses.text: For I hear many saying these words worthy of all scorn, 'Give me to-day and take tomorrow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:104
verses.text: ' 'For,' saith one, 'if indeed there be such things there as ye affirm, then it is one for one; but if there be no such thing at all, then it is two for nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:105
verses.text: ' What can be more lawless than these words? or what more idle prating? We are discoursing about Heaven and those unspeakable good things; and thou bringest forth unto us the terms of the race-course, yet art not ashamed nor hidest thy face, whilst uttering such things as befit maniacs? Blushest thou not that art so rivetted to the present things? Wilt thou not cease from being distraught and beside thyself, and in youth a dotard? Were Greeks indeed to talk in this way, it were no marvel: but that believers should vent such dotage, of what forgiveness doth it admit? For dost thou hold those immortal hopes in utter suspicion? Dost thou think these things to be utterly doubtful? And in what are these things deserving of pardon? 'And who hath come,' saith one, 'and brought back word what is there?' Of men indeed not any one, but God, more trustworthy than all, hath declared these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:106
verses.text: But thou beholdest not what is there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:107
verses.text: Neither dost thou see God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:108
verses.text: Wilt thou then deny that there is a God, because thou seest Him not? 'Yes,' he replies, 'I firmly believe there is a God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:109
verses.text: ' If then an infidel should ask thee, 'And who came from Heaven and brought back word of this?' what wilt thou answer? Whence dost thou know that there is a God? 'From the things that are seen,' he answers, 'from the fair order existing through the whole creation, from its being manifest to all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:110
verses.text: ' Therefore receive also in the same way the doctrine of the judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:111
verses.text: 'How?' he asks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:112
verses.text: I will question thee, and do thou answer me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:113
verses.text: Is this God just, and will He render to each according to his deserving? or, on the contrary, doth He will the wicked should live happily and in luxury, and the good in the contrary things? 'By no means,' he answers, 'for man even would not feel thus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:114
verses.text: ' Where then shall they who have done virtuously here, enjoy the things that be good? and where the wicked the opposites, except there is to be a life and retribution hereafter? Seest thou that at present it is one for one, and not two for one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:115
verses.text: But I will show thee, as I proceed, that it is not even one against one, but it shall be for the righteous two for nothing; and for the sinners and these that live here riotously, quite the contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:116
verses.text: For they that have lived riotously here have received not even one for one; but those who pass their life in virtue two for nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:117
verses.text: For who are at in rest, they that have abused this present life, or they that followed heavenly wisdom? Perhaps thou wilt say the former, but I prove it of the latter, summoning for my witnesses those very men that have enjoyed these present things; and they will not be so shameless as to deny what I am going to say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:118
verses.text: For oftentimes have they imprecated curses upon matchmakers and upon the day that their bridal chamber was wreathed, and have proclaimed them happy who have not married.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:119
verses.text: Many too of the young, even when they might have married, have refused for no other reason than the troublesomeness of the thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:120
verses.text: And this I say, not as accusing marriage; for it is "honorable;" (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:121
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:122
verses.text: ) but those who have used it amiss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:123
verses.text: Now if they who have lived a married life, often considered their life not worth the living; what shall we say of those who have been swept down into whores' deep pits, and are more slavishly and wretchedly treated than any captive? what of those who have grown rotten in luxury and have enveloped their bodies with a thousand diseases? 'But it is a pleasure to be had in honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:124
verses.text: ' Yea, rather, nothing is bitterer than this slavery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:125
verses.text: For he that seeketh vain honor is more servile than any slave, and desirous of pleasing any body; but he that treads it under foot is superior to all, who careth not for the glory that cometh from others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:126
verses.text: 'But the possession of wealth is desirable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:127
verses.text: ' Yet we have often shown that they who are loose from it and have nothing, enjoy greater riches and repose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:128
verses.text: 'But to be drunken is pleasant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:129
verses.text: ' But who will say this? Surely then if to be without riches is pleasanter than to have them, and not to marry than to marry, and not to seek vainglory than to seek it, and not to live luxuriously than to live so; even in this world they who are not riveted to those present things have the advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:130
verses.text: And as yet I say not how that the former, even though he be racked with ten thousand tortures, hath that good hope to carry him through: whilst the latter, even though he is in the enjoyment of a thousand delights, hath the fear of the future disquieting and confounding his pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:131
verses.text: For this, too, is no light sort of punishment; nor therefore the contrary, of enjoyment and repose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:132
verses.text: And besides these there is a third sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:133
verses.text: And what is this? In that the things of worldly delight do not even whilst they are present appear such, being refuted both by nature and time; but the others not only are, but also abide immovable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:134
verses.text: Seest thou that we shall be able to put not two for nothing only, but three even, and five, and ten, and twenty, and ten thousand for nothing? But that thou mayest learn this same truth by an example also,—the rich man and Lazarus,—the one enjoyed the things present, the other those to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:135
verses.text: (Luke xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:137
verses.text: ) Seems it then to thee to be one and one, to be punished throughout all time, and to be an hungered for a little season? to be diseased in thy corruptible body, and to scorch miserably in an undying one? to be crowned and live in undying delights after that little sickness, and to be endlessly tormented after that short enjoyment of his goods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:138
verses.text: And who will say this? For what wilt thou we should compare? the quantity? the quality? the rank? the decision of God concerning each? How long will ye utter the words of beetles that are for ever wallowing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:139
verses.text: in dung! For these are not the words of reasoning men, to throw away a soul which is so precious for nothing, when there needeth little labor to receive heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:140
verses.text: Wilt thou that I teach thee also in another way that there is an awful tribunal there? Open the doors of thy conscience, and behold the judge that sitteth in thine heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 10:141
