verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 12:192
verses.text: So shall we also even here obtain already the kingdom and the good things to come; whereunto may we all attain, through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ; with Whom to the Father, with the Holy Spirit, be glory, might, honor, now and for ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:1
verses.text: Homily XII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:3
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:4
verses.text: ,  And working together with Him we intreat also that ye receive not the grace of God in vain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:5
verses.text: For he saith, At an acceptable time I hearkened unto thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:6
verses.text: And in a day of salvation did I succor thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:7
verses.text: For since he said, God beseeches, and we are ambassadors and suppliants unto you, that ye be "reconciled unto God:" lest they should become supine, he hereby again alarms and arouses them, saying: "We intreat that ye receive not the grace of God in vain".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:8
verses.text: 'For let us not,' he says, 'therefore be at ease, because He beseeches and hath sent some to be ambassadors; nay, but for this very reason let us make haste to please God and to collect spiritual merchandise;' as also he said above, "The love of God constraineth us," (ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:9
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:10
verses.text: ) that is presseth, driveth, urgeth us, 'that ye may not after so much affectionate care, by being supine and exhibiting no nobleness, miss of such great blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:11
verses.text: Do not therefore because He hath sent some to exhort you, deem that this will always be so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:12
verses.text: It will be so until His second coming; until then He beseeches, so long as we are here; but after that is judgment and punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:13
verses.text: ' Therefore, he says, "we are constrained".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:14
verses.text: For not only from the greatness of the blessings and His loving kindness, but also from the shortness of the time he urgeth them continually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:15
verses.text: Wherefore he saith also elsewhere, "For now is our salvation nearer".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:16
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:17
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:18
verses.text: ) And again; "The Lord is at hand".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:19
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:20
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:21
verses.text: ) But here he does something yet more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:22
verses.text: For not from the fact that the remainder of the time is short and little, but also from its being the only season available, for salvation, he incited them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:23
verses.text: For, "Behold," he saith, "now is the acceptable time; behold, now is the day of salvation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:24
verses.text: Let us therefore not let slip the favorable opportunity but display a zeal worthy of the grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:25
verses.text: For therefore is it that we also press forward, knowing both the shortness and the suitableness of the time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:26
verses.text: Wherefore also he said; "And working together we intreat also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:27
verses.text: Working together" with you; 'for we work together with you, rather than with God for Whom we are ambassadors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:28
verses.text: For He is in need of nothing, but the salvation all passeth over to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:29
verses.text: ' But if it is even with God that he speaks of working together, he repudiates not even this interpretation; for he says in another place, "we are God's fellow-workers:" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:30
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:31
verses.text: ) in this way, saith he, to save men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:32
verses.text: Again, "We entreat also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:33
verses.text: For he indeed, when beseeching, doth not barely beseech, but sets forth these His just claims; namely, that He gave His Son, the Righteous One that did not so much as know sin, and made Him to be sin for us sinners, that we might become righteous: which claims having, and being God, He displayed such goodness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:34
verses.text: But what we beseech is that ye would receive the benefit and not reject the gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:35
verses.text: Be persuaded therefore by us, and "receive not the grace in vain".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:36
verses.text: For lest they should think that this of itself is "reconciliation," believing on Him that calleth; he adds these words, requiting that earnestness which respects the life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:37
verses.text: For, for one who hath been freed from sins and made a friend to wallow in the former things, is to return again unto enmity, and to "receive the grace in vain," in respect of the life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:38
verses.text: For from "the grace" we reap no benefit towards salvation, if we live impurely; nay, we are even harmed, having this greater aggravation even of our sins, in that after such knowledge and such a gift we have gone back to our former vices.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:39
verses.text: This however he does not mention as yet: that he may not make his work harsh, but says only that we reap no benefit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:40
verses.text: Then he also reminds of a prophecy, urging and compelling them to bestir themselves in order to lay hold of their own salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:41
verses.text: "For," saith he, "He saith,  "At an acceptable time I hearkened unto thee,  "And in a day of salvation did I succor thee:  "behold, now is the acceptable time: behold, now is the day of salvation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:42
verses.text: "The acceptable time".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:43
verses.text: What is this? That of the Gift, that of the Grace, when it is appointed not that an account should be required of our sins nor penalty exacted; but besides being delivered, that we should also enjoy ten thousand goods, righteousness, sanctification, and all the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:44
verses.text: For how much toil would it have behoved us to undergo in order to obtain this "time!" But, behold, without our toiling at all it hath come, bringing remission of all that was before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:45
verses.text: Wherefore also He calls it "acceptable," because He both accepted those that had transgressed in ten thousand things, and not acceded merely, but advanced them to the highest honor; just as when a monarch arrives, it is a time not for judgment, but for grace and pardon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:46
verses.text: Wherefore also He calleth it acceptable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:47
verses.text: Whilst then we are yet in the lists, whilst we are at work in the vineyard, whilst the eleventh hour is left us, let us draw nigh and show forth life; for it is also easy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:48
verses.text: For he that striveth for the mastery at such a time, when so great a gift hath been shed forth, when so great grace, will early obtain the prizes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:49
verses.text: For in the case of monarchs here below also, at the time of their festivals, and when they appear in the dress of Consuls, he who bringeth a small offering receiveth large gifts; but on the days in which they sit in judgment, much strictness, much sifting is requisite.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:50
verses.text: Let us too therefore strive for the mastery in the time of this gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:51
verses.text: It is a day of grace, of grace divine; wherefore with ease even we shall obtain the crown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:52
verses.text: For if when laden with so great evils He both received and delivered us: when delivered from all and contributing our part, shall He not rather accept us?   Then, as it is his constant wont, namely, to place himself before them and bid them hence to take their example, so he does in this place also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:53
verses.text: Wherefore also he addeth,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:54
verses.text: "Giving no occasion of stumbling, that our ministration be not blamed," persuading them not from considering "the time" only, but also those that had successfully labored with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:55
verses.text: And behold with what absence of pride.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:56
verses.text: For he said not, 'Look at us how we are such and such,' but, for the present, it is only to do away accusation that he relates his own conduct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:57
verses.text: And he mentions two chief points of a blameless life, "none" in "any" thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:58
verses.text: And he said not 'accusation,' but, what was far less, "occasion of stumbling;" that is, giving ground against us to none for censure, for condemnation, "that our ministration be not blamed;" that is, that none may take hold of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:59
verses.text: And again, he said not, 'that it be not accused,' but that it may not have the least fault, nor any one have it in his power to animadvert upon it in any particular.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:60
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:61
verses.text: "But in every thing commending ourselves as ministers of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:62
verses.text: This is far greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:63
verses.text: For it is not the same thing to be free from accusation; and to exhibit such a character as in everything to appear "ministers of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:64
verses.text: For neither is it the same thing to be quit of accusation, and to be covered with praises.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:65
verses.text: And he said not appearing, but "commending," that is 'proving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:66
verses.text: ' Then he mentions also whence they became such.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:67
verses.text: Whence then was it? "In much patience," he says, laying the foundation of those good things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:68
verses.text: Wherefore he said not barely "patience," but "much," and he shows also how great it was.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:69
verses.text: For to bear some one or two things is no great matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:70
verses.text: But he addeth even snow storms of trials in the words, "In afflictions, in necessities".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:71
verses.text: This is a heightening of affliction, when the evils are unavoidable, and there lies upon one as it were a necessity hardly extricable of misfortune.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:72
verses.text: "In distresses".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:73
verses.text: Either he means those of hunger and of other necessaries, or else simply those of their trials.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:74
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:75
verses.text: "In stripes, in imprisonments, in tossings to and fro".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:76
verses.text: Yet every one of these by itself was intolerable, the being scourged only, and being bound only, and being unable through persecution to remain fixed any where, (for this is in 'tossings to and fro,') but when both all, and all at once, assail, consider what a soul they need.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:77
verses.text: Then along with the things from without, he mentions those imposed by himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:78
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:80
verses.text: "In labors, in watchings, in fastings; in pureness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:81
verses.text: But by "pureness" here, he means either chasteness again, or general purity, or incorruptness, or even his preaching the Gospel freely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:82
verses.text: "In knowledge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:83
verses.text: What is "in knowledge?" In wisdom such as is given from God; that which is truly knowledge; not as those that seem to be wise and boast of their acquaintance with the heathen discipline, but are deficient in this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:84
verses.text: "In long-suffering, in kindness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:85
verses.text: For this also is a great note of a noble soul, though exasperated and goaded on every side, to bear all with long-suffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:86
verses.text: Then to show whence he became such, he added;  "In the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:87
verses.text: 'For in Him,' he saith, 'we do all these good works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:88
verses.text: ' But observe when it is that he has mentioned the aid of the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:89
verses.text: After he had set forth what was from himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:90
verses.text: Moreover, he seems to me to say another thing herein.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:91
verses.text: What then is this? Namely, 'we have both been filled with abundance of the Spirit and hereby also give a proof of our Apostleship in that we have been counted worthy of spiritual gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:92
verses.text: ' For if this be grace also, yet still he himself was the cause who by his good works and his toils attracted that grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:93
verses.text: And if any should assert that besides what has been said, he shows that in his use of the gifts of the Spirit also he gave none offence; he would not miss of his meaning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:94
verses.text: For they who received the gift of tongues amongst them and were lifted up, were blamed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:95
verses.text: For it is possible for one even in receiving a gift of the Spirit, not to use it aright.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:96
verses.text: 'But not so we,' he saith, 'but in the Spirit also, that is, in the gifts also, we have been blameless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:97
verses.text: '  "In love unfeigned".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:98
verses.text: This was the cause of all those good things; this made him what he was; this caused the Spirit also to abide with him, by Whose aid also all things were rightly done of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:99
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:100
verses.text: "In the word of truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:101
verses.text: A thing he says in many places, that 'we continued neither to handle the word of God deceitfully nor to adulterate it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:102
verses.text: '  "In the power of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:103
verses.text: That which he always does ascribing nothing to himself but the whole to God, and imputing whatsoever he hath done aright to Him, this he hath done here also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:104
verses.text: For since he uttered great things, and affirmed that he had manifested in all things an irreproachable life and exalted wisdom, he ascribes this to the Spirit and to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:105
verses.text: For neither were those commonplace things which he had said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:106
verses.text: For if it be a difficult thing even for one who lives in quiet to do aright and be irreproachable, consider him who was harassed by so great temptations, and yet shone forth through all, what a spirit he was of! And yet he underwent not these alone, but even far more than these, as he mentions next.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:107
verses.text: And what is indeed marvelous is, not that he was irreproachable though sailing in such mighty waves, nor that he endured all nobly, but all with pleasure even.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:108
verses.text: Which things, all, he makes clear to us by the next words, saying,  "By the armor of righteousness on the right and the left".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:109
verses.text: Seest thou his self-possession of soul and well-strung spirit? For he shows that afflictions are arms not only which strike not down, but do even fortify and make stronger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:110
verses.text: And he calls those things 'left,' which seem to be painful; for such those are which bring with them the reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:111
verses.text: Wherefore then doth he call them thus? Either in conformity with the conception of the generality, or because God commanded us to pray that we enter not into temptation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:112
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:113
verses.text: "By glory and dishonor, by evil report and good report".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:114
verses.text: What saying thou? That thou enjoyest honor, and setting down this as a great thing? 'Yes,' he saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:115
verses.text: Why, forsooth? For to bear dishonor indeed is a great thing, but to partake of honor requires not a vigorous soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:116
verses.text: Nay, it needs a vigorous and exceeding great soul, that he who enjoys it may not be thrown and break his neck.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:117
verses.text: Wherefore he glories in this as well as in that, for he shone equally in both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:118
verses.text: But how is it a weapon of righteousness? Because that the teachers are held in honor induceth many unto godliness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:119
verses.text: And besides, this is a proof of good works, and this glorifieth God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:120
verses.text: And this is, further, an instance of the wise contrivance of God, that by things which are opposite He brings in the Preaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:121
verses.text: For consider.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:122
verses.text: Was Paul bound? This too was on behalf of the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:123
verses.text: For, saith he, "the things which happened unto me have fallen out unto the progress of the Gospel; so that most of the brethren, being confident through my bonds, are more abundantly bold to speak the word without fear".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:124
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:125
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:127
verses.text: ) Again, did he enjoy honor? This too again rendered them more forward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:128
verses.text: "By evil report and good report".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:129
verses.text: For not only did he bear those things nobly which happen to the body, the 'afflictions,' and whatever he enumerated, but those also which touch the soul; for neither are these wont to disturb slightly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:130
verses.text: Jeremiah at least having borne many temptations, gave in upon these, and when he was reproached, said, "I will not prophesy, neither will I name the Name of the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:131
verses.text: (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:132
verses.text: xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:133
verses.text: ) And David too many places complains of reproach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:134
verses.text: Isaiah also, after many things, exhorteth concerning this, saying, "Fear ye not the reproach of men, neither be ye overcome by their reviling".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:135
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:136
verses.text: li.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:137
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:138
verses.text: ) And again, Christ also to His disciples; "When they shall speak all manner of evil against you falsely, rejoice and be exceeding glad," (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:139
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:141
verses.text: ) He saith, "for great is your reward in heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:142
verses.text: Elsewhere too He says," And leap for joy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:143
verses.text: (Luke vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:144
verses.text: ) But He would not have made the reward so great, had not the contest been a great one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:145
verses.text: For in tortures the body also shareth the anguish with the soul; for the pain is both of the body and of the soul; but here it is of the soul alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:146
verses.text: Many at any rate have fallen by these alone, and have lost their own souls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:147
verses.text: And to Job also the reproaches of his friends appeared more grievous than the worms and the sores.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:148
verses.text: For there is nothing, there is nothing more intolerable to those in affliction than a word capable of stinging the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:149
verses.text: Wherefore along with the perils and the toils he names these also, saying, "By glory and dishonor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:150
verses.text: At any rate, many of the Jews also on account of glory derived from the many would not believe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:151
verses.text: For they feared, not lest they should be punished, but lest they should be put out of the synagogue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:152
verses.text: Wherefore He saith, "How can ye believe which receive glory one of another?" (John v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:153
verses.text: ) And we may see numbers who have indeed despised all dangers, but have been worsted by glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:154
verses.text: "As deceivers, and yet true".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:155
verses.text: This is, "by evil report and good report".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:156
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:157
verses.text: "As unknown, and yet well known".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:158
verses.text: This is, "by glory and dishonor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:159
verses.text: For by some they were well known and much sought after, whilst others designed not to know them at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:160
verses.text: "As dying, and behold, we live".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:161
verses.text: As under sentence of death and condemned; which was itself also matter of dishonor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:162
verses.text: But this he said, to show both the unspeakable power of God and their own patience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:163
verses.text: For so far as those who plotted against us were concerned, we died; and this is what all suppose; but by God's aid we escaped the dangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:164
verses.text: Then to manifest also on what account God permits these things, he added, "As chastened, and not killed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:165
verses.text: Showing that the gain accruing to them from their temptations, even before the rewards, was great, and that their enemies against their will did them service.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:166
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:167
verses.text: "As sorrowful, yet alway rejoicing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:168
verses.text: For by those that are without, indeed, we are suspected of being in despair; but we give no heed to them; yea, we have our pleasure at the full.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:169
verses.text: And he said not "rejoicing" only, but added also its perpetuity, for he says "alway rejoicing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:170
verses.text: What then can come up to this life? wherein, although dangers so great assault, the joy becometh greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:171
verses.text: "As poor, yet making many rich".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:172
verses.text: Some indeed affirm that the spiritual riches are spoken of here; but I would say that the carnal are so too; for they were rich in these also, having, after a new kind of manner, the houses of all opened to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:173
verses.text: And this too he signified by what follows, saying,  "As having nothing, and yet possessing all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:174
verses.text: And how can this be? Yea rather, how can the opposite be? For he that possesseth many things hath nothing; and he that hath nothing possesseth the goods of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:175
verses.text: And not here only, but also in the other points, contraries were produced by their contraries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:176
verses.text: But if thou marvellest how it is possible for one that hath nothing to have all things, let us bring forth this man himself into the midst, who commanded the world and was lord not only of their substance, but of their very eyes even.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:177
verses.text: "If possible," he says, "ye would have plucked out your eyes, and have given them to me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:178
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:179
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:180
verses.text: )  Now these things he says, to instruct us not to be disturbed at the opinions of the many, though they call us deceivers, though they know us not, though they count us condemned, and appointed unto death, to be in sorrow, to be in poverty, to have nothing, to be (us, who are in cheerfulness) desponding: because that the sun even is not clear to the blind, nor the pleasure of the sane intelligible to the mad.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:181
verses.text: For the faithful only are right judges of these matters, and are not pleased and pained at the same things as other people.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:182
verses.text: For if any one who knew nothing of the games were to see a boxer, having wounds upon him and wearing a crown; he would think him in pain on account of the wounds, not understanding the pleasure the crown would give him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:183
verses.text: And these therefore, because they know what we suffer but do not know for what we suffer them, naturally suspect that there is nought besides these; for they see indeed the wrestling and the dangers, but not the prizes and the crowns and the subject of the contest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:184
verses.text: What then were the "all things" which Paul possessed, when he said, "As having nothing, and yet possessing all things?" Things temporal, things spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:185
verses.text: For he whom the cities received as an angel, for whom they would have plucked out their own eyes and have given them to him, (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:186
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:188
verses.text: ) he for whom they laid down their own necks, how had he not all things that were theirs? (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:189
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:190
verses.text: ) But if thou desirest to see the spiritual also, thou wilt find him in these things also especially rich.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:191
verses.text: For he that was so dear to the King of all as even to share in unspeakable things with the Lord of the angels, (ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:192
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:193
verses.text: ) how was not he more opulent than all men, and had all things? Devils had not else been so subject to him, suffering and disease had not so fled away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:194
verses.text: And let us therefore, when we suffer aught for Christ's sake, not merely bear it nobly but also rejoice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:195
verses.text: If we fast, let us leap for joy as if enjoying luxury; if we be insulted, let us dance as if praised; if we spend, let us feel as if gaining; if we bestow on the poor, let us count ourselves to receive: for he that gives not thus will not give readily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:196
verses.text: When then thou hast a mind to scatter abroad, look not at this only in almsgiving, but also in every kind of virtue, compute not alone the severity of the toils, but also the sweetness of the prizes; and before all the subjects of this wrestling, our Lord Jesus; and thou wilt readily enter upon the contest, and wilt live the whole time in pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:197
verses.text: For nothing is wont so to cause pleasure as a good conscience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:198
verses.text: Therefore Paul indeed, though wounded every day, rejoiced and exulted; but the men of this day, although they endure not a shadow even of what he did, grieve and make lamentations from no other cause than that they have not a mind full of heavenly philosophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:199
verses.text: For, tell me, wherefore the lamentation? Because thou art poor, and in want of necessaries? Surely for this thou oughtest rather to make lamentation, not because thou weepest, not because thou art poor, but because thou art mean-spirited; not because thou hast not money, but because thou prizest money so highly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:200
verses.text: Paul died daily, yet wept not but even rejoiced; he fought with continual hunger, yet grieved not but even gloried in it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:201
verses.text: And dost thou, because thou hast not all the year's provisions stored up, grieve and beat thyself? 'Yes,' he replies, 'for he had to care only for his own needs, whilst I have besides to care for servants, and children, and wife.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:202
verses.text: ' Rather, he alone had not to care for his own needs, but for the whole world's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:203
verses.text: And thou indeed hast to care for one household, but he for those so many poor at Jerusalem, for those in Macedonia, for those everywhere in poverty, for those who give to them no less than for those who receive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:204
verses.text: For his care for the world was of a twofold nature, both that they might not be destitute of necessaries, and that they might be rich in spiritual things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:205
verses.text: And thy famishing children distress not thee so much as all the concerns of the faithful did him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:206
verses.text: Why do I say, of the faithful? For neither was he free from care for the unfaithful, but was so eaten up with it that he wished even to become accursed for their sakes; but thou, were a famine to rage ten thousand times over, wouldest never choose to die for any whomsoever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:207
verses.text: And thou indeed carest for one woman, but he for the Churches throughout the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:208
verses.text: For he saith, "My anxiety for all the Churches".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:209
verses.text: (ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:210
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:211
verses.text: ) How long then, O man, dost thou trifle, comparing thyself with Paul; and wilt not cease from this thy much meanness of spirit? For it behoveth to weep, not when we are in poverty but when we sin; for this is worthy of lamentations, as all the other things are of ridicule even.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:212
verses.text: 'But,' he saith, 'this is not all that grieves me; but that also such an one is in power, whilst I am unhonored and outcast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:213
verses.text: ' And what is this? for the blessed Paul too appeared to the many to be unhonored and an outcast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:214
verses.text: 'But,' saith he, 'he was Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:215
verses.text: ' Plainly then not the nature of the things, but thy feebleness of spirit causeth thy desponding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:216
verses.text: Lament not therefore thy poverty, but thyself who art so minded, yea rather, lament not thyself, but reform thee; and seek not for money, but pursue that which maketh men of more cheerful countenance than thousands of money, philosophy and virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:217
verses.text: For where indeed these are, there is no harm in poverty; and where these are not there is no good in money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:218
verses.text: For tell me, what good is it when men are rich indeed, but have beggarly souls? Thou dost not bewail thyself, so much as that rich man himself, because he hath not the wealth of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:219
verses.text: And if he doth not weep as thou dost, yet lay open his conscience, and thou wilt see his wailings and lamentations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:220
verses.text: Wilt thou that I show thee thine own riches, that thou mayest cease to count them happy that are rich in money? Seest thou this heaven here, the sun, this bright and far shining star, and that gladdeneth our eyes, is not this too set out common to all? and do not all enjoy it equally, both poor and rich? And the wreath of the stars and the orb of the moon, are they not left equally to all? Yea, rather, if I must speak somewhat marvellous, we poor enjoy these more than they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:221
verses.text: For they indeed being for the most part steeped in drunkenness, and passing their time in revellings and deep sleep, do not even perceive these things, being always under cover and reared in the shade: but the poor do more than any enjoy the luxury of these elements.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:222
verses.text: And further, if thou wilt look into the air which is every where diffused, thou wilt see the poor man enjoying it in greater both freshness and abundance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:223
verses.text: For wayfarers and husbandmen enjoy these luxuries more than the inhabitants of the city; and again, of those same inhabitants of the city, the handicraftsmen more than those who are drunken all the day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:224
verses.text: What too of the earth, is not this left common to all? 'No,' he saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:225
verses.text: How sayest thou so? tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:226
verses.text: 'Because the rich man, even in the city, having gotten himself several plethra, raises up long fences round them; and in the country cuts off for himself many portions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:227
verses.text: ' What then? When he cuts them off, does he alone enjoy them? By no means, though he should contend for it ever so earnestly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:228
verses.text: For the produce he is compelled to distribute amongst all, and for thee he cultivates grain, and wine, and oil, and every where ministers unto thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:229
verses.text: And those long fences and buildings, after his untold expense and his toils and drudgery he is preparing for thy use, receiving from thee only a small piece of silver for so great a service.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:230
verses.text: And in baths and every where, one may see the same thing obtaining; the rich of it all with perfect ease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:231
verses.text: And his enjoyment of the earth is no more than thine; for sure he filleth not ten stomachs, and thou only one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:232
verses.text: 'But he partaketh of costlier meats?' Truly, this is no mighty superiority; howbeit, even here, we shall find thee to have the advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:233
verses.text: For this costliness is therefore thought by thee a matter of envy because the pleasure with it is greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:234
verses.text: Yet this is greater in the poor man's case; yet not pleasure only, but health also; and in this alone is the advantage with the rich, that he maketh his constitution feebler and collects more abundant fountains of disease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:235
verses.text: For the poor man's diet is all ordered according to nature, but his through its excess resulteth in corruption and disease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:236
verses.text: But if ye will, let us also look at this same thing in an example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:237
verses.text: For if it were requisite to light a furnace, and then one man were to throw in silken garments and fine linens, many and numberless, and so kindle it; and another logs of oak and pine, what advantage would this man have over that? None, but even disadvantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:238
verses.text: But what? (for there is nothing to prevent our turning the same illustration round after another manner,) if one were to throw in logs, and another were to light his fire under bodies, by which furnace wouldest thou like to stand, that with the logs, or that with the bodies? Very plainly that with the logs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:239
verses.text: For that burns naturally and is a pleasant spectacle to the beholders: whilst this with the steam, and juices, and smoke, and the stench of the bones would drive every one away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:240
verses.text: Didst thou shudder at the hearing, and loathe that furnace? Like it are the bellies of the rich.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:241
verses.text: For in them one would find more rottenness than in that furnace, and stinking vapors, and filthy humors, because that, all over in every part, indigestion abounds in consequence of their surfeiting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:242
verses.text: For the natural heat not sufficing for the digestion of the whole but being smothered under them, they lie smoking above, and the unpleasantness produced is great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:243
verses.text: To what then should one compare those stomachs of theirs? Yet do not be offended at what I say, but if I do not say true things, refute me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:244
verses.text: To what then should one compare them? for even what has been said is not enough to show their wretched plight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:245
verses.text: I have found another resemblance yet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:246
verses.text: What then is it? As in the sewers where there is accumulation of refuse, of dung, hay, stubble, stones, clay, frequent stoppages occur; and then the stream of filth overflows at top: so also it happeneth with the stomachs of those people.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:247
verses.text: For these being stopped up below, the greater part of these villainous streams spurts up above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:248
verses.text: But not so with the poor, but like those fountains which well forth pure streams, and water gardens and pleasure grounds, so also are their stomachs pure from such-like superfluities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:249
verses.text: But not such are the stomachs of the rich, or rather of the luxurious; but they are filled with humors, phlegm, bile, corrupted blood, putrid rheums, and other suchlike matters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:250
verses.text: Wherefore no one, if he lives always in luxury, can bear it even for a short time; but his life will be spent in continual sicknesses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:251
verses.text: Wherefore I would gladly ask them, for what end are meats given? that we may be destroyed, or be nourished? that we may be diseased, or be strong? that we may be healthful, or be sickly? Very plainly, for nourishment, creating unto the body disease and sickness? But not so the poor man; on the contrary, by his plain diet he purchases to himself health, and vigor, and strength.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:252
verses.text: Weep not then on account of poverty, the mother of health, but even exult in it; and if thou wouldest be rich, despise riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:253
verses.text: For this, not the having money but the not wanting to have it, is truly affluence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 13:254
verses.text: If we can achieve this, we shall both be here more affluent than all that are rich, and there shall obtain the good things to come, whereunto may all we attain, through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, with the Holy Ghost, be glory, might, honor, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:1
verses.text: Homily XIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:3
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:4
verses.text: ,  Our mouth is open unto you, O ye Corinthians, our heart is enlarged, ye are not straitened in us, but ye are straitened in your own affections.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:5
verses.text: Having detailed his own trials and afflictions, for "in patience," saith he, "in afflictions, in necessities, in distresses, (v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:7
verses.text: ) in stripes, in imprisonments, in tumult, in labors, in watchings;" and having shown that the thing was a great good, for "as sorrowful," saith he, "yet always rejoicing; as poor, yet making many rich; as having nothing, and yet possessing all things;" (v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:8
verses.text: ) and having called those things "armor," for "as chastened," saith he, "and not killed:" and having hereby represented God's abundant care and power, for he saith, "that the exceeding greatness of the power may be of God, and not of us;" (c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:9
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:10
verses.text: ) and having recounted his labors, for he saith, "we always bear about His dying;" and that this is a clear demonstration of the Resurrection, for he says, "that the life also of Jesus may be manifested in our mortal flesh;" (c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:11
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:12
verses.text: ) and of what things he was made partaker, and with what he had been entrusted, for "we are ambassadors on behalf of Christ," (c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:13
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:14
verses.text: ) saith he, "as though God were entreating by us;" and of what things he is a minister, namely, "not of the letter, but of the Spirit;" (c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:15
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:16
verses.text: ) and that he was entitled to reverence not only on this account, but also for his trials, for, "Thanks be to God," saith he, "which always causeth us to triumph:" he purposeth now also to rebuke them as not being too well minded towards himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:17
verses.text: But though purposing he does not immediately come upon this, but having his discussion of these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:18
verses.text: For if even from his own good deeds he that rebuketh be entitled to reverence; yet still, when he also displayeth the love, which he bears towards those who are censured, he maketh his speech less offensive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:19
verses.text: Therefore the Apostle also having stepped out of the subject of his own trials and toils and contests, passes on into speaking of his love, and in this way toucheth them to the quick.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:20
verses.text: What then are the indications of his love? "Our mouth is open unto you, O ye Corinthians".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:21
verses.text: And what kind of sign of love is this? or what meaning even have the words at all? 'We cannot endure,' he says, 'to be silent towards you, but are always desiring and longing to speak to and converse with you;' which is the wont of those who love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:22
verses.text: For what grasping of the hands is to the body, that is interchange of language to the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:23
verses.text: And along with this he implies another thing also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:24
verses.text: Of what kind then is this? That 'we discourse unto nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:25
verses.text: ' For since afterwards he proposes to rebuke, he asks forgiveness, using the rebuking them with freedom as itself a proof of his loving them exceedingly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:26
verses.text: Moreover the addition of their name is a mark of great love and warmth and affection; for we are accustomed to be repeating continually the bare names of those we love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:27
verses.text: "Our heart is enlarged".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:28
verses.text: For as that which warmeth is wont to dilate; so also to enlarge is the work of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:29
verses.text: For virtue is warm and fervent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:30
verses.text: This both opened the mouth of Paul and enlarged his heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:31
verses.text: For, 'neither do I love with the mouth only,' saith he, 'but I have also a heart in union.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:32
verses.text: Therefore I speak with openness, with my whole mouth, with my whole mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:33
verses.text: ' For nothing is wider than was Paul's heart which loved all the faithful with all the vehemence that one might bear towards the object of his affection; this his love not being divided and therefore weakened, but abiding in full entireness with each.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:34
verses.text: And what marvel that this was so in the case of the faithful, seeing that even in that of the unfaithful, the heart of Paul embraced the whole world? Therefore he said not 'I love you,' but with more emphasis, "Our mouth is open, our heart is enlarged," we have you all within it, and not this merely, but with much largeness of room.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:35
verses.text: For he that is beloved walketh with great unrestraint within the heart of him that loveth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:36
verses.text: Wherefore he saith, "Ye are not straitened in us, but ye are straightened in your own affections".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:37
verses.text: And this reproof, see it administered with forbearance, as is the wont of such as love exceedingly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:38
verses.text: He did not say, 'ye do not love us,' but, 'not in the same measure,' for he does not wish to touch them too sensibly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:39
verses.text: And indeed every where one may see how he is inflamed toward the faithful, by selecting words out of every Epistle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:40
verses.text: For to the Romans he saith, "I long to see you;" and, "oftentimes I purposed to come unto you;" and, "If by any means now at length I may be prospered to come unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:41
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:42
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:44
verses.text: ) And to the Galatians, he says, "My little children of whom I am again in travail".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:45
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:46
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:47
verses.text: ) To the Ephesians again, "For this cause I bow my knees" for you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:48
verses.text: (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:49
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:50
verses.text: ) And to the Philippians, "For what is my hope, or joy, or crown of rejoicing? are not even ye?" and he said that he bare them about in his heart, and in his bonds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:51
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:52
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:53
verses.text: ) And to the Colossians, "But I would that ye knew greatly I strive for you, and for as many as have not seen my face in the flesh; that your hearts might be comforted".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:54
verses.text: (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:55
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:57
verses.text: ) And to the Thessalonians, "As when a nurse cherisheth her children, even so being affectionately desirous of you, we were well pleased to impart unto you, not the Gospel only, but also our own souls".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:58
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:59
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:61
verses.text: ) And to Timothy, "Remembering thy tears, that I may be filled with joy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:62
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:63
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:64
verses.text: ) And to Titus, "To my beloved son; (Titus i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:65
verses.text: ) and to Philemon, in like manner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:66
verses.text: (Philem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:67
verses.text: ) And to the Hebrews too, he writes many other such-like things, and ceaseth not to beseech them, and say, "A very little while, and he that cometh shall come, and shall not tarry:" (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:68
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:69
verses.text: ) just like a mother to her pettish children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:70
verses.text: And to themselves he says, "Ye are not straitened in us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:71
verses.text: But he does not say only that he loves, but also that he is beloved by them, in order that hereby also he may the rather win them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:72
verses.text: And indeed testifying to this in them, he says, Titus came and "told us your longing, your mourning, your zeal".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:73
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:74
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:75
verses.text: ) And to the Galatians, "If possible, ye would have plucked out your eyes and given them to me," (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:76
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:77
verses.text: ) And to the Thessalonians, "What manner of entering in we had unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:78
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:79
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:80
verses.text: ) And to Timothy also, "Remembering thy tears, that I may be filled with joy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:81
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:82
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:83
verses.text: ) And also throughout his Epistles one may find him bearing this testimony to the disciples, both that he loved and that he is loved, not however equally.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:84
verses.text: And here he saith, "Though the more abundantly I love you, the less I be loved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:85
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:86
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:87
verses.text: ) This, however, is near the end; but at present more vehemently, "Ye are not straitened in us, but ye are straitened in your own affections," 'You receive one,' he says, 'but I a whole city, and so great a population.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:88
verses.text: ' And he said not, 'ye do not receive us,' but, 'ye are straitened;' implying indeed the same thing but with forbearance and without touching them too deeply.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:89
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:90
verses.text: "Now for a recompense in like kind (I speak as unto my children,) be ye also enlarged".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:91
verses.text: And yet it is not an equal return, first to be loved, afterwards to love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:92
verses.text: For even if one were to contribute that which is equal in amount, he is inferior in that he comes to it second.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:93
verses.text: 'But nevertheless I am not going to reckon strictly,' saith he, 'and if ye after having received the first advances from me do but show forth the same amount, I am well-pleased and contented.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:94
verses.text: ' Then to show that to do this was even a debt, and that what he said was void of flattery, he saith, "I speak as unto my children".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:95
verses.text: What meaneth, "as unto my children?" 'I ask no great thing, if being your father I wish to be loved by you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:96
verses.text: ' And see wisdom and moderation of mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:97
verses.text: He mentions not here his dangers on their behalf, and his labors, and his deaths, although he had many to tell of: (so free from pride is he!) but his love: and on this account he claims to be loved; 'because,' saith he, 'I was your father, because I exceedingly burn for you,' for it is often especially offensive to the person beloved when a man sets forth his benefits to him; for he seems to reproach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:98
verses.text: Wherefore Paul doth not this; but, 'like children, love your father,' saith he, which rather proceeds from instinct; and is the due of every father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:99
verses.text: Then that he may not seem to speak these things for his own sake, he shows that it is for their advantage even that he invites this love from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:100
verses.text: And therefore he added,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:101
verses.text: "Be ye not unequally yoked together with unbelievers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:102
verses.text: He said not, 'Intermix not with unbelievers,' but rather dealing sharply with them, as transgressing what was right, 'Suffer not yourselves to turn aside,' saith he, "For what fellowship have righteousness and iniquity?" Here in what follows he institutes a comparison, not between his own love and theirs who corrupt them, but between their nobleness and the others' dishonor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:103
verses.text: For thus his discourse became more dignified and more beseeming himself, and would the rather win them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:104
verses.text: Just as if one should say to a son that despised his parents, and gave himself up to vicious persons, 'What art thou doing, child? Dost thou despise thy father and prefer impure men filled with ten thousand vices? Knowest thou not how much better and more respectable thou art than they?' For so he detaches him more readily from their society than if he should express admiration of his father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:105
verses.text: For were he to say indeed, 'Knowest thou not how much thy father is better than they?' he will not produce so much effect; but if, leaving mention of his father, he bring himself before them, saying, 'Knowest thou not who thou art and what they are? Dost thou not bear in mind thine own high birth and gentle blood, and their infamy? For what communion hast thou with them, those thieves, those adulterers, those impostors?' by elevating him with these praises of himself, he will quickly prepare him to break off from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:106
verses.text: For the former address indeed, he will not entertain with overmuch acceptance, because the exalting of his father is an accusation of himself, when he is shown to be not only grieving a father, but such a father; but in this case he will have no such feeling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:107
verses.text: For none would choose not to be praised, and therefore, along with these praises of him that hears, the rebuke becometh easy of digestion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:108
verses.text: For the listener is softened, and is filled with high thoughts, and disdains the society of those persons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:109
verses.text: But not this only is the point to be admired in him that thus he prosecuted his comparison, but that he imagined another thing also still greater and more astounding; in the first place, prosecuting his speech in the form of interrogation, which is proper to things that are clear and admitted, and then dilating it by the quick succession and multitude of his terms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:110
verses.text: For he employs not one or two or three only, but several.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:111
verses.text: Add to this that instead of the persons he employs the names of the things, and he delineates here high virtue and there extreme vice; and shows the difference between them to be great and infinite so as not even to need demonstration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:112
verses.text: "For what fellowship," saith he, "have righteousness and iniquity?"  "And what communion hath light with darkness?" (v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:114
verses.text: ) "And what concord hath Christ with Beliar? Or what portion hath a believer with an unbeliever? Or what agreement hath a temple of God with idols?"  Seest thou how he uses the bare names, and how adequately to his purpose of dissuasion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:115
verses.text: For he did not say, 'neglect of righteousness,' but what was stronger iniquity; nor did he say those who are of the light, and those who are of the darkness; but he uses opposites themselves which can not admit of their opposites, 'light and darkness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:116
verses.text: ' Nor said he those who are of Christ, with those who are of the devil; but, which was far wider apart, Christ and Beliar, so calling that apostate one, in the Hebrew tongue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:117
verses.text: "Or what portion hath a believer with an unbeliever?" Here, at length, that he may not seem simply to be going through a censure of vice and an encomium of virtue, he mentions persons also without particularizing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:118
verses.text: And he said not, 'communion,' but spoke of the rewards, using the term "portion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:119
verses.text: What agreement hath a temple of God with idols?"  "For ye are a temple of the living God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:120
verses.text: Now what he says is this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:121
verses.text: Neither hath your King aught in common with him, "for what concord hath Christ with Beliar?" nor have the things aught in common, "for what communion hath light with darkness?" Therefore neither should ye.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:122
verses.text: And first he mentions their king and then themselves; by this separating them most effectually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:123
verses.text: Then having said, "a temple of God with idols," and having declared, "For ye are a temple of the living God," he is necessitated to subjoin also the testimony of this to show that the thing is no flattery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:124
verses.text: For he that praises except he also exhibit proof, even appears to flatter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:125
verses.text: What then is his testimony? For,  "I will dwell in them," saith he, "and walk in them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:126
verses.text: I will dwell in," as in temples, "and walk in them," signifying the more abundant attachment to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:127
verses.text: "And they shall be my people and I will be their God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:128
verses.text: 'What?' saith he, 'Dost thou bear God within thee, and runnest unto them? God That hath nothing in common with them? And in what can this deserve forgiveness? Bear in mind Who walketh, Who dwelleth in thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:129
verses.text: '  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:130
verses.text: "Wherefore come ye out from among them, and be ye separate, and touch no unclean thing; and I will receive you, saith the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:131
verses.text: And He said not, 'Do not unclean things;' but, requiring greater strictness, 'do not even touch,' saith he, 'nor go near them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:132
verses.text: ' But what is filthiness of the flesh? Adultery, fornication, lasciviousness of every kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:133
verses.text: And what of the soul? Unclean thoughts, as gazing with unchaste eyes, malice, deceits, and whatsoever such things there be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:134
verses.text: He wishes then that they should be clean in both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:135
verses.text: Seest thou how great the prize? To be delivered from what is evil, to be made one with God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:136
verses.text: Hear also what follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:137
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:138
verses.text: "And I will be to you a Father, and ye shall be to me sons and daughters, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:139
verses.text: Seest thou how from the beginning the Prophet fore-announceth our present high birth, the Regeneration by grace?  Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:140
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:141
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:142
verses.text: "Having therefore these promises, beloved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:143
verses.text: What promises? That we should be temples of God, sons and daughters, have Him indwelling, and walking in us, be His people, have Him for our God and Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:144
verses.text: "Let us cleanse ourselves from all defilement of flesh and spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:145
verses.text: Let us neither touch unclean things, for this is cleansing of the flesh; nor things which defile the soul, for this is cleansing of the spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:146
verses.text: Yet he is not content with this only, but adds also,  "Perfecting holiness in the fear of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:147
verses.text: For not to touch the unclean thing doth not make clean, but there needeth something else besides to our becoming holy; earnestness, heedfulness, piety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:148
verses.text: And he well said, "In the fear of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:149
verses.text: For it is possible to perfect chasteness, not in the fear of God but for vainglory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:150
verses.text: And along with this he implies yet another thing, by saying, "In the fear of God;" the manner, namely, whereafter holiness may be perfected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:151
verses.text: For if lust be even an imperious thing, still if thou occupy its territory with the fear of God, thou hast stayed its frenzy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:152
verses.text: Now by holiness here he means not chastity alone, but the freedom from every kind of sin, for he is holy that is pure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:153
verses.text: Now one will become pure, not if he be free from fornication only, but if from covetousness also, and envy, and pride, and vainglory, yea especially from vainglory which in every thing indeed it behoveth to avoid, but much more in almsgiving; since neither will it be almsgiving, if it have this distemper, but display and cruelty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:154
verses.text: For when thou dost it not out of mercy, but from parade, such deed is not only no alms but even an insult; for thou hast put thy brother to open shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:155
verses.text: Not then the giving money, but the giving it out of mercy, is almsgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:156
verses.text: For people too at the theatres give, both to prostitute boys and to others who are on the stage; but such a deed is not almsgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:157
verses.text: And they too give that abuse the persons of prostitute women; but this is not lovingkindness, but insolent treatment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:158
verses.text: Like this is the vainglorious also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:159
verses.text: For just as he that abuseth the person of the harlot, pays her a price for that abuse; so too dost thou demand a price of him that receiveth of thee, thine insult of him and thine investing him as well as thyself with an evil notoriety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:160
verses.text: And besides this, the loss is unspeakable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:161
verses.text: For just as a wild beast and a mad dog springing upon us might, so doth this ill disease and this inhumanity make prey of our good things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:162
verses.text: For inhumanity and cruelty such a course is; yea, rather more grievous even than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:163
verses.text: For the cruel indeed would not give to him that asked; but thou dost more than this; thou hinderest those that wish to give.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:164
verses.text: For when thou paradest thy giving, thou hast both lowered the reputation of the receiver, and hast pulled back him that was about to give, if he be of a careless mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:165
verses.text: For he will not give to him thenceforth, on the ground of his having already received, and so not being in want; yea he will often accuse him even, if after having received he should draw near to beg, and will think him impudent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:166
verses.text: What sort of almsgiving then is this when thou both shamest thyself and him that receiveth; and also in two ways Him that enjoined it: both because while having Him for a spectator of thine alms, thou seekest the eyes of thy fellow-servants besides Him, and because thou transgressest the law laid down by Him forbidding these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:167
verses.text: I could have wished to carry this out into those other subjects as well, both fasting and prayer, and to show in how many respects vainglory is injurious there also; but I remember that in the discourse before this I left unfinished a certain necessary point.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:168
verses.text: What was the point? I was saying, that the poor have the advantage of the rich in the things of this life, when I discoursed concerning health and pleasure; and this was shown indistinctly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:169
verses.text: Come then, to-day let us show this, that not in the things of this life only, but also in those that are higher, the advantage is with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:170
verses.text: For what leadeth unto a kingdom, riches or poverty? Let us hear the Lord Himself of the heavens saying of those, that "it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of heaven:" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:171
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:172
verses.text: ) but of the poor the contrary, "If thou wilt be perfect, sell that thou hast, and give to the poor; and come, follow Me; and thou shalt have treasure in heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:173
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:174
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:175
verses.text: ) But if ye will, let us see what is said on either side.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:176
verses.text: "Narrow and straitened is the way," He saith, "that leadeth unto life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:177
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:178
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:179
verses.text: ) Who then treadeth the narrow way, he that is in luxury, or that is in poverty; that is independent, or that carrieth ten thousand burdens; the lax and dissolute, or the thoughtful and anxious? But what need of these arguments, when it is best to betake one's self to the persons themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:180
verses.text: Lazarus was poor, yea very poor; and he that passed him by as he lay at his gateway was rich.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:181
verses.text: Which then entered into the kingdom, and was in delights in Abraham's bosom? and which of them was scorched, with not even a drop at his command? But, saith one, 'both many poor will be lost, and many rich will enjoy those unspeakable goods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:182
verses.text: ' Nay rather, one may see the contrary, few rich saved, but of the poor far more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:183
verses.text: For, consider, making accurate measure of the hindrances of riches and the defects of poverty, (or rather, neither of riches nor of poverty are they, but each of those who have riches or poverty; howbeit,) let us at least see which is the more available weapon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:184
verses.text: What defect then doth poverty seem to possess? Lying.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:185
verses.text: And what, wealth? Pride, the mother of evils; which also made the devil a devil, who was not such before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:186
verses.text: Again, "the love of money is a root of all kinds of evil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:187
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:188
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:189
verses.text: ) Which then stands near this root, the rich man, or the poor? Is it not very plainly the rich? For the more things anyone surrounds himself with, he desires so much the more.
