verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:190
verses.text: Vainglory again damages tens of thousands of good deeds, and near this too again the rich man hath his dwelling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:191
verses.text: "But," saith one, "thou mentionest not the evils of the poor man, his affliction, his straits".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:192
verses.text: Nay, but this is both common to the rich, and is his more than the poor man's; so that those indeed which appear to be evils of poverty are common to either: whilst those of riches are riches' only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:193
verses.text: 'But what,' saith one, 'when for want of necessaries the poor man committeth many horrible things?' But no poor man, no, not one, committeth as many horrible things from want, as do the rich for the sake of surrounding themselves with more, and of not losing what stores they have.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:194
verses.text: For the poor man doth not so eagerly desire necessaries as the rich doth superfluities; nor again has he as much strength to put wickedness in practice as the other hath power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:195
verses.text: If then the rich man is both more willing and able, it is quite plain that he will rather commit such, and more of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:196
verses.text: Nor is the poor man so much afraid in respect of hunger, as the rich trembleth and is anxious in respect of the loss of what he has, and because he has not yet gotten all men's possessions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:197
verses.text: Since then he is near both vainglory and arrogance, and the love of money, the root of all evils, what hope of salvation shall he have except he display much wisdom? And how shall he walk the narrow way? Let us not therefore carry about the notions of the many, but examine into the facts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 14:198
verses.text: For how is it not absurd that in respect to money, indeed, we do not trust to others, but refer this to figures and calculation; but in calculating upon facts we are lightly drawn aside by the notions of others; and that too, though we possess an exact balance, and square and rule for all things, the declaration of the divine laws? Wherefore I exhort and entreat you all, disregard what this man and that man thinks about these things, and inquire from the Scriptures all these things; and having learnt what are the true riches, let us pursue after them that we may obtain also the eternal good things; which may we all obtain, through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom, to the Father and the Holy Spirit, be glory, might, and honor, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:1
verses.text: Homily XIV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:3
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:4
verses.text: ,  Open your hearts to us: we wronged no man, we corrupted no man, we took advantage of no man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:5
verses.text: I say it not to condemn you; for l have said before, as I have also declared above, that ye are in our hearts to die together and live together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:6
verses.text: Again he raiseth the discourse about love, mitigating the harshness of his rebuke.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:7
verses.text: For since he had convicted and reproached them as being beloved indeed, yet not loving in an equal degree, but breaking away from his love and mixing up with other pestilent fellows; again he softens the vehemence of his rebuke, saying, "Make room for us," that is, "love us;" and prays to receive a favor involving no burden, and advantaging them that confer above them that receive it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:8
verses.text: And he said not, 'love,' but with a stronger appeal to their pity, "make room for".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:9
verses.text: 'Who expelled us?' saith he: 'Who cast us out of your hearts? How come we to be straitened in you?' for since he said above, "Ye are straitened in your affections;" here declaring it more clearly, he said, "make room for us:" in this way also again winning them to himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:10
verses.text: For nothing doth so produce love as for the beloved to know that he that loveth him exceedingly desireth his love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:11
verses.text: "We wronged no man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:12
verses.text: See how again he does not mention the benefits done by him, but frameth his speech in another way, so as to be both less offensive and more cutting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:13
verses.text: And at the same time he also alludes to the false apostles, saying, "We wronged no man, we corrupted no man, we defrauded no man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:14
verses.text: What is "we corrupted?" That is, we beguiled no man; as he says elsewhere also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:15
verses.text: "Lest by any means, as the serpent beguiled Eve, so your minds should be corrupted".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:16
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:17
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:18
verses.text: )  "We defrauded no man;" we plundered, plotted against no man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:19
verses.text: And he for the present forbears to say, 'we benefited you in such and such ways;' but framing his language so as more to shame them, "We wronged no man," he says; as much as saying, 'Even had we in no wise benefited you, not even so ought ye to turn away from us; for ye have nothing to lay to our charge, either small or great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:20
verses.text: ' Then, for he felt the heaviness of his rebuke, he tempers it again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:21
verses.text: And he was neither silent altogether, for so he would not have aroused them; nor yet did he let the harshness of his language go unmodified, for so he would have wounded them too much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:22
verses.text: And what says he?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:23
verses.text: "I say it not to condemn you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:24
verses.text: How is this evident? "For I have said before," he adds, "that ye are in our hearts to die and live with you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:25
verses.text: This is the greatest affection, when even though treated with contempt, he chooseth both to die and live with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:26
verses.text: 'For neither are ye merely in our hearts,' he says, 'but in such sort as I said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:27
verses.text: For it is possible both to love and to shun dangers, but we do not thus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:28
verses.text: ' And behold here also wisdom unspeakable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:29
verses.text: For he spake not of what had been done for them, that he might not seem to be again reproaching them, but he promiseth for the future.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:30
verses.text: 'For should it chance,' saith he, 'that danger should invade, for your sakes I am ready to suffer every thing; and neither death nor life seemeth aught to me in itself, but in whichever ye be, that is to me more desirable, both death than life and life than death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:31
verses.text: ' Howbeit, dying indeed is manifestly a proof of love; but living, who is there that would not choose, even of those who are not friends? Why then does the Apostle mention it as something great? Because it is even exceeding great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:32
verses.text: For numbers indeed sympathize with their friends when they are in misfortune, but when they are in honor rejoice not with, but envy, them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:33
verses.text: 'But not so we; but whether ye be in calamity, we are not afraid to share your ill fortune; or whether ye be prosperous, we are not wounded with envy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:34
verses.text: '   Then after he had continually repeated these things, saying, "Ye are not straitened in us;" and, "Ye are straitened in your own affections;" and, "make room for us;" and, "Be ye also enlarged;" and, "We wronged no man;" and all these things seemed to be a condemnation of them: observe how he also in another manner alleviates this severity by saying, "Great is my boldness of speech towards you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:35
verses.text: 'Therefore I venture upon such things,' he says, 'not to condemn you by what I say, but out of my great boldness of speech,' which also farther signifying, he said, "Great is my glorying on your behalf".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:36
verses.text: 'For think not indeed,' he saith, 'that because I thus speak, I speak as though I had condemned you altogether; (for I am exceedingly proud of, and glory in, you;) but both out of tender concern and a desire that you should make greater increase unto virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:37
verses.text: ' And so he said to the Hebrews also after much rebuke; "But we are persuaded better things of you, and things that accompany salvation, though we thus speak: and we desire that each one of you may show the same diligence to the fullness of hope even to the end".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:38
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:39
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:41
verses.text: ) So indeed here also, "Great is my glorying on your behalf".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:42
verses.text: 'We glory to others of you,' he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:43
verses.text: Seest thou what genuine comfort he has given? 'And,' he saith, 'I do not simply glory, but also, greatly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:44
verses.text: ' Accordingly he added these words; "I am filled with comfort".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:45
verses.text: What comfort? 'That coming from you; because that ye, having been reformed, comforted me by your conduct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:46
verses.text: ' This is the test of one that loveth, both to complain of not being loved and to fear lest he should inflict pain by complaining immoderately.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:47
verses.text: Therefore he says, "I am filled with comfort, I overflow with joy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:48
verses.text: 'But these expressions,' saith one, 'seem to contradict the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:49
verses.text: ' They do not do so, however, but are even exceedingly in harmony with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:50
verses.text: For these procure for the former a favorable reception; and the praise which they convey makes the benefit of those rebukes more genuine, by quietly abstracting what was painful in them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:51
verses.text: Wherefore he uses these expressions, but with great genuineness and earnestness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:52
verses.text: For he did not say, 'I am filled with joy;' but, "I abound;" or rather, not "abound" either, but "superabound;" in this way also again showing his yearning, that even though he be so loved as to rejoice and exult, he does not yet think himself loved as he ought to be loved, nor to have received full payment; so insatiable was he out of his exceeding love of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:53
verses.text: For the joy it brings to be loved in any degree by those one passionately loves, is great by reason of our loving them exceedingly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:54
verses.text: So that this again was a proof of his affection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:55
verses.text: And of the comfort indeed, he saith, "I am filled;" 'I have received what was owing to me;' but of the joy, "I superabound;" that is, 'I was desponding about you; but ye have sufficiently excused yourselves and supplied comfort: for ye have not only removed the ground of my sorrow, but have even increased joy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:56
verses.text: ' Then showing its greatness, he not only declares it by saying, "I superabound in joy," but also by adding, "in all our affliction".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:57
verses.text: 'For so great was the delight arising to us on your account that it was not even dimmed by so great tribulation, but through the excess of its own greatness it overcame the sorrows that had hold of us, and suffered us not to feel the sense of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:58
verses.text: '  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:59
verses.text: "For even when we were come into Macedonia, our flesh had no relief".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:60
verses.text: For since he said, "our tribulation;" he both explains of what sort it was, and magnifies it by his words, in order to show that the consolation and joys received from them was great, seeing it had repelled so great a sorrow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:61
verses.text: "But we were afflicted on every side".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:62
verses.text: How on every side? for "without were fightings," from the unbelievers; "within were fears;" because of the weak among the believers, lest they should be drawn aside.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:63
verses.text: For not amongst the Corinthians only did these things happen, but elsewhere also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:64
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:65
verses.text: "Nevertheless He that comforteth the lowly comforted us by the coming of Titus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:66
verses.text: For since he had testified great things of them in what he said, that he may not seem to be flattering them he cites as witness Titus the brother, who had come from them to Paul after the first Epistle to declare unto him the particulars of their amendment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:67
verses.text: But consider, I pray you, how in every place he maketh a great matter of the coming of Titus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:68
verses.text: For he saith also before, "Furthermore when I came to Troas for the Gospel, I had no relief for my spirit because I found not Titus my brother;" (c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:69
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:71
verses.text: ) and in this place again "we were comforted," he saith, "by the coming of Titus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:72
verses.text: For he is desirous also of establishing the man in their confidence and of making him exceedingly dear to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:73
verses.text: And observe how he provides for both these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:74
verses.text: For by saying on the one hand, "I had no relief for my spirit," he showeth the greatness of his virtue; and by saying on the other, that, in our tribulation his coming sufficed unto comfort; yet "not by his coming only, but also by the comfort wherewith he was comforted in you," he endeareth the man unto the Corinthians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:75
verses.text: For nothing doth so produce and cement friendships as the saying something sound and favorable of any one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:76
verses.text: And such he testifies Titus did; when he says that 'by his coming he hath given us wings with pleasure; such things did he report of you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:77
verses.text: On this ground his coming made us glad.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:78
verses.text: For we were delighted not "only by his coming, but also for the comfort wherewith he was comforted in you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:79
verses.text: And how was he comforted? By your virtue, by your good deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:80
verses.text: ' Wherefore also he adds,  "While he told us your longing, your mourning, your zeal for me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:81
verses.text: 'These things made him glad,' he says, 'these things comforted him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:82
verses.text: ' Seest thou how he shows that he also is an earnest lover of theirs, seeing he considers their good report as a consolation to himself; and when he was come, gloried, as though on account of his own good things, unto Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:83
verses.text: And observe with what warmth of expression he reporteth these things, "Your longing, your mourning, your zeal".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:84
verses.text: For it was likely that they would mourn and grieve why the blessed Paul was so much displeased, why he had kept away from them so long.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:85
verses.text: And therefore he did not say simply tears, but "mourning;" nor desire, but "longing;" nor anger, but "zeal;" and again "zeal toward him," which they displayed both about him that had committed fornication and about those who were accusing him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:86
verses.text: 'For,' saith he, 'ye were inflamed and blazed out on receiving my letters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:87
verses.text: ' On these accounts he abounds in joy, on these accounts he is filled with consolation, because he made them feel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:88
verses.text: It seems to me, however, that these things are said not only to soften what has gone before, but also in encouragement of those who had acted in these things virtuously.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:89
verses.text: For although I suppose that some were obnoxious to those former accusations and unworthy of these praises; nevertheless, he doth not distinguish them, but makes both the praises and the accusations common, leaving it to the conscience of his hearers to select that which belongs to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:90
verses.text: For so both the one would be void of offence, and the other lead them on to much fervor of mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:91
verses.text: Such also now should be the feelings of those who are reprehended; thus should they lament and mourn; thus yearn after their teachers; thus, more than fathers, seek them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:92
verses.text: For by those indeed living cometh, but by these good living.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:93
verses.text: Thus ought they to bear the rebukes of their fathers, thus to sympathize with their rulers on account of those that sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:94
verses.text: For it does not rest all with them, but with you also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:95
verses.text: For if he that hath sinned perceives that he was rebuked indeed by his father, but flattered by his brethren; he becometh more easy of mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:96
verses.text: But when the father rebukes, be thou too angry as well, whether as concerned for thy brother or as joining in thy father's indignation; only be the earnestness thou showest great; and mourn, not that he was rebuked, but that he sinned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:97
verses.text: But if I build up and thou pull down, what profit have we had but labor? (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:98
verses.text: xxxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:99
verses.text: ) Yea, rather, thy loss stops not here, but thou bringest also punishment on thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:100
verses.text: For he that hindereth the wound from being healed is punished not less than he that inflicted it, but even more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:101
verses.text: For it is not an equal offence to wound and to hinder that which is wounded from being healed; for this indeed necessarily gendereth death, but that not necessarily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:102
verses.text: Now I have spoken thus to you; that ye may join in the anger of your rulers whenever they are indignant justly; that when ye see any one rebuked, ye may all shun him more than does the teacher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:103
verses.text: Let him that hath offended fear you more than his rulers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:104
verses.text: For if he is afraid of his teacher only, he will readily sin: but if he have to dread so many eyes, so many tongues, he will be in greater safety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:105
verses.text: For as, if we do not thus act, we shall suffer the extremest punishment; so, if we perform these things, we shall partake of the gain that accrues from his reformation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:106
verses.text: Thus then let us act; and if any one shall say, 'be humane towards thy brother, this is a Christian's duty;' let him be taught, that he is humane who is angry with him, not he who sets him at ease prematurely and alloweth him not even to come to a sense of his transgression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:107
verses.text: For which, tell me, pities the man in a fever and laboring under delirium, he that lays him on his bed, and binds him down, and keeps him from meats and drinks that are not fit for him; or he that allows him to glut himself with strong drink, and orders him to have his liberty, and to act in every respect as one that is in health? Does not this person even aggravate the distemper, the man that seemeth to act humanely, whereas the other amends it? Such truly ought our decision to be in this case also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:108
verses.text: For it is the part of humanity, not to humor the sick in every thing nor to flatter their unseasonable desires.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:109
verses.text: No one so loved him that committed fornication amongst the Corinthians, as Paul who commandeth to deliver him to Satan; no one so hated him as they that applaud and court him; and the event showed it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:110
verses.text: For they indeed both puffed him up and increased his inflammation; but the Apostle both lowered it and left him not until he brought him to perfect health.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:111
verses.text: And they indeed added to the existing mischief, he eradicated even that which existed from the first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:112
verses.text: These laws, then, of humanity let us learn also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:113
verses.text: For if thou seest a horse hurrying down a precipice, thou appliest a bit and holdest him in with violence and lashest him frequently; although this is punishment, yet the punishment itself is the mother of safety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:114
verses.text: Thus act also in the case of those that sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:115
verses.text: Bind him that hath transgressed until he have appeased God; let him not go loose, that he be not bound the faster by the anger of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:116
verses.text: If I bind, God doth not chain; if I bind not, the indissoluble chains await him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:117
verses.text: "For if we judged ourselves, we should not be judged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:118
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:119
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:120
verses.text: ) Think not, then, that thus to act cometh of cruelty and inhumanity; nay, but of the highest gentleness and the most skillful leechcraft and of much tender care.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:121
verses.text: But, saith one, they have been punished for a long time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:122
verses.text: How long? Tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:123
verses.text: A year, and two, and three years? Howbeit, I require not this, length of time, but amendment of soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:124
verses.text: This then show, whether they have been pricked to the heart, whether they have reformed, and all is done: since if there be not this, there is no advantage in the time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:125
verses.text: For neither do we inquire whether the wound has been often bandaged, but whether the bandage has been of any service.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:126
verses.text: If therefore it hath been of service, although in a short time, let it be kept on no longer: but if it hath done no service, even at the end of ten years, let it be still kept on: and let this fix the term of release, the good of him that is bound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 15:127
verses.text: If we are thus careful both of ourselves and of others, and regard not honor and dishonor at the hands of men; but bearing in mind the punishment and the disgrace that is there, and above all the provoking of God, apply with energy the medicines of repentance: we shall both presently arrive at the perfect health, and shall obtain the good things to come; which may all we obtain, through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom, to the Father, with the Holy Spirit, be glory, might, honor, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:1
verses.text: Homily XV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:3
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:4
verses.text: So that though I made you sorry with my letter, I do not regret it, though I did regret.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:5
verses.text: He goes on to apologize for his Epistle, when, (the sin having been corrected,) to treat them tenderly was unattended with danger; and he shows the advantage of the thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:6
verses.text: For he did this indeed even before, when he said, "For out of much affliction and anguish of heart, I wrote unto you: not that ye should be made sorry, but that ye might know the love which I have toward you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:8
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:9
verses.text: ) And he does it also now, establishing this same point in more words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:10
verses.text: And he said not, 'I regretted indeed before, but now I do not regret:' but how? "I regret not now, though I did regret".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:11
verses.text: 'Even if what I wrote,' he says, 'was such as to overstep the due measure of rebuke, and to cause me to regret; still the great advantage which has accrued from them doth not allow me to regret.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:12
verses.text: ' And this he said, not as though he had rebuked them beyond due measure, but to heighten his praises of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:13
verses.text: 'For the amendment ye manifested was so great,' saith he, 'that even if I did happen to smite you too severely insomuch that I even condemned myself, I praise myself now from the result.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:14
verses.text: ' Just as with little children, when they have undergone a painful remedy, such as an incision, or cautery, or bitter physic, afterwards we are not afraid to sooth them; so also doth Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:15
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:17
verses.text: "For I see that that epistle made you sorry, though but for a season.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:18
verses.text: Now I rejoice not that ye were made sorry, but that ye were made sorry unto repentance".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:19
verses.text: Having said, "I do not regret," he tells the reason also; alleging the good that resulted from his letter; and skillfully excusing himself by saying, "though but for a season".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:20
verses.text: For truly that which was painful was brief, but that which was profitable was perpetual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:21
verses.text: And what indeed followed naturally was to say, 'even though it grieved you for a season, yet it made you glad and benefited you forever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:22
verses.text: ' But he doth not say this: but before mentioning the gain he passes again to his praises of them, and the proof of his own concern for them, saying, "Now I rejoice, not that ye were made sorry," ('for what gain came to me from you being made sorry?) "but that ye were made sorry unto repentance," that the sorrow brought some gain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:23
verses.text: ' For a father also when he sees his son under the knife rejoiceth not that he is being pained, but that he is being cured; so also doth this man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:24
verses.text: But observe how he transfers all that was well achieved in the matter unto themselves; and lays whatever was painful to the account of the Epistle, saying, "It made you sorry for a season;" whilst the benefit that resulted from it he speaks of as their own good achieving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:25
verses.text: For he said not, 'The Epistle corrected you,' although this was the case; but, "ye sorrowed unto repentance".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:26
verses.text: "For ye were made sorry after a godly sort, that ye might suffer loss by us in nothing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:27
verses.text: Seest thou wisdom unspeakable? 'For had we not done this,' he says, 'we had done you damage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:28
verses.text: ' And he affirms that indeed which was well achieved to be theirs, but the damage his own, if indeed he had been silent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:29
verses.text: For if they are likely to be corrected by a sharp rebuke, then, if we did not sharply rebuke, we should have done you damage; and the injury would not be with you alone, but also with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:30
verses.text: For just as he that gives not to the merchant what is necessary for his voyage, he it is that causeth the damage; so also we, if we did not offer you that occasion of repentance, should have wrought you damage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:31
verses.text: Seest thou that the not rebuking those that sin is a damage both to the master and to the disciple?   Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:32
verses.text: "For godly sorrow worketh repentance unto salvation, a repentance which bringeth no regret".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:33
verses.text: 'Therefore,' he says, 'though I did regret before I saw the fruit and the gain, how great they were I do not regret now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:34
verses.text: ' For such a thing is godly sorrow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:35
verses.text: And then he philosophizeth about it, showing that sorrow is not in all cases a grievous thing, but when it is worldly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:36
verses.text: And what is worldly? If thou be in sorrow for money, for reputation, for him that is departed, all these are worldly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:37
verses.text: Wherefore also they work death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:38
verses.text: For he that is in sorrow for reputation's sake feeleth envy and is driven oftentimes to perish: such sorrow was that which Cain sorrowed, such Esau.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:39
verses.text: By this worldly sorrow then he meaneth that which is to the harm of those that sorrow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:40
verses.text: For only in respect to sins is sorrow a profitable thing; as is evident in this way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:41
verses.text: He that sorroweth for loss of wealth repaireth not that damage; he that sorroweth for one deceased raiseth not the dead to life again; he that sorroweth for a sickness, not only is not made well but even aggravates the disease: he that sorroweth for sins, he alone attains some advantage from his sorrow, for he maketh his sins wane and disappear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:42
verses.text: For since the medicine has been prepared for this thing, in this case only is it potent and displays its profitableness; and in the other cases is even injurious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:43
verses.text: 'And yet Cain,' saith one, 'sorrowed because he was not accepted with God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:44
verses.text: ' It was not for this, but because he saw his brother glorious in honor; for had he grieved for this, it behoved him to emulate and rejoice with him; but, as it was, grieving, he showed that his was a worldly sorrow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:45
verses.text: But not so did David, nor Peter, nor any of the righteous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:46
verses.text: Wherefore they were accepted, when grieving either over their own sins or those of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:47
verses.text: And yet what is more oppressive than sorrow? Still when it is after a godly sort, it is better than the joy in the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:48
verses.text: For this indeed ends in nothing; but that "worketh repentance unto salvation, a salvation that bringeth no regret".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:49
verses.text: For what is admirable in it is this that one who had thus sorrowed would never repent, whilst this is an especial characteristic of worldly sorrow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:50
verses.text: For what is more regretted than a true born son? And what is a heavier grief than a death of this sort? But yet those fathers who in the height of their grief endure nobody and who wildly beat themselves, after a time repent because they have grieved immoderately; as having thereby nothing benefitted themselves, but even added to their affliction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:51
verses.text: But not such as this is godly sorrow; but it possesseth two advantages, that of not being condemned in that a man grieves for, and that this sorrow endeth in salvation; of both which that is deprived.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:52
verses.text: For they both sorrow unto harm and after they have sorrowed vehemently condemn themselves, bringing forth this greatest token of having done it unto harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:53
verses.text: But godly sorrow is the reverse of this: wherefore also he said, "worketh repentance unto salvation, a repentance that bringeth no regret".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:54
verses.text: For no one will condemn himself if he have sorrowed for sin, if he have mourned and afflicted himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:55
verses.text: Which also when the blessed Paul hath said he needeth not to adduce from other sources the proof of what he said, nor to bring forward those in the old histories who sorrowed, but he adduceth the Corinthians themselves; and furnishes his proof from what they had done; that along with praises he might both instruct them and the rather win them to himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:56
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:57
verses.text: "For behold," he saith, "this self-same thing, that ye were made sorry after a godly sort, what earnest care it wrought in you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:58
verses.text: 'For not only,' he saith, 'did your sorrow not cast you into that condemning of yourselves, as having acted idly in so doing; but it made you even more careful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:59
verses.text: ' Then he speaks of the certain tokens of that carefulness;  "Yea," what "clearing of yourselves," towards me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:60
verses.text: "Yea, what indignation" against him that had sinned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:61
verses.text: "Yea, what fear".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:62
verses.text: (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:63
verses.text: ) For so great carefulness and very speedy reformation was the part of men who feared exceedingly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:64
verses.text: And that he might not seem to be exalting himself, see how quickly he softened it by saying,  "Yea, what longing," that towards me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:65
verses.text: "Yea, what zeal," that on God's behalf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:66
verses.text: "Yea, what avenging:" for ye also avenged the laws of God that had been outraged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:67
verses.text: "In every thing ye approved yourselves to be pure in the matter".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:68
verses.text: Not only by not having perpetrated, for this was evident before, but also by not consenting unto it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:69
verses.text: For since he said in the former Epistle, "and ye are puffed up;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:70
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:71
verses.text: ) he also says here, 'ye have cleared yourselves of this suspicion also; not only by not praising, but also by rebuking and being indignant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:72
verses.text: '   Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:73
verses.text: "So although I wrote unto you," I wrote "not for his cause that did the wrong, nor for his cause that suffered the wrong".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:74
verses.text: For that they might not say, Why then dost thou rebuke us if we were "clear in the matter?" setting himself to meet this even further above, and disposing of it beforehand, he said what he said, namely, "I do not regret, though I did regret".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:75
verses.text: 'For so far,' says he, 'am I from repenting now of what I wrote then, that I repented then more than I do now when ye have approved yourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:76
verses.text: ' Seest thou again his vehemence and earnest contention, how he has turned around what was said unto the very opposite.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:77
verses.text: For what they thought would have made him recant in confusion as having rebuked them hastily, by reason of their amendment; that he uses as a proof that it was right in him to speak freely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:78
verses.text: For neither does he refuse afterwards to humor them fearlessly, when he finds he can do this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:79
verses.text: For he that said farther above such things as these, "He that is joined to an harlot is one body," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:80
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:81
verses.text: ) and, "Deliver such an one to Satan for the destruction of the flesh," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:82
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:83
verses.text: ) and, "Every sin that a man doeth is without the body," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:84
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:85
verses.text: ) and such like things; how saith he here, "Not for his cause that did the wrong, nor for his cause that suffered the wrong?" Not contradicting, but being even exceedingly consistent with himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:86
verses.text: How consistent with himself? Because it was a very great point with him to show the affection he bore towards them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:87
verses.text: He does not therefore discard concern for him, but shows at the same time, as I said, the love he had for them, and that a greater fear agitated him, namely for the whole Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:88
verses.text: For he had feared lest the evil should eat further, and advancing on its way should seize upon the whole Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:89
verses.text: Wherefore also he said, "A little leaven leaveneth the whole lump".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:90
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:91
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:92
verses.text: ) This however he said at the time; but now that they had well done, he no longer puts it so but differently: and implies indeed the same thing, but manages his expressions more agreeably, saying,  "That our care for you might appear unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:93
verses.text: That is, 'that ye might know how I love you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:94
verses.text: ' Now this is the same thing as the former, but being differently expressed seemed to convey another meaning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:95
verses.text: For to convince thyself that it is the same, unfold his conception and thou wilt perceive the difference to be nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:96
verses.text: 'For because I love you exceedingly,' saith he, 'I was afraid lest ye should suffer any injury from that quarter, and yourselves succeed to that sorrow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:97
verses.text: ' As therefore when he says, "Doth God take care for oxen?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:98
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:99
verses.text: ) he doth not mean that He careth not, (for it is not possible for any existing thing to consist if deserted by the Providence of God:) but that He did not legislate primarily for oxen, so also here he means to say, 'I wrote first indeed on your account, but secondly on his also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:100
verses.text: And I had indeed that love in myself,' he says, 'even independently of mine Epistle: but I was desirous of showing it both to you, and in a word to all, by that writing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:101
verses.text: '  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:102
verses.text: "Therefore we have been comforted".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:103
verses.text: Since we both showed our care for you and have been wholly successful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:104
verses.text: As he said also in another place, "Now we live, if ye stand fast in the Lord;" ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:105
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:106
verses.text: ) and again, "For what is our hope, or joy, or crown of rejoicing? are not even ye?" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:107
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:108
verses.text: ) For this is life, this comfort, this consolation to a teacher possessed of understanding; the growth of his disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:109
verses.text: For nothing doth so declare him that beareth rule as paternal affection for the ruled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:110
verses.text: For begetting alone constitutes not a father; but after begetting, also loving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:111
verses.text: But if where nature is concerned there is so great need of love, much more where grace is concerned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:112
verses.text: In this way were all the ancients distinguished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:113
verses.text: As many, for instance, as obtained a good report amongst the Hebrews, by this were made manifest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:114
verses.text: So was Samuel shown to be great, saying, "But God forbid that I should sin against God in ceasing to pray for you:" ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:115
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:116
verses.text: ) so was David, so Abraham, so Elijah, and so each one of the righteous, those in the New Testament and those in the Old.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:117
verses.text: For so Moses for the sake of those he ruled left so great riches and treasures untold, "choosing to suffer affliction with the people of God," (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:118
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:119
verses.text: ) and before his appointment was leader of the people by his actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:120
verses.text: Wherefore also very foolishly did that Hebrew say to him, "Who made thee a ruler and a judge over us?" (Exod.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:121
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:122
verses.text: ) What sayest thou? Thou seest the actions and doubtest of the title? Just as if one seeing a physician using the knife excellently well, and succoring that limb in the body which was diseased, should say, 'Who made thee a physician and ordered thee to use the knife?' 'Art, my good Sir, and thine own ailment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:123
verses.text: ' So too did his knowledge make him (i-e:, Moses,) what he claimed to be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:124
verses.text: For ruling is an art, not merely a dignity, and an art above all arts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:125
verses.text: For if the rule of those without is an art and science superior to all other, much more this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:126
verses.text: For this rule is as much better than that, as that than the rest; yea, rather, even much more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:127
verses.text: And, if ye will, let us examine this argument more accurately.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:128
verses.text: There is an art of agriculture, of weaving, of building; which are both very necessary and tend greatly to preserve our life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:129
verses.text: For others surely are but ancillary to these; the coppersmith's, the carpenter's, the shepherd's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:130
verses.text: But further, of arts themselves the most necessary of all is the agricultural, which was even that which God first introduced when He had formed man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:131
verses.text: For without shoes and clothes it is possible to live; but without agriculture it is impossible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:132
verses.text: And such they say are the Hamaxobii, the Nomads amongst the Scythians, and the Indian Gymnosophists.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:133
verses.text: For these troubled not themselves with the arts of housebuilding, and weaving, and shoemaking, but need only that of agriculture.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:134
verses.text: Blush ye that have need of those arts that be superfluous, cooks, confectioners, embroiderers, and ten thousand other such people, that ye may live; blush ye that introduce vain refinements into life; blush ye who are unbelievers, before those barbarians who have no need of art.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:135
verses.text: For God made nature exceedingly independent, needing only a few things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:136
verses.text: However, I do not compel you nor lay it down for law that ye should live thus; but as Jacob asked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:137
verses.text: And what did he ask? "If the Lord will give me bread to eat and raiment to put on".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:138
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:139
verses.text: xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:140
verses.text: ) So also Paul commanded, saying, "And having food and covering let us be therewith content".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:141
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:142
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:143
verses.text: ) First then comes agriculture; second, weaving; and third after it, building; and shoemaking last of all; for amongst us at any rate there are many both servants and laborers who live without shoes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:144
verses.text: These, therefore, are the useful and necessary arts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:145
verses.text: Come, then, let us compare them with that of ruling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:146
verses.text: For I have therefore brought forward these that are of all most important, that when it shall have been seen to be superior to them, its victory over the rest may be unquestioned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:147
verses.text: Whereby then shall we show that it is more necessary than all? Because without it there is no advantage in these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:148
verses.text: And if you think good, let us leave mention of the rest and bring on the stage that one which stands higher and is more important than any, that of agriculture.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:149
verses.text: Where then will be the advantage of the many hands of your laborers, if they are at war with one another and plunder one another's goods? For, as it is, the fear of the ruler restrains them and protects that which is wrought by them; but if thou take this away, in vain is their labor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:150
verses.text: But if one examine accurately, he will find yet another rule which is the parent and bond of this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:151
verses.text: What then may this be? That according to which it behoveth each man to control and rule himself, chastising his unworthy passions, but both nourishing and promoting the growth of all the germs of virtue with all care.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:152
verses.text: For there are these species of rule; one, that whereby men rule peoples and states, regulating this the political life; which Paul denoting said, "Let every soul be subject to the higher powers; for there is no power but of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:153
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:154
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:156
verses.text: ) Afterwards to show the advantage of this, he went on to say, that the ruler "is a minister of God for good;" and again, "he is a minister of God, and avenger to execute wrath on him that doeth evil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:157
verses.text: A second there is whereby every one that hath understanding ruleth himself; and this also the Apostle further denoted, saying, "Wouldest thou have no fear of the power? do that which is good;" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:158
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:159
verses.text: ) speaking of him that ruleth himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:160
verses.text: Here, however, there is yet another rule, higher than the political rule.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:161
verses.text: And what is this? That in the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:162
verses.text: And this also itself Paul mentions, saying, "Obey them that have the rule over you and submit to them; for they watch in behalf of your souls as they that shall give account".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:163
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:164
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:165
verses.text: ) For this rule is as much better than the political as heaven is than earth; yea rather, even much more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:166
verses.text: For, in the first place, it considers principally not how it may punish sins committed, but how, they may never be committed at all; next, when committed, not how it may remove the deceased member, but how they may be blotted out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:167
verses.text: And of the things of this life indeed it maketh not much account, but all its transactions are about the things in heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:168
verses.text: "For our citizenship is in heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:169
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:170
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:171
verses.text: ) And our life is here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:172
verses.text: "For our life," saith he, "is hid with Christ in God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:173
verses.text: (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:174
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:175
verses.text: ) And our prizes are there, and our race is for the crowns that be there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:176
verses.text: For this life is not dissolved after the end, but then shineth forth the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:177
verses.text: And therefore, in truth, they who bear this rule have a greater honor committed to their hands, not only than viceroys but even than those themselves who wear diadems, seeing that they mould men in greater, and for greater, things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:178
verses.text: But neither he that pursueth political rule nor he that pursueth spiritual, will be able well to administer it, unless they have first ruled themselves as they ought, and have observed with all strictness the respective laws of their polity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:179
verses.text: For as the rule over the many is in a manner twofold, so also is that which each one exerts over himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:180
verses.text: And again, in this point also the spiritual rule transcends the political, as what we have said proved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:181
verses.text: But one may observe certain also of the arts imitating rule; and in particular, that of agriculture.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:182
verses.text: For just as the tiller of the soil is in a sort a ruler over the plants, clipping and keeping back some, making others grow and fostering them: just so also the best rulers punish and cut off such as are wicked and injure the many; whilst they advance the good and orderly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:183
verses.text: For this cause also the Scripture likeneth rulers to vine-dressers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:184
verses.text: For what though plants utter no cry, as in states the injured do? nevertheless they still show the wrong by their appearance, withering, straitened for room by the worthless weeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:185
verses.text: And like as wickedness is punished by laws, so truly here also by this art both badness of soil and degeneracy and wildness in plants, are corrected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:186
verses.text: For all the varieties of human dispositions we shall find here also, roughness, weakness, timidity, forwardness, steadiness: and some of them through wealth luxuriating unseasonably, and to the damage of their neighbors, and others impoverished and injured; as, for instance, when hedges are raised to luxuriance at the cost of the neighboring plants; when other barren and wild trees, running up to a great height, hinder the growth of those beneath them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:187
verses.text: And like as rulers and kings have those that vex their rule with outrage and war; so also hath the tiller of the soil attacks of wild beasts, irregularity of weather, hail, mildew, great rain, drought, and all such things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:188
verses.text: But these things happen in order that thou mayest constantly look unto the hope of God's aid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:189
verses.text: For the other arts indeed hold their way through the diligence of men as well; but this getteth the better as God determines the balance, and is throughout almost wholly dependent thereupon; and it needeth rains from above, and the admixture of weathers, and, above all, His Providence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:190
verses.text: "For neither is he that planteth any thing, nor he that watereth, but God that giveth the increase".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:191
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:192
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:193
verses.text: )  Here also there is death and life, and throes and procreation, just as with men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:194
verses.text: For here happen instances both of being cut off, and of bearing fruit, and of dying, and of being born (the same that was dead) over again, wherein the earth discourseth to us both variously and clearly of a resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:195
verses.text: For when the root beareth fruit, when the seed shooteth, is not the thing a resurrection? And one might perceive a large measure of God's providence and wisdom involved in this rule, if one go over it point by point.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:196
verses.text: But what I wished to say is that this rule is concerned with earth and plants; but ours with care of souls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:197
verses.text: And great as is the difference between plants and a soul; so great is the superiority of this to that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:198
verses.text: And the rulers of the present life again are as much inferior to that rule, as it is better to have mastery over the willing than the unwilling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:199
verses.text: For this is also a natural rule; for truly in that case every thing is done through fear and by constraint; but here, what is done aright is of choice and purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:200
verses.text: And not in this point alone doth this excel the other, but in that it is not only a rule, but a fatherhood so to speak; for it has the gentleness of a father; and whilst enjoining greater things, still persuades.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:201
verses.text: For the temporal ruler indeed says, 'If thou committest adultery, thou hast forfeited thy life,' but this, shouldst thou look with unchaste eyes, threatens the highest punishments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:202
verses.text: For awful is this judgment court, and for the correction of soul, not of body only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:203
verses.text: As great then as the difference between soul and body, is that which separates this rule again from that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:204
verses.text: And the one indeed sitteth as judge of things that are open; yea, rather, not of all these even, but of such as can be fully proved; and ofttimes moreover, even in these dealeth treacherously, but this court instructeth those that enter it that He that judgeth in our case, will bring forward "all things naked and laid open," (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:205
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:206
verses.text: ) before the common theatre of the world, and that to be hidden will be impossible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:207
verses.text: So that Christianity keeps together this our life far more than temporal laws.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:208
verses.text: For if to tremble about secret sins makes a man safer than to fear for such as are open; and if to call him to account even for those offences which be less doth rather excite him unto virtue, than to punish the graver only; then it is easily seen that this rule, more than all others, welds our life together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:209
verses.text: But, if thou wilt, let us consider also the mode of electing the rulers; for here too thou shalt behold the difference to be great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:210
verses.text: For it is not possible to gain this authority by giving money, but by having displayed a highly virtuous character; and not as unto glory with men and ease unto himself, but as unto toils and labors and the welfare of the many, thus, (I say,) is he that hath been appointed inducted unto this rule.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:211
verses.text: Wherefore also abundant is the assistance he enjoys from the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:212
verses.text: And in that case indeed the rule can go no further than to declare merely what is to be done; but in this it addeth besides the help derived from prayers and from the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:213
verses.text: But further; in that case indeed is not a word about philosophy, nor doth any sit to teach what a soul is, and what the world, and what we are to be hereafter, and unto what things we shall depart hence, and how we shall achieve virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:214
verses.text: Howbeit of contracts and bonds and money, there is much speech, but of those things not a thought; whereas in the Church one may see that these are the subjects of every discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:215
verses.text: Wherefore also with justice may one call it by all these names, a court of justice, and a hospital, and a school of philosophy, and a nursery of the soul, and a training course for that race that leadeth unto heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:216
verses.text: Further, that this rule is also the mildest of all, even though requiring greater strictness, is plain from hence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:217
verses.text: For the temporal ruler if he catch an adulterer straightway punishes him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:218
verses.text: And yet what is the advantage of this? For this is not to destroy the passion, but to send away the soul with its wound upon it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:219
verses.text: But this ruler, when he hath detected, considers not how he shall avenge, but how extirpate the passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:220
verses.text: For thou indeed dost the same thing, as if when there was a disease of the head, thou shouldest not stay the disease, but cut off the head.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:221
verses.text: But I do not thus: but I cut off the disease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:222
verses.text: And I exclude him indeed from mysteries and hallowed precincts; but when I have restored him I receive him back again, at once delivered from that viciousness and amended by his repentance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:223
verses.text: 'And how is it possible,' saith one, 'to extirpate adultery?' It is possible, yea, very possible, if a man comes under these laws.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:224
verses.text: For the Church is a spiritual bath, which wipeth away not filth of body, but stains of soul, by its many methods of repentance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:225
verses.text: For thou, indeed, both if thou let a man go unpunished hast made him worse, and if thou punish hast sent him away uncured: but I neither let him go unpunished, nor punish him, as thou, but both exact a satisfaction which becomes me, and set that right which hath been done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:226
verses.text: Wilt thou learn in yet another way how that thou indeed, though drawing swords and displaying flames to them that offend, workest not any considerable cure; whilst I, without these things, have conducted them to perfect health? But no need have I of arguments or words, but I bring forth earth and sea, and human nature itself, for witnesses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:227
verses.text: And inquire, before this court held its sittings, what was the condition of human affairs; how, not even the names of the good works which now are done, were ever heard of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:228
verses.text: For who braved death? who despised money? who was indifferent to glory? who, fleeing from the turmoils of life, bade welcome to mountains and solitude, the mother of heavenly wisdom? where was at all the name of virginity? For all these things, and more than these, were the good work of this judgment court, the doings of this rule.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:229
verses.text: Knowing these things then, and well understanding that from this proceedeth every benefit of our life, and the reformation of the world, come frequently unto the hearing of the Divine words, and our assemblies here, and the prayers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 16:230
verses.text: For if ye thus order yourselves, ye will be able, having displayed a deportment worthy of heaven, to obtain the promised good things; which may all we obtain, through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, to Whom be glory for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:1
verses.text: Homily XVI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:3
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:4
verses.text: And in your comfort, we joyed the more exceedingly for the joy of Titus, because his spirit hath been refreshed by you all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:5
verses.text: See again how he exalts their praises, and showeth their love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:6
verses.text: For having said, 'I was pleased that my Epistle wrought so much and that ye gained so much,' for "I rejoice," he saith, "not that ye were made sorry, but that ye were made sorry unto repentance;" and having shown his own love, for he saith, "Though I wrote unto you, I wrote not for his cause that did the wrong, nor for his cause that suffered the wrong, but that our care for you might be made manifest to you:" again he mentioneth another sign of their good will, which bringeth them great praise and showeth the genuineness of their affection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:7
verses.text: For, "in your comfort," he saith, "we joyed the more exceedingly for the joy of Titus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:8
verses.text: And yet this is no sign of one that loveth them exceedingly; rejoicing rather for Titus than for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:9
verses.text: 'Yes,' he replies, 'it is, for I joyed not so much for his cause as for yours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:10
verses.text: ' Therefore also he subjoins the reason, saying, "because his bowels were refreshed by you all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:11
verses.text: He said not, 'he,' but "his bowels;" that is, 'his love for you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:12
verses.text: ' And how were they refreshed? "By all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:13
verses.text: For this too is a very great praise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:14
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:15
verses.text: "For if in anything I have gloried to him on your behalf".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:16
verses.text: It is high praise when the teacher boasted, for he saith, "I was not put to shame".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:17
verses.text: I therefore rejoiced, because ye showed yourselves to be amended and proved my words by your deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:18
verses.text: So that the honor accruing to me was twofold; first, in that ye had made progress; next, in that I was not found to fall short of the truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:19
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:20
verses.text: "But as we spake always to you in truth, so our glorying also which I made before Titus was found to be truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:21
verses.text: Here he alludes to something further.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:22
verses.text: As we spake all things among you in truth, (for it is probable that he had also spoken to them much in praise of this man,) so also, what we said of you to Titus has been proved true.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:23
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:24
verses.text: "And his inward affection is more abundant toward you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:25
verses.text: What follows is in commendation of him, as exceedingly consumed with love and attached to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:26
verses.text: And he said not 'his love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:27
verses.text: ' Then that he may not appear to be flattering, he everywhere mentions the causes of his affection; in order that he may, as I said, both escape the imputation of flattery and the more encourage them by making the praise redound unto them, and by showing that it was they who had infused into him the beginning and ground of this so great love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:28
verses.text: For having said, "his inward affection is more abundant toward you;" he added,  "Whilst he remembereth the obedience of you all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:29
verses.text: Now this both shows that Titus was grateful to his benefactors, seeing he had returned, having them all in his heart, and continually remembereth them, and beareth them on his lips and in his mind; and also is a greater distinction to the Corinthians, seeing that so vanquished they sent him away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:30
verses.text: Then he mentions their obedience also, magnifying their zeal: wherefore also he addeth these words,  "How with fear and trembling ye received him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:31
verses.text: Not with love only, but also with excessive honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:32
verses.text: Seest thou how he bears witness to a twofold virtue in them, both that they loved him as a father and had feared him as a ruler, neither for fear dimming love, nor for love relaxing fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:33
verses.text: He expressed this also above, "That ye sorrow after a godly sort, what earnest care it wrought in you; yea what fear, yea what longing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:34
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:35
verses.text: "I rejoice therefore, that in every thing I am of good courage concerning you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:36
verses.text: Seest thou that he rejoiceth more on their account; 'because,' he saith, 'ye have in no particular shamed your teacher, nor show yourselves unworthy of my testimony.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:37
verses.text: ' So that he joyed not so much for Titus' sake, that he enjoyed so great honor; as for their own, that they had displayed so much good feeling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:38
verses.text: For that he may not be imagined to joy rather on Titus' account, observe how in this place also he states the reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:39
verses.text: As then he said above, "If in anything I have gloried to him on your behalf I was not put to shame;" so here also, "In everything I am of good courage concerning you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:40
verses.text: 'Should need require me to rebuke, I have no apprehension of your being alienated; or again to boast, I fear not to be convicted of falsehood; or to praise you as obeying the rein, or as loving, or as full of zeal, I have confidence in you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:41
verses.text: I bade you cut off, and ye did cut off; I bade you receive, and ye did receive; I said before Titus that ye were great and admirable kind of people and knew to reverence teachers: ye proved these things true by your conduct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:42
verses.text: And he learnt these things not so much from me as from you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:43
verses.text: At any rate when he returned, he had become a passionate lover of you: your behavior having surpassed what he had been told.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:44
verses.text: '   Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:45
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:46
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:47
verses.text: "Moreover, brethren, we make known to you the grace of God which hath been given in the Churches of Macedonia".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:48
verses.text: Having encouraged them with these encomiums, he again tries exhortation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:49
verses.text: For on this account he mingled these praises with his rebuke, that he might not by proceeding from rebuke to exhortation make what he had to say ill received; but having soothed their ears, might by this means pave the way for his exhortation.
