verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:50
verses.text: For he purposeth to discourse of alms-giving; wherefore also he saith beforehand, "I rejoice that in everything I am of good courage concerning you;" by their past good works, making them the more ready to this duty also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:51
verses.text: And he said not at once, 'Therefore give alms,' but observe his wisdom, how he draws from a distance and from on high the preparation for his discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:52
verses.text: For he says, "I make known to you the grace of God which hath been given in the Churches of Macedonia".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:53
verses.text: For that they might not be uplifted he calleth what they did "grace;" and whilst relating what others did he worketh greater zeal in them by his encomiums on others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:54
verses.text: And he mentions together two praises of the Macedonians, or rather three; namely, that they bear trials nobly; and that they know how to pity; and that, though poor, they had displayed profuseness in almsgiving, for their property had been also plundered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:55
verses.text: And when he wrote his Epistle to them, it was as signifying this that he said, "For ye became imitators of the Churches of God which are in Judaea, for ye also suffered the same things of your own countrymen, even as they did of the Jews".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:56
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:57
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:58
verses.text: ) Hear what he said afterwards in writing to the Hebrews, "For ye took joyfully the spoiling of your possessions".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:59
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:60
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:61
verses.text: ) But He calls what they did "grace," not in order to keep them humble merely; but both to provoke them to emulation and to prevent what he said from proving invidious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:62
verses.text: Wherefore he also added the name of "brethren" so as to undermine all envious feeling; for he is about to praise them in high-flown terms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:63
verses.text: Listen, at least, to his praises.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:64
verses.text: For having said, "I make known to you the grace of God," he said not 'which hath been given in this or that city,' but praiseth the entire nation, saying, "in the Churches of Macedonia".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:65
verses.text: Then he details also this same grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:66
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:67
verses.text: "How that in much proof of affliction the abundance of their joy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:68
verses.text: Seest thou his wisdom? For he says not first, that which he wishes; but another thing before it, that he may not seem to do this of set purpose, but to arrive at it by a different connection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:69
verses.text: "In much proof of affliction".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:70
verses.text: This was what he said in his Epistle to the Macedonians themselves, "Ye became imitators of the Lord, having received the word in much affliction, with joy of the Holy Ghost;" and again, "From you sounded forth the word of the Lord, not only in Macedonia and Achaia, but also in every place, your faith to God-ward is gone forth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:71
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:72
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:74
verses.text: ) But what is, "in much proof of affliction the abundance of their joy?" Both, he says, happened to them in excess; both the affliction and the joy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:75
verses.text: Wherefore also the strangeness was great that so great an excess of pleasure sprang up to them out of affliction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:76
verses.text: For in truth the affliction not only was not the parent of grief, but it even became unto them an occasion of gladness; and this too, though it was "great".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:77
verses.text: Now this he said, to prepare them to be noble and firm in their trials.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:78
verses.text: For they were not merely afflicted, but so as also to have become approved by their patience: yea rather, he says not by their patience, but what was more than patience, "joy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:79
verses.text: And neither said he "joy" simply, but "abundance of joy," for it sprang up in them, great and unspeakable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:80
verses.text: "And their deep poverty abounded unto the riches of their liberality".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:81
verses.text: Again, both these with excessiveness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:82
verses.text: For as their great affliction gave birth to great joy, yea, "abundance of joy," so their great poverty gave birth to great riches of alms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:83
verses.text: For this he showed, saying, "abounded unto the riches of their liberality".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:84
verses.text: For munificence is determined not by the measure of what is given, but by the mind of those that bestow it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:85
verses.text: Wherefore he nowhere says, 'the richness of the gifts,' but "the riches of their liberality".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:86
verses.text: Now what he says is to this effect; 'their poverty not only was no impediment to their being bountiful, but was even an occasion to them of abounding, just as affliction was of feeling joy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:87
verses.text: For the poorer they were, the more munificent they were and contributed the more readily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:88
verses.text: ' Wherefore also he admires them exceedingly, for that in the midst of so great poverty they had displayed so great munificence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:89
verses.text: For "their deep," that is, 'their great and unspeakable,' "poverty," showed their "liberality".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:90
verses.text: But he said not 'showed,' but "abounded;" and he said not "liberality," but "riches of liberality;" that is, an equipoise to the greatness of their poverty, or rather much outweighing it, was the bountifulness they displayed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:91
verses.text: Then he even explains this more clearly, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:92
verses.text: "For according to their power, I bear witness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:93
verses.text: Trustworthy is the witness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:94
verses.text: "And beyond their power".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:95
verses.text: That is, it "abounded unto the riches of their liberality".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:96
verses.text: Or rather, he makes this plain, not by this expression alone, but also by all that follows; for he says, "of their own accord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:97
verses.text: Lo! yet another excessiveness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:98
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:99
verses.text: "With much intreaty".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:100
verses.text: Lo! yet a third and a fourth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:101
verses.text: "Praying us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:102
verses.text: Lo! even a fifth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:103
verses.text: And when they were in affliction and in poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:104
verses.text: Here are a sixth and seventh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:105
verses.text: And they gave with excessiveness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:106
verses.text: Then since this is what he most of all wishes to provide for in the Corinthians' case, namely, the giving deliberately, he dwells especially upon it, saying, "with much intreaty," and "praying us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:107
verses.text: 'We prayed not them, but they us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:108
verses.text: ' Pray us what? "That the grace and the fellowship in the ministering to the saints".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:109
verses.text: Seest thou how he again exalts the deed, calling it by venerable names.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:110
verses.text: For since they were ambitious of spiritual gifts, he calls it by the name grace that they might eagerly pursue it; and again by that of "fellowship," that they might learn that they receive, not give only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:111
verses.text: 'This therefore they intreated us,' he says, 'that we would take upon us such a ministry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:112
verses.text: '  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:113
verses.text: "And" this, "not as we hoped".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:114
verses.text: This he says with reference both to the amount and to their afflictions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:115
verses.text: 'For we could never have hoped,' he says, 'that whilst in so great affliction and poverty, they would even have urged us and so greatly intreated us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:116
verses.text: ' He showed also their carefulness of life in other respects, by saying,  "But first they gave their own selves to the Lord, and to us by the will of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:117
verses.text: 'For in everything their obedience was beyond our expectations; nor because they showed mercy did they neglect the other virtues,' "but first gave themselves to the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:118
verses.text: What is, "gave themselves to the Lord?" 'They offered up themselves; they showed themselves approved in faith; they displayed much fortitude in their trials, order, goodness, love, in all things both readiness and zeal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:119
verses.text: ' What means, "and to us?" 'They were tractable to the rein, loved, obeyed us; both fulfilling the laws of God and bound unto us by love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:120
verses.text: ' And observe how here also he again shows their earnestness, saying, "gave themselves to the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:121
verses.text: They did not in some things obey God, and in some the world; but in all things Him; and gave themselves wholly unto God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:122
verses.text: For neither because they showed mercy were they filled up with senseless pride, but displaying much lowlymindedness, much obedience, much reverence, much heavenly wisdom, they so wrought their almsdeeds also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:123
verses.text: But what is, "by the will of God?" Since he had said, they "gave themselves to us," yet was it not "to us," after the manner of men, but they did this also according to the mind of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:124
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:125
verses.text: "Insomuch that we exhorted Titus, that as he made a beginning before, so he would also complete in you this grace also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:126
verses.text: And what connexion is there here? Much; and closely bearing on what went before.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:127
verses.text: 'For because we saw them vehement,' he says, 'and fervent in all things, in temptations, in almsgiving, in their love toward us, in the purity otherwise of their life: in order that ye too might be made their equals, we sent Titus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:128
verses.text: ' Howbeit he did not say this, though he implied it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:129
verses.text: Behold excessiveness of love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:130
verses.text: 'For though intreated and desired by them,' he says, 'we were anxious about your state, lest by any means ye should come short of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:131
verses.text: Wherefore also we sent Titus, that by this also being stirred up and put in mind, ye might emulate the Macedonians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:132
verses.text: ' For Titus happened to be there when this Epistle was writing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:133
verses.text: Yet he shows that he had made a beginning in this matter before Paul's exhortation; "that as he had made a beginning before," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:134
verses.text: Wherefore also he bestows great praise on him; for instance, in the beginning of the Epistle; "Because I found not Titus my brother, I had no relief for my spirit:" (chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:135
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:136
verses.text: ) and here all those things which he has said, and this too itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:137
verses.text: For this also is no light praise, the having begun before even: for this evinces a warm and fervent spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:138
verses.text: Wherefore also he sent him, infusing amongst them in this also a very great incentive unto giving, the presence of Titus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:139
verses.text: On this account also he extols him with praises, wishing to endear him more exceedingly to the Corinthians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:140
verses.text: For this too hath a great weight unto persuading, when he who counsels is upon intimate terms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:141
verses.text: And well does he both once and twice and thrice, having made mention of almsgiving, call 'it grace,' now indeed saying, "Moreover, brethren, I make known to you the grace of God bestowed on the Churches of Macedonia;" and now, "they of their own accord, praying us with much intreaty in regard of this grace and fellowship:" and again, "that as he had begun, so he would also finish in you this grace also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:142
verses.text: For this is a great good and a gift of God; and rightly done assimilates us, so far as may be, unto God; for such an one is in the highest sense a man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:143
verses.text: A certain one, at least, giving a model of a man has mentioned this, for "Man," saith he, "is a great thing; and a merciful man is an honorable thing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:144
verses.text: (Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:145
verses.text: xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:146
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:147
verses.text: ) Greater is this gift than to raise the dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:148
verses.text: For far greater is it to feed Christ when an hungered than to raise the dead by the name of Jesus: for in the former case thou doest good to Christ, in the latter He to thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:149
verses.text: And the reward surely comes by doing good, not by receiving good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:150
verses.text: For here indeed, in the case of miracles I mean, thou art God's debtor; in that of almsgiving, thou hast God for a debtor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:151
verses.text: Now it is almsgiving, when it is done with willingness, when with bountifulness, when thou deemest thyself not to give but to receive, when done as if thou wert benefitted, as if gaining and not losing; for so this were not a grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:152
verses.text: For he that showeth mercy on another ought to feel joyful, not peevish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:153
verses.text: For how is it not absurd, if whilst removing another's downheartedness, thou art thyself downhearted? for so thou no longer sufferest it to be alms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:154
verses.text: For if thou art downhearted because thou hast delivered another from downheartedness, thou furnishest an example of extreme cruelty and inhumanity; for it were better not to deliver him, than so to deliver him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:155
verses.text: And why art thou also downhearted at all, O man? for fear thy gold should diminish? If such are thy thoughts, do not give at all: if thou art not quite sure that it is multiplied for thee in heaven, do not bestow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:156
verses.text: But thou seekest the recompense here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:157
verses.text: Wherefore? Let thine alms be alms, and not traffic.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:158
verses.text: Now many have indeed received a recompense even here; but have not so received it, as if they should have an advantage over those who received it not here; but some of them as being weaker than they ought, because they were not so strongly attracted by the things which are there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:159
verses.text: And as those who are greedy, and ill-mannered, and slaves of their bellies, being invited to a royal banquet, and unable to wait till the proper time, just like little children mar their own enjoyment, by taking food beforehand and stuffing themselves with inferior dishes: even so in truth do these who seek for and receive recompense here, diminish their reward there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:160
verses.text: Further, when thou lendest, thou wishest to receive thy principal after a longer interval, and perhaps even not to receive it at all, in order that by the delay thou mayest make the interest greater; but, in this case, dost thou ask back immediately; and that too when thou art about to be not here, but there forever; when thou art about not to be here to be judged, but to render thine account? And if indeed one were building thee mansions where thou wert not going to remain, thou wouldest deem it to be a loss; but now, desirest thou here to be rich, whence possibly thou art to depart even before the evening? Knowest thou not that we live in a foreign land, as though strangers and sojourners? Knowest thou not that it is the lot of sojourners to be ejected when they think not, expect not? which is also our lot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:161
verses.text: For this reason then, whatsoever things we have prepared, we leave here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:162
verses.text: For the Lord does not allow us to receive them and depart, if we have built houses, if we have bought fields, if slaves, if gear, if any other such thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:163
verses.text: But not only does He not allow us to take them and depart hence, but doth not even account to thee the price of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:164
verses.text: For He forwarned thee that thou shouldest not build, nor spend what is other men's but thine own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:165
verses.text: Why therefore, leaving what is thine own, dost thou work and be at cost in what is another's, so as to lose both thy toil and thy wages and to suffer the extremest punishment? Do not so, I beseech thee; but seeing we are by nature sojourners, let us also be so by choice; that we be not there sojourners and dishonored and cast out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:166
verses.text: For if we are set upon being citizens here, we shall be so neither here nor there; but if we continue to be sojourners, and live in such wise as sojourners ought to live in, we shall enjoy the freedom of citizens both here and there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:167
verses.text: For the just, although having nothing, will both dwell here amidst all men's possessions as though they were his own; and also, when he hath departed to heaven, shall see those his eternal habitations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:168
verses.text: And he shall both here suffer no discomfort, (for none will ever be able to make him a stranger that hath every land for his city;) and when he hath been restored to his own country, shall receive the true riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:169
verses.text: In order that we may gain both the things of this life and of that, let us use aright the things we have.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 17:170
verses.text: For so shall we be citizens of the heavens, and shall enjoy much boldness; whereunto may we all attain, through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father with the Holy Ghost, be glory and power for ever, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:1
verses.text: Homily XVII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:3
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:4
verses.text: Therefore that ye abound in every thing; in faith and utterance, and knowledge, and in all earnestness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:5
verses.text: See again his exhortation accompanied with commendations, greater commendations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:6
verses.text: And he said not, 'that ye give,' but "that ye abound; in faith," namely, of the gifts, and "in utterance," the word of wisdom, and "knowledge," namely, of the doctrines, and "in all earnestness," to the attaining of all other virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:7
verses.text: "And in your love," that, namely of which I have before spoken, of which I have also made proof.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:8
verses.text: "That ye may abound in this grace also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:9
verses.text: Seest thou that for this reason it was that he began by those praises, that advancing forward he might draw them on to the same diligence in these things also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:10
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:11
verses.text: "I speak not by way of commandment".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:12
verses.text: See how constantly he humors them, how he avoids offensiveness, and is not violent nor compulsory; or rather what he says hath both these, with the inoffensiveness of that which is uncompelled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:13
verses.text: For after he had repeatedly exhorted them and had greatly commended the Macedonians, in order that this might not seem to constitute a necessity, he says,  "I speak not by way of commandment, but as proving through the earnestness of others, the sincerity also of your love".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:14
verses.text: 'Not as doubting it,' (for that is not what he would here imply,) 'but to make it approved, display it and frame it unto greater strength.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:15
verses.text: For I therefore say these things that I may provoke you to the same forwardness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:16
verses.text: And I mention their zeal to brighten, to cheer, to stimulate your inclinations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:17
verses.text: ' Then from this he proceeded to another and a greater point.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:18
verses.text: For he lets slip no mode of persuasion, but moves heaven and earth in handling his argument.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:19
verses.text: For he exhorted them both by other men's praises, saying, Ye know "the grace of God which hath been given in the Churches of Macedonia;" and by their own, "therefore that ye abound in everything, in utterance and knowledge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:20
verses.text: For this hath power to sting man more that he falls short of himself, than that he does so of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:21
verses.text: Then he proceeds afterwards to the head and crown of his persuasion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:22
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:23
verses.text: "For ye know the grace of our Lord, that though He was rich, yet for our sakes He became poor, that we through His poverty might become rich".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:24
verses.text: 'For have in mind,' says he, 'ponder and consider the grace of God and do not lightly pass it by, but aim at realizing the greatness of it both as to extent and nature, and thou wilt grudge nothing of thine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:25
verses.text: He emptied Himself of His glory that ye, not through His riches but through His poverty, might be rich.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:26
verses.text: If thou believest not that poverty is productive of riches, have in mind thy Lord and thou wilt doubt no longer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:27
verses.text: For had He not become poor, thou wouldest not have become rich.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:28
verses.text: For this is the marvel, that poverty hath made riches rich.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:29
verses.text: ' And by riches here he meaneth the knowledge of godliness, the cleansing away of sins, justification, sanctification, the countless good things which He bestowed upon us and purposeth to bestow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:30
verses.text: And all these things accrued to us through His poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:31
verses.text: What poverty? Through His taking flesh on Him and becoming man and suffering what He suffered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:32
verses.text: And yet he owed not this, but thou dost owe to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:33
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:34
verses.text: "And herein I give you my advice for your profit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:35
verses.text: See how again he is careful to give no offence and softens down what he says, by these two things, by saying, "I give advice," and, "for your profit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:36
verses.text: 'For, neither do I compel and force you,' says he, 'or demand it from unwilling subjects; nor do I say these things with an eye so much to the receivers benefit as to yours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:37
verses.text: ' Then the instance also which follows is drawn from themselves, and not from others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:38
verses.text: "Who were the first to make a beginning a year ago, not only to do, but also to will".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:39
verses.text: See how he shows both that themselves were willing, and had come to this resolution without persuasion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:40
verses.text: For since he had borne this witness to the Thessalonians, that "of their own accord with much intreaty," they had prosecuted this giving of alms; he is desirous of showing of these also that this good work is their own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:41
verses.text: Wherefore he said, "not only to do, but also to will," and not "begun," but "begun before, a year ago".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:42
verses.text: Unto these things therefore I exhort you, whereunto ye beforehand bestirred yourselves with all forwardness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:43
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:44
verses.text: "And now also ye have completed the doing of it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:45
verses.text: He said not, ye have done it, but, ye have put a completion to it,  "That as there was the readiness to will, so also there may be the completion also out of your ability".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:46
verses.text: That this good work halt not at readiness but receive also the reward that follows upon deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:47
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:48
verses.text: "For if the readiness is there, it is acceptable according as a man hath, not according as he hath not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:49
verses.text: See wisdom unspeakable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:50
verses.text: In that (having pointed out those who were doing beyond their power, I mean the Thessalonians, and having praised them for this and said, "I bear them record that even beyond their power;") he exhorteth the Corinthians to do only "after" their power, leaving the example to do its own work; for he knew that not so much exhortation, as emulation, inciteth unto imitation of the like; wherefore he saith, "For if the readiness is there, it is acceptable according as a man hath, not according as he hath not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:51
verses.text: 'Fear not,' he means, 'because I have said these things, for what I said was an encomium upon their munificence, but God requires things after a man's power,' "according as he hath, not according as he hath not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:52
verses.text: For the word "is acceptable," here implies 'is required.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:53
verses.text: ' And he softens it greatly, in confident reliance upon this example, and as winning them more surely by leaving them at liberty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:54
verses.text: Wherefore also he added,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:55
verses.text: "For I say not this, that others may be eased, and ye distressed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:56
verses.text: And yet Christ praised the contrary conduct in the widow's case, that she emptied out all of her living and gave out of her want.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:57
verses.text: (Mark xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:58
verses.text: ) But because he was discoursing to Corinthians amongst whom he chose to suffer hunger; "for it were good for me rather to die, than that any man should make my glorying void;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:59
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:60
verses.text: ) he therefore uses a tempered exhortation, praising indeed those who had done beyond their power, but not compelling these to do so; not because he did not desire it, but because they were somewhat weak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:61
verses.text: For wherefore doth he praise those, because "in much proof of affliction the abundance of their joy and their deep poverty abounded unto the riches of their liberality:" and because they gave "beyond their power?" is it not very evident that it is as inducing these also to this conduct? So that even if he appears to permit a lower standard; he doth so, that by it he may raise them to this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:62
verses.text: Consider, for instance, how even in what follows he is covertly preparing the way for this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:63
verses.text: For having said these things, he added,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:64
verses.text: "Your abundance being a supply for their want".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:65
verses.text: For not only by the words he has before used but by these also, he is desirous of making the commandment light.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:66
verses.text: Nor yet from this consideration alone, but from that of the recompense also, again he maketh it easier; and uttereth higher things than they deserve, saying, "That there may be equality at this time, and their abundance" a supply "for your want".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:67
verses.text: Now what is it that he saith? 'Ye are flourishing in money; they in life and in boldness towards God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:68
verses.text: ' 'Give ye to them, therefore, of the money which ye abound in but they have not; that ye may receive of that boldness wherein they are rich and ye are lacking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:69
verses.text: ' See how he hath covertly prepared for their giving beyond their power and of their want.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:70
verses.text: 'For,' he saith, 'if thou desirest to receive of their abundance, give of thine abundance; but if to win for thyself the whole, thou wilt give of thy want and beyond thy power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:71
verses.text: ' He doth not say this, however, but leaves it to the reasoning of his hearers; and himself meanwhile works out his object and the exhortation that was meet, adding in keeping with what appeared, the words, that "there may be equality at this time".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:72
verses.text: How equality? You and they mutually giving your superabundance, and filling up your wants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:73
verses.text: And what sort of equality is this, giving spiritual things for carnal? for great is the advantage on that side; how then doth he call it "equality?" either in respect of each abounding and wanting, doth he say that this equality takes place; or else in respect of the present life only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:74
verses.text: And therefore after saying "equality," he added, "at this time".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:75
verses.text: Now this he said, both to subdue the high-mindedness of the rich, and to show that after our departure hence the spiritual possess the greater advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:76
verses.text: For here indeed we all enjoy much equality of honor; but then there will be a wide distinction and a very great superiority, when the just shine brighter than the sun.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:77
verses.text: Then since he showed that they were to be not only giving, but also receiving, and more, in return; he tries by a further consideration to make them forward, showing that if they did not give of their substance to others, they would not gain anything by gathering all together within.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:78
verses.text: And he adduces an ancient story, thus saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:79
verses.text: "As it is written, He that gathered much had nothing over, and he that gathered little had no lack".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:80
verses.text: Now this happened in the case of the manna.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:81
verses.text: For both they that gathered more, and they that gathered less, were found to have the same quantity, God in this way punishing insatiableness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:82
verses.text: And this he said at once both to alarm them by what then happened, and to persuade them never to desire to have more nor to grieve at having less.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:83
verses.text: And this one may see happening now in things of this life not in the manna only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:84
verses.text: For if we all fill but one belly, and live the same length of time, and clothe one body; neither will the rich gain aught by his abundance nor the poor lose aught by his poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:85
verses.text: Why then tremblest thou at poverty? and why pursuest thou after wealth? 'I fear,' saith one, 'lest I be compelled to go to other men's doors and to beg from my neighbor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:86
verses.text: ' And I constantly hear also many praying to this effect, and saying, 'Suffer me not at any time to stand in need of men?' And I laugh exceedingly when I hear these prayers, for this fear is even childish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:87
verses.text: For every day and in every thing, so to speak, do we stand in need of one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:88
verses.text: So that these are the words of an unthinking and puffed up spirit, and that doth not clearly discern the nature of things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:89
verses.text: Seest thou not that all of us are in need one of another? The soldier of the artisan, the artisan of the merchant, the merchant of the husbandman, the slave of the free man, the master of the slave, the poor man of the rich, the rich man of the poor, he that worketh not of him that giveth alms, he that bestoweth of him that receiveth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:90
verses.text: For he that receiveth alms supplieth a very great want, a want greater than any.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:91
verses.text: For if there were no poor, the greater part of our salvation would be overthrown, in that we should not have where to bestow our wealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:92
verses.text: So that even the poor man who appears to be more useless than any is the most useful of any.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:93
verses.text: But if to be in need of another is disgraceful, it remains to die; for it is not possible for a man to live who is afraid of this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:94
verses.text: 'But,' saith one, 'I cannot bear blows arched in scorn.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:95
verses.text: ' Why dost thou in accusing another of arrogance, disgrace thyself by this accusation? for to be unable to endure the inflation of a proud soul is arrogant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:96
verses.text: And why fearest thou these things, and tremblest at these things, and on account of these things which are worthy of no account, dreadest poverty also? For if thou be rich, thou wilt stand in need of more, yea of more and meaner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:97
verses.text: For just in proportion to thy wealth dost thou subject thyself to this curse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:98
verses.text: So ignorant art thou of what thou prayest when thou askest for wealth in order to be in need of no man; just as if one having come to a sea, where there is need both of sailors and a ship and endless stores of outfit, should pray that he might be in need of nothing at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:99
verses.text: For if thou art desirous of being exceedingly independent of every one, pray for poverty; and then if thou art dependent on any, thou wilt be so only for bread and raiment; but in the other case thou wilt have need of others, both for lands, and for houses, and for imposts, and for wages, and for rank, and for safety, and for honor, and for magistrates, and those subject to them, both those in the city and those in the country, and for merchants, and for shopkeepers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:100
verses.text: Do you see that those words are words of extreme carelessness? For, in a word, if to be in need one of another appears to thee a dreadful thing, know that it is impossible altogether to escape it; but if thou wilt avoid the tumult, (for thou mayest take refuge in the waveless haven of poverty,) cut off the great tumult of thy affairs, and deem it not disgraceful to be in need of another; for this is the doing of God's unspeakable wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:101
verses.text: For if we stand in need one of another, yet even the compulsion of this need draweth us not together unto love; had we been independent, should we not have been untamed wild beasts? Perforce and of compulsion God hath subjected us one to another, and every day we are in collision one with another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:102
verses.text: And had He removed this curb, who is there who would readily have longed after his neighbor's love? Let us then neither deem this to be disgraceful, nor pray against it and say, 'Grant us not to stand in need of any one;' but let us pray and say, 'Suffer us not, when we are in need, to refuse those who are able to help us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:103
verses.text: ' It is not the standing in need of others, but seizing the things of others, that is grievous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:104
verses.text: But now we have never prayed in respect to that nor said, 'Grant me not to covet other men's goods;' but to stand in need, this we think a fit subject of deprecation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:105
verses.text: Yet Paul stood in need many times, and was not ashamed; nay, even prided himself upon it, and praised those that had ministered to him, saying, "For ye sent once and again to my need;" (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:106
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:107
verses.text: ) and again, "I robbed other Churches, taking wages of them that I might minister unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:108
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:109
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:110
verses.text: ) It is no mark therefore of a generous temper, but of weakness and of a low minded and senseless spirit, to be ashamed of this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:111
verses.text: For it is even God's decree that we should stand in need one of another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:112
verses.text: Push not therefore thy philosophy beyond the mean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:113
verses.text: 'But,' saith one, 'I cannot bear a man that is entreated often and complieth not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:114
verses.text: ' And how shall God bear thee who art entreated by Him, and yet obeyest not; and entreated too in things that advantage thee? "For we are ambassadors on behalf of Christ," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:115
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:116
verses.text: ) saith he, "as though God were entreating by us; be ye reconciled unto God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:117
verses.text: 'And yet, I am His servant,' saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:118
verses.text: And what of that? For when thou, the servant, art drunken, whilst He, the Master, is hungry and hath not even necessary food, how shall thy name of servant stand thee in stead? Nay, this itself will even the more weigh thee down, when thou indeed abidest in a three-storied dwelling whilst He owns not even a decent shelter; when thou liest upon soft couches whilst He hath not even a pillow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:119
verses.text: 'But,' saith one, 'I have given.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:120
verses.text: ' But thou oughtest not to leave off so doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:121
verses.text: For then only wilt thou have an excuse, when thou hast not what to give, when thou possessest nothing; but so long as thou hast, (though thou have given to ten thousand,) and there be others hungering, there is no excuse for thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:122
verses.text: But when thou both shuttest up corn and raisest the price, and devisest other unusual tricks of traffic; what hope of salvation shalt thou have henceforth? Thou hast been bidden to give freely to the hungry, but thou dost not give at a suitable price even.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:123
verses.text: He emptied Himself of so great glory for thy sake, but thou dost not count Him deserving even of a loaf; but thy dog is fed to fulness whilst Christ wastes with hunger; and thy servant bursteth with surfeiting whilst thy Lord and his is in want of necessary food.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:124
verses.text: And how are these the deeds of friends? "Be reconciled unto God," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:125
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:126
verses.text: ) for these are the deeds of enemies and such as are in hostility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:127
verses.text: Let us then think with shame on the great benefits we have already received, the great benefits we are yet to receive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:128
verses.text: And if a poor man come to us and beg, let us receive him with much good will, comforting, raising him up with our words, that we ourselves also may meet with the like, both from God and from men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:129
verses.text: "For whatsoever ye would that they should do unto you, do ye also unto them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:130
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:131
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:132
verses.text: ) Nothing burdensome, nothing offensive, doth this law contain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:133
verses.text: 'What thou wouldest receive, that do,' it saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:134
verses.text: The return is equal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:135
verses.text: And it said not, 'what thou wouldest not receive, that do not,' but what is more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:136
verses.text: For that indeed is an abstinence from evil things, but this is a doing of good things, in which the other is involved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:137
verses.text: Also He said not 'that do ye also wish, but do, to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:138
verses.text: ' And what is the advantage? "This is the Law and the Prophets".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:139
verses.text: Wouldest thou have mercy shown thee? Then show mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:140
verses.text: Wouldest thou obtain forgiveness? Then grant it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:141
verses.text: Wouldest thou not be evil spoken of? Then speak not evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:142
verses.text: Longest thou to receive praise? Then bestow it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:143
verses.text: Wouldest thou not be wronged? Then do not thou plunder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:144
verses.text: Seest thou how He shows that virtue is natural, and that we need no external laws nor teachers? For in the things we wish to receive, or not to receive from our neighbors, we legislate unto ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:145
verses.text: So that if thou wouldest not receive a thing, yet doest it, or if thou wouldest receive it, yet doest it not, thou art become self-condemned and art henceforth without any excuse, on the ground of ignorance and of not knowing what ought to be done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 18:146
verses.text: Wherefore, I beseech you, having set up this law in ourselves for ourselves, and reading this that is written so clearly and succinctly, let us become such to our neighbors, as we would have them be to ourselves; that may we both enjoy present immunity, and obtain the future good things, though the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, together with the Holy Spirit, be glory, power, honor, now and for ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:1
verses.text: Homily XVIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:3
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:4
verses.text: But thanks be to God, Which put the same earnest care for you into the heart of Titus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:5
verses.text: Again he praises Titus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:6
verses.text: For since he had discoursed of almsgiving, he afterwards discourseth also of those who are to receive the money from them and carry it away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:7
verses.text: For this was of aid towards this collection, and towards increasing the forwardness of the contributors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:8
verses.text: For he that feels confidence as to him that ministereth, and suspects not those who are to be receivers, gives with the fuller bountifulness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:9
verses.text: And that this might be the case then also, hear how he commends those that had come for this purpose, the first of whom was Titus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:10
verses.text: Wherefore also he saith, "But thanks be to God, Which put (literally, 'gave') the same earnest care into the heart of Titus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:11
verses.text: What is "the same?" Which he had also in respect to the Thessalonians, or "the same" with me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:12
verses.text: And mark here wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:13
verses.text: Showing this to be the work of God, he also gives thanks to Him that gave, so as to incite by this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:14
verses.text: 'For if God stirred him up and sent him to you, He asks through Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:15
verses.text: Think not therefore that what has happened is of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:16
verses.text: ' And whence is it manifest that God incited him?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:17
verses.text: "For indeed he accepted our exhortation, but being himself very earnest, he went forth of his own accord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:18
verses.text: Observe how he also represents him as fulfilling his own part, and needing no prompting from others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:19
verses.text: And having mentioned the grace of God, he doth not leave the whole to be God's; again, that by this also he may win them unto greater love, having said that he was stirred up from himself also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:20
verses.text: For, "being very earnest, he went forth of his own accord," 'he seized at the thing, he rushed upon the treasure, he considered your service to be his own advantage; and because he loved you exceedingly, he needed not the exhortation I gave; but though he was exhorted by me also, yet it was not by that he was stirred up; but from himself and by the grace of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:21
verses.text: '  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:22
verses.text: "And we have sent together with him the brother whose praise in the Gospel is spread through all the Churches".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:23
verses.text: And who is this brother? Some indeed say, Luke, because of the history which he wrote, but some, Barnabas; for he calls the unwritten preaching also Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:24
verses.text: And for what cause does he not mention their names; whilst he both makes Titus known (vid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:25
verses.text: also ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:26
verses.text: ) by name, and praises him for his cooperation in the Gospel, (seeing that he was so useful that by reason of his absence even Paul could do nothing great and noble; for, "because I found not Titus my brother, I had no relief for my spirit,"—c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:27
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:28
verses.text: ) and for his love towards them, (for, saith he, "his inward affection is more abundant towards you;"—c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:29
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:30
verses.text: ) and for his zeal in this matter ("for," he saith, "of his own accord he went")? But these he neither equally commends, nor mentions by name? What then is one to say? Perhaps they did not know them; wherefore he does not dwell upon their praises because as yet they had had no experience of them, but only says so much as was sufficient for their commendation unto them (i-e: the Corinthians,) and to their escaping all evil suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:31
verses.text: However, let us see on what score he eulogizes this man himself also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:32
verses.text: On what score then does he eulogize? First, praising him from his preaching; that he not only preached, but also as he ought, and with the befitting earnestness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:33
verses.text: For he said not, 'he preaches and proclaims the Gospel,' but, "whose praise is in the Gospel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:34
verses.text: And that he may not seem to flatter him, he brings not one or two or three men, but whole Churches to testify to him, saying, "through all the churches".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:35
verses.text: Then he makes him respected also from the judgment of those that had chosen him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:36
verses.text: And this too is no light matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:37
verses.text: Therefore after saying, "Whose praise in the Gospel is spread through all the churches," he added,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:38
verses.text: "And not only so".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:39
verses.text: What is, "and not only so?" 'Not only on this account,' he says, 'is respect due to him, that he is approved as a preacher and is praised by all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:40
verses.text: '  "But he was also appointed by the churches along with us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:41
verses.text: Whence it seems to me, that Barnabas is the person intimated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:42
verses.text: And he signifies his dignity to be great, for he shows also for what office he was appointed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:43
verses.text: For he saith,  "To travel with us in the matter of this grace which is ministered by us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:44
verses.text: Seest thou how great are these praises of him? He shone as a preacher of the Gospel and had all the churches testifying to this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:45
verses.text: He was chosen by us; and unto the same office with Paul, and everywhere was partner with him, both in his trials and in his dangers, for this is implied in the word "travel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:46
verses.text: But what is, "with this grace which is ministered by us?" So as to proclaim the word, he means, and to preach the Gospel; or to minister also in respect of the money; yea rather, he seems to me to refer to both of these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:47
verses.text: Then he adds,  "To the glory of the same Lord, and to show your readiness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:48
verses.text: What he means is this: 'We thought good,' he says, 'that he should be chosen with us and be appointed unto this work, so as to become a dispenser and a minister of the sacred money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:49
verses.text: ' Nor was this a little matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:50
verses.text: For, "Look ye out," it saith, "from among you seven men of good report;" (Acts vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:51
verses.text: ) and he was chosen by the churches, and there was a vote of the whole people taken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:52
verses.text: What is, "to the glory of the same Lord, and your readiness?" 'That both God may be glorified and ye may become the readier, they who are to receive this money being of proved character, and no one able to engender any false suspicion against them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:53
verses.text: Therefore we sought out such persons, and entrusted not the whole to one person only, that he might escape this suspicion also; but we sent both Titus and another with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:54
verses.text: Then to interpret this same expression, "to the glory of the Lord and your ready mind:" he added,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:55
verses.text: "Avoiding this, that any man should blame us in the matter of this bounty which is ministered by us".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:56
verses.text: What can this be which is said? A thing worthy of the virtue of Paul; and showing the greatness of his tender care and his condescension.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:57
verses.text: 'For,' he says, 'that none should suspect us, nor have the slightest cavil against us, as though we purloined aught of the money placed in our hands; therefore we send such persons, and not one only, but even two or three.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:58
verses.text: ' Seest thou how he clears them of all suspicions? Not on account of the Gospel, nor of their having been chosen merely; but also, from their being persons of proved character, (and for this very reason) having been chosen, that they might not be suspected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:59
verses.text: And he said not 'that ye should not blame,' but 'that no other person should.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:60
verses.text: ' And yet it was on their account that he did this; and he implied as much in saying, "to the glory of the same Lord, and your readiness:" however, he does not wish to wound them; and so expresses himself differently,  "Avoiding this".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:61
verses.text: And he is not satisfied with this either, but by what he adds, soothes again, saying,  "In the matter of this bounty which is ministered by us," and mingling his severity with praise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:62
verses.text: For that they might not feel hurt, and say, 'Is he obliged then to eye us stealthily, and are we so miserable as ever to have been suspected of these things?' Providing a correction against this too, he says, 'the money sent by you is of large amount, and this abundance, that is, the large amount of the money, is enough to afford suspicion to the evil-minded had we not offered that security.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:63
verses.text: '  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:64
verses.text: For "we take thought for things, honorable not only in the sight of the Lord, but also in the sight of men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:65
verses.text: What can compare with Paul? For he said not, 'Perdition and woe to him who chooses to suspect anything of the kind: so long as my conscience does not condemn me, I waste not a thought on those who suspect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:66
verses.text: ' Rather, the weaker they were, the more he condescended.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:67
verses.text: For it is meet not to be angry with, but help, him that is sick.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:68
verses.text: And yet from what sin are we so removed as he was from any such suspicion? For not even a demon could have suspected that blessed saint of this unfaithfulness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:69
verses.text: But still although so far removed from that evil suspicion, he does everything and resorts to every expedient, so as not to leave a shadow even to those who might be desirous in any way of suspecting something wrong; and he avoids not only accusations, but also blame and the slightest censure, even bare suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:70
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:71
verses.text: "And we have sent with them our brother".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:72
verses.text: Behold, again he adds yet another, and him also with an encomium; both his own judgment, and many other witnesses to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:73
verses.text: "Whom," saith he, "we have many times proved earnest in many things, but now much more earnest".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:74
verses.text: And having praised him from his own good works, he extols him also from his love towards them; and what he said of Titus, that "being very earnest he went forth of his own accord;" this he says of this person also, saying, "but now much more earnest;" laying up beforehand for them the seeds of the proof of their love toward the Corinthians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:75
verses.text: And then, after having showed forth their virtue, he exhorts them also on their behalf, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:76
verses.text: "Whether any inquire about Titus; he is my partner and my fellow-worker to youward".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:77
verses.text: What is, "Whether about Titus?" 'If,' says he, 'it be necessary to say any thing, this I have to say,' "that he is my partner and fellow-worker to youward".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:78
verses.text: For he either means this; or, 'if ye will do anything for Titus, ye will do it unto no ordinary person, for he is "my partner".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:79
verses.text: ' And whilst appearing to be praising him, he magnifies them, showing them to be so disposed towards himself as that it were sufficient ground of honor amongst them that any one should appear to be his "partner".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:80
verses.text: But, nevertheless, he was not content with this, but he also added another thing, saying, "fellow-worker to youward".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:81
verses.text: Not merely "fellow-worker," 'but in matters concerning you, in your progress, in your growth, in our friendship, in our zeal for you;' which last would avail most especially to endear him unto them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:82
verses.text: "Or our brethren:" 'or whether you wish,' he says, 'to hear any thing about the others: they too have great claims to be commended to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:83
verses.text: For they also,' he saith, 'are our brethren, and,  "The messengers of the Churches,"' that is, sent by the Churches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:84
verses.text: Then, which is greater than all,  "The glory of Christ;" for to Him is referred whatever shall be done to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:85
verses.text: 'Whether then ye wish to receive them as brethren, or as Apostles of the Churches, or as acting for the glory of Christ; ye have many motives for good will towards them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:86
verses.text: For on behalf of Titus, I have to say, that he is both "my partner," and a lover of you; on behalf of these, that they are "brethren," that they are "the messengers of the churches," that they are "the glory of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:87
verses.text: Seest thou that it is plain from hence also, that they were of such as were unknown to them? For otherwise he would have set them off by those things with which he had also set off Titus, namely, his love towards them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:88
verses.text: But whereas as yet they were not known to them, 'Receive them,' he says, 'as brethren, as messengers of the churches, as acting for the glory of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:89
verses.text: ' On which account he adds;  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:90
verses.text: "Wherefore show ye unto them, to the person of the churches, the proof of your love, and of our glorying on your behalf".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:91
verses.text: 'Now show,' he saith, 'how ye love us; and how we do not lightly nor vainly boast in you: and this ye will show, if ye show forth love towards them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:92
verses.text: ' Then he also makes his words more solemn, by saying, "unto the person of the churches".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:93
verses.text: He means, to the glory, the honor, of the churches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:94
verses.text: 'For if ye honor them, ye have honored the churches that sent them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:95
verses.text: For the honor passeth not to them alone, but also to those that sent them forth, who ordained them, and more than these, unto the glory of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:96
verses.text: ' For when we honor those that minister to Him, the kind reception passeth unto Him, unto the common body of the churches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:97
verses.text: Now this too is no light thing, for great is the potency of that assembly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:98
verses.text: Certain it is at least that the prayer of the churches loosed Peter from his chains, opened the mouth of Paul; their voice in no slight degree equips those that arrive unto spiritual rule.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:99
verses.text: Therefore indeed it is that both he who is going to ordain calleth at that time for their prayers also, and that they add their votes and assent by acclamations which the initiated know: for it is not lawful before the uninitiated to unbare all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:100
verses.text: But there are occasions in which there is no difference at all between the priest and those under him; for instance, when we are to partake of the awful mysteries; for we are all alike counted worthy of the same things: not as under the Old Testament when the priest ate some things and those under him others, and it was not lawful for the people to partake of those things whereof the priest partook.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:101
verses.text: But not so now, but before all one body is set and one cup.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:102
verses.text: And in the prayers also, one may observe the people contributing much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:103
verses.text: For in behalf of the possessed, in behalf of those under penance, the prayers are made in common both by the priest and by them; and all say one prayer, the prayer replete with pity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:104
verses.text: Again when we exclude from the holy precincts those who are unable to partake of the holy table, it behoveth that another prayer be offered, and we all alike fall upon the ground, and all alike rise up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:105
verses.text: Again, in the most awful mysteries themselves, the priest prays for the people and the people also pray for the priest; for the words, "with thy spirit," are nothing else than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:106
verses.text: The offering of thanksgiving again is common: for neither doth he give thanks alone, but also all the people.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:107
verses.text: For having first taken their voices, next when they assent that it is "meet and right so to do," then he begins the thanksgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:108
verses.text: And why marvellest thou that the people any where utter aught with the priest, when indeed even with the very Cherubim, and the powers above, they send up in common those sacred hymns? Now I have said all this in order that each one of the laity also may be wary, that we may understand that we are all one body, having such difference amongst ourselves as members with members; and may not throw the whole upon the priests but ourselves also so care for the whole Church as for a body common to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:109
verses.text: For this course will provide for our greater safety, and for your greater growth unto virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:110
verses.text: Here, at least, in the case of the Apostles, how frequently they admitted the laity to share in their decisions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:111
verses.text: For when they ordained the seven, (Acts vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:113
verses.text: ) they first communicated with the people; and when Peter ordained Matthias, with all that were then present, both men and women.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:114
verses.text: (Acts i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:116
verses.text: ) For here is no pride of rulers nor slavishness in the ruled; but a spiritual rule, in this particular usurping most, in taking on itself the greater share of the labor and of the care which is on your behalf, not in seeking larger honors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:117
verses.text: For so ought the Church to dwell as one house; as one body so to be all disposed; just as therefore there is both one Baptism, and one table, and one fountain, and one creation, and one Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:118
verses.text: Why then are we divided, when so great things unite us; why are we torn asunder? For we are compelled again to bewail the same things, which I have lamented often.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:119
verses.text: The state in which we are calls for lamentation; so widely are we severed from each other, when we ought to image the conjunction of one body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:120
verses.text: For in this way will he that is greater, be able to gain even from him that is less.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:121
verses.text: For if Moses learnt from his father-in-law somewhat expedient which himself had not perceived, (Exod.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:122
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:124
verses.text: ) much more in the Church may this happen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:125
verses.text: And how then came it that what he that was an unbeliever perceived, he that was spiritual perceived not? That all those of that time might understand that he was a man; and though he divide the sea, though he cleave the rock, he needeth the influence of God, and that those acts were not of man's nature, but of God's power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:126
verses.text: And so let another rise up and speak; and so now, if such and such an one doth not say expedient things, let another rise up and speak; though he be an inferior, yet if he say somewhat to the purpose, confirm his opinion; and even if he be of the very meanest, do not show him disrespect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:127
verses.text: For no one of these is at so great a distance from his neighbor, as Moses' father-in-law was from him, yet he disdained not to listen to him, but even admitted his opinion, and was persuaded, and recorded it; and was not ashamed to hand down the circumstances to history; casting down so the pride of the many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:128
verses.text: Wherefore also he left this story to the world engraven as it were on a pillar, for he knew that it would be useful to many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:129
verses.text: Let us then not overlook those who give us behoveful counsel, even though they be of the meaner sort, nor insist that those counsels prevail which we have ourselves introduced; but whatever shall appear to be best, let that be approved by all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:130
verses.text: For many of duller sight have perceived things sooner than those of acute vision, by means of diligence and attention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:131
verses.text: And say not, "why dost thou call me to council, if thou hearkenest not to what I say?" These accusations are not a counsellor's, but a despot's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:132
verses.text: For the counsellor hath only power to speak his own opinion; but if something else appear more profitable, and yet he will carry his own opinion into effect, he is no longer a counsellor but a despot, as I said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:133
verses.text: Let us not, then, act in this manner; but having freed our souls from all arrogancy and pride, let us consider, not how our counsels only may stand, but how that opinion which is best may prevail, even though it may not have been brought forward by us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:134
verses.text: For no light gain will be ours, even though we should not have discovered what behoveth, if ourselves accepted what has been pointed out by others; and abundant is the reward we shall receive from God, and so too shall we best attain to glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:135
verses.text: For as he is wise that speaketh that which is behoveful, so shall we that have accepted it, ourselves also reap the praise of prudence and of candor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 19:136
verses.text: Thus if both houses and states, thus too if the Church be ordered, she will receive a larger increase; and so too shall we ourselves, having thus best ordered our present lives, receive the good things to come: whereunto may we all attain, through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, to Whom be glory for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:1
verses.text: Homily XIX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:3
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:4
verses.text: For as touching the ministering to the saints, it is superfluous for me to write to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:5
verses.text: Though he had said so much about it, he says here, "It is superfluous for me to write to you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:6
