verses.text: And his wisdom is shown not only in this, that though he had said so much about it, he saith, "it is superfluous for me to write to you," but in that he yet again speaketh of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:7
verses.text: For what he said indeed a little above, he said concerning those who received the money, to ensure them the enjoyment of great honor: but what he said before that, (his account of the Macedonians, that "their deep poverty abounded unto the riches of their liberality," and all the rest,) was concerning loving-kindness and almsgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:8
verses.text: But nevertheless even though he had said so much before and was going to speak again, he says, "it is superfluous for me to write to you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:9
verses.text: And this he does the rather to win them to himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:10
verses.text: For a man who has so high a reputation as not to stand in need even of advice, is ashamed to appear inferior to, and come short of, that opinion of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:11
verses.text: And he does this often in accusation also, using the rhetorical figure, omission, for this is very effective.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:12
verses.text: For the judge seeing the magnanimity of the accuser entertains no suspicions even.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:13
verses.text: For he argues, 'he who when he might say much, yet saith it not, how should he invent what is not true?' And he gives occasion to suspect even more than he says, and invests himself with the presumption of a good disposition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:14
verses.text: This also in his advice and in his praises he does.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:15
verses.text: For having said, "It is superfluous for me to write to you," observe how he advises them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:16
verses.text: "For I know your readiness of which I glory on your behalf to them of Macedonia".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:17
verses.text: Now it was a great thing that he even knew it himself, but much greater, that he also published it to others: for the force it has is greater: for they would not like to be so widely disgraced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:18
verses.text: Seest thou his wisdom of purpose? He exhorted them by others' example, the Macedonians, for, he says, "I make known to you the grace of God which hath been given in the Churches of Macedonia".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:19
verses.text: He exhorted them by their own, for he saith, "who were the first to make a beginning a year ago not only to do, but also to will".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:20
verses.text: He exhorted them by the Lord's, for "ye know" he saith, "the grace of our Lord, that though He was rich, yet for our sakes He became poor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:21
verses.text: (ibid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:22
verses.text: ) Again he retreats upon that strong main point, the conduct of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:23
verses.text: For mankind is emulous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:24
verses.text: And truly the example of the Lord ought to have had most power to draw them over: and next to it, the consideration of the recompense: but because they were somewhat weak, this draws them most.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:25
verses.text: For nothing does so much as emulation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:26
verses.text: But observe how he introduces it in a somewhat novel way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:27
verses.text: For He did not say, 'Imitate them;' but what?  "And your zeal has stirred up very many".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:28
verses.text: What sayest thou? A little before thou saidst, they did it "of their own accord, beseeching us with much entreaty," how then now, "your zeal?" 'Yes,' he saith, 'we did not advise, we did not exhort, but we only praised you, we only boasted of you, and this was enough to incite them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:29
verses.text: Seest thou how he rouses them each by the other, these by those, and those by these, and, along with the emulation, has intermingled also a very high encomium.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:30
verses.text: Then, that he may not elate them, he follows it up in a tempered tone, saying, "Your zeal hath stirred up very many".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:31
verses.text: Now consider what a thing it is that those who have been the occasion to others of this munificence, should be themselves behind hand in this contribution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:32
verses.text: Therefore he did not say, 'Imitate them,' for it would not have kindled so great an emulation, but how? 'They have imitated you; see then that ye the teachers appear not inferior to your disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:33
verses.text: '  And see how, whilst stirring up and inflaming them still more, he feigns to be standing by them, as if espousing their party in some rivalry and contention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:34
verses.text: For, as he said above, "Of their own accord, with much entreaty they came to us, insomuch that we exhorted Titus, that as he had made a beginning before, so he would complete this grace;" so also he says here,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:35
verses.text: "For this cause have I sent the brethren that our glorying on your behalf may not be made void".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:36
verses.text: Seest thou that he is in anxiety and terror, lest he should seem to have said what he said only for exhortation's sake? 'But because so it is,' saith he, "I have sent the brethren;" 'so earnest am I on your behalf,' "that our glorying may not be made void".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:37
verses.text: And he appears to make himself of the Corinthians' party throughout, although caring for all alike.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:38
verses.text: What he says is this; 'I am very proud of you, I glory before all, I boasted even unto them, so that if ye be found wanting, I am partner in the shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:39
verses.text: ' And this indeed he says under limitation, for he added,  "In this respect," not, in all points;  "That even as I said, ye may be prepared".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:40
verses.text: 'For I did not say, 'they are purposing,' but 'all is ready; and nothing is now wanting on their part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:41
verses.text: This then,' he says, 'I wish to be shown by your deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:42
verses.text: ' Then he even heightens the anxiety, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:43
verses.text: "Lest by any means if there come with me any from Macedonia, we, (that we say not ye,) should be put to shame in this confidence".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:44
verses.text: The shame is greater when the spectators he has arrayed against them are many, even those same persons who had heard his boasting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:45
verses.text: And he did not say, 'for I am bringing with me Macedonians;' 'for there are Macedonians coming with me;' lest he should seem to do it on purpose; but how said he? "Lest by any means, if there come with me any from Macedonia?" 'For this may happen,' he says, 'it is matter of possibility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:46
verses.text: ' For thus he also made what he said unsuspected, but had he expressed himself in that other way, he would have even made them the more contentious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:47
verses.text: See how he leads them on, not from spiritual motives only, but from human ones as well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:48
verses.text: 'For,' says he, 'though you make no great account of me, and reckon confidently on my excusing you, yet think of them of Macedonia,' "lest by any means, if they come and find you;" and he did not say 'unwillingly,' but "unprepared," not having got all completed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:49
verses.text: But if this be a disgrace, not to contribute quickly; consider how great it were to contribute either not at all, or less than behoved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:50
verses.text: Then he lays down what would thereupon follow, in terms at once gentle and pungent, thus saying, "We, (that we say not ye,) should be put to shame".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:51
verses.text: And he tempers it again, saying, "in this confidence" not as making them more listless, but as showing that they who were approved in all other respects, ought in this one also to have great fearlessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:52
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:53
verses.text: "I thought it necessary therefore to entreat the brethren, that they would make up beforehand this your bounty, that the same might be ready, as a matter of bounty and not of extortion".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:54
verses.text: Again, he resumed the subject in a different manner: and that he may not seem to be saying these things without object, he asserts that the sole reason for this journey was, that they might not be put to shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:55
verses.text: Seest thou how his words, "It is superfluous for me to write," were the beginning of advising? You see, at least, how many things he discourses concerning this ministering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:56
verses.text: And along with this, one may further remark that, (lest he should seem to contradict himself as having said, "It is superfluous," yet discoursing at length about it,) he passed on unto discourse of quickness and largeness and forwardness in contributing, by this means securing that point also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:57
verses.text: For these three things he requires.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:58
verses.text: And indeed he moved these three main points even at the first, for when he says, "In much proof of affliction the abundance of their joy, and their deep poverty, abounded unto the riches of their liberality," he says nothing else than that they contributed both much and gladly and quickly; and that not only did not giving much pain them, but not even being in trials, which is more grievous than giving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:59
verses.text: And the words, "they gave themselves to us;" these also show both their forwardness and the greatness of their faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:60
verses.text: And here too again he treats of those heads.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:61
verses.text: For since these are opposed to each other, munificence and forwardness, and one that has given much is often sorrowful, whilst another, that he may not be sorry, gives less; observe how he takes care for each, and with the wisdom which belongs to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:62
verses.text: For he did not say, 'it is better to give a little and of free choice, than much of necessity;' because he wished them to contribute both much and of free choice; but how saith he? "that they might make up beforehand this your bounty, that the same might be ready as a matter of bounty, and not extortion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:63
verses.text: He begins first with that which is pleasantest and lighter; namely, the 'not of necessity,' for, it is "bounty" he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:64
verses.text: Observe how in the form of his exhortation he represents at once the fruit as springing up, and the givers as filled with blessing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:65
verses.text: And by the term employed he won them over, for no one gives a blessing with pain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:66
verses.text: Yet neither was he content with this; but added, "not as of extortion".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:67
verses.text: 'Think not,' he says, 'that we take it as extortioners, but that we may be the cause of a blessing unto you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:68
verses.text: ' For extortion belongs to the unwilling, so that whoso giveth alms unwillingly giveth of extortion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:69
verses.text: Then from this he passed on again unto that, the giving munificently.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:70
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:71
verses.text: "But this I say:" that is, along with this I say also that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:72
verses.text: What?  "He that soweth sparingly, shall reap also sparingly; and he that soweth bountifully shall reap also bountifully".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:73
verses.text: And he did not say niggardly, but a milder expression, employing the name of the sparing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:74
verses.text: And he called the thing sowing; that thou mightest at once look unto the recompense, and having in mind the harvest, mightest feel that thou receivest more than thou givest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:75
verses.text: Wherefore he did not say, 'He that giveth,' but "He that soweth:" and he said not 'ye, if ye sow,' but made what he said general.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:76
verses.text: Neither did he say, 'largely,' but "bountifully," which is far greater than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:77
verses.text: And again, he betakes himself to that former point of gladness; saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:78
verses.text: "Let each man do according as he hath purposed in his heart".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:79
verses.text: For a man when left to himself, does a thing more readily than when compelled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:80
verses.text: Wherefore also he dwells upon this: for having said, "according as he is disposed," he added,  "Not grudgingly, nor of necessity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:81
verses.text: And neither was he content with this, but he adds a testimony from Scripture also, saying,  "For God loveth a cheerful giver".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:82
verses.text: Seest thou how frequently he lays this down? "I speak not by commandment:" and, "Herein I give my advice:" and, "as a matter of bounty, and not as of extortion," and again, "not grudgingly, nor of necessity; for God loveth a cheerful giver".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:83
verses.text: In this passage I am of opinion that a large giver is intended; the Apostle however has taken it as giving with readiness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:84
verses.text: For because the example of the Macedonians and all those other things were enough to produce sumptuousness, he does not say many things on that head, but upon giving without reluctance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:85
verses.text: For if it is a work of virtue, and yet all that is done of necessity is shorn of its reward, with reason also he labors at this point.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:86
verses.text: And he does not advise merely, but also adds a prayer, as his wont is to do, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:87
verses.text: "And may God, that is able, fulfill all grace towards you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:88
verses.text: By this prayer he takes out the way a thought which lay in wait against this liberality and which is now also an hinderance to many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:89
verses.text: For many persons are afraid to give alms, saying, 'Lest perchance I become poor,' 'lest perchance I need aid from others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:90
verses.text: ' To do away with this fear then, he adds this prayer, saying, May "He make all grace abound towards you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:91
verses.text: Not merely fulfil, but "make it abound".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:92
verses.text: And what is "make grace abound?" 'Fill you,' he means, 'with so great things, that ye may be able to abound in this liberality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:93
verses.text: '  "That ye, having always all sufficiency in every thing, may abound to every good work".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:94
verses.text: Observe, even in this his prayer, his great philosophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:95
verses.text: He prays not for riches nor for abundance, but for all sufficiency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:96
verses.text: Nor is this all that is admirable in him; but that as he prayed not for superfluity, so he doth not press sore on them nor compel them to give of their want, condescending to their weakness; but asks for a "sufficiency," and shows at the same time that they ought not to abuse the gifts received from God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:97
verses.text: "That ye may abound," he saith, "to every good work".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:98
verses.text: 'It is therefore,' saith he, 'I ask for this, that ye may bestow on others also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:99
verses.text: ' Yet he did not say, 'bestow,' but 'abound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:100
verses.text: ' For in carnal things he asks for a sufficiency for them, but in spiritual things for abundance even; not in almsgiving only, but in all other things also, "unto every good work".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:101
verses.text: Then he brings forward unto them the prophet for a counsellor, having sought out a testimony inviting them to bountifulness, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:102
verses.text: "As it is written,  He hath scattered abroad, he hath given to the poor;  His righteousness abideth for ever".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:103
verses.text: This is the import of "abound;" for the words, "he hath dispersed abroad," signify nothing else but the giving plentifully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:104
verses.text: For if the things themselves abide not, yet their results abide.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:105
verses.text: For this is the thing to be admired, that when they are kept they are lost; but when dispersed abroad they abide, yea, abide for ever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:106
verses.text: Now by "righteousness," here, he means love towards men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:107
verses.text: For this maketh righteous, consuming sins like a fire when it is plentifully poured out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:108
verses.text: Let us not therefore nicely calculate, but sow with a profuse hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:109
verses.text: Seest thou not how much others give to players and harlots? Give at any rate the half to Christ, of what they give to dancers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:110
verses.text: As much as they give of ostentation to those upon the stage, so much at any rate give thou unto the hungry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:111
verses.text: For they indeed even clothe the persons of wantons with untold gold; but thou not even with a threadbare garment the flesh of Christ, and that though beholding it naked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:112
verses.text: What forgiveness doth this deserve, yea, how great a punishment doth it not deserve, when he indeed bestoweth so much upon her that ruineth and shameth him, but thou not the least thing on Him that saveth thee and maketh thee brighter? But as long as thou spendest it upon thy belly and on drunkenness and dissipation, thou never thinkest of poverty: but when need is to relieve poverty, thou art become poorer than any body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:113
verses.text: And when feeding parasites and flatterers, thou art as joyous as though thou hadst fountains to spend from; but if thou chance to see a poor man, then the fear of poverty besets thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:114
verses.text: Therefore surely we shall in that day be condemned, both by ourselves and by others, both by those that have done well and those that have done amiss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:115
verses.text: For He will say to thee, 'Wherefore wast thou not thus magnanimous in things where it became thee? But here is a man who, when giving to an harlot, thought not of any of these things; whilst thou, bestowing upon thy Master Who hath bid thee "not be anxious" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:116
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:117
verses.text: ), art full of fear and trembling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:118
verses.text: ' And what forgiveness then shalt thou deserve? For if a man who hath received will not overlook, but will requite the favor, much more will Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:119
verses.text: For He that giveth even without receiving, how will He not give after receiving? 'What then,' saith one, 'when some who have spent much come to need other men's help?' Thou speakest of those that have spent their all; when thou thyself bestowest not a farthing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:120
verses.text: Promise to strip thyself of every thing and then ask questions about such men; but as long as thou art a niggard and bestowest little of thy substance, why throw me out excuses and pretenses? For neither am I leading thee to the lofty peak of entire poverty but for the present I require thee to cut off superfluities and to desire a sufficiency alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:121
verses.text: Now the boundary of sufficiency is the using those things which it is impossible to live without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:122
verses.text: No one debars thee from these; nor forbids thee thy daily food.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:123
verses.text: I say food, not feasting; raiment, not ornament.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:124
verses.text: Yea rather, if one should enquire accurately, this is in the best sense feasting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:125
verses.text: For, consider.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:126
verses.text: Which should we say more truly feasted, he whose diet was herbs, and who was in sound health and suffered no uneasiness: or he who had the table of a Sybarite, and was full of ten thousand disorders? Very plainly the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:127
verses.text: Therefore let us seek nothing more than this, if we would at once live luxuriously and healthfully: and let us set these boundaries to sufficiency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:128
verses.text: And let him that can be satisfied with pulse and can keep in good health, seek for nothing more; but let him who is weaker and requires to be dieted with garden herbs, not be hindered of this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:129
verses.text: But if any be even weaker than this and require the support of flesh in moderation, we will not debar him from this either.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:130
verses.text: For we do not advise these things, to kill and injure men but to cut off what is superfluous; and that is superfluous which is more than we need.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:131
verses.text: For when we are able even without a thing to live healthfully and respectably, certainly the addition of that thing is a superfluity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:132
verses.text: Thus let us think also in regard of clothing and of the table and of a dwelling house and of all our other wants; and in every thing inquire what is necessary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:133
verses.text: For what is superfluous is also useless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:134
verses.text: When thou shalt have practised living on what is sufficient; then if thou hast a mind to emulate that widow, we will lead thee on to greater things than these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:135
verses.text: For thou hast not yet attained to the philosophy of that woman, whilst thou art anxious about what is sufficient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:136
verses.text: For she soared higher even than this; for what was to have been her support; that she cast in, all of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:137
verses.text: Wilt thou then still distress thyself about such things as be necessary; and dost thou not blush to be vanquished by a woman; and not only not to emulate her, but to be left even of her far behind? For she did not say the things we say, 'But what, if when I have spent all I be compelled to beg of another?' but in her munificence stripped herself of all she had.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:138
verses.text: What shall we say of the widow in the Old Testament in the time of the prophet Elias? For the risk she ran was not of poverty, but even of death and extinction, and not her own only, but her children's too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:139
verses.text: For neither had she any expectation of receiving from others, but of presently dying.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:140
verses.text: 'But,' saith one, 'she saw the prophet, and that made her munificent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:141
verses.text: ' But do not ye see saints without number? And why do I speak of saints? Ye see the Lord of the prophets asking an alms, and yet not even so do ye become humane; but though ye have coffers spewing one into another, do not even impart of your superfluity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:142
verses.text: What sayest thou? Was he a prophet that came to her, and did this persuade her to so great a magnanimity? This of itself deserves much admiration, that she was persuaded of his being a great and wonderful person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:143
verses.text: For how was it she did not say, as it would have been likely that a barbarian woman and a foreigner would have reasoned, 'If he were a prophet, he would not have begged of me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:144
verses.text: If he were a friend of God, He would not have neglected him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:145
verses.text: Be it that because of sins the Jews suffer this punishment: but whence, and wherefore, doth this man suffer?' But she entertained none of these thoughts; but opened to him her house, and before her house, her heart; and set before him all she had; and putting nature on one side and disregarding her children, preferred the stranger unto all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:146
verses.text: Consider then how great punishment will be laid up for us, if we shall come behind and be weaker than a woman, a widow, poor, a foreigner, a barbarian, a mother of children, knowing nothing of these things which we know! For because we have strength of body, we are not therefore manly persons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:147
verses.text: For he alone hath this virtue, yea though he be laid upon his bed, whose strength is from within; since without this, though a man should tear up a mountain by his strength of body, I would call him nothing stronger than a girl or wretched crone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:148
verses.text: For the one struggles with incorporeal ills, but the other dares not even look them in the face.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:149
verses.text: And that thou mayest learn that this is the measure of manliness, collect it from this very example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:150
verses.text: For what could be more manly than that woman who both against the tyranny of nature, and against the force of hunger, and against the threat of death, stood nobly fast, and proved stronger than all? Hear at least how Christ proclaimeth her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:151
verses.text: For, saith He, "there were many widows in the days of Elias, and to none of them was the prophet sent but to her".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:152
verses.text: (Luke iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:154
verses.text: ) Shall I say something great and startling? This woman gave more to hospitality, than our father Abraham.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:155
verses.text: For she "ran" not "unto the herd," as he, (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:156
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:157
verses.text: ) but by that "handful" ( Kings xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:158
verses.text: ) outstripped all that have been renowned for hospitality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:159
verses.text: For in this was his excellence that he set himself to do that office; but hers, in that for the sake of the stranger she spared not her children even, and that too, though she looked not for the things to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:160
verses.text: But we, though a heaven exists, though a hell is threatened, though (which is greater than all) God hath wrought such great things for us and is made glad and rejoiceth over such things, sink back supinely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:161
verses.text: Not so, I beseech you: but let us "scatter abroad," let us "give to the poor" as we ought to give.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:162
verses.text: For what is much and what little, God defines, not by the measure of what is given, but by the extent of the substance of him that gives.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:163
verses.text: Often surely hast thou who didst cast in an hundred staters of gold offered less than he that offered but one obol, for thou didst cast in of thy superfluity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:164
verses.text: Howbeit do if but this, and thou wilt come quickly even to greater munificence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:165
verses.text: Scatter wealth that thou mayest gather righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:166
verses.text: For along with wealth this refuseth to come to us; yet through it, though not with it, it is made present to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:167
verses.text: For it is not possible that lust of wealth and righteousness should dwell together; they have their tents apart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:168
verses.text: Do not then obstinately strive to bring things together which are incompatible, but banish the usurper covetousness, if thou wouldest obtain the kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:169
verses.text: For this is the rightful queen, and of slaves makes freemen, the contrary of which the other doth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 20:170
verses.text: Wherefore with all earnestness let us shun the one and welcome the other, that we may both gain freedom in this life and obtain the kingdom of heaven, through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom, to the Father together with the Holy Spirit, be glory, might, honor, now and for ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:1
verses.text: Homily XX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:3
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:4
verses.text: Now He that supplied seed to the sower, both minister bread for your food, and multiply your seed for sowing and increase the fruits of your righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:5
verses.text: Herein one may particularly admire the wisdom of Paul, that after having exhorted from spiritual considerations and from temporal, in respect of the recompense also he again does the very same, making the returns he mentions of either kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:6
verses.text: This, (for instance,) "He hath scattered abroad, he hath given to the poor, his righteousness abideth for ever," belongs to a spiritual return; that again, "multiply your seed for sowing," to a temporal recompense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:7
verses.text: Still, however, he rests not here, but even again passes back to what is spiritual, placing the two continually side by side; for "increase the fruits of your righteousness," is spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:8
verses.text: This he does, and gives variety by it to his discourse, tearing up by the roots those their unmanly and faint-hearted reasonings, and using many arguments to dissipate their fear of poverty, as also the example which he now brings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:9
verses.text: For if even to those that sow the earth God gives, if to those that feed the body He grants abundance; much more will He to those who till the soil of heaven, to those who take care for the soul; for these things He willeth should yet more enjoy His providing care.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:10
verses.text: However, he does not state this in the way of inference nor in the manner I have done, but in the form of a prayer; thus at once making the reference plain, and the rather leading them on to hope, not only from what commonly takes place, but also from his own prayer: for, 'May He minister,' saith he, 'and multiply your seed for sowing, and increase the fruits of your righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:11
verses.text: ' Here also again he hints, in an unsuspicious way, at largeness in giving, for the words, "multiply and increase," are by way of indicating this; and at the same time he allows them to seek for nothing more than necessaries, saying, "bread for food".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:12
verses.text: For this also is particularly worthy of admiration in him, (and it is a point he successfully established even before,) namely, that in things which be necessary, he allows them to seek for nothing more than need requires; but in spiritual things counsels them to get for themselves a large superabundance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:13
verses.text: Wherefore he said above also, "that having a sufficiency ye may abound to every good work:" and here, "He that ministereth bread for food, multiply your seed for sowing;" that is to say, the spiritual seed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:14
verses.text: For he asks not almsgiving merely, but with largeness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:15
verses.text: Wherefore also he continually calls it "seed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:16
verses.text: For like as the corn cast into the ground showeth luxuriant crops, so also many are the handfuls almsgiving produceth of righteousness, and unspeakable the fruits it showeth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:17
verses.text: Then having prayed for great affluence unto them, he shows again in what they ought to expend it, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:18
verses.text: "That being enriched in every thing to all liberality, which worketh through us thanksgiving to God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:19
verses.text: Not that ye may consume it upon things not fitting, but upon such as bring much thanksgiving to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:20
verses.text: For God made us to have the disposal of great things, and reserving to Himself that which is less yielded to us that which is greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:21
verses.text: For corporeal nourishment is at His sole disposal, but mental He permitted to us; for we have it at our own disposal whether the crops we have to show be luxuriant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:22
verses.text: For no need is here of rains and of variety of seasons, but of the will only, and they run up to heaven itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:23
verses.text: And largeness in giving is what he here calls liberality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:24
verses.text: "Which worketh through us thanksgiving to God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:25
verses.text: For neither is that which is done almsgiving merely, but also the ground of much thanksgiving: yea rather, not of thanksgiving only, but of many other things besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:26
verses.text: And these as he goes on he mentions, that by showing it to be the cause of many good works, he may make them thereby the forwarder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:27
verses.text: What then are these many good works? Hear him saying:  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:29
verses.text: "For the ministration of this service, not only filleth up the measure of the wants of the saints, but aboundeth also through many thanksgivings unto God; seeing that through the proving of you by this ministration, they glorify God for the obedience of your confession unto the Gospel, and for the liberality of your contribution unto them and unto all; while they also with supplication on your behalf, long after you by reason of the exceeding grace of God in you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:30
verses.text: What he says is this; 'in the first place ye not only supply the wants of the saints, but ye are abundant even;' that is, 'ye furnish them with even more than they need: next, through them ye send up thanksgiving to God, for they glorify Him for the obedience of your confession.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:31
verses.text: ' For that he may not represent them as giving thanks on this account solely, (I mean, because they received somewhat,) see how high-minded he makes them, exactly as he himself says to the Philippians, "Not that I desire a gift".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:32
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:33
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:34
verses.text: ) 'To them too I bear record of the same thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:35
verses.text: For they rejoice indeed that ye supply their wants and alleviate their poverty; but far more, in that ye are so subjected to the Gospel; whereof this is an evidence, your contributing so largely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:36
verses.text: ' For this the Gospel enjoins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:37
verses.text: "And for the liberality of your contribution unto them and unto all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:38
verses.text: 'And on this account,' he says, 'they glorify God that ye are so liberal, not unto them only, but also unto all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:39
verses.text: ' And this again is made a praise unto them that they gave thanks even for that which is bestowed upon others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:40
verses.text: 'For,' saith he, 'they do honor, not to their own concerns only, but also to those of others, and this although they are in the extremest poverty; which is an evidence of their great virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:41
verses.text: For nothing is so full of envy as the whole race of such as are in poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:42
verses.text: But they are pure from this passion; being so far from feeling pained because of the things ye impart to others, that they even rejoice over it no less than over the things themselves receive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:43
verses.text: '  "While they themselves also with supplication".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:44
verses.text: 'For in respect of these things,' saith he, 'they give thanks to God, but in respect of your love and your coming together, they beseech Him that they may be counted worthy to see you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:45
verses.text: For they long after this, not for the money's sake, but that they may be witnesses of the grace that hath been bestowed upon you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:46
verses.text: ' Seest thou Paul's wisdom, how after having exalted them, he ascribed the whole to God by calling the thing "grace?" For seeing he had spoken great things of them, in that he called them ministers and exalted them unto a great height, (since they offered service whilst he himself did but administer,) and termed them 'proved,' he shows that God was the Author of all these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:47
verses.text: And he himself again, along with them, sends up thanksgiving, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:48
verses.text: "Thanks be to God for His unspeakable gift".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:49
verses.text: And here he calls "gift," even those so many good things which are wrought by almsgiving, both to them that receive and them that give; or else, those unspeakable good things which through His advent He gave unto the whole world with great munificence, which one may suspect to be the most probable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:50
verses.text: For that he may at once both sober, and make them more liberal, he puts them in mind of the benefits they had received from God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:51
verses.text: For this avails very greatly in inciting unto all virtue; and therefore he concluded his discourse with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:52
verses.text: But if His Gift be unspeakable, what can match their frenzy who raise curious questions as to His Essence? But not only is His Gift unspeakable, but that "peace" also "passeth all understanding," (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:53
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:54
verses.text: ) whereby He reconciled the things which are above with those which are below.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:55
verses.text: Seeing then that we are in the enjoyment of so great grace, let us strive to exhibit a virtue of life worthy of it, and to make much account of almsgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:56
verses.text: And this we shall do, if we shun excess and drunkenness and gluttony.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:57
verses.text: For God gave meat and drink not for excess, but for nourishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:58
verses.text: For it is not the wine that produceth drunkenness, for if that were the case, every body would needs be drunken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:59
verses.text: 'But,' saith one, 'it would be better, if even to drink it largely did not injure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:60
verses.text: ' These are drunkards' words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:61
verses.text: For if to drink it largely doth injure, and yet not even so thou desistest from thy excess in it; if this is so disgraceful and injurious, and yet thou ceasest not even so from thy depraved longing; if it were possible both to drink largely and be nothing harmed, where wouldest thou have stayed in thine excess? Wouldest thou not have longed that the rivers even might become wine? wouldest thou not have destroyed and ruined everything? If there is a mean in food which when we overpass we are injured, and yet even so thou canst not bear the curb, but snapping it as under seizest on what every body else hath, to minister to the wicked tyranny of this gluttony; what wouldest thou not have done, if this natural mean were abolished? wouldest thou not have spent thy whole time upon it? Would it then have been well to strengthen a lust so unreasonable, and not prevent the harm arising from excess? and to how many other harms would not this have given birth?  But O the senseless ones! who wallowing as in mire, in drunkeness and all other debauchery, when they have got a little sober again, sit down and do nothing but utter such sort of sayings, 'Why doth this end in this way?' when they ought to be condemning their own transgressions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:62
verses.text: For instead of what thou now sayest, 'Why hath He set bounds? why do not all things go on without any order?' say, 'Why do we not cease from being drunken? why are we never satiated? why are we more senseless than creatures without reason?' For these things they ought to ask one another, and to hearken to the voice of the Apostle and learn how many good things he witnesseth to the Corinthians proceed from almsgiving, and to seize upon this treasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:63
verses.text: For to contemn money maketh men approved, as he said; and provideth that God be glorified; and warmeth love; and worketh in men loftiness of soul; and constituteth them priests, yea of a priesthood that bringeth great reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:64
verses.text: For the merciful man is not arrayed in a vest reaching to the feet, nor does he carry about bells, nor wear a crown; but he is wrapped in the robe of loving-kindness, a holier than the sacred vestment; and is anointed with oil, not composed of material elements, but produced by the Spirit, and he beareth a crown of mercies, for it is said, "Who crowneth thee with pity and mercies;" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:65
verses.text: ciii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:66
verses.text: ) and instead of wearing a plate bearing the Name of God, is himself like to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:67
verses.text: For how? "Ye," saith He, "shall be like unto your Father which is in heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:68
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:69
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:70
verses.text: )  Wouldest thou see His altar also? Bezaleel built it not, nor any other but God Himself; not of stones, but of a material brighter than the heaven, of reasonable souls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:71
verses.text: But the priest entereth into the holy of holies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:72
verses.text: Into yet more awful places mayest thou enter when thou offerest this sacrifice, where none is present but "thy Father, Which seeth in secret," (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:73
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:74
verses.text: ) where no other beholdeth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:75
verses.text: 'And how,' saith one, 'is it possible that none should behold, when the altar standeth in public view?' Because this it is that is admirable, that in those times double doors and veils made the seclusion: but now, though doing thy sacrifice in public view, thou mayest do it as in the holy of holies, and in a far more awful manner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:76
verses.text: For when thou doest it not for display before men; though the whole world hath seen, none hath seen, because thou hast so done it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:77
verses.text: For He said not simply, "Do" it "not before men," but added, "to be seen of them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:78
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:79
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:80
verses.text: ) This altar is composed of the very members of Christ, and the body of the Lord is made thine altar.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:81
verses.text: That then revere; on the flesh of the Lord thou sacrificest the victim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:82
verses.text: This altar is more awful even than this which we now use, not only than that used of old.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:83
verses.text: Nay, clamor not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:84
verses.text: For this altar is admirable because of the sacrifice that is laid upon it: but that, the merciful man's, not only on this account, but also because it is even composed of the very sacrifice which maketh the other to be admired.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:85
verses.text: Again, this is but a stone by nature; but become holy because it receiveth Christ's Body: but that is holy because it is itself Christ's Body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:86
verses.text: So that this beside which thou, the layman, standest, is more awful than that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:87
verses.text: Whether then does Aaron seem to thee aught in comparison of this, or his crown, or his bells, or the holy of holies? For what need is there henceforth to make our comparison refer to Aaron's altar, when even compared with this, it has been shown to be so glorious? But thou honorest indeed this altar, because it receiveth Christ's body; but him that is himself the body of Christ thou treatest with contumely, and when perishing, neglectest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:88
verses.text: This altar mayest thou everywhere see lying, both in lanes and in market places, and mayest sacrifice upon it every hour; for on this too is sacrifice performed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:89
verses.text: And as the priest stands invoking the Spirit, so dost thou too invoke the Spirit, not by speech, but by deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:90
verses.text: For nothing doth so sustain and kindle the fire of the Spirit, as this oil largely poured out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:91
verses.text: But if thou wouldest see also what becomes of the things laid upon it, come hither, and I will show thee them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:92
verses.text: What then is the smoke, what the sweet savor of this altar? Praise and thanksgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:93
verses.text: And how far doth it ascend? as far as unto heaven? By no means, but it passeth beyond the heaven itself, and the heaven of heaven, and arriveth even at the throne of the King.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:94
verses.text: For, "Thy prayers," saith he, "and thine alms are come up before God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:95
verses.text: (Acts x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:96
verses.text: ) And the sweet savor which the sense perceives pierceth not far into the air, but this opened the very vault of heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:97
verses.text: And thou indeed art silent, but thy work speaketh: and a sacrifice of praise is made, no heifer slain nor hide burnt, but a spiritual soul presenting her proper offering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:98
verses.text: For such a sacrifice is more acceptable than any loving-kindness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:99
verses.text: When then thou seest a poor believer, think that thou beholdest an altar: when thou seest such an one a beggar, not only insult him not, but even reverence him, and if thou seest another insulting him, prevent, repel it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 21:100
verses.text: For so shalt thou thyself be able both to have God propitious to thee, and to obtain the promised good things, whereunto may we all attain, through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, by Whom and with Whom, to the Father and the Holy Ghost, be glory, might, honor, now and forever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:1
verses.text: Homily XXI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:3
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:4
verses.text: ,  Now I Paul myself entreat you by the meekness and gentleness of Christ, I who in your presence am lowly among you, but being absent am of good courage toward you: yea, I beseech you, that I may not when present show courage with the confidence, wherewith I count to be bold against some, which count of us as if we walked according to the flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:5
verses.text: Having completed, in such sort as behoved his discourse of almsgiving, and having shown that he loves them more than he is loved, and having recounted the circumstances of his patience and trials, he now opportunely enters upon points involving more of reproof, making allusion to the false apostles, and concluding his discourse with more disagreeable matter, and with commendations of himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:6
verses.text: For he makes this his business also throughout the Epistle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:7
verses.text: Which also perceiving, he hence oftentimes corrects himself, saying in so many words; "Do we begin again to commend ourselves?" (Ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:8
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:9
verses.text: ) and further on; "We commend not ourselves again, but give you occasion to glory:" (Ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:10
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:11
verses.text: ) and afterwards; "I am become a fool in glorying; ye have compelled me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:12
verses.text: (Ch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:13
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:14
verses.text: ) And many such correctives doth he use.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:15
verses.text: And one would not be wrong in styling this Epistle an eulogium of Paul; he makes such large mention both of his grace and his patience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:16
verses.text: For since there were some amongst them who thought great things of themselves, and set themselves above the Apostle, and accused him as a boaster, and as being nothing, and teaching no sound doctrine; (now this was in itself the most certain evidence of their own corruptness;) see how he begins his rebuke of them; "Now I Paul myself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:17
verses.text: Seest thou what severity, what dignity, is here? For what he would say is this, 'I beseech you do not compel me, nor leave me to use my power against those that hold us cheap, and think of us as carnal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:18
verses.text: ' This is severer than those threats towards them uttered in the former Epistle; "Shall I come unto you with a rod, or in love and a spirit of meekness?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:19
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:20
verses.text: ) and then again; "Now some are puffed up as though I were not coming to you; but I will come, and will know, not the word of them that are puffed up, but the power".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:21
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:23
verses.text: ) For in this place he shows both things, both his power, and his philosophy and forbearance; since he so beseeches them, and with such earnestness, that he may not be compelled to come to a display of the avenging power pertaining to him, and to smite and chastise them and exact the extreme penalty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:24
verses.text: For he implied this in saying, "But I beseech you, that I may not when present show courage with the confidence, wherewith I count to be bold against some which count of us as if we walked according to the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:25
verses.text: For the present, however, let us speak of the commencement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:26
verses.text: "Now I Paul myself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:27
verses.text: Great emphasis, great weight is here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:28
verses.text: So he says elsewhere, "Behold I Paul say unto you;" (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:29
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:30
verses.text: ) and again, "As Paul the aged;" (Philem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:31
verses.text: ) and again in another place, "Who hath been a succorer of many, and of me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:32
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:33
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:34
verses.text: ) So also here, "Now I Paul myself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:35
verses.text: This even is a great thing, that himself beseecheth; but that other is greater which he added, saying, "by the meekness and gentleness of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:36
verses.text: For with the wish of greatly shaming them, he puts forward that "meekness and gentleness," making his entreaty in this way more forcible; as if he had said, 'Reverence the gentleness of Christ by which I beseech you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:37
verses.text: ' And this he said, at the same time also showing that although they should lay ever so strong a necessity upon him, he himself is more inclined to this: it is from being meek, not from want of power, that he does not proceed against them: for Christ also did in like manner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:38
verses.text: "Who in your presence am lowly among you, but being absent am of good courage toward you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:39
verses.text: What, pray, is this? Surely he speaks in irony, using their speeches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:40
verses.text: For they said this, that 'when he is present indeed, he is worthy of no account, but poor and contemptible; but when absent, swells, and brags, and sets himself up against us, and threatens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:41
verses.text: ' This at least he implies also afterwards, saying, "for his letters," say they, "are weighty, but his bodily presence is weak, and his speech of no account".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:43
verses.text: ) He either then speaks in irony, manifesting great severity and saying, 'I, the base, I, the mean, when present, (as they say,) and when absent, lofty:' or else meaning that even though he should utter great things, it is not out of pride, but out of his confidence in them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:44
verses.text: "But I beseech you, that I may not when present show courage with the confidence, wherewith I count to be bold against some which count of us as if we walked according to the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:45
verses.text: Seest thou how great his indignation, and how complete his refutation of those sayings of theirs? For he saith, 'I beseech you, do not compel me to show that even present I am strong and have power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:46
verses.text: ' For since they said that 'when absent, he is quite bold against us and exalteth himself,' he uses their very words, 'I beseech therefore that they compel me not to use my power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:47
verses.text: ' For this is the meaning of, "the confidence".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:48
verses.text: And he said not, 'wherewith I am prepared,' but 'wherewith I count.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:49
verses.text: ' 'For I have not yet resolved upon this; they however give me reason enough, but not even so do I wish it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:50
verses.text: ' And yet he was doing this not to vindicate himself, but the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:51
verses.text: Now if where it was necessary to vindicate the Message, he is not harsh, but draws back and delays, and beseeches that there may be no such necessity; much more would he never have done any thing of the kind in his own vindication.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:52
verses.text: 'Grant me then this favor,' he saith, 'that ye compel me not to show, that even when present I am able to be bold against whomsoever it may be necessary; that is, to chastise and punish them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:53
verses.text: ' Seest thou how free he was from ambition, how he did nothing for display, since even where it was matter of necessity, he hesitates not to call the act, boldness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:54
verses.text: "For I beseech you," he says, "that I may not when present show courage with the confidence, wherewith I think to be bold" against some.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:55
verses.text: For this especially is the part of a teacher, not to be hasty in taking vengeance, but to work a reformation, and ever to be reluctant and slow in his punishments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:56
verses.text: How, pray, does he describe those whom he threatens? "Those that count of us as though we walked according to the flesh:" for they accused him as a hypocrite, as wicked, as a boaster.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:57
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:58
verses.text: "For though we walk in the flesh, we do not war according to the flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:59
verses.text: Here he goes on to alarm them also by the figure he uses, 'for,' says he, 'we are indeed encompassed with flesh; I own it, but we do not live by the flesh;' or rather, he said not even this, but for the present reserves it, for it belongs to the encomium on his life: but first discourseth of the Preaching, and shows that it is not of man, nor needeth aid from beneath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:60
verses.text: Wherefore he said not, 'we do not live according to the flesh,' but, "we do not war according to the flesh," that is, 'we have undertaken a war and a combat; but we do not war with carnal weapons, nor by help of any human succors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:61
verses.text: '  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:62
verses.text: "For our weapons are not of the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:63
verses.text: For what sort of weapons are of the flesh? Wealth, glory, power, fluency, cleverness, circumventions, flatteries, hypocrisies, whatsoever else is similar to these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:64
verses.text: But ours are not of this sort: but of what kind are they?  "Mighty before God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:65
verses.text: And he said not, 'we are not carnal,' but, "our weapons".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:66
verses.text: For as I said, for the present he discourseth of the Preaching, and refers the whole power to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:67
verses.text: And he says not, 'spiritual,' although this was the fitting opposite to "carnal," but "mighty," in this implying the other also, and showing that their weapons are weak and powerless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:68
verses.text: And mark the absence of pride in him; for he said not, 'we are mighty,' but, "our weapons are mighty before God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:69
verses.text: 'We did not make them such, but God Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:70
verses.text: ' For because they were scourged, were persecuted, and suffered wrongs incurable without number, which things were proofs of weakness: to show the strength of God he says, "but they are mighty before God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:71
verses.text: For this especially shows His strength, that by these things He gains the victory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:72
verses.text: So that even though we are encompassed with them, yet it is He that warreth and worketh by them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:73
verses.text: Then he goes through a long eulogium upon them, saying,  "To the casting down of strong holds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:74
verses.text: And lest when hearing of strong holds thou shouldest think of aught material, he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:75
verses.text: "Casting down imaginations".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:76
verses.text: First giving emphasis by the figure, and then by this additional expression declaring the spiritual character of the warfare.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:77
verses.text: For these strongholds besiege souls, not bodies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:78
verses.text: Whence they are stronger than the others, and therefore also the weapons they require are mightier.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:79
verses.text: But by strongholds he means the Grecian pride, and the strength of their sophisms and their syllogisms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:80
verses.text: But nevertheless, 'these weapons,' he says, 'confounded every thing that stood up against them; for they cast down imaginations,  'And every high thing that is exalted against the knowledge of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:81
verses.text: ' He persisted in the metaphor that he might make the emphasis greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:82
verses.text: 'For though there should be strongholds,' he saith, 'though fortifications, though any other thing soever, they yield and give way before these weapons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:83
verses.text: "And bringing every thought into captivity to the obedience of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:84
verses.text: And yet the name, "captivity," hath an ill sound with it; for it is the destruction of liberty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:85
verses.text: Wherefore then has he used it? With a meaning of its own, in regard to another point.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:86
verses.text: For the word "captivity" conveys two ideas, the loss of liberty, and the being so violently overpowered as not to rise up again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:87
verses.text: It is therefore in respect to this second meaning that he took it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:88
verses.text: As when he shall say "I robbed other churches," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:89
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:90
verses.text: ) he does not intend the taking stealthily, but the stripping and taking their all, so also here in saying, "bringing into captivity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:91
verses.text: For the fight was not equally maintained, but he conquered with great ease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:92
verses.text: Wherefore he did not say, 'we conquer and have the better,' only; but 'we even bring "into captivity;"' just as above, he did not say, 'we advance engines against the "strongholds:"' but, 'we cast them down, for great is the superiority of our weapons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:93
verses.text: ' 'For we war not with words,' he saith, but with deeds against words, not with fleshly wisdom, but with the spirit of meekness and of power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:94
verses.text: How was it likely then I should hunt after honor, and boast in words, and threaten by letters;' (as they accused him, saying, "his letters are weighty,") 'when our might lay not in these things?' But having said, "bringing every thought into captivity to the obedience of Christ," because the name of "captivity" was unpleasant, he presently afterwards put an end to the metaphor, saying, "unto the obedience of Christ:" from slavery unto liberty, from death unto life, from destruction to salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:95
verses.text: For we came not merely to strike down, but to bring over to the truth those who are opposed to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:96
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:97
verses.text: "And being in readiness to avenge all disobedience, when your obedience shall be fulfilled".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:98
verses.text: Here he alarmed these also, not those alone: 'for,' says he, 'we were waiting for you, that when by our exhortations and threatenings we have reformed you, and purged and separated you from their fellowship; then, when those only are left who are incurably diseased, we may visit with punishment, after we see that you have really separated from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:99
verses.text: For even now indeed ye obey, but not perfectly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:100
verses.text: ' 'And yet if thou hadst done it now,' saith one, 'thou wouldest have wrought greater gain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:101
verses.text: ' 'By no means, for if I had done it now, I should have involved you also in the punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:102
verses.text: Howbeit it behoved to punish them, indeed, but to spare you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:103
verses.text: Yet if I spared, I should have seemed to do it out of favor: now this I do not desire, but first to amend you, and then to proceed against them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:104
verses.text: ' What can be tenderer than the heart of the Apostle? who because he saw his own mixed up with aliens, desires indeed to inflict the blow, but forbears, and restrains his indignation until these shall have withdrawn, that he may smite these alone; yea rather, not these even.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:105
verses.text: For he therefore threatens this, and says he is desirous to separate unto punishment them alone, that they also being amended by the fear may change, and he let loose his anger against no one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:106
verses.text: For just like a most excellent physician, and common father, and patron, and guardian, so did he all things, so cared he for all, removing impediments, checking the pestilent, running about every whither.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:107
verses.text: For not by fighting did he so achieve the work, but advancing as if to a ready and an easy victory, he planted his trophies, undermining, casting down, overthrowing the strongholds of the devil, and the engines of the demons; and carried over their whole booty to the camp of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:108
verses.text: Nor did he even take breath a little, bounding off from these to those, and from those again to others, like some very able general, raising trophies every day, or rather every hour.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:109
verses.text: For having entered into the battle with nothing but a little tunic, the tongue of Paul took the cities of his enemies with their men and bows and spears and darts and all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:110
verses.text: For he spake only; and, falling upon his enemies more fiercely than any fire, his words drave out the demons and brought over unto him the men that were possessed of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:111
verses.text: For when he cast out that demon, the evil one, fifty thousand sorcerers coming together burnt their books of magic and revolted to the truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:112
verses.text: (See Acts xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:113
verses.text: ) And like as in a war, when a tower has fallen or a tyrant been brought low, all his partizans cast away their arms and run unto the opposing general; so truly did it happen then also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:114
verses.text: For when the demon was cast out, they all having been besieged, and having cast away, yea rather having destroyed, their books, ran unto the feet of Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:115
verses.text: But he setting himself against the world as though against a single army, no where stayed his march, but did all things as if he were some man endued with wings: and now restored a lame, now raised a dead man, now blinded a third, (I mean the sorcerer,) nor even when shut up in a prison indulged in rest, but even there brought over to himself the jailor, effecting the goodly captivity we treat of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:116
verses.text: Let us also imitate him after our power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:117
verses.text: And why do I say, after our power? For he that wills may come even near unto him, and behold his valor, and imitate his heroism.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:118
verses.text: For still he is doing this work, "casting down imaginations, and every high thing that is exalted against the knowledge of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:119
verses.text: And although many heretics have attempted to cut him in pieces; yet still, even though dismembered, he displayeth a mighty strength.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:120
verses.text: For both Marcion and Manichaeus use him indeed, but after cutting him in pieces; but still even so they are refuted by the several members.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:121
verses.text: For even a hand only of this champion being found among them puts them utterly to the rout; and a foot only, left amongst others, pursues and prostrates them, in order that thou mayest learn the superabundance of his power, and that, although shorn of his limbs even, he is able to destroy all his adversaries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:122
verses.text: 'This however,' saith one, 'is an instance of perversion, that those who are battling with each other should all use him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:123
verses.text: ' An instance of perversion certainly, but not in Paul, (God forbid,) but in them who use him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:124
verses.text: For he was not parti-colored, but uniform and clear, but they perverted his words to their own notions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:125
verses.text: 'And wherefore,' saith one, 'were they so spoken as to give handles to those that wished for them?'
