He did not give handles, but their frenzy used his words not rightly; since this whole world also is both wonderful and great, and a sure proof of the wisdom of God, and "the heavens declare the glory of God, and day unto day uttereth speech, and night unto night declareth knowledge;" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:126
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:128
verses.text: ) but nevertheless, many have stumbled at it and in contrary directions to one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:129
verses.text: And some have admired it so much above its worth as to think it God; whilst others have been so insensible of its beauty as to assert it to be unworthy of God's creating hand, and to ascribe the greater share in it to a certain evil matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:130
verses.text: And yet God provided for both points by making it beautiful and great that it might not be deemed alien from his wisdom; yet defective and not sufficient unto itself that it might not be suspected to be God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:131
verses.text: But nevertheless those who were blinded by their own reasonings fell away into contradictory notions, refuting one another, and becoming each the other's accuser, and vindicating the wisdom of God even by the very reasonings which led them astray.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:132
verses.text: And why do I speak of the sun and the heaven? The Jews saw so many marvels happen before their eyes, yet straightway worshipped a calf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:133
verses.text: Again they saw Christ casting out demons, yet called him one that had a demon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:134
verses.text: But this was no imputation against him that cast them out, but an accusation of their understanding who were so blinded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:135
verses.text: Condemn not then Paul on account of their judgment who have used him amiss; but understand well the treasures in him, and develop his riches, so shalt thou make noble stand against all, fenced by his armor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:136
verses.text: So shalt thou be able to stop the mouths both of Greeks and Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:137
verses.text: 'And how,' saith one, 'seeing they believe him not?' By the things wrought through him, by the reformation effected in the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:138
verses.text: For it was not of human power that so great things could be done, but the Might of the Crucified, breathing on him, made him such as he was, and showed him more powerful than orators and philosophers and tyrants and kings and all men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:139
verses.text: He was not only able to arm himself and to strike down his adversaries, but to make others also such as himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:140
verses.text: Therefore in order that we may become useful both to ourselves and to others, let us continually have him in our hands, using his writings for a meadow and garden of delight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 22:141
verses.text: For so shall we be able both to be delivered from vice and to choose virtue, and to obtain the promised good things, whereunto may we all attain, through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father with the Holy Spirit, be glory, might, honor, now and for ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:1
verses.text: Homily XXII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:3
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:4
verses.text: Ye look at the things that are before your face.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:5
verses.text: If any man trusteth in himself that he is Christ's, let him consider this again with himself that even as he is Christ's, so also are we.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:6
verses.text: What one may especially admire in Paul amongst other things is this, that when he has fallen upon an urgent necessity for exalting himself, he manages both to accomplish this point, and also not to appear offensive to the many on account of this egotism; a thing we may see particularly in his Epistle to the Galatians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:7
verses.text: For having there fallen upon such an argument, he provides for both these points; a matter of the very utmost difficulty and demanding much prudence; he is at once modest and says somewhat great of himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:8
verses.text: And observe how in this place also he makes it of great account, "Ye look at the things that are before your face".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:9
verses.text: Behold here also prudence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:10
verses.text: For having rebuked those that deceived them, he confined not his remarks to them, but he leaps away from them to these too; and he does so constantly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:11
verses.text: For, in truth, he scourgeth not those only that lead astray, but the deceived also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:12
verses.text: For had he let even them go without calling them to an account, they would not so easily have been reformed by what was said to the others; but would have been greatly elated even, as not being amenable to accusations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:13
verses.text: Therefore he scourgeth them also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:14
verses.text: And this is not all that is to be admired in him, but this farther, that he rebukes either party in a manner suitable to each.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:15
verses.text: Hear at least what he says to these, "Ye look at the things that are before your face".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:16
verses.text: The accusation is no light one; but a mark of men exceedingly easy to be deceived.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:17
verses.text: Now what he says is this, 'ye test by what appear, by things carnal, by things bodily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:18
verses.text: ' What is meant by 'what appear?' If one is rich, if one is puffed up, if one is surrounded by many flatterers, if one says great things of himself, if one is vain-glorious, if one makes a pretence of virtue without having virtue, for this is the meaning of, "ye look at the things that are before your face".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:19
verses.text: "If any man trust in himself that he is Christ's, let him consider this again with himself, that even as he is Christ's, even so also are we".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:20
verses.text: For he does not wish to be vehement at the beginning, but he increases and draws to a head by little and little.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:21
verses.text: But observe here how much harshness and covert meaning there is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:22
verses.text: He shows this by using the words "with himself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:23
verses.text: For he saith, 'Let him not wait to learn this from us; that is, by our rebuke of himself,' but "let him consider this with himself, that even as he is Christ's, so also are we;" not that he was Christ's in such manner as the other was, but, "that even as he is Christ's, so also am I Christ's".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:24
verses.text: Thus far the community holds good: for it is not surely the case that he indeed is Christ's, but I some other's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:25
verses.text: Then having laid down this equality between them, he goes on to add wherein he exceeded, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:26
verses.text: "For though I should glory somewhat abundantly concerning our authority which the Lord gave for building you up, and not for casting you down, I shall not be put to shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:27
verses.text: For since he was going to say somewhat great, observe how he softens it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:28
verses.text: For nothing doth so offend the majority of hearers as for any one to praise himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:29
verses.text: Wherefore to cut at the root of this offensiveness, he says, "For though I should glory somewhat abundantly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:30
verses.text: And he did not say, 'if any man trust that he is Christ's let him think that he is far short of us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:31
verses.text: For I possess much authority from Him, so as to punish and to kill whomsoever I choose;' but what? "For though I should glory even somewhat abundantly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:32
verses.text: And yet he possessed more than can be told, but nevertheless he lowers it in his way of speaking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:33
verses.text: And he said not, 'I glory,' but, "if I should glory," if I should choose to do so: at once both showing modesty, and declaring his superiority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:34
verses.text: If therefore he says, "I should glory concerning the authority which the Lord gave me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:35
verses.text: Again, he ascribes the whole to Him, and makes the gift common.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:36
verses.text: "For building up, and not for casting down".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:37
verses.text: Seest thou how again he allays the envy his praises might give rise to, and draws the hearer over to himself by mentioning the use for which he received it? Then why doth he say, "Casting down imaginations?" Because this is itself an especial form of building up, the removing of hindrances, and detecting the unsound, and laying the true together in the building.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:38
verses.text: For this end therefore we received it, that we might build up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:39
verses.text: But if any should spar and battle with us, and be incurable, we will use that other power also, destroying and overthrowing him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:40
verses.text: Wherefore also he says, "I shall not be put to shame," that is, I shall not be proved a liar or a boaster.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:41
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:43
verses.text: "But that I may not seem as if I would terrify you: for his letters, say they, are weighty and strong: but his bodily presence is weak, and his speech of no account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:44
verses.text: Let such a one reckon this, that what we are in word by letters when we are absent, such are we also in deed when we are present".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:45
verses.text: What he says is this: 'I could boast indeed, but that they may not say the same things again, to wit, that I boast in my letters, and am contemptible when present, I will say nothing great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:46
verses.text: ' And yet afterwards he did say something great, but not about this power by which he was formidable, but about revelations and at greater lengths about trials.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:47
verses.text: 'Therefore, that I may not seem to be terrifying you, "let such an one reckon this, that what we are by letters when we are absent, such are we also in deed when we are present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:48
verses.text: '" For since they said, 'he writes great things of himself, but when he is present he is worthy of no consideration,' therefore he says these things, and those again in a moderated form.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:49
verses.text: For he did not say, 'as we write great things, so when we are present we also do great things,' but in more subdued phrase.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:50
verses.text: For when he addressed himself to the others indeed, he stated it with vehemency, saying, "I beseech you that I may not when present show courage with the confidence wherewith I think to be bold against some:" but when to these, he is more subdued.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:51
verses.text: And therefore he says, 'what we are when present, such too when absent, that is, lowly, modest, no where boasting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:52
verses.text: And it is plain from what follows,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:53
verses.text: "For we are not bold to number, or compare in ourselves with some that commend themselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:54
verses.text: Here he both shows that those false Apostles are boasters and say great things of themselves: and ridicules them as commending themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:55
verses.text: 'But we do no such thing: but even if we shall do any thing great, we refer all unto God, and compare ourselves with one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:56
verses.text: ' Wherefore also he added,  "But they themselves measuring themselves by themselves and comparing themselves among themselves are without understanding".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:57
verses.text: Now what he says is this: 'we do not compare ourselves with them, but with one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:58
verses.text: ' For further on he says, "in nothing am I behind the very chiefest Apostles;" (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:59
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:60
verses.text: ) and in the former Epistle, "I labored more abundantly than they all;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:61
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:62
verses.text: ) and again, "Truly the signs of an Apostle were wrought among you in all patience".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:63
verses.text: (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:64
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:65
verses.text: ) 'So that we compare ourselves with ourselves, not with those that have nothing: for such arrogance cometh of folly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:66
verses.text: ' Either then he says this with reference to himself, or with reference to them, that 'we dare not compare ourselves with those who contend with one another and boast great things and do not understand:' that is, do not perceive how ridiculous they are in being thus arrogant, and in exalting themselves amongst one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:67
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:68
verses.text: "But we will not glory beyond our measure:" as they do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:69
verses.text: For it is probable that in their boasting they said, 'we have converted the world, we have reached unto the ends of the earth,' and vented many other such like big words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:70
verses.text: 'But not so we,' he says,  "But according to the measure of the province which God apportioned to us as a measure, to reach even unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:71
verses.text: So that his humility is evident on either hand, both in that he boasted nothing more than he had wrought, and that he refers even this itself to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:72
verses.text: For, "according to the measure of the province," saith he, "which God apportioned to us, a measure to reach even unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:73
verses.text: Just as if portioning out a vine to husbandmen, even so He meted out unto us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:74
verses.text: As far then as we have been counted worthy to attain to, so far we boast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:75
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:76
verses.text: "For we stretch not ourselves overmuch, as though we reached not unto you: for we came even as far as unto you in preaching the Gospel of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:77
verses.text: Not simply 'we came,' but, 'we announced, we preached, we persuaded, we succeeded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:78
verses.text: ' For it is probable that they having merely come to the disciples of the Apostles, ascribed the whole to themselves, from their bare presence among them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:79
verses.text: 'But not so we: nor can any one say that we were not able to come as far as to you, and that we stretched our boasting as far as to you in words only; for we also preached the word to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:80
verses.text: '   Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:82
verses.text: "Not glorying beyond" our "measure," that is, "in other men's labors, but having hope that as your faith groweth, we shall be magnified in you according to our province unto further abundance, so as to preach the Gospel even unto the parts beyond you, and not to glory in another's province in regard of things ready to our hand".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:83
verses.text: He sets forth a large accusation of them on these grounds, both that they boasted of things without their measure, and of other men's labors; and that whilst the whole of the toil was the Apostles', they plumed themselves upon their labors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:84
verses.text: 'But we,' says he, 'showed these things in our deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:85
verses.text: We will not imitate those men therefore, but will say such things where our deeds bear us witness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:86
verses.text: And why,' saith he, 'do I say, you?' "for I have hope that as your faith groweth;" for he doth not assert absolutely, preserving his own character, but, 'I hope,' he says, 'if you make progress, that our province will be extended even farther, "to preach the Gospel in the regions beyond".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:87
verses.text: For we shall advance farther yet,' he says, 'so as to preach and labor, not so as to boast in words of what other men have labored.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:88
verses.text: ' And well did he call it "province and measure," as though he had come into possession of the world, and a rich inheritance; and showing that the whole was wholly God's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:89
verses.text: 'Having then such works,' he says, 'and expecting greater, we do not boast as they do who have nothing, nor do we ascribe any part to ourselves, but the whole to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:90
verses.text: Wherefore also he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:91
verses.text: "He that glorieth, let him glory in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:92
verses.text: This also, he saith, accrueth to us from God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:93
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:94
verses.text: "For not he that commendeth himself is approved, but whom the Lord commendeth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:95
verses.text: He did not say, we are so, "but whom the Lord commendeth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:96
verses.text: Seest thou how modestly he speaks? But if as he proceeds he stirreth up loftier words, wonder not, for this also cometh of Paul's prudence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:97
verses.text: For if he had gone on in every part to speak lowly words, he would not have hit these men so effectually, nor have extricated the disciples from their error.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:98
verses.text: For it is possible both by modesty ill-timed to do harm, and by saying something admirable of one's self at a proper time to do good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:99
verses.text: As therefore he also did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:100
verses.text: For there was no little danger in the disciples being persuaded into any mean opinion of Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:101
verses.text: Not that Paul sought the glory that cometh of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:102
verses.text: For had he sought this, he would not have kept silence so long on those great and marvellous matters of "fourteen years ago;" (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:103
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:104
verses.text: ) nor would he, when necessity was laid upon him, have so shrunk back and hesitated to speak of them; very evidently he would not even then have spoken, had he not been compelled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:105
verses.text: Certainly then it was not from a desire after the glory which cometh from men that he said these things, but out of tender care for the disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:106
verses.text: For since they cast reproaches at him as a braggart, and as boastful in words but able to show nothing in deeds, he is compelled subsequently to come to those revelations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:107
verses.text: Although he had it in his power to convince them by his deeds, at the time when he said these things: yet he still persists, nevertheless, in using menaces in words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:108
verses.text: For he was most especially free from vain-glory; and this his whole life proves, both before and after this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:109
verses.text: For instance, it was because of this that he changed all at once; and having changed, confounded the Jews and cast away all that honor he had from them, although he was himself their head and their champion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:110
verses.text: But he considered none of those things when he had found the truth; but took instead their insults and contumely; for he looked to the salvation of the many, thinking this everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:111
verses.text: For he that thinketh nothing of hell nor of heaven nor of ten thousand worlds in regard of his longing after Christ, how should he hunt after the glory which cometh from the many? By no means; but he is even very lowly when he may be so, and brands his former life with infamy when he calls himself, "a blasphemer, and a persecutor, and injurious".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:112
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:113
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:114
verses.text: ) And his disciple Luke too says many things of him, evidently having learnt them from himself, himself displaying fully his former life no less than that after his conversion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:115
verses.text: Now I say these things, not that we may hear merely, but that we may learn also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:116
verses.text: For if he remembered those transgressions before the Laver, although they were all effaced, what forgiveness can we have who are unmindful of those after the Laver ourselves? What sayest thou, O man? Thou hast offended God, and dost thou forget? This is a second offence, a second enmity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:117
verses.text: Of what sins then dost thou ask forgiveness? Of those which thou even knowest not thyself? Surely, (for is it not so?) thou art deeply anxious and thoughtful how thou mayest give account of them, thou who dost not so much as care to remember them, but sportest with what is no sporting matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:118
verses.text: But there will come a time when our sport can go on no longer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:119
verses.text: For we must needs die: (for the great insensibility of the many obliges me to speak even of things that are evident:) and must needs rise again, and be judged, and be punished; nay rather this needs not, if we choose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:120
verses.text: For those other things are not at our own disposal; neither our end, nor our resurrection, nor our judgment, but at our Lord's; but our suffering punishment or not is at our own disposal; for this is of those things that may or may not happen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:121
verses.text: But if we choose, we shall make it of the number of impossible things; just as Paul, as Peter, as all the saints did; for it is even impossible for them to be punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:122
verses.text: If therefore we have a mind, it is in like manner impossible also that we should suffer ought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:123
verses.text: For even if we have offended in ten thousand things, it is possible to recover ourselves so long as we are here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:124
verses.text: Let us then recover ourselves: and let the old man consider that in a little while hence he will depart, since he took his pleasure long enough in his lifetime; (although what sort of pleasure is this, to live in wickedness? but for the present I so speak in respect to his way of thinking;) let him consider, besides, that it is possible for him in a short time to wash away all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:125
verses.text: The young man again, let him also consider the uncertainty of death, and that oftentimes, when many older persons continued here, the young were carried off before them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:126
verses.text: For, for this reason, that we may not make traffic of our death, it is left in uncertainty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:127
verses.text: Wherefore also a certain wise man adviseth, saying, "Make no tarrying to turn unto the Lord, and put not off from day to day: for thou knowest not what to-morrow shall bring forth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:128
verses.text: (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:129
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:130
verses.text: ; Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:131
verses.text: xxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:132
verses.text: ) For by putting off there is danger and fear; but by not putting off manifest and secure salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:133
verses.text: Hold fast then by virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:134
verses.text: For so, even if thou have departed young, thou hast departed in safety; and if thou shouldst come to old age, thou shalt arrive at death with great provision made, and shalt have a double feast all thy life long; both in that thou abstainest from vice, and layest hold on virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:135
verses.text: Say not, 'there will come a time when it may be well to turn,' for this language provokes God exceedingly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:136
verses.text: And why so? Because He hath promised thee countless ages, but thou art not even willing to labor during this present life, this short life that dureth but a season; but art so indolent and unmanly as to seek a shorter even than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:137
verses.text: Are there not the same revellings daily? Are there not the same tables, the same harlots, the same theatres, the same wealth? How long wilt thou love those things as though they were aught? How long will thy appetite for evil remain insatiate? Consider that as often as thou hast fornicated, so often hast thou condemned thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:138
verses.text: For such is the nature of sin: once committed, the Judge hath also passed his sentence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:139
verses.text: Hast thou been drunken, been gluttonous, or robbed? Hold now, turn right back, acknowledge it to God as a mercy that He snatched thee not away in the midst of thy sins; seek not yet another set time wherein to work evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:140
verses.text: Many have been snatched away in the midst of their covetousness, and have departed to manifest punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:141
verses.text: Fear lest thou also shouldest suffer this, and without excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:142
verses.text: 'But God gave to many a set time for confession in extreme old age.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:143
verses.text: ' What then? Will He give it to thee also? 'Perhaps He will,' says one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:144
verses.text: Why sayest thou 'perhaps,' and 'sometimes,' and 'often?' Consider that thou art deliberating about thy soul, and put also the contrary case, and calculate, and say, 'But what if He should not give it?' 'But what if He should give it?' saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:145
verses.text: God hath indeed given it; but still this supposition is safer and more profitable than that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:146
verses.text: For if thou begin now, thou hast gained all, whether thou hast a set time granted thee or not; but if thou art always putting off, for this very cause perhaps thou shalt not have one given thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:147
verses.text: When thou goest out to battle, thou dost not say, 'there is no need to make my will, perhaps I shall come back safe;' nor dost thou when deliberating about marriage, say 'suppose I take a poor wife, many have even in this way got rich contrary to expectation;' nor when building a house, 'suppose I lay a rotten foundation, many houses have stood even so;' yet in deliberating about the soul, thou leanest on things more rotten still; urging thy 'perhaps,' and 'often,' and 'sometimes,' and trustest thyself to these uncertainties.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:148
verses.text: 'Nay,' saith one, 'not to an uncertainty, but to the mercy of God, for God is merciful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:149
verses.text: ' I know it too; but still this merciful God snatched those away of whom I spoke.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:150
verses.text: And what if after thou hast had time given thee, thou shalt still continue as thou wert? for this sort of man will be listless even in old age.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:151
verses.text: 'Nay,' he said, 'not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:152
verses.text: ' For this mode of reasoning even after the eighty years desireth ninety, and after the ninety an hundred, and after the hundred will be yet more indisposed to act.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:153
verses.text: And so the whole of life will have been consumed in vain, and what was spoken of the Jews will happen also to thee; "Their days were consumed in vanity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:154
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:155
verses.text: lxxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:156
verses.text: ) And would that in vanity only, and not unto evil also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:157
verses.text: For when we have departed thither bearing the heavy burden of our sins, this will be unto evil also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:158
verses.text: For we shall carry away fuel for the fire and a plentiful feast for the worm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 23:159
verses.text: Wherefore I pray and conjure you to halt at length in noble wise, and to desist from wickedness, that we may also obtain the promised good things: whereunto may we all attain, through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, together with the Holy Spirit, be glory, might, honor, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:1
verses.text: Homily XXIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:3
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:4
verses.text: Would that ye could bear with me in a little foolishness and, indeed ye do bear with me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:5
verses.text: Being about to enter upon his own praises he uses much previous correction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:6
verses.text: And he does this not once or twice, although the necessity of the subject, and what he had often said, were sufficient excuse for him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:7
verses.text: For he that remembereth sins which God remembered not, and who therefore saith that he was unworthy of the very name of the Apostles, even by the most insensate is seen clearly not to be saying what he is now going to say, for the sake of glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:8
verses.text: For if one must say something startling, even this would be especially injurious to his glory, his speaking something about himself; and to the more part it is offensive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:9
verses.text: But nevertheless he regarded not timidly any of these things, but he looked to one thing, the salvation of his hearers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:10
verses.text: But still in order that he might not cause harm to the unthinking by this, by saying, I mean, great things of himself, he employs out of abundant caution these many preparatory correctives, and says, "Would that ye could bear with me," whilst I play the fool in some little things, yea, rather, "ye do indeed bear with me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:11
verses.text: Beholdest thou wisdom? For when he says, "would that," it is as putting it at their disposal: but when he even asserts that they do, it is as confiding greatly in their affection, and as declaring that he both loves and is loved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:12
verses.text: Yea, rather, not from bare love merely, but from a sort of warm and insane passion he says that they ought to bear with him even when he plays the fool.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:13
verses.text: And therefore he added, "For I am jealous over you with a godly jealousy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:14
verses.text: He did not say, 'for I love you,' but uses a term far more vehement than this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:15
verses.text: For those souls are jealous which burn ardently for those they love, and jealousy can in no other way be begotten than out of a vehement affection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:16
verses.text: Then that they may not think, that it is for the sake of power, or honor, or wealth, or any other such like thing, that he desires their affection, he added, "with a jealousy of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:17
verses.text: For God also is said to be jealous, not that any should suppose passion, (for the Godhead is impassible,) but that all may know that He doeth all things from no other regard than their sakes over whom He is jealous; not that Himself may gain aught, but that He may save them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:18
verses.text: Among men indeed jealousy ariseth not from this cause, but for the sake of their own repose; not because the beloved ones sustain outrage, but lest these who love them should be wounded, and be outshone in the good graces, and stand lower in the affections, of the beloved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:19
verses.text: But here it is not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:20
verses.text: 'For I care not,' he says, 'for this, lest I should stand lower in your esteem; but lest I should see you corrupted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:21
verses.text: For such is God's jealousy; and such is mine also, intense at once and pure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:22
verses.text: ' Then there is also this necessary reason;  "For I espoused you to one husband, as a pure virgin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:23
verses.text: 'Therefore I am jealous, not for myself, but for him to whom I have espoused you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:24
verses.text: ' For the present time is the time of espousal, but the time of the nuptials is another; when they sing, 'the Bridegroom hath risen up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:25
verses.text: ' Oh what things unheard of! In the world they are virgins before the marriage, but after the marriage no longer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:26
verses.text: But here it is not so: but even though they be not virgins before this marriage, after the marriage they become virgins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:27
verses.text: So the whole Church is a virgin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:28
verses.text: For addressing himself even to all, both husbands and wives, he speaks thus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:29
verses.text: But let us see what he brought and espoused us with, what kind of nuptial gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:30
verses.text: Not gold, not silver, but the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:31
verses.text: Wherefore also he said, "We are ambassadors on behalf of Christ," and beseeches them, when he was about to receive the Bride.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:32
verses.text: What happened in Abraham's case was a type of this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:33
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:34
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:36
verses.text: ) For he sent his faithful servant to seek a Gentile maiden in marriage; and in this case God sent His own servants to seek the Church in marriage for His son, and prophets from of old saying, "Hearken, O daughter, and consider, and forget thine own people and thy father's house, and the King shall desire thy beauty".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:37
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:38
verses.text: xlv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:40
verses.text: ) Seest thou the prophet also espousing? seest thou the Apostle too expressing the same thing himself with much boldness, and saying, "I espoused you to one husband that I might present you as a pure virgin to Christ?" Seest thou wisdom again? For having said, 'Ye ought to bear with me,' he did not say, 'for I am your teacher and I speak not for mine own sake:' but he uses this expression which invested them with especial dignity, placing himself in the room of her who promotes a match, and them in the rank of the bride; and he adds these words;  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:41
verses.text: "But I fear lest by any means, as the serpent beguiled Eve through his subtlety, so your minds should be corrupted from the simplicity that is toward Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:42
verses.text: 'For although the destruction be yours alone, yet is the sorrow mine as well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:43
verses.text: ' And consider his wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:44
verses.text: For he does not assert, although they were corrupted; and so he showed when he said, "When your obedience is fulfilled," (c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:45
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:46
verses.text: ) and "I shall bewail many which have sinned already;" (c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:47
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:48
verses.text: ) but still he does not leave them to get shameless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:49
verses.text: And therefore he says, "lest at any time".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:50
verses.text: For this neither condemns nor is silent; for neither course were safe, whether to speak out plainly or to conceal perpetually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:51
verses.text: Therefore he employs this middle form, saying, "lest at any time".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:52
verses.text: For this is the language neither of one that entirely distrusts, nor entirely relies on them, but of one who stands between these two.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:53
verses.text: In this way then he palliated, but by his mention of that history threw them into an indescribable terror, and cuts them off from all forgiveness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:54
verses.text: For even although the serpent was malignant, and she senseless, yet did none of these things snatch the woman from punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:55
verses.text: 'Beware then,' he says, 'lest such be your fate, and there be naught to screen you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:56
verses.text: For he too promising greater things, so deceived.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:57
verses.text: ' Whence it is plain that these too, by boasting and puffing themselves up, deceived.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:58
verses.text: And this may be conjectured not from this place only, but also from what he says afterwards,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:59
verses.text: "If he that cometh preacheth another Jesus, whom we did not preach, or if ye receive a different Spirit which ye did not receive, or a different Gospel which ye did not accept, ye do well to bear with him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:60
verses.text: And he does not say, 'Lest by any means as Adam was deceived:' but shows that those men are but women who are thus abused, for it is the part of woman to be deceived.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:61
verses.text: And he did not say, 'so ye also should be deceived:' but keeping up the metaphor, he says, "so your minds should be corrupted from the simplicity that is toward Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:62
verses.text: 'From the simplicity, I say, not from wickedness; neither out of wickedness is it, nor out of your not believing, but out of simplicity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:63
verses.text: ' But, nevertheless, not even under such circumstances are the deceived entitled to forgiveness, as Eve showed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:64
verses.text: But if this does not entitle to forgiveness, much more will it not do so, when through vain-glory any is so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:65
verses.text: "For if he that cometh preacheth another Jesus whom we did not preach:" showing hereby that their deceivers were not Corinthians, but persons from some other quarter previously corrupted: wherefore he saith, "he that cometh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:66
verses.text: "If ye receive a different Spirit, if a different Gospel which ye did not accept, ye do well to bear" with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:67
verses.text: What sayest thou? Thou that saidst to the Galatians, "If any preach another Gospel to you than that ye have received, let him be anathema;" dost thou now say, "ye do well to bear" with him? And yet on this account it were meet not to bear with, but to recoil, from them; but if they say the same things, it is meet to bear with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:68
verses.text: How then dost thou say, 'because they say the same things, it is not meet to bear with them?' for he says, 'if they said other things, it were meet to bear with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:69
verses.text: ' Let us then give good heed, for the danger is great, and the precipice deep, if men run past this carelessly; and what is here said giveth an entrance to all the heresies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:70
verses.text: What then is the sense of these words? Those persons so boasted as if the Apostles taught incompletely, and they were introducing somewhat more than they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:71
verses.text: For it is probable that with much idle talk, they were bringing in senseless rubbish so as to overlay these doctrines.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:72
verses.text: And therefore he made mention of the serpent and of Eve who was thus deceived by the expectation of acquiring more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:73
verses.text: And alluding to this in the former Epistle also, he said, "Now ye are become rich, ye have reigned as kings without us;" and again, "we are fools for Christ's sake, but ye are wise in Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:74
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:75
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:76
verses.text: ; ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:77
verses.text: ) Since then it was probable that using the wisdom which is without, they talked much idly, what he says is this: that 'if these persons said any thing more, and preached a different Christ who ought to have been preached, but we omitted it, "ye do well to bear" with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:78
verses.text: ' For on this account he added, "whom we did not preach".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:79
verses.text: 'But if the chief points of the faith are the same, what have ye the more of them? for whatsoever things they may say, they will say nothing more than what we have said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:80
verses.text: ' And observe with what precision he states the case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:81
verses.text: For he did not say, 'if he that cometh saith any thing more;' for they did say something more, haranguing with more authority and with much beauty of language; wherefore he did not say this, but what? If "he that cometh preacheth another Jesus," a thing which had no need of that array of words: "or ye receive a different Spirit," (for neither was there need of words in this case;) that is to say, 'makes you richer in grace;' or "a different Gospel which ye did not accept," (nor did this again stand in need of words,) "ye do well to bear" with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:82
verses.text: But consider, I pray thee, how he every where uses such a definition as shows that nothing very great, nor indeed any thing more, had been introduced by them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:83
verses.text: For when he had said, "If he that cometh preacheth another Jesus," he added, "whom we did not preach;" and "ye receive a different Spirit," he subjoined, "which ye did not receive; or a different Gospel," he added, "which ye did not accept," by all these showing that it is meet to attend to them, not simply if they say something more, but if they said any thing more which ought to have been said and was by us omitted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:84
verses.text: But if it ought not to have been said, and was therefore not said by us; or if they say only the same things as we, why gape ye so admiringly upon them? 'And yet if they say the same things,' saith one, 'wherefore dost thou hinder them?' Because that using hypocrisy, they introduce strange doctrines.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:85
verses.text: This however for the present he doth not say, but afterwards asserts it, when he says, "They fashion themselves into Apostles of Christ;" (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:86
verses.text: ) for the present he withdraws the disciples from their authority by less offensive considerations; and this not out of envy to them, but to secure these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:87
verses.text: Else why does he not hinder Apollos, who was, however, a "learned man, and mighty in the Scriptures;" (Acts xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:88
verses.text: ;  Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:89
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:90
verses.text: ) but even beseeches him, and promises he will send him? Because together with his learning he preserved also the integrity of the doctrines; but with these it was the reverse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:91
verses.text: And therefore he wars with them and blames the disciples for gaping admiringly upon them, saying, 'if aught that should have been said we omitted and they supplied, we do not hinder you from giving heed to them: but if all has been fully completed by us and nothing left deficient, whence is it that they caught you?' Wherefore also he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:92
verses.text: "For I reckon that I am not a whit behind the very chiefest Apostles," no longer making comparison of himself with them, but with Peter and the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:93
verses.text: 'So that if they know more than I do, they know more than they also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:94
verses.text: ' And observe how here also he shows modesty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:95
verses.text: For he did not say, 'the Apostles said nothing more than I,' but what? "I reckon," so I deem, "that I am not a whit behind the very chiefest Apostles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:96
verses.text: For since this also appeared to bespeak an inferiority in him, that those having preceded him were of greater name; and more respect was entertained for them, and these persons were intending to foist themselves in; therefore he makes this comparison of himself with them with the dignity that becomes him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:97
verses.text: Therefore he also mentions them with encomiums, not speaking simply of "the Apostles," but "the very chiefest," meaning Peter and James and John.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:98
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:99
verses.text: "But though I be rude in speech, yet am I not in knowledge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:100
verses.text: For since those that corrupted the Corinthians had the advantage in this, that they were not rude; he mentions this also, showing that he was not ashamed of, but even prided himself upon it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:101
verses.text: And he said not, "But though I be rude in speech," yet so also are they, for this would have seemed to be accusing them as well as himself, and exalting these: but he overthrows the thing itself, the wisdom from without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:102
verses.text: And indeed in his former Epistle he contends even vehemently about this thing, saying that it not only contributes nothing to the Preaching, but it even throws a shadow on the glory of the Cross; ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:103
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:104
verses.text: ) for he says, "I came not with excellency of speech or of wisdom unto you, lest the cross of Christ should be made void; ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:105
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:106
verses.text: ) and many other things of the same kind; because "in knowledge" they were "rude," which is also the extremest form of rudeness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:107
verses.text: When therefore it was necessary to institute a comparison in those things which were great, he compares himself with the Apostles: but when to show that which appeared to be a deficiency, he no longer does this, but grapples with the thing itself and shows that it was a superiority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:108
verses.text: And when indeed no necessity urged him, he says that he is "the least of the Apostles," and not worthy even of the title; but here again when occasion called, he says that he is "not a whit behind the very chiefest Apostles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:109
verses.text: For he knew that this would most advantage the disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:110
verses.text: Wherefore also he adds,  "Nay, in every thing we have made it manifest among all men to youward".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:111
verses.text: For here again he accuses the false Apostles as "walking in craftiness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:112
verses.text: (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:113
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:114
verses.text: ) And he said this of himself before also, that he did not live after the outward appearance, nor preach "handling the word deceitfully (ibid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:115
verses.text: ) and corrupting it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:116
verses.text: But those men were one thing and appeared another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:117
verses.text: But not so he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:118
verses.text: Wherefore also he every where assumes a high tone, as doing nothing with a view to men's opinion nor concealing aught about himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:119
verses.text: As he also said before, "by the manifestation of the truth commending ourselves to every man's conscience," (ibid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:120
verses.text: ) so now again he saith "in every thing we have made it manifest to you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:121
verses.text: But what does this mean? 'We are rude,' he said, 'and do not conceal it: we receive from some persons and we do not keep it secret.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:122
verses.text: We receive then from you, and we pretend not that we do not receive, as they do when they receive, but we make every thing that we do manifest unto you;' which was the conduct of one that both had exceeding confidence in them, and told them every thing truly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:123
verses.text: Wherefore he also calls them witnesses, saying now, "among all men to youward," and also before, "For we write none other things unto you, than what ye read or even acknowledge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:124
verses.text: (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:125
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:126
verses.text: )   Then after he had defended his own conduct he goes on next to say with severity,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:127
verses.text: "Or did I commit a sin in abasing myself that ye might be exalted?"  And in explanation of this, he adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:128
verses.text: "I robbed other churches, taking wages of them that I might minister unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:129
verses.text: What he says is this; 'I lived in straitness;' for this is the force of "abasing myself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:130
verses.text: 'Can you then lay this to my charge? and do ye therefore lift up yourselves against me, because I abased myself by begging, by enduring straits, by suffering, by hungering, that ye might be exalted?' And how were they exalted by his being in straits? They were more edified and were not offended; which also might well be a very great accusation of them and a reproach of their weakness; that it was not possible in any other way to lead them on than by first abasing himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:131
verses.text: 'Do ye then lay it to my charge that I abased myself? But thereby ye were exalted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:132
verses.text: ' For since he said even above that they accused him, for that when present he was lowly, and when absent bold, in defending himself he here strikes them again, saying, 'this too was for your sakes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:133
verses.text: '  "I robbed other churches".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:134
verses.text: Here finally he speaks reproachfully, but his former words prevent these from seeming offensive; for he said, "Bear with me in a little foolishness:" and before all his other achievements makes this his first boast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:135
verses.text: For this worldly men look to especially, and on this also those his adversaries greatly prided themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:136
verses.text: Therefore it is that he does not first enter on the subject of his perils, nor yet of his miracles, but on this of his contempt of money, because they prided themselves on this; and at the same time he also hints that they were wealthy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:137
verses.text: But what is to be admired in him is this, that when he was able to say that he was even supported by his own hands, he did not say this; but says that which especially shamed them and yet was no encomium on himself, namely, 'I took from others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:138
verses.text: ' And he did not say "took," but "robbed," that is, 'I stripped them, and made them poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:139
verses.text: ' And what surely is greater, that it was not for superfluities, but for his necessities, for when he says 'wages,' he means necessary subsistence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:140
verses.text: And what is more grievous yet, "to minister unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:141
verses.text: We preach to you; and when I ought to be supported by you, I have enjoyed this at others' hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:142
verses.text: The accusation is twofold, or rather three-fold; that when both living amongst them and ministering to them, and seeking necessary support, he had others supplying his wants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:143
verses.text: Great the excess, of the one negligence, of the other in zeal! For these sent to him even when at a great distance, and those did not even support him when amongst them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:144
verses.text: Then because he had vehemently scourged them, he quietly again relaxes the vehemence of his rebuke, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:145
verses.text: "And when I was present with you, and was in want, I was not a burden on any man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:146
verses.text: For he did not say, 'ye did not give to me,' but, 'I did not take,' for as yet he spares them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:147
verses.text: But nevertheless even in the subduedness of his language he covertly strikes them again, for the word, "present," is exceedingly emphatic, and so is "in want".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:148
verses.text: For that they might not say, 'what matter then, if you had enough?' he added, "and was in want".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:149
verses.text: "I was not a burden" on you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:150
verses.text: Here again he hits them gently, as making such contributions reluctantly, as feeling them a burden.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:151
verses.text: Then comes the reason also, full of accusation and fraught with jealousy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:152
verses.text: Wherefore also he introduced it, not in the way of a leading point, but as informing them whence and by whom he was supported, so as to stimulate them again, in an unsuspicious way, as to the point of almsgiving;  "For the measure of my want," he says, "the brethren which came from Macedonia supplied".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:153
verses.text: Seest thou how he provokes them again, by bringing forward those that had ministered to him? For inspiring them first with a desire of knowing who these could be, when he said, "I robbed other churches;" he then mentions them also by name; which would incite them also unto almsgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:154
verses.text: For he thus persuades those who had been beaten by them in the matter of supporting the Apostle, not to be also beaten in the succor they gave to the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:155
verses.text: And he says this also in his Epistle to the Macedonians themselves, "For in my necessities ye sent unto me once and again, even in the beginning of the Gospel;" (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:156
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:158
verses.text: ) which point also was a very great commendation of them, that from the very beginning they shone forth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:159
verses.text: But observe how everywhere he mentions his "necessity," and no where a superfluity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:160
verses.text: Now therefore by saying "present," and in "want" he showed that he ought to have been supported by the Corinthians; and by the words, "they supplied the measure of my want," he shows that he did not so much as ask.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:161
verses.text: And he assigns a reason which was not the real one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:162
verses.text: What then is this? That he had received from others; "for," says he, "the measure of my want those that came supplied".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:163
verses.text: 'For this reason,' he says, 'I was not a burden; not because I had no confidence in you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:164
verses.text: ' And yet it is for this latter reason that he so acts, and he shows it in what follows; but does not say it plainly, but throws it into the shade, leaving it to the conscience of his hearers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:165
verses.text: And he gives proof of it covertly in what follows, by saying,  "And in every" thing "I kept myself from being burdensome, and so will I keep" myself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:166
verses.text: "For think not," says he, "that I say these things that I may receive".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:167
verses.text: Now the words "so will I keep myself," are severer, if he has not even yet confidence in them; but once for all had given up the idea of receiving aught from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:168
verses.text: He shows, moreover, that they even considered this to be a burden; wherefore he said, "I have kept myself from being burdensome, and so will I keep myself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:169
verses.text: He says this in his former Epistle also, "I write not this that it may be so done unto me; for" it were "good for me rather to die, than that any man should make my glorying void".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:170
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:171
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:172
verses.text: ) And here again, "I have kept myself from being burdensome unto you, and so will I keep" myself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:173
verses.text: Then, that he may not seem to speak these things for the sake of winning them on the better to do this, he saith,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:174
verses.text: "As the truth of Christ is in me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:175
verses.text: 'Do not think that I therefore have spoken, that I may receive, that I may the rather draw you on: for,' saith he, "as the truth is in me,  "No man shall stop me of this glorying in the regions of Achaia".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:176
verses.text: For that none should think again that he is grieved at this, or that he speaks these things in anger, he even calls the thing a "glorying".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:177
verses.text: And in his former Epistle too he dressed it out in like terms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:178
verses.text: For so that he may not wound them there either, he says, "What then is my reward?" "That when I preach the Gospel, I may make the Gospel of Christ without charge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:179
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:180
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:181
verses.text: ) And as he there calls it "reward," so doth he here "glorying," that they may not be excessively ashamed at what he said, as if he were asking and they gave not to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:182
verses.text: 'For, what, if even ye would give?' saith he, 'Yet I do not accept it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:183
verses.text: ' And the expression, "shall not stop me," is a metaphor taken from rivers, or from the report, as if running every where, of his receiving nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:184
verses.text: 'Ye stop not with your giving this my freedom of speech.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:185
verses.text: ' But he said not, 'ye stop not,' which would have been too cutting, but it "no man shall stop me in the regions of Achaia".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:186
verses.text: This again was like giving them a fatal blow, and exceedingly apt to deject and pain them, since they were the only persons he refused to take from.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:187
verses.text: 'For if he made that his boast, it were meet to make it so every where: but if he only does so among us, perchance this is owing to our weakness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:188
verses.text: ' Lest therefore they should so reason and be dejected, see how he corrects this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:189
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:190
verses.text: "Wherefore? because I love you not? God knoweth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:191
verses.text: Quickly is it done, and by an easy method.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:192
verses.text: But still, not even so did he rid them of those charges.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:193
verses.text: For he neither said, 'ye are not weak,' nor yet, 'ye are strong;' but, "I love you," which very greatly aggravated the accusation against them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:194
verses.text: For the not receiving from them, because they felt it an exceeding grievance, was a proof of special love toward them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:195
verses.text: So he acted in two contrary ways out of love; he both did receive, and did not receive: but this contrariety was on account of the disposition of the givers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:196
verses.text: And he did not say, 'I therefore do not take of you, because I exceedingly love you,' for this would have contained an accusation of their weakness and have thrown them into distress; but he turned what he said to another reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:197
verses.text: What then is this?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:198
verses.text: "That I may cut off occasion from them that desire an occasion; that wherein they glory, they may be found even as we".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:199
verses.text: For since this they sought earnestly, to find some handle against him, it is necessary to remove this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:200
verses.text: For this is the one point on which they pique themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:201
verses.text: Therefore that they might not have any advantage whatever, it was necessary to set this right; for in other things they were inferior.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:202
verses.text: For, as I have said, nothing doth so edify worldly people as the receiving nothing from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:203
verses.text: Therefore the devil in his craftiness dropped this bait especially, when desirous to injure them in other respects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:204
verses.text: But it appears to me that this even was in hypocrisy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:205
verses.text: And therefore he did not say, 'wherein they have well done,' but what? "wherein they glory;" which also was as jeering at their glorying; for they gloried also of that which they were not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:206
verses.text: But the man of noble spirit not only ought not to boast of what he has not, but not even of what he possesses; as this blessed saint was wont to do, as the patriarch Abraham did, saying, "But I am earth and ashes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:207
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:208
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:209
verses.text: ) For since he had no sins to speak of, but shone with good works; having run about in every direction and found no very great handle against himself, he betakes himself to his nature; and since the name of "earth" is in some way or other one of dignity, he added to it that of "ashes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:210
verses.text: Wherefore also another saith, "Why is earth and ashes proud?" (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:211
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:212
verses.text: )   For tell me not of the bloom of the countenance, nor of the uplifted neck, nor of the mantle, and the horse, and the followers; but reflect where all these things do end, and put that to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:213
verses.text: But and if thou tell me of what appears to the eye, I too will tell thee of things in pictures, brighter far than these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:214
verses.text: But as we do not admire those for their appearance, as seeing what their nature is, that all is clay; so therefore let us not these either, for these too are but clay.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:215
verses.text: Yea rather, even before they are dissolved and become dust, show me this uplifted neck a prey to fever and gasping out life; and then will I discourse with thee and will ask, What has become of all that profuse ornament? whither has that crowd of flatterers vanished, that attendance of slaves, that abundance of wealth and possessions? What wind hath visited and blown all away? Nay, even stretched upon the bier, he beareth the tokens of that wealth and that pride; a splendid garment thrown over him, poor and rich following him forth, the assembled crowds breathing words of good omen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:216
verses.text: Surely this also is a very mockery; howbeit even this besides is presently proved naught, like a blossom that perishes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:217
verses.text: For when we have passed over the threshold of the city gates, and after having delivered over the body to the worms, return, I will ask thee again, where is that vast crowd gone to? What has become of the clamor and uproar? where are the torches? where the bands of women? are not these things, then, a dream? And what too has become of the shouts? where are those many lips that cried, and bade him 'be of good cheer, for no man is immortal?' These things ought not now to be said to one that heareth not, but when he made prey of others, when he was overreaching, then with a slight change should it have been said to him, 'Be not of good cheer, no man is immortal; hold in thy madness, extinguish thy lust;' but 'Be of good cheer' is for the injured party.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:218
verses.text: For to chant such things over this man now, is but like men exulting over him and speaking irony; for he ought not for this now to be of good cheer, but to fear and tremble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:219
verses.text: And if even this advice is now of no use to him since he has run his course, yet at least let those of the rich who labor under the same disease, and follow him to the tomb, hear it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:220
verses.text: For although beforehand through the intoxication of wealth, they have no such thing in mind, yet at that season when the sight of him that is laid out even confirms what is said, let them be sober, let them be instructed: reflecting that yet a little while and they will come that shall bear them away to that fearful account, and to suffer the penalty of their acts of rapacity and extortion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:221
verses.text: 'And what is this to the poor?' saith one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:222
verses.text: Why, to many this also is a satisfaction, to see him that hath wronged them punished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:223
verses.text: 'But to us it is no satisfaction, but the escaping suffering ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:224
verses.text: ' I praise you exceedingly and approve of you in that ye exult not over the calamities of others, but seek only your own safety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:225
verses.text: Come then, I will ensure you this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:226
verses.text: For if we suffer evil at the hands of men, we cut off no small part of our debt by bearing what is done to us nobly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:227
verses.text: We receive therefore no injury; for God reckons the ill-treatment towards our debt, not according to the principle of justice but of His loving-kindness; and because He succored not him that suffered evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:228
verses.text: 'Whence doth this appear?' saith one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:229
verses.text: The Jews once suffered evil at the hand of the Babylonians; and God did not prevent it: but they were carried away, children and women; yet afterwards did this captivity become a consolation to them in respect of their sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:230
