verses.text: Therefore He saith to Isaiah, "Comfort ye, comfort ye My people, ye priests: speak unto the heart of Jerusalem, for she hath received of the Lord's hand double for sins".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:231
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:232
verses.text: xl.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:234
verses.text: ) And again; "Grant us peace, for Thou hast repaid us every thing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:235
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:236
verses.text: xxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:237
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:238
verses.text: ) And David saith; "Behold mine enemies, for they are multiplied; and forgive all my sins".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:239
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:240
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:242
verses.text: ) And when he bore with Shimei cursing him, he said, "Let him alone, that the Lord may see my abasement, and requite me good for this day".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:243
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:244
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:246
verses.text: ) For when He aideth us not when we suffer wrong, then most of all are we advantaged; for He sets it to the account of our sins, if we bear it thankfully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:247
verses.text: So that when thou seest a rich man plundering a poor, leave him that suffereth wrong, and weep for the plunderer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:248
verses.text: For the one putteth off filth, the other bedaubeth himself with more filth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:249
verses.text: Such was the fate of Elisha's servant in the story of Naaman ( Kings v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:251
verses.text: ) For though he took not by violence, yet he did a wrong; for to get money by deceit is a wrong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:252
verses.text: What then befel? With the wrong he received also the leprosy; and he that was wronged was benefited, but he that did the wrong received the greatest possible harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:253
verses.text: The same happens now also in the case of the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:254
verses.text: And this is of so great force that often by itself it hath propitiated God; yea though he who suffereth evil be unworthy of aid; yet when he so suffers in excess, by this alone he draweth God unto the forgiveness of himself, and to the punishment of him that did the wrong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:255
verses.text: Wherefore also God said of old to the heathen, "I indeed delivered them over unto a few things, but they have set themselves on together unto evil things;" (Zech.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:256
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:257
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:258
verses.text: ) they shall suffer ills irremediable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:259
verses.text: For there is nothing, no, nothing, that doth so much exasperate God as rapine and violence and extortion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:260
verses.text: And why forsooth? Because it is very easy to abstain from this sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:261
verses.text: For here it is not any natural desire that perturbeth the mind, but it ariseth from wilful negligence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:262
verses.text: How then doth the Apostle call it, "a root of evils".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:263
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:264
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:265
verses.text: ) Why, I say so too, but this root is from us, and not from the nature of the things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:266
verses.text: And, if ye will, let us make a comparison and see which is the more imperious, the desire of money or of beauty; for that which shall be found to have struck down great men is the more difficult to master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:267
verses.text: Let us see then what great man the desire of money ever got possession of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:268
verses.text: Not one; only of exceeding pitiful and abject persons, Gehazi, Ahab, Judas, the priests of the Jews: but the desire for beauty overcame even the great prophet David.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:269
verses.text: And this I say, not as extending forgiveness to those who are conquered by such a lust, but rather, as preparing them to be watchful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:270
verses.text: For when I have shown the strength of the passion, then, most especially, I show them to be deprived of every claim to forgiveness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:271
verses.text: For if indeed thou hadst not known the wild beast, thou wouldest have this to take refuge in; but now, having known, yet falling into it, thou wilt have no excuse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:272
verses.text: After him, it took possession of his son still more completely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:273
verses.text: And yet there was never man wiser than he, and all other virtue did he attain; still, however, he was seized so violently by this passion, that even in his vitals he received the wound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:274
verses.text: And the father indeed rose up again and renewed the struggle, and was crowned again; but the son showed nothing of the kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:275
verses.text: Therefore also Paul said, "It is better to marry than to burn:" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:276
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:277
verses.text: ) and Christ, "He that is able to receive it, let him receive it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:278
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:279
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:280
verses.text: ) But concerning money He spake not so, but, "whoso hath forsaken" his goods "shall receive an hundredfold".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:281
verses.text: (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:282
verses.text: ) 'How then,' saith one, 'did He say of the rich, that they shall hardly obtain the kingdom?' Again implying their weakness of character; not the imperiousness of money, but their utter slavery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:283
verses.text: And this is evident also from the advice which Paul gave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:284
verses.text: For from that lust he leads men quite away, saying, "But they that desire to be rich fall into temptation;" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:285
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:286
verses.text: ) but in the case of the other not so; but having separated them "for a season" only, and that by "consent," he advises to 'come together again' ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:287
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:288
verses.text: ) For he feared the billows of lust lest they should occasion a grievous shipwreck.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:289
verses.text: This passion is even more vehement than anger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:290
verses.text: For it is not possible to feel anger when there is nothing proving it, but a man cannot help desiring even when the face which moveth to it is not seen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:291
verses.text: Therefore this passion indeed He did not cut off altogether, but added the words, "without a cause".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:292
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:293
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:294
verses.text: ) Nor again did He abolish all desire, but only that which is unlawful, for he saith, "Nevertheless, because of desires, let every man have his own wife".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:295
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:296
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:297
verses.text: ) But to lay up treasure He allowed not, either with cause or without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:298
verses.text: For those passions were implanted in our nature for a necessary end; desire, for the procreation of children, and anger, for the succor of the injured, but desire of money not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:299
verses.text: Therefore neither is the passion natural to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:300
verses.text: So then if thou art made captive by it, thou wilt suffer so much the more the vilest punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:301
verses.text: Therefore surely, it is, that Paul, permitting even a second marriage, demands in the case of money great strictness, saying, "Why not rather take wrong? why not rather be defrauded?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:302
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:303
verses.text: ) And when treating of virginity, he says, "I have no commandment," (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:304
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:305
verses.text: ) and "I speak this for your profit, not that I may cast a snare upon you;" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:306
verses.text: ) but when his discourse is of money, he says, "Having raiment and food, let us be therewith content".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:307
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:308
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:309
verses.text: ) 'How then is it,' saith one, 'that by this, more than the other, are many overcome?' Because they stand not so much on their guard against it as against lasciviousness and fornication; for if they had thought it equally dangerous, they would not, perhaps, have been made its captives.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:310
verses.text: So also were those wretched virgins cast out of the bridechamber, because that, having struck down the great adversary, they were wounded by one weaker, and who was nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:311
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:312
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:314
verses.text: ) Besides this, one may say further, that if any, subduing lust, is overcome by money, often he does not in fact subdue lust, but has received from nature the gift of suffering no great uneasiness of that sort; for all are not equally inclined to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:315
verses.text: Knowing then these things, and revolving frequently with ourselves the example of the virgins, let us shun this evil wild beast.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:316
verses.text: For if virginity profited them nothing, but after countless toils and labors they perished through the love of money, who shall deliver us if we fall into this passion? Wherefore I beseech you to do all you can, both that ye be not taken captive by it, and that if taken, ye continue not in captivity, but break asunder those hard bonds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 24:317
verses.text: For so shall we be able to secure a footing in heaven and to obtain the countless good things; whereunto may all we attain, through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, with the Holy Ghost, be glory, might, honor, now and for ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:1
verses.text: Homily XXIV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:3
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:4
verses.text: For such are false apostles, deceitful workers, fashioning themselves into Apostles of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:5
verses.text: What sayest thou? they that preach Christ, they that take not money, they that bring not in a different gospel, "false apostles?" 'Yes,' he saith, and for this very reason most of all, because they make pretense of all these things for the purpose of deceiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:6
verses.text: "Deceitful workers," for they do work indeed, but pull up what has been planted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:7
verses.text: For being well aware that otherwise they would not be well received, they take the mask of truth and so enact the drama of error.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:8
verses.text: 'And yet,' saith one, 'they take no money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:9
verses.text: ' That they may take greater things; that they may destroy the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:10
verses.text: Yea rather, even that was a falsehood; and they took money but did it secretly: and he shows this in what follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:11
verses.text: And indeed he already hinted this where he said, "that wherein they glory, they may be found even as we:" (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:12
verses.text: ) in what follows, however, he hinted it more plainly, saying, "If a man devour you, if a man take you captive, if a man exalt himself, ye bear with him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:13
verses.text: (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:14
verses.text: ) But at present he accuses them on another account, saying, "fashioning themselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:15
verses.text: They had only a "fashion;" the skin of the sheep was but outside clothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:16
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:18
verses.text: "And no marvel; for if even Satan fashioneth himself into an angel of light, is it a great thing if his ministers also fashion themselves as ministers of righteousness?"  So that if one ought to marvel, this is what he ought to marvel at, and not at their transformation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:19
verses.text: For when their teacher dares do any thing, no marvel that the disciples also follow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:20
verses.text: But what is "an angel of light?" That hath free liberty to speak, that standeth near to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:21
verses.text: For there are also angels of darkness; those which be the devil's, those dark and cruel ones.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:22
verses.text: And the devil hath deceived many so, fashioning himself "into," not becoming, "an angel of light".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:23
verses.text: So do also do these bear about them the form of an Apostle, not the power itself, for this they cannot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:24
verses.text: But nothing is so like the devil as to do things for display.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:25
verses.text: But what is "a ministry of righteousness?" That which we are who preach to you a Gospel having righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:26
verses.text: For he either means this, or else that they invest themselves with the character of righteous men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:27
verses.text: How then shall we know them? "By their works," as Christ said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:28
verses.text: Wherefore he is compelled to place his own good deeds and their wickedness side by side, that the spurious may become evident by the comparison.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:29
verses.text: And when about again to enter upon his own praises, he first accuses them, in order to show that such an argument was forced upon him, lest any should accuse him for speaking about himself, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:30
verses.text: "Again I say".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:31
verses.text: For he had even already used much preparatory corrective: 'But nevertheless I am not contented with what I have said, but I say yet again,'  "Let no man think me foolish".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:32
verses.text: For this was what they did—boasted without a reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:33
verses.text: —But observe, I pray you, how often, when about to enter upon his own praises, he checks himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:34
verses.text: 'For indeed it is the act of folly,' he says, 'to boast: but I do it, not as playing the fool, but because compelled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:35
verses.text: But if ye do not believe me, but though ye see there is a necessity will condemn me; not even so will I decline the task.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:36
verses.text: ' Seest thou how he showed that there was great necessity for his speaking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:37
verses.text: For he that shunned not even this suspicion, consider what violent impulsion to speak he must have undergone, how he travailed and was constrained to speak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:38
verses.text: But, nevertheless, even so he employs this thing with moderation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:39
verses.text: For he did not say, 'that I may glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:40
verses.text: ' And when about to do "a little," again he uses yet another deprecatory expression, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:41
verses.text: "That which I speak, I speak not after the Lord, but as in foolishness, in this confidence of glorifying".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:42
verses.text: Seest thou how glorying is not "after the Lord?" For He saith, "When ye shall have done all, say, We are unprofitable servants".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:43
verses.text: (Luke xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:44
verses.text: ) Howbeit, by itself indeed it is not "after the Lord," but by the intention it becomes so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:45
verses.text: And therefore he said, "That which I speak," not accusing the motive, but the words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:46
verses.text: Since his aim is so admirable as to dignify the words also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:47
verses.text: For as a manslayer, though his action be of those most strictly forbidden, has often been approved from the intention; and as circumcision, although it is not 'after the Lord,' has become so from the intention, so also glorying.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:48
verses.text: And wherefore then does he not use so great strictness of expression? Because he is hastening on to another point, and he freely gratifies even to superfluity those who are desirous to find a handle against him, so that he may say only the things that are profitable; for when said they were enough to extinguish all that suspicion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:49
verses.text: "But as in foolishness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:50
verses.text: Before he says, "Would that ye could bear with me in a little foolishness,'' (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:51
verses.text: ) but now "as in foolishness;" for the farther he proceeds, the more he clears his language.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:52
verses.text: Then that thou mayest not think that he plays the fool on all points, he added, "in this confidence of glorying".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:53
verses.text: In this particular he means: just as in another place he said, "that we be not put to shame," and added, "in this confidence of glorying".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:54
verses.text: (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:55
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:56
verses.text: ) And again, in another place, having said, "Or what I purpose do I purpose according to the flesh, that with me there should be the yea yea, and the nay nay?" (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:57
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:58
verses.text: ) And having shown that he cannot in all cases even fulfil what he promises, because he does not purpose after the flesh, lest any should make this suspicion stretch to the doctrine also, he adds, "But as God is faithful our word towards you was not yea and nay".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:59
verses.text: (Ibid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:60
verses.text: )   And observe how after having said so many things before, he again sets down yet other grounds of excuse, saying further thus,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:61
verses.text: "Seeing that many glory after the flesh, I will glory also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:62
verses.text: What is, "after the flesh?" Of things external, of high birth, of wealth, of wisdom, of being circumcised, of Hebrew ancestry, of popular renown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:63
verses.text: And behold wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:64
verses.text: He sets down those things which he shows to be nothings, and then, folly also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:65
verses.text: For if to glory in what are really good things be folly, much more is it so to glory in those that are nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:66
verses.text: And this is what he calls, "not after the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:67
verses.text: For it is no advantage to be a Hebrew, or any such like things soever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:68
verses.text: 'Think not, therefore, that I set these down as a virtue; no; but because those men boast I also am compelled to institute my comparison on these points.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:69
verses.text: ' Which he does also in another place, saying, "If any man thinketh that he may trust in the flesh, I more:" (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:70
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:71
verses.text: ) and there, it is on their account that trusted in this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:72
verses.text: Just as if one who was come of an illustrious race but had chosen a philosophic life, should see others priding themselves greatly on being well-born; and being desirious of taking down their vanity, should be compelled to speak of his own distinction; not to adorn himself, but to humble them; so, truly, does Paul also do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:73
verses.text: Then leaving those, he empties all his censure upon the Corinthians, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:74
verses.text: "For ye bear with the foolish gladly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:75
verses.text: 'So that ye are to blame for this, and more than they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:76
verses.text: For if ye had not borne with them, and so far as it lay in them received damage, I would not have spoken a word; but I do it out of a tender care for your salvation, and in condescension.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:77
verses.text: And behold, how he accompanies even his censure with praise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:78
verses.text: For having said, "ye bear with the foolish gladly;" he added,  "Being wise yourselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:79
verses.text: For it was a sign of folly to glory, and on such matters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:80
verses.text: And yet it behoved to rebuke them, and say, 'Do not bear with the foolish;' he does this, however, at greater advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:81
verses.text: For in that case he would have seemed to rebuke them because he himself was destitute of these advantages; but now having showed himself to be their superior even in these points, and to esteem them to be nothing, he corrects them with greater effect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:82
verses.text: At present, however, before entering upon his own praises and the comparison, he also reproaches the Corinthians with their great slavishness, because they were extravagantly submissive to them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:83
verses.text: And observe how he ridicules them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:84
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:85
verses.text: "For ye bear with a man," he says, "if he devour you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:86
verses.text: How then saidst thou, "that wherein they glory, they may be found even as we?" (ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:87
verses.text: ) Seest thou that he shows that they did take of them, and not simply take, but even in excess: for the term "devour" plainly shows this,  "If a man bring you into bondage".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:88
verses.text: 'Ye have given away both your money,' he says, 'and your persons, and your freedom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:89
verses.text: For this is more than taking of you; to be masters not only of your money, but of yourselves also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:90
verses.text: ' And he makes this plain even before, where he says, "If others partake of this right over you, do not we much more?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:91
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:92
verses.text: ) Then he addeth what is more severe, saying,  "If a man exalt himself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:93
verses.text: 'For neither is your slavery of a moderate sort, nor are your masters gentle, but burdensome and odious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:94
verses.text: '  "If a man smite you on the face".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:95
verses.text: Seest thou again a further stretch of tyranny? He said this, not meaning that they were stricken on the face, but that they spat upon and dishonored them; wherefore he added,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:96
verses.text: "I speak by way of disparagement," for ye suffer no whit less than men smitten on the face.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:97
verses.text: What now can be stronger than this? What oppression more bitter than this? when having taken from you both your money and your freedom and your honor, they even so are not gentle towards you nor suffer you to abide in the rank of servants, but have used you more insultingly than any bought slave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:98
verses.text: "As though we had been weak".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:99
verses.text: The expression is obscure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:100
verses.text: For since it was a disagreeable subject he therefore so expressed it as to steal away the offensiveness by the obscurity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:101
verses.text: For what he wishes to say is this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:102
verses.text: 'For cannot we also do these things? Yes, but we do them not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:103
verses.text: Wherefore then do ye bear with these men, as though we could not do these things? Surely it were something to impute to you that ye even bear with men who play the fool; but that ye do this, even when they so despise you, plunder you, exalt themselves, smite you, can admit neither of excuse nor any reason at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:104
verses.text: For this is a new fashion of deceiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:105
verses.text: For men that deceive both give and flatter; but these both deceive, and take and insult you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:106
verses.text: Whence ye cannot have a shadow of allowance, seeing that ye spit on those that humble themselves for your sakes that ye may be exalted, but admire those who exalt themselves that ye may be humbled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:107
verses.text: For could not we too do these things? Yes, but we do not wish it, looking to your advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:108
verses.text: For they indeed sacrificing your interests seek their own, but we sacrificing our own interests seek for yours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:109
verses.text: ' Seest thou how in every instance, whilst speaking plainly to them, he also alarms them by what he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:110
verses.text: 'For,' he says, 'if it be on this account that ye honor them, because they smite and insult you, we also can do this, enslave, smite, exalt ourselves against you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:111
verses.text: '   Seest thou how he lays upon them the whole blame, both of their senseless pride and of what seems to be folly in himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:112
verses.text: 'For not that I may show myself more conspicuous, but that I may set you free from this bitter slavery, am I compelled to glory some little.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:113
verses.text: But it is meet to examine not simply things that are said, but, in addition, the reason also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:114
verses.text: For Samuel also put together a high panegyric upon himself, when he anointed Saul, saying, "Whose ass have I taken, or calf, or shoes? or have I oppressed any of you?" ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:115
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:116
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:117
verses.text: ) And yet no one finds fault with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:118
verses.text: And the reason is because he did not say it by way of setting off himself; but because he was going to appoint a king, he wishes under the form of a defence of himself to instruct him to be meek and gentle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:119
verses.text: And observe the wisdom of the prophet, or rather the loving kindness of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:120
verses.text: For because he wished to turn them from their design, bringing together a number of grievous things he asserted them of their future king, as, for instance, that he would make their wives grind at the mill, ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:121
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:123
verses.text: ) the men shepherds and muleteers; for he went through all the service appertaining to the kingdom with minuteness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:124
verses.text: But when he saw that they would not be hindered by any of these things, but were incurably distempered; he thus both spareth them and composeth their king to gentleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:125
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:126
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:127
verses.text: ) Therefore he also takes him to witness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:128
verses.text: For indeed no one was then bringing suit or charge against him that he needed to defend himself, but he said those things in order to make him better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:129
verses.text: And therefore also he added, to take down his pride, "If ye will hearken, ye and your king," (ibid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:130
verses.text: ) such and such good things shall be yours; "but if ye will not hearken, then the reverse of all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:131
verses.text: Amos also said, "I was no prophet, nor the son of a prophet, but only a herdsman, a gatherer of sycamore fruit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:132
verses.text: And God took me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:133
verses.text: (Amos vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:135
verses.text: ) But he did not say this to exalt himself, but to stop their mouths that suspected him as no prophet, and to show that he is no deceiver, nor says of his own mind the things which he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:136
verses.text: Again, another also, to show the very same thing, said, "But truly I am full of power by the spirit and might of the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:137
verses.text: (Micah iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:138
verses.text: ) And David also when he related the matter of the lion and of the bear, ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:139
verses.text: xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:141
verses.text: ) spake not to glorify himself, but to bring about a great and admirable end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:142
verses.text: For since it was not believed possible he could conquer the barbarian unarmed, he that was not able even to bear arms; he was compelled to give proofs of his own valor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:143
verses.text: And when he cut off Saul's skirt, he said not what he said out of display, but to repel an ill suspicion which they had scattered abroad against him, saying, that he wished to kill him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:144
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:145
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:147
verses.text: ) It is meet therefore every where to seek for the reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:148
verses.text: For he that looks to the advantage of his hearers even though he should praise himself, not only deserves not to be found fault with, but even to be crowned; and if he is silent, then to be found fault with.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:149
verses.text: For if David had then been silent in the matter of Goliath, they would not have allowed him to go out to the battle, nor to have raised that illustrious trophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:150
verses.text: On this account then he speaks being compelled; and that not to his brethren, although he was distrusted by them too as well as by the king; but envy stopped their ears.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:151
verses.text: Therefore leaving them alone, he tells his tale to him who was not as yet envious of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:152
verses.text: For envy is a fearful, a fearful thing, and persuades men to despise their own salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:153
verses.text: In this way did both Cain destroy himself, and again, before his time, the devil who was the destroyer of his father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:154
verses.text: So did Saul invite an evil demon against his own soul; and when he had invited, he again envied his physician.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:155
verses.text: For such is the nature of envy; he knew that he was saved, yet he would rather have perished than see him that saved him had in honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:156
verses.text: What can be more grievous than this passion? One cannot err in calling it the devil's offspring.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:157
verses.text: And in it is contained the fruit of vainglory, or rather its root also; for both these evils are wont mutually to produce each other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:158
verses.text: And thus in truth it was that Saul even thus envied, when they said, "David smote by ten thousands," ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:159
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:160
verses.text: ) than which what can be more senseless? For why dost thou envy? tell me! 'Because such an one praised him?' Yet surely thou oughtest to rejoice; besides, thou dost not know even whether the praise be true.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:161
verses.text: And dost thou therefore grieve because without being admirable he hath been praised as such? And yet thou oughtest to feel pity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:162
verses.text: For if he be good, thou oughtest not to envy him when praised, but thyself to praise along with those that speak well of him; but if not such, why art thou galled? why thrust the sword against thyself? 'Because admired by men?' But men to-day are and to-morrow are not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:163
verses.text: 'But because he enjoys glory?' Of what sort, tell me? That of which the prophet says that it is "the flower of grass".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:164
verses.text: (Is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:165
verses.text: xl.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:166
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:167
verses.text: ) Art thou then therefore envious because thou bearest no burden, nor carriest about with thee such loads of grass? But if he seems to thee to be enviable on this account, then why not also woodcutters who carry burdens every day and come to the city with them? For that burden is nothing better than this, but even worse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:168
verses.text: For theirs indeed galls the body only, but this hath oftentimes harmed the soul even and occasioned greater solicitude than pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:169
verses.text: And should one have gained renown through eloquence, the fear he endures is greater than the good report he bears; yea, what is more, the one is short, the other perpetual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:170
verses.text: 'But he is in favor with those in authority?' In that too again is danger and envy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:171
verses.text: For as thou feelest towards him, so do many others feel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:172
verses.text: 'But he is praised continually?' This produces bitter slavery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:173
verses.text: For he will not dare to do fearlessly aught of what according to his judgment he should, lest he should offend those that extol him, for that distinction is a hard bondage to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:174
verses.text: So that the more he is known to, so many the more masters he has, and his slavery becomes the greater, as masters of his are found in every quarter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:175
verses.text: A servant indeed, when he is released from the eye of his master, both takes breath and lives in all freedom; but this man meets with masters at every turn, for he is the slave of all that appear in the forum.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:176
verses.text: And even should some necessary object press, he dares not set foot in the forum, except it be with his servants following, and his horse, and all his other show set in array, lest his masters condemn him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:177
verses.text: And if he sees some friend of those who are truly so, he has not the boldness to talk with him on an equal footing: for he is afraid of his masters, lest they depose him from his glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:178
verses.text: So that the more distinguished he is, so much the more he is enslaved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:179
verses.text: And if he suffer aught that is disagreeable, the insult is the more annoying, both in that he has more to witness it and it seems to infringe his dignity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:180
verses.text: It is not only an insult, but a calamity also, for he has also many who exult at it; and in like way if he come to the enjoyment of any good thing, he has more who envy and detract and do their vigilance to destroy him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:181
verses.text: Is this then a good? tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:182
verses.text: Is this glory? By no means; but ingloriousness, and slavery, and bonds, and every burdensome thing one can say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:183
verses.text: But if the glory that cometh of men be so greatly to be coveted in thy account, and if it quite disquiets thee that such and such an one is applauded of the many; when thou beholdest him in the enjoyment of that applause, pass over in thy thought to the world to come and the glory which is there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:184
verses.text: And just as when hurrying to escape the onset of a wild beast, thou enterest into a cabin and shuttest to the doors; so now also flee unto the life to come, and that unspeakable glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 25:185
verses.text: For so shalt thou both tread this under thy feet, and wilt easily lay hold upon that, and wilt enjoy the true liberty, and the eternal good things; whereunto may we all attain through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, with the Holy Spirit, be glory, might, honor, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:1
verses.text: Homily XXV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:3
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:4
verses.text: Yet whereinsoever any is bold, (I speak in foolishness,) I am bold also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:5
verses.text: See him again drawing back and using depreciation and correctives beforehand, although he has already even said many such things: "Would that ye could bear with me in a little foolishness;" (Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:6
verses.text: ) and again, "Let no man think me foolish: if ye do, yet as foolish receive me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:7
verses.text: (Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:8
verses.text: ) "That which I speak, I speak not after the Lord, but as in foolishness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:9
verses.text: (Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:10
verses.text: ) "Seeing that many glory after the flesh, I will glory also;" (Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:11
verses.text: ) and here again, "Whereinsoever any is bold, (I speak in foolishness) I am bold also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:12
verses.text: Boldness and folly he calls it to speak aught great of himself, and that though there was a necessity, teaching us even to an excess to avoid any thing of the sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:13
verses.text: For if after we have done all, we ought to call ourselves unprofitable; of what forgiveness can he be worthy who, when no reason presses, exalts himself and boasts? Therefore also did the Pharisee meet the fate he did, and even in harbor suffered shipwreck because he struck upon this rock.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:14
verses.text: Therefore also doth Paul, although he sees very ample necessity for it, draw back nevertheless, and keep on observing that such speaking is a mark of foolishness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:15
verses.text: And then at length he makes the venture, putting forward the plea of necessity, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:16
verses.text: "Are they Hebrews? so am I.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:17
verses.text: Are they Israelites? so am I".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:18
verses.text: For it was not all Hebrews that were Israelites, since both the Ammonites and Moabites were Hebrews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:19
verses.text: Wherefore he added somewhat to clear his nobility of descent, and says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:21
verses.text: "Are they the seed of Abraham? so am I.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:22
verses.text: Are they ministers of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:23
verses.text: (I speak as one beside himself,) I more".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:24
verses.text: He is not content with his former deprecation, but uses it again here also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:25
verses.text: "I speak as one beside himself, I more".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:26
verses.text: I am their superior and their better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:27
verses.text: And indeed he possessed clear proofs of his superiority, but nevertheless even so he terms the thing a folly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:28
verses.text: And yet if they were false Apostles, he heeded not to have introduced his own superiority by way of comparison, but to have destroyed their claim to "be ministers" at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:29
verses.text: Well, he did destroy it, saying, "False Apostles, deceitful workers, fashioning themselves into Apostles of Christ," (Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:30
verses.text: ) but now he doth not proceed in that way, for his discourse was about to proceed to strict examination; and no one when an examination is in hand simply asserts; but having first stated the case in the way of comparison, he shows it to be negatived by the facts, a very strong negative.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:31
verses.text: But besides, it is their opinion he gives, not his own assertion, when he says, "Are they ministers of Christ?" And having said, "I more," he proceeds in his comparison, and shows that not by bare assertions, but by furnishing the proof that facts supply, he maintains the impress of the Apostleship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:32
verses.text: And leaving all his miracles, he begins with his trials; thus saying,  "In labors more abundantly, in stripes above measure".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:33
verses.text: This latter is greater than the former; to be both beaten and scourged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:34
verses.text: "In prisons more abundantly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:35
verses.text: Here too again is there an increase.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:36
verses.text: "In deaths oft".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:37
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:38
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:39
verses.text: ) For, "I die," saith he, "daily".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:40
verses.text: But here, even in reality; 'for I have oft been delivered into mortal dangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:41
verses.text: '  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:42
verses.text: "Of the Jews five times received I forty stripes save one".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:43
verses.text: Why, "save one?" There was an ancient law that he who had received more than the forty should be held disgraced amongst them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:44
verses.text: Lest then the vehemence and impetuosity of the executioner by inflicting more than the number should cause a man to be disgraced, they decreed that they should be inflicted, "save one," that even if the executioner should exceed, he might not overpass the forty, but remaining within the prescribed number might not bring degradation on him that was scourged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:45
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:46
verses.text: "Thrice was I beaten with rods, once was I stoned, thrice I suffered shipwreck".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:47
verses.text: And what has this to do with the Gospel? Because he went forth on long journeys; and those by sea.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:48
verses.text: "A night and a day I have been in the deep".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:49
verses.text: Some say this means out on the open sea, others, swimming upon it, which is also the truer interpretation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:50
verses.text: There is nothing wonderful, at least, about the former, nor would he have placed it as greater than his shipwrecks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:51
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:52
verses.text: "In perils of rivers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:53
verses.text: For he was compelled also to cross rivers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:54
verses.text: "In perils of robbers, in perils in the city, in perils in the wilderness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:55
verses.text: 'Everywhere were contests set before me, in places, in countries, in cities, in deserts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:56
verses.text: '  "In perils from the Gentiles, in perils amongst false brethren".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:57
verses.text: Behold another kind of warfare.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:58
verses.text: For not only did such as were enemies strike at him, but those also who played the hypocrite; and he had need of much firmness, much prudence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:59
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:60
verses.text: "In labor and travail".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:61
verses.text: Perils succeed to labors, labors to perils, one upon other and unintermitted, and allowed him not to take breath even for a little.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:62
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:64
verses.text: "In journeyings often, in hunger and thirst and nakedness, besides those things that are without".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:65
verses.text: What is left out is more than what is enumerated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:66
verses.text: Yea rather, one cannot count the number of those even which are enumerated; for he has not set them down specifically, but has mentioned those the number of which was small and easily comprehended, saying, "thrice" and "thrice," (Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:67
verses.text: ) and again "once;" but of the others he does not mention the number because he had endured them often.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:68
verses.text: And he recounts not their results as that he had converted so many and so many, but only what he suffered on behalf of the Preaching; at once out of modesty, and as showing that even should nothing have been gained but labor, even so his title to wages has been fulfilled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:69
verses.text: "That which presseth upon me daily".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:70
verses.text: The tumults, the disturbances, the assaults of mobs, onsets of cities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:71
verses.text: For the Jews waged war against this man most of all because he most of all confounded them, and his changing sides all at once was the greatest refutation of their madness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:72
verses.text: And there breathed a mighty war against him, from his own people, from strangers, from false brethren; and every where were billows and precipices, in the inhabited world, in the uninhabited, by land, by sea, without, within.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:73
verses.text: And he had not even a full supply of necessary food, nor even of thin clothing, but the champion of the world wrestled in nakedness and fought in hunger; so far was he from enriching himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:74
verses.text: Yet he murmured not, but was grateful for these things to the Judge of the combat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:75
verses.text: "Anxiety for all the Churches".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:76
verses.text: This was the chief thing of all, that his soul too was distracted, and his thoughts divided.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:77
verses.text: For even if nothing from without had assailed him; yet the war within was enough, those waves on waves, that sleet of cares, that war of thoughts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:78
verses.text: For if one that hath charge of but a single house, and hath servants and superintendents and stewards, often cannot take breath for cares, though there be none that molests him: he that hath the care not of a single house, but of cities and peoples and nations and of the whole world; and in respect to such great concerns, and with so many spitefully entreating him, and single-handed, and suffering so many things, and so tenderly concerned as not even a father is for his children—consider what he endured.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:79
verses.text: For that thou mayest not say, What if he was anxious, yet the anxiety was slight, he added further the intensity of the care, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:80
verses.text: "Who is weak, and I am not weak?" He did not say, 'and I share not in his dejection?' but, 'so am I troubled and disturbed, as though I myself were laboring under that very affection, that very infirmity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:81
verses.text: '  "Who is made to stumble, and I burn not?" See, again, how he places before us the excess of his grief by calling it "burning".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:82
verses.text: 'I am on fire,' 'I am in a flame,' he says, which is surely greater than any thing he has said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:83
verses.text: For those other things, although violent, yet both pass quickly by, and brought with them that pleasure which is unfading; but this was what afflicted and straightened him, and pierced his mind through and through; the suffering such things for each one of the weak, whosoever he might be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:84
verses.text: For he did not feel pained for the greater sort only and despise the lesser, but counted even the abject amongst his familiar friends.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:85
verses.text: Wherefore also he said, "who is weak?" whosoever he may be; and as though he were himself the Church throughout the world, so was he distressed for every member.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:86
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:87
verses.text: "If I must needs glory, I will glory of the things which concern my weakness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:88
verses.text: Seest thou that he no where glorieth of miracles, but of his persecutions and his trials? For this is meant by "weaknesses".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:89
verses.text: And he shows that his warfare was of a diversified character.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:90
verses.text: For both the Jews warred upon him, and the Gentiles stood against him, and the false brethren fought with him, and brethren caused him sorrow, through their weakness and by taking offense:—on every side he found trouble and disturbance, from friends and from strangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:91
verses.text: This is the especial mark of an Apostle, by these things is the Gospel woven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:92
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:94
verses.text: "The God and Father of the Lord Jesus knoweth that I lie not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:95
verses.text: The Governor under Aretas the king guarded the city of the Damascenes, desiring to apprehend me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:96
verses.text: What can be the reason that he here strongly confirms and gives assurance of his truth, seeing he did not so in respect to any of the former things? Because, perhaps, this was of older date and not so well known; whilst of those other facts, his care for the churches, and all the rest, they were themselves cognisant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:97
verses.text: See then how great the war against him was, since on his account the city was "guarded".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:98
verses.text: And when I say this of the war, I say it of the zeal of Paul; for except this had breathed intensely, it had not kindled the governor to so great madness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:99
verses.text: These things are the part of an apostolic soul, to suffer so great things and yet in nothing to veer about, but to bear nobly whatever befalls; yet not to go out to meet dangers, nor to rush upon them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:100
verses.text: See for instance here, how he was content to evade the siege, by being "let down through a window in a basket".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:101
verses.text: For though he were even desirous "to depart hence;" still nevertheless he also passionately affected the salvation of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:102
verses.text: And therefore he ofttimes had recourse even to such devices as these, preserving himself for the Preaching; and he refused not to use even human contrivances when the occasion called for them; so sober and watchful was he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:103
verses.text: For in cases where evils were inevitable, he needed only grace; but where the trial was of a measured character, he devises many things of himself even, here again ascribing the whole to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:104
verses.text: And just as a spark of unquenchable fire, if it fell into the sea, would be merged as many waves swept over it, yet would again rise shining to the surface; even so surely the blessed Paul also would now be overwhelmed by perils, and now again, having dived through them, would come up more radiant, overcoming by suffering evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:105
verses.text: For this is the brilliant victory, this is the Church's trophy, thus is the Devil overthrown when we suffer injury.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:106
verses.text: For when we suffer, he is taken captive; and himself suffers harm, when he would fain inflict it on us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:107
verses.text: And this happened in Paul's case also; and the more he plied him with perils, the more was he defeated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:108
verses.text: Nor did he raise up against him only one kind of trials, but various and diverse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:109
verses.text: For some involved labor, others sorrow, others fear, others pain, others care, others shame, others all these at once; but yet he was victorious in all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:110
verses.text: And like as if a single soldier, having the whole world fighting against him, should move through the mid ranks of his enemies, and suffer no harm: even so did Paul, showing himself singly, among barbarians, among Greeks, on every land, on every sea, abide unconquered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:111
verses.text: And as a spark, falling upon reeds and hay, changes into its own nature the things so kindled; so also did this man setting upon all make things change over unto the truth; like a winter torrent, sweeping over all things and overturning every obstacle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:112
verses.text: And like some champion who wrestles, runs, and boxes too; or soldier engaged by turns in storming, fighting on foot, on shipboard; so did he try by turns every form of fight, and breathed out fire, and was unapproachable by all; with his single body taking possession of the world, with his single tongue putting all to flight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:113
verses.text: Not with such force did those many trumpets fall upon the stones of Jericho and throw them down, as did the sound of this man's voice both dash to the earth the devil's strong-holds and bring over to himself those that were against him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:114
verses.text: And when he had collected a multitude of captives, having armed the same, he made them again his own army, and by their means conquered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:115
verses.text: Wonderful was David who laid Goliah low with a single stone; but if thou wilt examine Paul's achievements, that is a child's exploit, and great as is the difference between a shepherd and a general, so great the difference thou shalt see here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:116
verses.text: For this man brought down no Goliath by the hurling of a stone, but by speaking only he scattered the whole array of the Devil; as a lion roaring and darting out flame from his tongue, so was he found by all irresistible; and bounded everywhere by turns continually; he ran to these, he came to those, he turned about to these, he bounded away to others, swifter in his attack than the wind; governing the whole world, as though a single house or a single ship; rescuing the sinking, steadying the dizzied, cheering the sailors, sitting at the tiller, keeping an eye to the prow, tightening the yards, handling an oar, pulling at the mast, watching the sky; being all things in himself, both sailor, and pilot, and pilot's mate, and sail, and ship; and suffering all things in order to relieve the evils of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:117
verses.text: For consider.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:118
verses.text: He endured shipwreck that he might stay the shipwreck of the world; "a day and a night he passed in the deep," that he might draw it up from the deep of error; he was "in weariness" that he might refresh the weary; he endured smiting that he might heal those that had been smitten of the devil; he passed his time in prisons that he might lead forth to the light those that were sitting in prison and in darkness; he was "in deaths oft" that he might deliver from grievous deaths; "five times he received forty stripes save one" that he might free those that inflicted them from the scourge of the devil; he was "beaten with rods" that he might bring them under "the rod and the staff" of Christ; (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:119
verses.text: xxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:120
verses.text: ) he "was stoned," that he might deliver them from the senseless stones; he "was in the wilderness," that he might take them out of the wilderness; "in journeying," to stay their wanderings and open the way that leadeth to heaven; he "was in perils in the cities," that he might show the city which is above; "in hunger and thirst," to deliver from a more grievous hunger; "in nakedness," to clothe their unseemliness with the robe of Christ; set upon by the mob, to extricate them from the besetment of fiends; he burned, that he might quench the burning darts of the devil: "through a window was let down from the wall," to send up from below those that lay prostrate upon the ground.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:121
verses.text: Shall we then talk any more, seeing we do not so much as know what Paul suffered? shall we make mention any more of goods, or even of wife, or city, or freedom, when we have seen him ten thousand times despising even life itself? The martyr dies once for all: but that blessed saint in his one body and one soul endured so many perils as were enough to disturb even a soul of adamant; and what things all the saints together have suffered in so many bodies, those all he himself endured in one: he entered into the world as if a race-course, and stripped himself of all, and so made a noble stand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:122
verses.text: For he knew the fiends that were wrestling with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:123
verses.text: Wherefore also he shone forth brightly at once from the beginning, from the very starting-post, and even to the end he continued the same; yea, rather he even increased the intensity of his pursuit as he drew nearer to the prize.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:124
verses.text: And what surely is wonderful is that though suffering and doing such great things, he knew how to maintain an exceeding modesty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:125
verses.text: For when he was driven upon the necessity of relating his own good deeds, he ran quickly over them all; although he might have filled books without number, had he wished to unfold in detail every thing he mentioned; if he had specified the Churches he was in care for, if his prisons and his achievements in them, if of the other things one by one, the besetments, the assaults.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:126
verses.text: But he would not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:127
verses.text: Knowing then these things, let us also learn to be modest and not to glory at any time in wealth or other worldly things, but in the reproaches we suffer for Christ's sake, and in these, only when need compels; for if there be nothing urging it, let us not mention these even, (lest we be puffed up,) but our sins only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 26:128
verses.text: For so shall we both easily be released from them and shall have God propitious to us, and shall attain the life to come; whereunto may we all attain through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, with the Holy Ghost, be glory, might, honor, now and for ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:1
verses.text: Homily XXVI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:3
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:4
verses.text: It is not expedient for me doubtless to glory, for I will come to visions and revelations of the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:5
verses.text: What is this? Doth he who has spoken such great things say, It is not expedient "doubtless to glory?" as if he had said nothing? No; not as if he had said nothing: but because he is going to pass to another species of boasting, which is not intended indeed by so great a reward, but which to the many (though not to careful examiners) seems to set him off in brighter colors, he says, "It is not expedient for me doubtless to glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:6
verses.text: For truly the great grounds of boasting were those which he had recounted, those of his trials; he has however other things also to tell of, such as concern the revelations, the unspeakable mysteries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:7
verses.text: And wherefore, says he, "It is not expedient for me?" he means, 'lest it lift me up to pride.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:8
verses.text: ' What sayest thou? For if thou speak not of them, yet dost thou not know of them? But our knowing of them ourselves doth not lift us up so much as our publishing them to others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:9
verses.text: For it is not the nature of good deeds that useth to lift a man up, but their being witnessed to, and known of, by the many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:10
verses.text: For this cause therefore he saith, "It is not expedient for me;" and, 'that I may not implant too great an idea of me in those who hear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:11
verses.text: ' For those men indeed, the false apostles, said even what was not true about themselves; but this man hides even what is true, and that too although so great necessity lies upon him, and says, "It is not expedient for me;" teaching one and all even to superfluity to avoid any thing of the sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:12
verses.text: For this thing is attended with no advantage, but even with harm, except there be some necessary and useful reason which induceth us thereto.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:13
verses.text: Having then spoken of his perils, trials, snares, dejections, shipwrecks, he passeth to another species of boasting, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:15
verses.text: "I knew a man, fourteen years ago (whether in the body, I know not; or out of the body, I know not: God knoweth;) such an one caught up even to the third heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:16
verses.text: And I know how that he was caught up into Paradise, (whether in the body, I know not; or out of the body, I know not;) and heard unspeakable words, which it is not lawful for a man to utter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:17
verses.text: On behalf of such an one will I glory: but on mine own behalf I will not glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:18
verses.text: Great indeed was this revelation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:19
verses.text: But this was not the only one: there were many others besides, but he mentions one out of many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:20
verses.text: For that there were many, hear what he says: "Lest I should be exalted overmuch through the exceeding greatness of the revelations".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:21
verses.text: 'And yet,' a man may say, 'if he wished to conceal them, he ought not to have given any intimation whatever or said any thing of the sort; but if he wished to speak of them, to speak plainly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:22
verses.text: ' Wherefore then is it that he neither spoke plainly nor kept silence? To show by this also that he resorts to the thing unwillingly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:23
verses.text: And therefore also he has stated the time, "fourteen years".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:24
verses.text: For he does not mention it without an object, but to show that he who had refrained for so long a time would not now have spoken out, except the necessity for doing so had been great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:25
verses.text: But he would have still kept silence, had he not seen the brethren perishing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:26
verses.text: Now if Paul from the very beginning was such an one as to be counted worthy of such a revelation, when as yet he had not wrought such good works; consider what he must have grown to in fourteen years.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:27
verses.text: And observe how even in this very matter he shows modesty, by his saying some things, but confessing that of others he is ignorant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:28
verses.text: For that he was caught up indeed, he declared, but whether "in the body" or "out of the body" he says he does not know.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:29
verses.text: And yet it would have been quite enough, if he had told of his being caught up and had been silent about the other; but as it is, in his modesty he adds this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:30
verses.text: What then? Was it the mind that was caught up and the soul, whilst the body remained dead? or was the body caught up? It is impossible to tell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:31
verses.text: For if Paul who was caught up and whom things unspeakable, so many and so great, had befallen was in ignorance, much more we.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:32
verses.text: For, indeed, that he was in Paradise he knew, and that he was in the third heaven he was not ignorant, but the manner he knew not clearly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:33
verses.text: And see from yet another consideration how free he is from pride.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:34
verses.text: For in his narrative about "the city of the Damascenes" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:35
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:36
verses.text: ) he confirms what he says, but here not; for it was not his aim to establish this fact strongly, but to mention and intimate it only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:37
verses.text: Wherefore also he goes on to say, "Of such an one will I glory;" not meaning that he who was caught up was some other person, but he so frames his language in the best manner he possibly could, so as at once to mention the fact, and to avoid speaking of himself openly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:38
verses.text: For what sequence would there be in bringing some one else forward, when discoursing about himself? Wherefore then did he so put it? It was not all one to say, 'I was caught up,' and, "I knew one that was caught up;" and 'I will glory of myself,' and, "I will glory of such an one".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:39
verses.text: Now if any should say, 'And how is it possible to be caught up without a body?' I will ask him, 'How is it possible to be caught up with a body?' for this is even more inexplicable than the other, if you examine by reasonings and do not give place to faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:40
verses.text: But wherefore was he also caught up? As I think, that he might not seem to be inferior to the rest of the Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:41
verses.text: For since they had companied with Christ, but Paul had not: He therefore caught up unto glory him also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:42
verses.text: "Into Paradise".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:43
verses.text: For great was the name of this place, and it was everywhere celebrated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:44
verses.text: Wherefore also Christ said, "To-day thou shalt be with Me in Paradise".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:45
