verses.text: (Luke xxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:46
verses.text: )  "On behalf of such an one will I glory?" wherefore? For if another were caught up, wherefore dost thou glory? Whence it is evident that he said these things of himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:47
verses.text: And if he added, "but of myself I will not glory," he says nothing else than this, that, 'when there is no necessity, I will say nothing of that kind fruitlessly and at random;' or else he is again throwing obscurity over what he had said, as best he might.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:48
verses.text: For that the whole discourse was about himself, what follows also clearly shows; for he went on to say,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:49
verses.text: "But if I should even desire to glory, I shall not be foolish; for I shall speak the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:50
verses.text: How then saidst thou before, "Would that ye could bear with me a little in my foolishness;" (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:51
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:52
verses.text: ) and, "That which I speak, I speak not after the Lord, but as it were foolishly;" (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:53
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:54
verses.text: ) but here, "Though I should even desire to glory, I shall not be foolish?" Not in regard of glorying, but of lying; for if glorying be foolishness, how much more lying?  It is then with regard to this that he says, "I shall not be foolish".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:55
verses.text: Wherefore also he added,  "For I shall speak the truth; but I forbear, lest any man should account of me above that which he seeth, or that he heareth from me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:56
verses.text: Here you have the acknowledged reason; for they even deemed them to be gods, on account of the greatness of their miracles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:57
verses.text: As then in the case of the elements, God hath done both things, creating them at once weak and glorious; the one, to proclaim His own power; the other, to prevent the error of mankind: so truly here also were they both wonderful and weak, so that by the facts themselves were the unbelievers instructed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:58
verses.text: For if whilst continuing to be wonderful only and giving no proof of weakness, they had by words tried to draw away the many from conceiving of them more than the truth; not only would they have nothing succeeded, but they would even have brought about the contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:59
verses.text: For those dissuasions in words would have seemed rather to spring of lowliness of mind, and would have caused them to be the more admired.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:60
verses.text: Therefore in act and by deeds was their weakness disclosed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:61
verses.text: And one may see this exemplified in the men who lived under the old dispensation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:62
verses.text: For Elias was wonderful, but on one occasion he stood convicted of faint-heartedness; and Moses was great, but he also fled under the influence of the same passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:63
verses.text: Now such things befel them, because God stood aloof and permitted their human nature to stand confessed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:64
verses.text: For if because he led them out they said, 'Where is Moses?' what would they not have said, if he had also led them in? Wherefore also Paul himself says, "I forbear, lest any should account of me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:65
verses.text: He said not, 'say of me,' but, "lest any should even account of me" beyond my desert.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:66
verses.text: ' Whence it is evident from this also that the whole discourse relates to himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:67
verses.text: Wherefore even when he began, he said, "It is not expedient for me doubtless to glory," which he would not have said, had he been going to speak the things which he said of another man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:68
verses.text: For wherefore is it "not expedient to glory" about another? But it was himself that was counted worthy of these things; and therefore it is that he goes on to say,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:69
verses.text: "And that I should not be exalted overmuch, through the exceeding greatness of the revelations, there was given to me a thorn in the flesh, a messenger of Satan, to buffet me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:70
verses.text: What sayest thou? He that counted not the kingdom to be any thing; no, nor yet hell in respect of his longing after Christ; did he deem honor from the many to be any thing, so as both to be lifted up and to need that curb continually? for he did not say, 'that he "might" buffet me,' but "that he" may "buffet me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:71
verses.text: Yet who is there would say this? What then is the meaning of what is said? When we have explained what is meant at all by the "thorn," and who is this "messenger of Satan," then will we declare this also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:72
verses.text: There are some then who have said that he means a kind of pain in the head which was inflicted of the devil; but God forbid! For the body of Paul never could have been given over to the hands of the devil, seeing that the devil himself submitted to the same Paul at his mere bidding; and he set him laws and bounds, when he delivered over the fornicator for the destruction of the flesh, and he dared not to transgress them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:73
verses.text: What then is the meaning of what is said? An adversary is called, in the Hebrew, Satan; and in the third Book of Kings the Scripture has so termed such as were adversaries; and speaking of Solomon, says, 'In his days there was no Satan,' that is, no adversary, enemy, or opponent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:74
verses.text: ( Kings v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:75
verses.text: ) What he says then is this: God would not permit the Preaching to progress, in order to check our high thoughts; but permitted the adversaries to set upon us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:76
verses.text: For this indeed was enough to pluck down his high thoughts; not so that, pains in the head.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:77
verses.text: And so by the "messenger of Satan," he means Alexander the coppersmith, the party of Hymenaeus and Philetus, all the adversaries of the word; those who contended with and fought against him, those that cast him into a prison, those that beat him, that led him away to death; for they did Satan's business.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:78
verses.text: As then he calls those Jews children of the devil, who were imitating his deeds, so also he calls a "messenger of Satan" every one that opposeth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:79
verses.text: He says therefore, "There was given to me a thorn to buffet me;" not as if God putteth arms into such men's hands, God forbid! not that He doth chastise or punish, but for the time alloweth and permitteth them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:80
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:81
verses.text: "Concerning this thing I besought the Lord thrice".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:82
verses.text: That is, oftentimes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:83
verses.text: This also is a mark of great lowliness of mind, his not concealing that he could not bear those insidious plottings, that he fainted under them and was reduced to pray for deliverance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:84
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:85
verses.text: "And He said unto me, My grace is sufficient for thee; for my power is made perfect in weakness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:86
verses.text: That is to say, 'It is sufficient for thee that thou raisest the dead, that thou curest the blind, that thou cleansest lepers, that thou workest those other miracles; seek not also exemption from danger and fear and to preach without annoyances.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:87
verses.text: But art thou pained and dejected lest it should seem to be owing to My weakness, that there are many who plot against and beat thee and harass and scourge thee? Why this very thing doth show My power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:88
verses.text: "For My power," He saith, "is made perfect in weakness," when being persecuted ye overcome your persecutors; when being harassed ye get the better of them that harass you; when being put in bonds ye convert them that put you in bonds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:89
verses.text: Seek not then more than is needed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:90
verses.text: ' Seest thou how he himself assigns one reason, and God another? For he himself says, "Lest I should be exalted overmuch, there was given to me a thorn;" but he says that God said He permitted it in order to show His power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:91
verses.text: 'Thou seekest therefore a thing which is not only not needed, but which also obscureth the glory of My power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:92
verses.text: ' For by the words, "is sufficient for thee," He would signify this, that nothing else need be added, but the whole was complete.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:93
verses.text: So that from this also it is plain that he does not intend pains in the head; for in truth they did not preach when they were sick, for they could not preach when ill; but that harassed and persecuted, they overcame all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:94
verses.text: 'After having heard this then,' he says,  "Most gladly therefore will I glory in my weaknesses".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:95
verses.text: For that they may not sink down, when those false Apostles are glorying over their contrary lot and these are suffering persecution, he shows that he shineth all the brighter for this, and that thus the power of God shines forth the rather, and what happens is just matter for glorying.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:96
verses.text: Wherefore he says, "Most gladly therefore will I glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:97
verses.text: 'Not as therefore sorrowing did I speak of the things which I enumerated, or of that which I have just now said, "there was given to me a thorn;" but as priding myself upon them and drawing to myself greater power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:98
verses.text: ' Wherefore also he adds,  "That the strength of Christ may rest upon me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:99
verses.text: Here he hints at another thing also, namely, that in proportion as the trials waxed in intensity, in the same proportion the grace was increased and continued.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:100
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:101
verses.text: "Wherefore I take pleasure in many weaknesses".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:102
verses.text: Of what sort? tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:103
verses.text: "In injuries, in persecutions, in necessities, in distresses".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:104
verses.text: Seest thou how he has now revealed it in the clearest manner? For in mentioning the species of the infirmity he spake not of fevers, nor any return of that sort, nor any other bodily ailment, but of "injuries, persecutions, distresses".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:105
verses.text: Seest thou a single-minded soul? He longs to be delivered from those dangers; but when he heard God's answer that this befitteth not, he was not only not sorry that he was disappointed of his prayer, but was even glad.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:106
verses.text: Wherefore he said, "I take pleasure," 'I rejoice, I long, to be injured, persecuted, distressed for Christ's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:107
verses.text: ' And he said these things both to check those, and to raise the spirits of these that they might not be ashamed at Paul's sufferings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:108
verses.text: For that ground was enough to make them shine brighter than all men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:109
verses.text: Then he mentions another reason also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:110
verses.text: "For when I am weak, then am I strong".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:111
verses.text: 'Why marvellest thou that the power of God is then conspicuous? I too am strong "then;"' for then most of all did grace come upon him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:112
verses.text: "For as His sufferings abound, so doth our consolation abound also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:113
verses.text: (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:114
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:115
verses.text: )   Where affliction is, there is also consolation; where consolation, there is grace also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:116
verses.text: For instance when he was thrown into the prison, then it was he wrought those marvellous things; when he was shipwrecked and cast away upon that barbarous country, then more than ever was he glorified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:117
verses.text: When he went bound into the judgment-hall, then he overcame even the judge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:118
verses.text: And so it was too in the Old Testament; by their trials the righteous flourished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:119
verses.text: So it was with the three children, so with Daniel, with Moses, and Joseph; thence did they all shine and were counted worthy of great crowns.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:120
verses.text: For then the soul also is purified, when it is afflicted for God's sake: it then enjoys greater assistance as needing more help and worthy of more grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:121
verses.text: And truly, before the reward which is proposed to it by God, it reaps a rich harvest of good things by becoming philosophic.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:122
verses.text: For affliction rends pride away and prunes out all listlessness and exerciseth unto patience: it revealeth the meanness of human things and leads unto much philosophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:123
verses.text: For all the passions give way before it, envy, emulation, lust, rule, desire of riches, of beauty, boastfulness, pride, anger; and the whole remaining swarm of these distempers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:124
verses.text: And if thou desirest to see this in actual working, I shall be able to show thee both a single individual and a whole people, as well under affliction as at ease; and so to teach thee how great advantage cometh of the one, and how great listlessness from the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:125
verses.text: For the people of the Hebrews, when they were vexed and persecuted, groaned and besought God, and drew down upon themselves great influences from above: but when they waxed fat, they kicked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:126
verses.text: The Ninevities again, when they were in the enjoyment of security, so exasperated God that He threatened to pluck up the entire city from its foundations: but after they had been humbled by that preaching, they displayed all virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:127
verses.text: But if thou wouldest see also a single individual, consider Solomon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:128
verses.text: For he, when deliberating with anxiety and trouble concerning the government of that nation, was vouchsafed that vision: but when he was in the enjoyment of luxury, he slid into the very pit of iniquity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:129
verses.text: And what did his father? When was he admirable and passing belief? Was it not when he was in trials? And Absalom, was he not sober-minded, whilst still an exile; but after his return, became both tyrannical and a parricide? And what did Job? He indeed shone even in prosperity, but showed yet brighter after his affliction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:130
verses.text: And why must one speak of the old and ancient things? for if one do but examine our own state at present, he will see how great is the advantage of affliction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:131
verses.text: For now indeed that we are in the enjoyment of peace, we are become supine, and lax and have filled the Church with countless evils; but when we were persecuted, we were more sober-minded, and kinder, and more earnest, and more ready as to these assemblies and as to hearing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:132
verses.text: For what fire is to gold, that is affliction unto souls; wiping away filth, rendering men clean, making them bright and shining.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:133
verses.text: It leadeth unto the kingdom, that unto hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:134
verses.text: And therefore the one way is broad, the other narrow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:135
verses.text: Wherefore also, He Himself said, "In the world ye shall have tribulation," (John xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:136
verses.text: ) as though he were leaving some great good behind unto us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:137
verses.text: If then thou art a disciple, travel thou the straight and narrow way, and be not disgusted nor discouraged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:138
verses.text: For even if thou be not afflicted in that way; thou must inevitably be afflicted on other grounds, of no advantage to thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:139
verses.text: For the envious man also, and the lover of money, and he that burneth for an harlot, and the vainglorious, and each one of the rest that follow whatsoever is evil, endureth many disheartenings and afflictions, and is not less afflicted than they who mourn.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:140
verses.text: And if he doth not weep nor mourn, it is for shame and insensibility: since if thou shouldest look into his soul, thou wilt see it filled with countless waves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:141
verses.text: Since then whether we follow this way of life or that, we must needs be afflicted: wherefore choose we not this way which along with affliction bringeth crowns innumerable? For thus hath God led all the saints through affliction and distress, at once doing them service, and securing the rest of men against entertaining a higher opinion of them than they deserve.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:142
verses.text: For thus it was that idolatries gained ground at first; men being held in admiration beyond their desert.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:143
verses.text: Thus the Roman senate decreed Alexander to be the thirteenth God, for it possessed the privilege of electing and enrolling Gods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:144
verses.text: For instance, when all about Christ had been reported, the ruler of the nation sent to inquire, whether they would be pleased to elect Him also a God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:145
verses.text: They however refused their consent, being angry and indignant that previous to their vote and decree, the Power of the Crucified flashing abroad had won over the whole world to its own worship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:146
verses.text: But thus it was ordered even against their will that the Divinity of Christ was not proclaimed by man's decree, nor was He counted one of the many that were by them elected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:147
verses.text: For they counted even boxers to be Gods, and the favorite of Hadrian; after whom the city Antinous is named.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:148
verses.text: For since death testifies against their moral nature, the devil invented another way, that of the soul's immortality; and mingling therewith that excessive flattery, he seduced many into impiety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:149
verses.text: And observe what wicked artifice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:150
verses.text: When we advance that doctrine for a good purpose, he overthrows our words; but when he himself is desirous of framing an argument for mischief, he is very zealous in setting it up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:151
verses.text: And if any one ask, 'How is Alexander a God? Is he not dead? and miserably too?' 'Yes, but the soul is immortal?' he replies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:152
verses.text: Now thou arguest and philosophizest for immortality, to detach men from the God Who is over all: but when we declare that this is God's greatest gift, thou persuadest thy dupes that men are low and grovelling, and in no better case than the brutes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:153
verses.text: And if we say, 'the Crucified lives,' laughter follows immediately: although the whole world proclaims it, both in old time and now; in old time by miracles, now by converts; for truly these successes are not those of a dead man: but if one say, 'Alexander lives,' thou believest, although thou hast no miracle to allege.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:154
verses.text: 'Yes,' one replies; 'I have; for when he lived he wrought many and great achievements; for he subdued both nations and cities, and in many wars and battles he conquered, and erected trophies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:155
verses.text: '  If then I shall show somewhat which he when alive never dreamed of, neither he, nor any other man that ever lived, what other proof of the resurrection wilt thou require? For that whilst alive one should win battles and victories, being a king and having armies at his disposal, is nothing marvelous, no, nor startling or novel; but that after a Cross and Tomb one should perform such great things throughout every land and sea, this it is which is most especially replete with such amazement, and proclaims His divine and unutterable Power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:156
verses.text: And Alexander indeed after his decease never restored again his kingdom which had been rent in pieces and quite abolished: indeed how was it likely he, dead, should do so? but Christ then most of all set up His after He was dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:157
verses.text: And why speak I of Christ? seeing that He granted to His disciples also, after their deaths, to shine? For, tell me, where is the tomb of Alexander? show it me and tell me the day on which he died.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:158
verses.text: But of the servants of Christ the very tombs are glorious, seeing they have taken possession of the most loyal city; and their days are well known, making festivals for the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:159
verses.text: And his tomb even his own people know not, but this man's the very barbarians know.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:160
verses.text: And the tombs of the servants of the Crucified are more splendid than the palaces of kings; not for the size and beauty of the buildings, (yet even in this they surpass them,) but, what is far more, in the zeal of those who frequent them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:161
verses.text: For he that wears the purple himself goes to embrace those tombs, and, laying aside his pride, stands begging the saints to be his advocates with God, and he that hath the diadem implores the tent-maker and the fisherman, though dead, to be his patrons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:162
verses.text: Wilt thou dare then, tell me, to call the Lord of these dead; whose servants even after their decease are the patrons of the kings of the world? And this one may see take place not in Rome only, but in Constantinople also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:163
verses.text: For there also Constantine the Great, his son considered he should be honoring with great honor, if he buried him in the porch of the fisherman; and what porters are to kings in their palaces, that kings are at the tomb to fisherman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:164
verses.text: And these indeed as lords of the place occupy the inside, whilst the others as though but sojourners and neighbors were glad to have the gate of the porch assigned them; showing by what is done in this world, even to the unbelievers, that in the Resurrection the fisherman will be yet more their superiors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:165
verses.text: For if here it is so in the burial of each, much more will it in the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:166
verses.text: And their rank is interchanged; kings assume that of servants and ministers, and subjects the dignity of kings, yea rather a brighter still.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:167
verses.text: And that this is no piece of flattery, the truth itself demonstrates; for by those these have become more illustrious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:168
verses.text: For far greater reverence is paid to these tombs than to the other royal sepulchres; for there indeed is profound solitude, whilst here there is an immense concourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:169
verses.text: But if thou wilt compare these tombs with the royal palaces, here again the palm remains with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:170
verses.text: For there indeed there are many who keep off, but here many who invite and draw to them rich, poor, men, women, bond, free; there, is much fear; here, pleasure unutterable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:171
verses.text: 'But,' saith one, 'it is a sweet sight to look on a king covered with gold and crowned, and standing by his side, generals, commanders, captains of horse and foot, lieutenants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:172
verses.text: ' Well, but this of ours is so much grander and more awful that that must be judged, compared with it, to be stage scenery and child's play.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:173
verses.text: For the instant thou hast stepped across the threshhold, at once the place sends up thy thoughts to heaven, to the King above, to the army of the Angels, to the lofty throne, to the unapproachable glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:174
verses.text: And here indeed He hath put in the ruler's power, of his subjects to loose one, and bind another; but the bones of the saints possess no such pitiful and mean authority, but that which is far greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:175
verses.text: For they summon demons and put them to the torture, and loose from those bitterest of all bonds, them that are bound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:176
verses.text: What is more fearful than this tribunal? Though no one is seen, though no one piles the sides of the demon, yet are there cries, and tearings, lashes, tortures, burning tongues, because the demon cannot endure that marvellous power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:177
verses.text: And they that once wore bodies, are victorious over bodiless powers; their dust and bones and ashes rack those invisible natures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:178
verses.text: And therefore in truth it is that none would ever travel abroad to see the palaces of kings, but many kings and have often traveled to see this spectacle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:179
verses.text: For the Martyries of the saints exhibit outlines and symbols of the judgment to come; in that demons are scourged, men chastened and delivered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:180
verses.text: Seest thou the power of saints, even dead? seest thou the weakness of sinners, even living? Flee then wickedness, that thou mayest have power over such; and pursue virtue with all thy might.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:181
verses.text: For if the case be thus here, consider what it will be in the world to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 27:182
verses.text: And as being evermore possessed with this love, lay hold on the life eternal; whereunto may we all attain, through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father together with the Holy Ghost, be glory, might, honor, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:1
verses.text: Homily XXVII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:3
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:4
verses.text: I am become foolish in glorying; ye compelled me: for I ought to have been commended of you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:5
verses.text: Having fully completed what he had to say about his own praises, he did not stay at this; but again excuses himself and asks pardon for what he said, declaring that his doing so was of necessity and not of choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:6
verses.text: Still nevertheless, although there was necessity, he calls himself "a fool".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:7
verses.text: And when he began indeed, he said, "As foolish receive me," and "as in foolishness;" but now, leaving out the 'as,' he calls himself "foolish".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:8
verses.text: For after he had established the point he wished by saying what he did, he afterwards boldly and unsparingly grapples with all failing of the sort, teaching all persons that none should ever praise himself where there is no necessity, seeing that even where a reason for it existed, Paul termed himself a fool for so doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:9
verses.text: Then he turns the blame also of his so speaking not upon the false Apostles, but wholly upon the disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:10
verses.text: For "ye," he saith, "compelled me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:11
verses.text: 'For if they gloried, but were not by doing so leading you astray nor causing your destruction, I should not have been thus led on to descend unto this discussion: but because they were corrupting the whole Church, with a view to your advantage I was compelled to become foolish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:12
verses.text: ' And he did not say, 'For I feared lest if they obtained the highest estimation with you, they should sow their doctrines,' yet this indeed he set down above when he said, "I fear, lest by any means, as the serpent deceived Eve, so your minds should be corrupted".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:13
verses.text: (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:14
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:15
verses.text: ) Here however he does not so express himself, but in a more commanding manner and with more authority, having gained boldness from what he had said, "For I ought to have been commended of you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:16
verses.text: Then he also assigns the reason; and again he mentions not his revelations nor his miracles only, but his temptations also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:17
verses.text: "For in nothing was I behind the chiefest Apostles".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:18
verses.text: See how he here too again speaks out with greater authoritativeness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:19
verses.text: For, before indeed he said, "I reckon I am not a whit behind," but here, after those proofs, he now boldly speaks out asserting the fact, as I said, thus absolutely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:20
verses.text: Not that even thus he departs from the mean, nor from his proper character.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:21
verses.text: For as though he had uttered something great and exceeding his deserts, in that he numbered himself with the Apostles, he thus again speaks modestly, and adds,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:22
verses.text: "Although I be nothing, the signs of an Apostle were wrought among you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:23
verses.text: 'Look not thou at this,' he says, 'whether I be mean and little, but whether thou hast not enjoyed those things which from an Apostle it was meet thou shouldest enjoy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:24
verses.text: ' Yet he did not say 'mean,' but what was lower, "nothing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:25
verses.text: For where is the good of being great, and of use to nobody? even as there is no advantage in a skilful physician if he heals none of those that be sick.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:26
verses.text: 'Do not then,' he says, 'scrutinize this that I am nothing, but consider that, that wherein ye ought to have been benefitted, I have failed in nothing, but have given proof of mine Apostleship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:27
verses.text: There ought then to have been no need for me to say aught.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:28
verses.text: ' Now he thus spoke, not as wanting to be commended, (for how should he, he who counted heaven itself to be a small thing in comparison with his longing after Christ?) but as desiring their salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:29
verses.text: Then lest they should say, 'And what is it to us, even though thou wast not a whit behind the very chiefest Apostles?' he therefore added,  "The signs of an Apostle were wrought among you in all patience, and by signs and wonders".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:30
verses.text: Amazing! what a sea of good works hath he traversed in a few words! And observe what it is he puts first, "patience".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:31
verses.text: For this is the note of an Apostle, bearing all things nobly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:32
verses.text: This then he expressed shortly by a single word; but upon the miracles, which were not of his own achieving, he employs more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:33
verses.text: For consider how many prisons, how many stripes, how many dangers, how many conspiracies, how many sleet-showers of temptations, how many civil, how many foreign wars, how many pains, how many attacks he has implied here in that word, "patience!" And by "signs" again, how many dead raised, how many blind healed, how many lepers cleansed, how many devils cast out! Hearing these things, let us learn if we happen upon a necessity for such recitals to cut our good deeds short, as he too did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:34
verses.text: Then lest any should say, Well! if thou be both great, and have wrought many things, still thou hast not wrought such great things, as the Apostles have in the other Churches, he added,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:35
verses.text: "For what is there wherein ye were made inferior to the rest of the Churches?"  'Ye were partakers,' he says, 'of no less grace than the others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:36
verses.text: ' But perhaps some one will say, 'What can be the reason that he turns the discourse upon the Apostles, abandoning the contest against the false Apostles?' Because he is desirous to erect their spirits yet further, and to show that he is not only superior to them, but not even inferior to the great Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:37
verses.text: Therefore, surely, when he is speaking of those he says, "I am more;" but when he compares himself with the Apostles, he considers it a great thing not to be "behind," although he labored more than they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:38
verses.text: And thence he shows that they insult the Apostles, in holding him who is their equal second to these men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:39
verses.text: "Except it be that I myself was not a burden to you?" Again he has pronounced their rebuke with great severity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:40
verses.text: And what follows is of yet more odious import.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:41
verses.text: "Forgive me this wrong".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:42
verses.text: Still, nevertheless, this severity contains both words of love and a commendation of themselves; if, that is, they consider it a wrong done to them, that the Apostle did not consent to receive aught from them, nor relied on them enough to be supported by them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:43
verses.text: 'If,' says he, 'ye blame me for this:' he did not say, 'Ye blame me wrongly,' but with great sweetness, 'I ask your pardon, forgive me this fault.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:44
verses.text: ' And observe his prudence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:45
verses.text: For because the mooting this continually tended to bring disgrace upon them, he continually softens it down; saying above, for instance, "As the truth of Christ is in me, this boasting shall not be stopped in me;" (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:46
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:47
verses.text: ) then again, "Because I love you not? God knoweth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:48
verses.text: …But that I may cut off occasion from them that desire occasion, and that wherein they glory, they may be found even as we".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:49
verses.text: (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:50
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:52
verses.text: ) And in the former Epistle "What is my reward then?" Verily, "that when I preach the Gospel, I may make the Gospel without charge".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:53
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:54
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:55
verses.text: ) And here; "Forgive me this wrong".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:56
verses.text: For every where he avoids showing that it is on account of their weakness he taketh not from them; and here not to wound them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:57
verses.text: And therefore here he thus expresses himself; 'If ye think this to be an offense, I ask forgiveness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:58
verses.text: ' Now he spoke thus, at once to wound and to heal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:59
verses.text: For do not say this, I pray thee; 'If thou meanest to wound, why excuse it? but if thou excusest it, why wound?' For this is wisdom's part, at once to lance, and to bind up the sore.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:60
verses.text: Then that he may not seem, as he also said before, to be continually harping upon this for the sake of receiving from them, he remedies this suspicion, even in his former Epistle, saying, "But I write not these things that it may be so done in my case; for it were good for me rather to die, than that any man should make my glorying void;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:61
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:62
verses.text: ) but here with more sweetness and gentleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:63
verses.text: How, and in what manner?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:64
verses.text: "Behold this is the third time I am ready to come to you, and I will not be a burden to you; for I seek not yours, but you: for the children ought not to lay up for the parents, but the parents for the children".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:65
verses.text: What he says is this; 'It is not because I do not receive of you that I do not come to you; nay, I have already come twice; and I am prepared to come this third time, "and I will not be a burden to you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:66
verses.text: ' And the reason is a noble one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:67
verses.text: For he did not say, 'because ye are mean,' 'because ye are hurt at it,' 'because, ye are weak:' but what? "For I seek not yours, but you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:68
verses.text: 'I seek greater things; souls instead of goods; instead of gold, salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:69
verses.text: ' Then because there still hung about the matter some suspicion, as if he were displeased at them; he therefore even states an argument.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:70
verses.text: For since it was likely they would say, 'Can you not have both us and ours?' he adds with much grace this excuse for them, saying, "For the children ought not to lay up for the parents, but the parents for the children;" instead of teachers and disciples, employing the term parents and children, and showing that he does as a matter of duty what was not of duty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:71
verses.text: For Christ did not so command, but he says this to spare them; and therefore he adds also something further.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:72
verses.text: For he did not only say that "the children ought not to lay up," but also that the parents ought to.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:73
verses.text: Therefore since it is meet to give,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:74
verses.text: "I will most gladly spend and be spent for your souls".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:75
verses.text: 'For the law of nature indeed has commanded the parents to lay up for the children; but I do not do this only, but I give myself also besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:76
verses.text: ' And this lavishness of his, the not only not receiving, but giving also besides, is not in common sort but accompanied with great liberality, and out of his own want; for the words, "I will be spent," are of one who would imply this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:77
verses.text: 'For should it be necessary to spend my very flesh, I will not spare it for your salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:78
verses.text: ' And that which follows contains at once accusation and love, "though the more abundantly I love you, the less I be loved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:79
verses.text: 'And I do this,' he says, 'for the sake of those who are beloved by me, yet love me not equally.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:80
verses.text: ' Observe then, now, how many steps there are in this matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:81
verses.text: He had a right to receive, but he did not receive; here is good work the first: and this, though in want; good work the second; and though preaching to them, the third; he gives besides, the fourth; and not merely gives, but lavishly too, the fifth; not money only, but himself, the sixth; for those who loved him not greatly, the seventh; and for those whom he greatly loved, the eighth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:82
verses.text: Let us then also emulate this man! For it is a serious charge, the not loving even; but becomes more serious, when although one is loved he loveth not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:83
verses.text: For if he that loveth one that loveth him be no better than the publicans; (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:84
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:85
verses.text: ) he that doth not so much as this ranks with the beasts; yea rather, is even below them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:86
verses.text: What sayest thou, O man? Lovest thou not him that loveth thee? What then dost thou live for? Wherein wilt thou be of use hereafter? in what sort of matters? in public? in private? By no means; for nothing is more useless than a man that knows not to love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:87
verses.text: This law even robbers have oftentimes respected, and murderers, and housebreakers; and having only taken salt with one, have been made his friends, letting the board change their disposition, and thou that sharest not salt only, but words and deeds, and comings in and goings out, with him, dost thou not love? Nay: those that live impurely lavish even whole estates on their strumpets; and thou who hast a worthy love, art thou so cold, and weak, and unmanly, as not to be willing to love, even when it costs thee nothing? 'And who,' one asks, 'would be so vile, who such a wild beast, as to turn away from and to hate him that loves him?' Thou dost well indeed to disbelieve it, because of the unnaturalness of the thing; but if I shall show that there are many such persons, how shall we then bear the shame? For when thou speakest ill of him whom thou lovest, when thou hearest another speak ill of him and thou defendest him not, when thou grudgest that he should be well accounted of, what sort of affection is this? And yet it is not sufficient proof of love, not grudging, nor yet again not being at enmity or war with, but only supporting and advancing him that loves thee: but when a man does and says everything to pull down his neighbor even, what can be more wretched than such a spirit? Yesterday and the day before his friend, thou didst both converse and eat with him: then because all at once thou sawest thine own member highly thought of, casting off the mask of friendship, thou didst put on that of enmity, or rather of madness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:88
verses.text: For glaring madness it is, to be annoyed at the goodness of neighbors; for this is the act of mad and rabid dogs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:89
verses.text: For like them, these also fly at all men's faces, exasperated with envy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:90
verses.text: Better to have a serpent twining about one's entrails than envy crawling in us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:91
verses.text: For that it is often possible to vomit up by means of medicines, or by food to quiet: but envy twineth not in entrails but harboreth in the bosom of the soul, and is a passion hard to be effaced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:92
verses.text: And indeed if such a serpent were within one, it would not touch men's bodies so long as it had a supply of food; but envy, even though thou spread for it ever so endless a banquet, devoureth the soul itself, gnawing on every side, tearing, tugging, and it is not possible to find any palliative whereby to make it quit its madness, save one only, the adversity of the prosperous; so is it appeased, nay rather, not so even.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:93
verses.text: For even should this man suffer adversity, yet still he sees some other prosperous, and is possessed by the same pangs, and everywhere are wounds, everywhere blows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:94
verses.text: For it is not possible to live in the world and not see persons well reputed of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:95
verses.text: And such is the extravagance of this distemper, that even if one should shut its victim up at home, he envies the men of old who are dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:96
verses.text: Now, that men of the world should feel in this way, is indeed a grievous thing, yet it is not so very dreadful; but that those who are freed from the turmoils of busy life should be possessed by this distemper,—this is most grievous of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:97
verses.text: And I could have wished indeed to be silent: and if silence took away too the disgrace of those doings, it were a gain to say nothing: if however, though I should hold my peace the doings will cry out more loudly than my tongue, no harm will accrue from my words, because of their parading these evils before us, but possibly some gain and advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:98
verses.text: For this distemper has infected even the Church, it has turned everything topsy-turvy, and dissevered the connection of the body, and we stand opposed to each other, and envy supplies us arms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:99
verses.text: Therefore great is the disruption.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:100
verses.text: For if when all build up, it is a great thing if our disciples stand; when all at once are pulling down, what will the end be?   What doest thou, O man? Thou thinkest to pull down thy neighbor's; but before his thou pullest down thine own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:101
verses.text: Seest thou not them that are gardeners, that are husbandmen, how they all concur in one object? One hath dug the soil, another planted, a third carefully covered the roots, another watereth what is planted, another hedges it round and fortifies it, another drives off the cattle; and all look to one end, the safety of the plant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:102
verses.text: Here, however, it is not so: but I plant indeed myself, and another shakes and disturbs the plant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:103
verses.text: At least, allow it to get nicely fixed, that it may be strong enough to resist the assault.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:104
verses.text: Thou destroyest not my work, but abandonest thine own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:105
verses.text: I planted, thou oughtest to have watered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:106
verses.text: If then thou shake it, thou hast torn it up by the roots, and hast not wherein to display thy watering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:107
verses.text: But thou seest the planter highly esteemed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:108
verses.text: Fear not: neither am I anything, nor thou.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:109
verses.text: "For neither is he that planteth nor he that watereth any thing;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:110
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:111
verses.text: ) one's is the work, God's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:112
verses.text: So it is with Him thou fightest and warrest, in plucking up what is planted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:113
verses.text: Let us then at length come to our sober senses again, let us watch.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:114
verses.text: For I fear not so much the battle without, as the fight within; for the root also, when it is well fitted into the ground, will suffer no damage from the winds; but if it be itself shaken, a worm gnawing through it from within, the tree will fall, even though none molest it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:115
verses.text: How long gnaw we the root of the Church like worms? For of earth such imaginings are begotten also, or rather not of earth, but of dung, having corruption for their mother; and they cease not from the detestable flattery that is from women.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:116
verses.text: Let us at length be generous men, let us be champions of philosophy, let us drive back the violent career of these evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:117
verses.text: For I behold the mass of the Church prostrate now, as though it were a corpse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:118
verses.text: And as in a body newly dead, one may see eyes and hands and feet and neck and head, and yet no one limb performing its proper office; so, truly, here also, all who are here are of the faithful, but their faith is not active; for we have quenched its warmth and made the body of Christ a corpse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:119
verses.text: Now if this sounds awful when said, it is much more awful when it appears in actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:120
verses.text: For we have indeed the name of brothers, but do the deeds of foes; and whilst all are called members, we are divided against each other like wild beasts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:121
verses.text: I have said this not from a desire to parade our condition, but to shame you and make you desist.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:122
verses.text: Such and such a man goes into a house; honor is paid to him; thou oughtest to give God thanks because thy member is honored and God is glorified; but thou doest the contrary: thou speakest evil of him to the man that honored him, so that thou trippest up the heels of both, and, besides, disgracest thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:123
verses.text: And wherefore, wretched and miserable one? Hast thou heard thy brother praised, either amongst men or women? Add to his praises, for so thou shalt praise thyself also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:124
verses.text: But if thou overthrow the praise, first, thou hast spoken evil of thyself, having so acquired an ill character, and thou hast raised him the higher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:125
verses.text: When thou hearest one praised, become thou a partner in what is said; if not in thy life and virtue, yet still in rejoicing over his excellencies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:126
verses.text: Hath such an one praised? Do thou too admire: so shall he praise thee also as good and candid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:127
verses.text: Fear not, as though thou wast ruining thine own interest by thy praises of another: for this is rather the result of accusation of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:128
verses.text: For mankind is of a contentious spirit; and when it sees thee speaking ill of any, it heaps on its praises, wishing to mortify by so doing; and reprobates those that are accusers, both in its own mind and to others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:129
verses.text: Seest thou what disgrace we are the causes of to ourselves? how we destroy and rend the flock? Let us at length be members (of one another), let us become one body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:130
verses.text: And let him that is praised repudiate the praises, and transfer the encomium to his brother; and let him that hears another praised, feel pleasure to himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:131
verses.text: If we thus come together ourselves, we shall also draw unto ourselves the Head; but if we live parted from each other, we shall also put from us the aid which comes from thence; and when that is put aside, the body will receive great damage, not being bound together from above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:132
verses.text: That this then may not happen, let us, banishing ill will and envy, and despising what the many may think of us, embrace love and concord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 28:133
verses.text: For thus we shall obtain both the present good things and those to come; whereunto may we all attain, through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father together with the Holy Ghost, be glory, might, honor, now and forever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:1
verses.text: Homily XXVIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:3
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:4
verses.text: –  But be it so, I myself did not burden you: but being crafty, I caught you with guile.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:5
verses.text: Did I take advantage of you by any one of them whom I have sent unto you? I exhorted Titus, and with him I sent the brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:6
verses.text: Did Titus take any advantage of you? Walked we not by the same spirit? walked we not in the same steps?  Paul has spoken these words very obscurely, but not without a meaning or purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:7
verses.text: For seeing he was speaking about money, and his defence on that score, it is reasonable that what he says must be wrapt in obscureness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:8
verses.text: What then is the meaning of what he says? He had said, 'I received not, nay I am ready even to give besides, and to spend;' and much discourse is made on this subject both in the former Epistle and in this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:9
verses.text: Now he says something else, introducing the subject in the form of an objection and meeting it by anticipation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:10
verses.text: What he says is something like this; 'I indeed have not made a gain of you: but perhaps some one has it to say that I did not receive of you indeed myself, but, being crafty, I procured those who were sent by me to ask for something of you as for themselves, and through them I myself received, yet keeping myself clear of seeming to receive, by receiving through others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:11
verses.text: But none can have this to say either; and you are witnesses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:12
verses.text: ' Wherefore also he proceeds by question, saying, "I exhorted Titus, and with him I sent the brother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:13
verses.text: Did Titus make a gain of you?" 'walked he not just as I walked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:14
verses.text: ' That is to say, neither did he receive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:15
verses.text: Seest thou how intense a strictness is here, in that he not only keeps himself clear of that receiving, but so modulates those also who are sent by him that he may not give so much as a slight pretence to those who were desirous of attacking him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:16
verses.text: For this is far greater than that which the Patriarch did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:17
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:18
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:19
verses.text: ) For he indeed, when he had returned from his victory, and the king would have given him the spoil, refused to accept aught save what the men had eaten; but this man neither himself enjoyed from them his necessary food, nor allowed his partners to partake of such: thus abundantly stopping the mouths of the shameless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:20
verses.text: Wherefore he makes no assertion, nor does he say that they did not receive either; but what was far more than this, he cites the Corinthians themselves as witnesses that they had received nothing, that he may not seem to be witnessing in his own person, but by their verdict; which course we are accustomed to take in matters fully admitted and about which we are confident.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:21
verses.text: 'For tell me,' he says, 'Did any one of those who were sent by us make unfair gain of you?' He did not say, 'Did any one receive aught from you?' but he calls the things 'unfair gain;' attacking them and shaming them exceedingly, and showing that to receive of an unwilling giver is 'unfair gain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:22
verses.text: ' And he said not 'did Titus?' but, "did any?" 'For ye cannot say this either,' he says, 'that such an one certainly did not receive, but another did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:23
verses.text: No single one of those who came did so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:24
verses.text: ' "I exhorted Titus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:25
verses.text: This too is severely said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:26
verses.text: For he did not say, 'I sent Titus,' but, 'I exhorted' him; showing that if he had received even, he would have done so justly; but, nevertheless, even so he remained pure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:27
verses.text: Wherefore he asks them again, saying, "Did Titus take any advantage of you? Walked we not by the same spirit?" What means, "by the same spirit?" He ascribes the whole to grace and shows that the whole of this praise is the good result not of our labors, but of the gift of the Spirit and of Grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:28
verses.text: For it was a very great instance of grace that although both in want and hunger they would receive nothing for the edification of the disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:29
verses.text: "Walked we not in the same steps?" That is to say, they did not depart the least from this strictness, but preserved the same rule entire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:30
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:31
verses.text: "Again, think ye that we are excusing ourselves unto you?"  Seest thou how he is continually in fear, lest he should incur the suspicion of flattery? Seest thou an Apostle's prudence, how constantly he mentions this? For he said before, "We commend not ourselves again, but give you occasion to glory;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:32
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:33
verses.text: ) and in the commencement of the Epistle, "Do we need letters of commendation?" (ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:34
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:35
verses.text: )  "But all things are for your edifying".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:36
verses.text: Again he is soothing them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:37
verses.text: And he does not here either say clearly, 'on this account we receive not, because of your weakness;' but, 'in order that we may edify you;' speaking out indeed more clearly than he did before, and revealing that wherewith he travailed; but yet without severity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:38
verses.text: For he did not say, 'because of your weakness;' but, 'that ye may be edified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:39
verses.text: '  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:40
verses.text: "For I fear, lest by any means when I come, I should not find you such as I would, and should myself be found of you such as ye would not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:41
verses.text: He is going to say something great and offensive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:42
verses.text: And therefore he also inserts this excuse for it, both by saying, "All things are for your edifying," and by adding, "I fear," softening the harshness of what was presently going to be said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:43
verses.text: For it was not here out of arrogance nor the authority of a teacher, but out of a father's tender concern, when he is more fearful and trembling than the sinners themselves at that which is likely to reform them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:44
verses.text: And not even so does he run them down or make an absolute assertion; but says doubtingly, "lest by any means when I come, I should not find you such as I would".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:45
verses.text: He did not say, 'not virtuous,' but "not such as I would," everywhere employing the terms of affection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:46
verses.text: And the words, "I should find," are of one who would express what is out of natural expectation, as are also those, "I shall be found by you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:47
verses.text: For the thing is not of deliberate choice, but of a necessity originating with you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:48
verses.text: Wherefore he says, "I should be found such as ye would not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:49
verses.text: He said not here, "such as I would not," but, with more severity, "such as ye wish not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:50
verses.text: For it would in that case become his own will, not indeed what he would first have willed, but his will nevertheless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:51
verses.text: For he might indeed have said again, 'such as I would not,' and so have showed his love: but he wishes not to relax his hearer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:52
verses.text: Yea rather, his words would in that case have been even harsher; but now he has at once dealt them a smarter blow and showed himself more gentle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:53
verses.text: For this is the characteristic of his wisdom; cutting more deeply, to strike more gently.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:54
verses.text: Then, because he had spoken obscurely, he unveils his meaning, saying,  "Lest there be strife, jealousy, wraths, backbitings, whisperings, swellings".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:55
verses.text: And what he might well put first, that he puts last: for they were very proud against him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:56
verses.text: Therefore, that he may not seem principally to be seeking his own, he first mentions what was common.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:57
verses.text: For all these things were gendered of envy, their slanderings, accusations, dissensions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:58
verses.text: For just like some evil root, envy produced wrath, accusation, pride, and all those other evils, and by them was increased further,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:59
verses.text: And "lest when I come again, my God should humble me among you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:60
verses.text: And the word "again," too, is as smiting them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:61
verses.text: For he means, 'What happened before is enough;' as he said also in the beginning of the Epistle, "to spare you, I came not as yet to Corinth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:62
verses.text: (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:63
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:65
verses.text: ) Seest thou how he shows both indignation and tender affection? But what means, "will humble me?" And yet this is glorious rather, to accuse, to take vengeance, to call to account, to be seated in the place of judge; howbeit he calls it a humbling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:66
verses.text: So far was he from being ashamed of that cause of humbling, because, "his bodily presence was weak, and his speech of no account," that he wished to be even for ever in that case, and deprecated the contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:67
verses.text: And he says this more clearly as he proceeds; and he counts this to be especially humbling, to be involved in such a necessity as the present, of punishing and taking vengeance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:68
verses.text: And wherefore did he not say, 'lest when I come I shall be humbled,' but, "lest when I come my God will humble me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:69
verses.text: 'Because had it not been for His sake, I should have paid no attention nor been anxious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:70
verses.text: For it is not as possessing authority and for my own pleasure, that I demand satisfaction, but because of His commandment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:71
verses.text: ' Now above, indeed, he expressed himself thus, "I shall be found;" here, however, he relaxes and adopts milder and gentler language, saying,  "I shall mourn for many of them who have sinned".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:72
verses.text: Not simply, "who have sinned," but,  "Who have not repented".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:73
verses.text: And he said not, 'all,' but "many;" nor made it clear who these were either, thereby making the return unto repentance easy to them; and to make it plain that a repentance is able to right transgressions, he bewails those that repent not, those who are incurably diseased, those who continue in their wounds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:74
verses.text: Observe then Apostolic virtue, in that, conscious of no evil in himself, he laments over the evils of others and is humbled for other men's transgressions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:75
verses.text: For this is the especial mark of a teacher, so to sympathize with the calamities of his disciples, and to mourn over the wounds of those who are under him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:76
verses.text: Then he mentions also the specific sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:77
verses.text: "Of the lasciviousness and uncleanness which they committed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:78
verses.text: Now in these words he alludes indeed to fornication; but if one carefully examine the subject, every kind of sin can be called by this name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:79
verses.text: For although the fornicator and adulterer is preeminently styled unclean, yet still the other sins also produce uncleanness in the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:80
verses.text: And therefore it is that Christ also calls the Jews unclean, not charging them with fornication only, but with wickedness of other kinds as well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:81
verses.text: Wherefore also He says that they made the outside clean, and that "not the things which enter in defile the man, but those which come out from him;" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:82
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:83
verses.text: ) and it is said in another place, "Every one that is proud in heart is unclean before the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:84
verses.text: (Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:85
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:86
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:87
verses.text: )   For nothing is purer than virtue, nothing uncleaner than vice; for the one is brighter than the sun, the other more stinking than mire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:88
verses.text: And to this they will themselves bear witness, who are wallowing in that mire and living in that darkness; at any rate, when one prepares them a little to see clearly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:89
verses.text: For as long as they are by themselves, and inebriate with the passion, just as if living in darkness they lie in unseemly wise to their much infamy, conscious even then where they are, although not fully; but after they have seen any of those who live in virtue reproving them or even showing himself, then they understand their own wretchedness more clearly; and as if a sunbeam had darted upon them, they cover up their own unseemliness and blush before those who know of their doings, yea, though the one be a slave and the other free, though the one be a king and the other a subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:90
verses.text: Thus when Ahab saw Elijah, he was ashamed, even when he had as yet said nothing; standing convicted by the mere sight of him; and when his accuser was silent, he pronounced a judgment condemnatory of himself; uttering the language of such as are caught, and saying, "Thou hast found me, O mine enemy!" ( Kings xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:91
verses.text: ) Thus Elijah himself conversed with that tyrant then with great boldness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:92
verses.text: Thus Herod, unable to bear the shame of those reproofs, (which shame the sound of the prophet's tongue with mighty and transparent clearness exposed more evidently,) cast John into the prison: like one who was naked and attempting to put out the light, that he might be in the dark again; or rather he himself dared not put it out, but, as it were, placed it in the house under a bushel; and that wretched and miserable woman compelled it to be done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:93
verses.text: But not even so could they cover the reproof, nay, they lit it up the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:94
verses.text: For both they that asked, Wherefore doth John dwell in prison? learnt the reason, and all they that since have dwelt on land or sea, who then lived, or now live, and who shall be hereafter, both have known and shall know clearly these wicked tragedies, both that of their lewdness and that of their bloodguiltiness, and no time shall be able to wipe out the remembrance of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:95
verses.text: So great a thing is virtue: so immortal is its memory, so completely even by words only doth it strike down its adversaries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:96
verses.text: For wherefore did he cast him into the prison? Wherefore did he not despise him? Was he going to drag him before the judgment-seat? Did he demand vengeance upon him for his adultery? Was not what he said then simply a reproof? Why then doth he fear and tremble? Was it not words and talk merely? But they stung him more than deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:97
verses.text: He led him not to any judgment-seat, but he dragged him before that other tribunal of conscience; and he sets as judges upon him all who freely gave their verdicts in their thought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:98
verses.text: Therefore the tyrant trembled, unable to endure the lustre of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:99
verses.text: Seest thou how great a thing is philosophy? It made a prisoner more lustrous than a king, and the latter is afraid and trembles before him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:100
verses.text: He indeed only put him in bonds; but that polluted woman rushed on to his slaughter also, although the rebuke was leveled rather against him, than herself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:101
verses.text: For he did not then meet "her" and say, Why cohabitest thou with the king? not that she was guiltless, (how should she be so?) but he wished by that other means to put all to rights.
