verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:102
verses.text: Wherefore he blamed the king, and yet not him with violence of manner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:103
verses.text: For he did not say, O polluted and all-polluted and lawless and profane one, thou hast trodden under foot the law of God, thou hast despised the commandments, thou hast made thy might law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:104
verses.text: None of these things; but even in his rebukings great was the gentleness of the man, great his meekness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:105
verses.text: For, "It is not lawful for thee," he says, "to have thy brother Philip's wife".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:106
verses.text: The words are those of one who teacheth rather than reproveth, instructeth rather than chasteneth, who composeth to order rather than exposeth, who amendeth rather than trampleth on him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:107
verses.text: But, as I said, the light is hateful to the thief, and the mere sight of the just man is odious to sinners; "for he is grievous unto us even to behold".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:108
verses.text: (Wisdom of Solomon ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:109
verses.text: ) For they cannot bear his radiance, even as diseased eyes cannot bear the sun's.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:110
verses.text: But to many of the wicked he is grievous not to behold only, but even to hear of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:111
verses.text: And therefore that polluted and all-polluted woman, the procuress of her girl, yea rather her murderess, although she had never seen him nor heard his voice, rushed on to his slaughter; and prepareth her whom she brought up in lasciviousnss to proceed also to murder, so extravagantly did she fear him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:112
verses.text: And what says she? "Give me here in a charger the head of John the Baptist".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:113
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:114
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:115
verses.text: ) Whither rushest thou over precipices, wretched and miserable one? What? is the accuser before thee? is he in sight and troubleth thee? Others said, "He is grievous unto us even to behold;" but to her, as I said, he was grievous to even hear of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:116
verses.text: Wherefore she saith, "Give me here in a charger the head of John".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:117
verses.text: And yet because of thee he inhabits a prison, and is laden with chains, and thou art free to wanton over thy love and to say, 'So completely have I subdued the king, that though publicly reproached he yielded not, nor desisted from his passion, nor tore asunder his adulterous connection with me, but even put him that reproached him in bonds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:118
verses.text: ' Why art thou mad and rabid, when even after that reproof of his sin thou retainest thy paramour? Why seekest thou a table of furies, and preparest a banquet of avenging demons? Seest thou how nothing-worth, how cowardly, how unmanly, is vice; how when it shall most succeed, it then becomes more feeble? For this woman was not so much disturbed before she had cast John into prison, as she is troubled after he is bound, and she is urgent, saying, "Give me here in a charger the head of John".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:119
verses.text: And wherefore so? 'I fear,' she says, 'lest there be any hushing up of his murder, lest any should rescue him from his peril.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:120
verses.text: ' And wherefore requirest thou not the whole corpse, but the head? 'The tongue,' she says, 'that pained me, that I long to see silent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:121
verses.text: ' But the contrary will happen, as indeed it also hath done, thou wretched and miserable one! it will cry louder afterwards, when it is cut out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:122
verses.text: For then indeed it cried in Judaea only, but now it will reach to the ends of the world; and wheresoever thou enterest into a church, whether it be among the Moors, or among the Persians, or even unto the British isles themselves, thou hearest John crying, "It is not lawful for thee to have thy brother Phillip's wife".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:123
verses.text: But she, unknowing to reason in any such way, urges and presses, and thrusts on the senseless tyrant to the murder, fearing lest he change his mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:124
verses.text: But from this too learn thou again the power of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:125
verses.text: Not even when he was shut up and bound and silent, does she bear the righteous man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:126
verses.text: Seest thou how weak a thing vice is? how unclean? For in the place of meats it bringeth in a human head upon a charger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:127
verses.text: What is more polluted, what more accursed, what more immodest, than that damsel? what a voice she uttered in that theatre of the devil, in that banquet of demons! Seest thou this tongue and that; the one bringing healthful medicines, the other one with poison on it, and made the purveyor to a devilish banquet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:128
verses.text: But wherefore did she not command him to be murdered within there, at the feast, when her pleasure would have been greater? She feared lest if he should come thither and be seen, he should change them all by his look, by his boldness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:129
verses.text: Therefore surely it is that she demandeth his head, wishing to set up a bright trophy of fornication; and give it to her mother.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:130
verses.text: Seest thou the wages of dancing, seest thou the spoils of that devilish plot? I mean not the head of John, but her paramour himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:131
verses.text: For if one examine it carefully, against the king that trophy was set up, and the victress was vanquished, and the beheaded was crowned, and proclaimed victor, even after his death shaking more vehemently the hearts of the offenders.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:132
verses.text: And that what I have said is no mere boast, ask of Herod himself; who, when he heard of the miracles of Christ, said, "This is John, he is risen from the dead: and therefore do these powers work in him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:133
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:134
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:135
verses.text: ) So lively was the fear, so abiding the agony he retained; and none had power to cast down the terror of his conscience, but that incorruptible Judge continued to take him by the throat, and day by day to demand of him satisfaction for the murder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:136
verses.text: Knowing, then, these things, let us not fear to suffer evil, but to do evil; for that indeed is victory, but this defeat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:137
verses.text: Wherefore also Paul said, "Why not rather take wrong, why not rather be defrauded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:138
verses.text: Nay, ye yourselves do wrong, and defraud, and that your brethren".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:139
verses.text: For by the suffering evil come those crowns, those prizes, that proclamation of victory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:140
verses.text: And this may be seen in all the saints.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 29:141
verses.text: Since then they all were thus crowned, thus proclaimed, let us too travel this road, and let us pray indeed that we enter not into temptation; but if it should come, let us make stand with much manliness and display the proper readiness of mind, that we may obtain the good things to come, through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, with Whom to the Father, together with the Holy Ghost, be glory, might, honor, now and for ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:1
verses.text: Homily XXIX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:3
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:4
verses.text: This is the third time I am coming to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:5
verses.text: At the mouth of two witnesses or three shall every word be established.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:6
verses.text: The wisdom of Paul and his much tender affection, one may observe in many other circumstances, but especially in this, his being so abundant and vehement in his admonitions, but so tardy and procrastinating in his punishments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:7
verses.text: For he did not chastise them immediately on their sinning, but warned them once and again; and not even so, upon their paying no attention, does he exact punishment, but warns again, saying, "This is the third time I am coming to you;" and 'before I come I write again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:8
verses.text: ' Then, that his procrastinating may not produce indifference, see how he corrects this result also, by threatening continually and holding the blow suspended over them, and saying, "If I come again I will not spare;" and "lest when I come again I should mourn for many".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:9
verses.text: These things, then, he doeth and speaketh, in this too imitating the Lord of all: because that God also threateneth indeed continually and warneth often, but not often chastiseth and punisheth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:10
verses.text: And so in truth also doth Paul, and therefore he said also before, "To spare you I came not as yet to Corinth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:11
verses.text: What is, "to spare you?" Lest finding you to have sinned and to continue unamended, I should visit with chastisement and punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:12
verses.text: And here, "This is the third time I am coming to you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:13
verses.text: At the mouth of two witnesses or three shall every word be established".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:14
verses.text: He joins the unwritten to the written, as he has done also in another place, saying, "He that is joined to an harlot is one body; for the twain," saith He, "shall become one flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:15
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:16
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:17
verses.text: ) Howbeit, this was spoken of lawful marriage; but he diverted its application unto this thing conveniently, so as to terrify them the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:18
verses.text: And so he doth here also, setting his comings and his warnings in the place of witnesses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:19
verses.text: And what he says is this: 'I spoke once and again when I was with you; I speak also now by letter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:20
verses.text: And if indeed ye attend to me, what I desired is accomplished; but if ye pay no attention, it is necessary henceforth to stop speaking, and to inflict the punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:21
verses.text: ' Wherefore he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:22
verses.text: "I have said beforehand, and I do say beforehand when I was present the second time; so now being absent I write to them that sinned heretofore and to all the rest, that if I come again, I will not spare".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:23
verses.text: 'For if at the mouth of two witnesses or three every word shall be established, and I have come twice and spoken, and speak now also by this Epistle; it follows, I must after this keep my word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:24
verses.text: For think not, I pray you, that my writing is of less account than my coming; for as I spoke when present, so now I write also when absent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:25
verses.text: ' Seest thou his fraternal solicitude? Seest thou forethought becoming a teacher? He neither kept silence nor punished, but he both foretells often, and continues ever threatening, and puts off the punishment, and if they should continue unamended, then he threatens to bring it to the proof.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:26
verses.text: 'But what didst thou tell them before when present, and when absent writest?' "That if I come again, I will not spare".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:27
verses.text: Having showed before that he is unable to do this unless he is compelled, and having called the thing a mourning, and a humbling; (for he saith, "lest my God should humble me before you, and I should mourn for them that have sinned heretofore, and not repented;—Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:28
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:29
verses.text: ) and having made his excuse unto them, namely, that he had told them before, once and twice and thrice, and that he does and contrives all he can so as to hold back the punishment, and by the fear of his words to make them better, he then used this unpleasing and terrifying expression, "If I come again, I will not spare".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:30
verses.text: He did not say, 'I will avenge and punish and exact satisfaction:' but again expresses even punishment itself in paternal language; showing his tender affection, and his heart to be grieved along with them; because that he always to "spare" them put off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:31
verses.text: Then that they may not think now also that there will be again a putting off, and merely a threat in words, therefore he both said before, "At the mouth of two witnesses or three shall every word be established;" and now, "If I come again, I will not spare".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:32
verses.text: Now what he means is this: 'I will no longer put off, if (which God forbid) I find you unamended; but will certainly visit it, and make good what I have said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:33
verses.text: '   Then with much anger and vehement indignation against those who make a mock of him as weak, and ridicule his presence, and say, "his presence is weak, and his speech of no account;" (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:34
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:35
verses.text: ) aiming his efforts at these men, he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:36
verses.text: "Seeing that ye seek a proof of Christ that speaketh in me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:37
verses.text: For he said this, dealing at once a blow at these, and at the same time lashing those also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:38
verses.text: Now what he means is this; 'Since ye are desirous of proving whether Christ dwelleth in me, and call me to an account, and on this score make a mock of me as mean and despicable, as if I were destitute of that Power; ye shall know that we are not destitute, if ye give us occasion, which God forbid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:39
verses.text: ' What then? tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:40
verses.text: Dost thou therefore punish, because they seek a proof? 'No,' he says; for had he sought this, he would have punished them at the first on their sinning, and would not have put off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:41
verses.text: But that he does not seek this, he has shown more clearly as he proceeds, saying, "Now I pray that ye do no evil, not that we may appear approved, but that ye may be approved, though we be as reprobates".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:42
verses.text: (Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:43
verses.text: )  He doth not employ those words then as assigning a reason, but rather in indignation, rather as attacking those that despise him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:44
verses.text: 'For,' he says, 'I have no desire indeed to give you such a proof, but if you yourselves should furnish cause and should choose to challenge me, ye shall know by very deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:45
verses.text: ' And observe how grievous he makes what he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:46
verses.text: For he said not, 'Since ye seek a proof of me,' but "of Christ that speakest in me, showing that it was against Him they sinned".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:47
verses.text: And he did not say merely, 'dwelling in me,' but "speaking in me," showing that his words are spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:48
verses.text: But if he doth not display His power nor punish, (for thenceforward the Apostle transferred what he said from himself to Christ, thus making his threat more fearful,) it is not from weakness; for He can do it: but from long suffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:49
verses.text: Let none then think His forbearance to be weakness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:50
verses.text: For why marvellest thou that He doth not now proceed against sinners, nor in his forbearance and long suffering exacts satisfaction, seeing that He endured even to be crucified, and though suffering such things punished not? Wherefore also he added,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:52
verses.text: "Who to you-ward is not weak, but is mighty in you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:53
verses.text: For though He was crucified through weakness, yet He liveth through the Power of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:54
verses.text: These words have much obscurity and give disturbance to the weaker sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:55
verses.text: Wherefore it is necessary to unfold them more clearly, and to explain the signification of the expression as to which the obscurity exists, that no one may be offended, even of the simpler sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:56
verses.text: What then, at all, is that which is here said, and what the term "weakness" designates, and in what signification it is used, it is necessary to learn.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:57
verses.text: For the term is indeed one, but it has many meanings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:58
verses.text: For bodily sickness is termed 'weakness:' whence it is even said in the Gospel, "Behold, he whom Thou lovest is weak," (John xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:60
verses.text: ) concerning Lazarus; and He Himself said, "This weakness is not unto death;" and Paul, speaking of Epaphras, "For indeed he was weak nigh unto death, but God had mercy on him;" (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:61
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:62
verses.text: ) and of Timothy, "Use a little wine for thy stomach's sake and thine often weaknesses".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:63
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:64
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:65
verses.text: ) For all these denote bodily sickness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:66
verses.text: Again, the not being established firmly in the faith is called 'weakness;' the not being perfect and complete.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:67
verses.text: And denoting this Paul said, "Him that is weak in the faith receive ye but not to doubtful disputations:" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:68
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:70
verses.text: ) and again, "One believeth that he may eat all things; another, who is weak, eateth herbs," denoting him who is weak in the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:71
verses.text: Here then are two significations of the term 'weakness;' there is yet a third thing which is called 'weakness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:72
verses.text: ' What then is this? Persecutions, plottings, insults, trials, assaults.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:73
verses.text: And denoting this Paul said, "For this thing I besought the Lord thrice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:74
verses.text: And He said unto me, My grace is sufficient for thee: for My power is made perfect in weakness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:75
verses.text: (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:76
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:78
verses.text: ) What is "in weakness?" In persecutions, in dangers, in trials, in plottings, in deaths.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:79
verses.text: And denoting this he said, Wherefore, I take pleasure in weakness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:80
verses.text: Then showing what kind of weakness he means, he spake not of fever, nor of doubt about the faith; but what? "in injuries, in necessities, in distresses, in stripes, in imprisonments, that the power of Christ may rest upon me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:81
verses.text: For when I am weak, then am I strong".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:82
verses.text: (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:83
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:84
verses.text: ) That is to say 'when I am persecuted, when I am driven up and down, when I am plotted against, then am I strong, then the rather I prevail over, and get the better of them that plot against me, because that grace resteth upon me, more largely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:85
verses.text: It is then in this third sense that Paul useth "weakness;" and this is what he means by it; aiming again, as I said also before, at that point, his seeming to them to be mean and contemptible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:86
verses.text: For indeed he had no desire to boast, nor to seem to be what he really was, nor yet to display the power which he possessed of punishing and revenging; whence also he was accounted to be mean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:87
verses.text: When then as so accounting they were going on in great indifference and insensibility, and repented not of their sins, he seizes a favorable opportunity, discourses with much vigor upon these points also, and shows that it was not from weakness he did nothing, but from long-suffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:88
verses.text: Then, as I said, by transferring the argument from himself to Christ, he enhances their fear, he increases his threat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:89
verses.text: And what he says is this; 'for even supposing I should do something and chastise and take vengeance on the guilty ones, is it I that chastise and take vengeance? it is He that dwelleth in me, Christ Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:90
verses.text: But if ye do not believe this, but are desirous of receiving a proof by deeds of Him that dwelleth in me, ye shall know presently; "For he is not weak to you-ward, but is even powerful".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:91
verses.text: ' And wherefore added he "to you-ward," seeing He is mighty everywhere? for should He be minded to punish unbelievers, He is able; or demons, or anything whatsoever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:92
verses.text: What then is the import of the addition? The expression is either as shaming them exceedingly by remembrance of the proofs they have already received; or else as declaring this, that meanwhile He shows His power in you who ought to be corrected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:93
verses.text: As he said also in another place, "For what have I to do to judge them also that are without?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:94
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:95
verses.text: ) 'For those that are without,' he says, 'He will then call to account in the day of judgment, but you even now, so as to rescue you from that punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:96
verses.text: ' But nevertheless even this instance of his solicitude, although arising from tender affection, observe how he combines with fear and much anger, saying, "Who to you-ward is not weak, but is powerful in you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:97
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:98
verses.text: "For though He was crucified through weakness, yet He liveth through the Power of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:99
verses.text: What is, "though He was crucified through weakness?" 'For though He chose,' he says, 'to endure a thing which seems to carry a notion of weakness, still this in no way breaks in upon His Power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:100
verses.text: That still remains invincible, and that thing which seemeth to be of weakness, hath nothing harmed it, nay this very thing itself shows His Power most of all, in that He endured even such a thing, and yet His Power was not mutilated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:101
verses.text: ' Let not then the expression "weakness" disturb thee; for elsewhere also he says, "The foolishness of God is wiser than men, and the weakness of God is stronger than men;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:102
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:103
verses.text: ) although in God is nothing either foolish or weak: but he called the Cross so, as setting forth the conception of the unbelieving regarding it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:104
verses.text: Hear him, at least, interpreting himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:105
verses.text: "For the preaching of the Cross is to them that perish foolishness, but unto us which are saved it is the power of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:106
verses.text: (Ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:107
verses.text: ) And again; "But we preach Christ crucified, unto the Jews a stumbling-block, and unto the Greeks foolishness; but unto them which are called, both Jews and Greeks, Christ the power of God and the wisdom of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:108
verses.text: (Ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:110
verses.text: ) And again; "But the natural man receiveth not the things of the Spirit, for they are foolishness unto him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:111
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:112
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:113
verses.text: ) Observe, how in every place he expresseth the conception of the unbelieving, who look upon the Cross as foolishness and weakness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:114
verses.text: And so, in truth, here also he means not "weakness" really such, but what was suspected to be such with the unbelieving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:115
verses.text: He doth not then say this, that because He was weak He was crucified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:116
verses.text: Away with the thought! For that He had it in His power not to have been crucified He showed throughout; when He now cast men down prostrate, now turned back the beams of the sun, and withered a fig-tree, and blinded their eyes that came against Him, and wrought ten thousand other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:117
verses.text: What then is this which he says, "through weakness!" That even although He was crucified after enduring peril and treachery, (for we have showed that peril and treachery are called weakness,) yet still He was nothing harmed thereby.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:118
verses.text: And he said this to draw the example unto his own case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:119
verses.text: For since the Corinthians beheld them persecuted, driven about, despised, and not avenging nor visiting it, in order to teach them that neither do they so suffer from want of power, nor from being unable to visit it, he leads on the argument up to The Master, because 'He too,' saith he, 'was crucified, was bound, suffered ten thousand things, and He visited them not, but continued to endure things which appeared to argue weakness, and in this way displaying His Power, in that although He punishes not nor requites, He is not injured any thing at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:120
verses.text: For instance, the Cross did not cut asunder His life, nor yet impeded His resurrection, but He both rose again and liveth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:121
verses.text: ' And when thou hearest of the Cross and of life, expect to find the doctrine concerning the Incarnation, for all that is said here hath reference to that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:122
verses.text: And if he says "though the Power of God," it is not as though He were Himself void of strength to quicken His flesh; but it was indifferent with him to mention either Father or Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:123
verses.text: For when he said, "the Power of God," he said by His own Power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:124
verses.text: For that both He Himself raised it up and sustains it, hear Him saying, "Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:125
verses.text: (John ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:126
verses.text: ) But if that which is His, this he saith to be the Father's, be not disturbed; "For," He saith, "all My Father's things are Mine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:127
verses.text: (John xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:128
verses.text: ) And again, "All Mine are Thine, and Thine are Mine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:129
verses.text: (Ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:130
verses.text: xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:131
verses.text: ) 'As then He that was crucified was nothing harmed,' he says, 'so neither are we when persecuted and warred against;' wherefore also he adds,  "For even we also if we are weak in Him, yet we shall live with Him through the Power of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:132
verses.text: What is the meaning of "we are weak in Him?" We are persecuted, are driven here and there, suffer extremity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:133
verses.text: But what is "with Him?" 'Because of the preaching,' he says, 'and our faith in Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:134
verses.text: But if for His sake we undergo what is sad and disagreeable, it is quite plain that we shall what is pleasant also:' and so he added, "but we are saved with Him by the Power of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:135
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:137
verses.text: "Try your own selves, whether ye be in the faith, prove your own selves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:138
verses.text: Know ye not as to your own selves, that Christ is in you, unless indeed ye be reprobate? But I hope that ye shall know that we are not reprobate".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:139
verses.text: For since by what he has said he hath shown that even if he does not punish, it is not because he hath not Christ in himself, but because he intimates His long-suffering, Who was crucified and yet avenged not Himself; he again, in another manner, produces the same effect, and still more irrefragably, establishing his argument by the disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:140
verses.text: 'For why speak I of myself,' he says 'the teacher, who have so much care upon me and am entrusted with the whole world and have done such great miracles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:141
verses.text: For if ye will but examine yourselves who are in the rank of disciples, ye will see that Christ is in you also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:142
verses.text: But if in you, then much more in your teacher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:143
verses.text: For if ye have faith, Christ is in you also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:144
verses.text: ' For they who then believed wrought miracles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:145
verses.text: Wherefore also he added, "Try your own selves, prove your own selves, whether ye be in the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:146
verses.text: Know ye not as to your own selves, unless indeed that Christ is in you, ye be reprobate?" 'But if in you, much more in your teacher?' He seems to me here to speak of the "faith" which relates to miracles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:147
verses.text: 'For if ye have faith,' he says, "Christ is in you, except ye have become reprobates".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:148
verses.text: Seest thou how again he terrifies them, and shows even to superfluity that Christ is with Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:149
verses.text: For he seems to me to be here alluding to them, even as to their lives.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:150
verses.text: For since faith is not enough by itself to draw down the energy of the Spirit, and he had said that '"if ye are in the faith" ye have Christ in you,' and it happened that many who had faith were destitute of that energy; in order to solve the difficulty, he says, "except ye be reprobate," except that is ye are corrupt in life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:151
verses.text: "But I hope that ye shall know that we are not reprobate".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:152
verses.text: What followed naturally was to have said, "but if ye have become reprobate, yet we have not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:153
verses.text: He doth not, however, say so, for fear of wounding them, but he hints it in an obscure manner, without either making the assertion thus, 'ye are reprobate,' or proceeding by question and saying, 'But if ye are reprobate,' but leaving out even this way of putting it by question, he indicates it obscurely by adding, "But I hope that ye shall know that we are not reprobate".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:154
verses.text: Here also again, great is the threat, great the alarm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:155
verses.text: 'For since ye desire,' he says, 'in this way, by your own punishment to receive the proof, we shall have no difficulty in giving you that demonstration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:156
verses.text: ' But he does not indeed so express himself, but with more weight and threatening.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:157
verses.text: "But I hope that ye shall know that we are not reprobate".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:158
verses.text: 'For ye ought indeed,' he saith, 'to have known even without this what we are, and that we have Christ speaking and working in us; but since ye desire to receive the proof of it by deeds also, ye shall know that we are not reprobate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:159
verses.text: ' Then when he has held the threat suspended over their heads, and brought the punishment now up to their doors, and has set them a trembling, and made them look for vengeance; see how again he sweetens down his words and soothes their fear, and shows his unambitious temper, his tender solicitude towards his disciples, his high-principledness of purpose, his loftiness and freedom from vain-glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:160
verses.text: For he exhibits all these qualities in what he adds, saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:162
verses.text: "Now I pray to God that ye do no evil, not that we may appear approved, but that ye may do that which is honorable, though we be as reprobate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:163
verses.text: For we can do nothing against the truth but for the truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:164
verses.text: For we rejoice when we are weak, and ye are strong.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:165
verses.text: For this also we pray for even your perfecting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:166
verses.text: What can be equal to this soul? He was despised, he was spit upon, he was ridiculed, he was mocked, as mean, as contemptible, as a braggart, as boastful in his words but in his deeds unable to make even a little show; and although seeing so great a necessity for showing his own power, he not only puts off, not only shrinks back, but even prays that he may not fall into such a position.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:167
verses.text: For he says, "I pray that ye do no evil, not that we may appear approved, but that ye may do that which is honorable, though we be as reprobate".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:168
verses.text: What is it he says? 'I entreat God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:169
verses.text: I beseech Him,' he says, 'that I may find no one unreformed, may find no one' that has not repented? yea, rather, not this alone, but that none may have sinned at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:170
verses.text: For,' he says, 'that ye have done no evil, but if ye have perchance sinned, then that ye may have changed your conduct, and been beforehand with me in reforming, and arresting all wrath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:171
verses.text: For this is not what I am eager about, that we should be approved in this way, but clean the contrary, that we should not appear approved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:172
verses.text: For if ye should continue,' he says, 'sinning and not repenting, it will be necessary for us to chastise, to punish, to maim your bodies; (as happened in the case of Sapphira and of Magus;) and we have given proof of our power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:173
verses.text: But we pray not for this, but the contrary, that we may not be shown to be approved in this way, that we may not in this way exhibit the proof of the power which is in us, by chastising you and punishing you as sinning and as incurably diseased, but what? "That ye should do that which is honorable," we pray for this, that ye should ever live in virtue, ever in amendment; "and we should be as reprobate," not displaying our power of punishing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:174
verses.text: ' And he said not, "reprobate" for he would not "be" reprobate, even though he did not punish, nay rather for this very reason he would be "approved;" 'but even if some suspect us,' he says, 'on account of our not displaying our power, to be contemptible and cast away, we care nothing for this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:175
verses.text: Better we should be so deemed of by those, than display the power which God hath given to us in those stripes, and in that unreformedness of heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:176
verses.text: '  "For we can do nothing against the truth, but for the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:177
verses.text: For that he may not seem merely to be gratifying them, (for this is what one who was void of vain-glory might do,) but to be doing what the nature of the thing demanded, he added this, "for we can do nothing against the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:178
verses.text: 'For if we find you,' he says, 'in good repute, having driven away your sins by repentance and having boldness towards God; we shall not be able thereafter, were we never so willing, to punish you, but should we attempt it even, God will not work with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:179
verses.text: For to this end gave He us our power that the judgment we give should be true and righteous, not contrary to the truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:180
verses.text: ' Seest thou how in every way he can, he makes what he says void of offensiveness, and softens the harshness of his menace? Moreover as he has eagerly endeavored this, so is he desirous also to show that his mind was quite joined to them; wherefore also he added, "For we rejoice when we are weak and ye are strong, and this also we pray for even your perfecting".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:181
verses.text: 'For most certainly,' he says, 'we cannot do any thing against the truth, that is, punish you if you are well pleasing to God; besides, because we cannot, we therefore do not wish it, and even desire the contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:182
verses.text: Nay, we are particularly glad of this very thing, when we find you giving us no occasion to show that power of ours for punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:183
verses.text: For even if the doing of such things shows men glorious and approved and strong; still we desire the contrary, that ye should be approved and unblamable, and that we should never at any time reap the glory thence arising.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:184
verses.text: ' Wherefore he says, "For we are glad when we are weak".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:185
verses.text: What is, "are weak?" 'When we may be thought weak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:186
verses.text: ' Not when we are weak, but when we are thought weak; for they were thought so by their enemies, because they displayed not their power of punishing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:187
verses.text: 'But still we are glad, when your behavior is of such a sort as to give us no pretence for punishing you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:188
verses.text: And it is a pleasure to us to be in this way considered weak, so that only ye be blameless;' wherefore he adds, "and ye are strong," that is, 'are approved, are virtuous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:189
verses.text: And we do not only wish for this, but we pray for this, that ye may be blameless, perfect, and afford us no handle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:190
verses.text: '   This is paternal affection, to prefer the salvation of the disciples before his own good name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:191
verses.text: This is the part of a soul free from vainglory; this best releaseth from the bonds of the body and makes one to rise aloft from earth to heaven, the being pure from vain-glory; just as therefore the contrary leadeth unto many sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:192
verses.text: For it is impossible that one who is not pure from vain-glory, should be lofty and great and noble; but he must needs grovel on the ground, and do much damage, whilst the slave of a polluted mistress, more cruel than any barbarian.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:193
verses.text: For what can be fiercer than she who, when most courted, is then most savage? Even wild beasts are not this, but are tamed by much attention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:194
verses.text: But vain-glory is quite the contrary, by being contemned she is made tame, by being honored she is made savage and is armed against her honorer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:195
verses.text: The Jews honored her and were punished with exceeding severity; the disciples slighted her and were crowned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:196
verses.text: And why speak I of punishment and crowns? for to this very point of being seen to be glorious, it contributes more than any thing, to spit upon vainglory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:197
verses.text: And thou shalt see even in this world that they who honor it are damaged, whilst those who slight it are benefited.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:198
verses.text: For the disciples who slighted it, (for there is no obstacle to our using the same example again,) and preferred the things of God, outshine the sun, having gained themselves an immortal memory even after their death; whilst the Jews who crouched to it are become cityless, heartless, degraded, fugitives, exiles, mean, contemptible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:199
verses.text: Do thou, therefore, if thou desirest to receive glory, repel glory; but if thou pursuest glory, thou shalt miss glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:200
verses.text: And, if ye will, let us also try this doctrine in worldly matters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:201
verses.text: For whom do we make sport of in our jests? Is it not of those whose minds are set upon it? Certainly then, these men are the most entirely destitute of it, having countless accusers and being slighted by all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:202
verses.text: And whom do we admire, tell me; is it not those who despise it? Certainly then, these are they that are glorified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:203
verses.text: For as he is rich, not who is in need of many things, but who is in need of nothing; so he is glorious, not who loveth glory, but who despiseth it; for this glory is but a shadow of glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:204
verses.text: No one having seen a loaf painted, though he should be pressed with hunger ever so much, will attack the picture.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:205
verses.text: Neither then do thou pursue these shadows, for this is a shadow of glory, not glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:206
verses.text: And that thou mayest know that this is the manner of it and that it is a shadow, consider this that it must be so, when the thing hath a bad name amongst men, when all consider it a thing to be avoided, they even who desire it; and when he who hath it and he covets it are ashamed to be called after it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:207
verses.text: 'Whence then is this desire,' saith one, 'and how is the passion engendered?' By littleness of soul, (for one ought not only to accuse it, but also to correct it,) by an imperfect mind, by a childish judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:208
verses.text: Let us then cease to be children, and let us become men: and let us every where pursue the reality, not the shadows, both in wealth, and in pleasure, and in luxury, and in glory, and in power; and this disease will cease, and many others also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:209
verses.text: For to pursue shadows is a madman's part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:210
verses.text: Wherefore also Paul said, "Awake up righteously and sin not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:211
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:212
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:213
verses.text: ) For there is yet another madness, sorer than that caused by devils, than that from frenzy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:214
verses.text: For that admits of forgiveness, but this is destitute of excuse, seeing the soul itself is corrupted and its right judgment lost; and that of frenzy indeed is an affection of the body, but this madness hath its seat in the artificer mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:215
verses.text: As then of fevers those are sorer, yea incurable, which seize upon firm bodies and lurk in the recesses of the nerves and are hidden away in the veins, so truly is this madness also, seeing it lurks in the recesses of the mind itself, perverting and destroying it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:216
verses.text: For how is it not clear and evident madness, yea, a distemper sorer than any madness, to despise the things which abide forever, and to cling with great eagerness to those which perish? For, tell me, if one were to chase the wind or try to hold it, should we not say that he was mad? And what? if one should grasp a shadow and neglect the reality; if one should hate his own wife and embrace her shadow; or loathe his son and again love his shadow, wouldest thou seek any other clearer sign in proof of madness? Such are they also who greedily follow the present things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:217
verses.text: For they are all shadow, yea, whether thou mention glory, or power, or good report, or wealth, or luxury, or any other thing of this life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:218
verses.text: And therefore truly it is that the prophet said, "Surely man walketh in a shadow, yea, he disquieth himself in vain;" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:219
verses.text: xxxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:220
verses.text: ) and again, "Our days decline like a shadow".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:221
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:222
verses.text: cii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:223
verses.text: ) And in another place, he calls human things smoke and the flower of grass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:224
verses.text: But it is not only his good things which are shadow, but his evils also, whether it be death thou mention, or poverty, or disease, or any other thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:225
verses.text: What then are those things which abide, both good and evil? The eternal kingdom and the everlasting hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:226
verses.text: For "neither shall the worm die, nor shall the fire be quenched:" (Mark ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:227
verses.text: ) and "these shall rise again to everlasting life: and these to everlasting punishment".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:228
verses.text: (Mark xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 30:229
verses.text: ) That then we may escape the one and enjoy the other, letting go the shadow, let us cling to the real things with all earnestness, for so shall we obtain the kingdom of heaven, which may we all obtain though the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ, to Whom be glory and might for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:1
verses.text: Homily XXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:2
verses.text: Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:3
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:4
verses.text: For this cause I write these things while absent, that I may not when present deal sharply, according to the authority which the Lord gave me for building up, and not for casting down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:5
verses.text: He was sensible he had spoken more vehemently than his wont, and especially towards the end of the Epistle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:6
verses.text: For he said before, "Now I Paul myself entreat you by the meekness and gentleness of Christ; I who in your presence am lowly among you, but being absent am of good courage towards you: Yea, I beseech you, that I may not be bold when I am present, with the confidence wherewith I count to be bold against some which count of us as if we walked according to the flesh;" (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:7
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:9
verses.text: ) and, "being in readiness to avenge all disobedience when your obedience shall be fulfilled:" (Ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:10
verses.text: ) and, "I fear lest when I come, I should find you not such as I would, and should myself be found of you such as ye would not;" (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:11
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:12
verses.text: ) and again, "lest when I come my God should humble me before you, and that I should mourn many of them which have sinned heretofore, and repented not of the lasciviousness and uncleanness which they committed:" (Ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:13
verses.text: ) and afterwards, "I told you before and foretell you, as if I were present the second time, and being absent now I write, that, if I come again, I will not spare; seeing that ye seek a proof of Christ, that speaketh in me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:14
verses.text: (Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:15
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:17
verses.text: ) Since then he had said these things and more besides, terrifying, shaming, reproaching, lashing them, he says, in excuse for all, "For this cause I write these things while absent, that I may not when present deal sharply".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:18
verses.text: For I am desirous the sharpness should lie in my letters and not in my deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:19
verses.text: I wish my threats to be vehement, that they may continue threats and never go forth into action.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:20
verses.text: Again even in this his apology he makes what he says more terrible, showing that it is not himself who is to punish, but God; for he added, "according to the authority which the Lord gave me;" and again, to show that he desires not to use his power to their punishment, he added, "not for casting down, but for building up".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:21
verses.text: And he hinted indeed this now, as I said, but he left it to them to draw the conclusion that if they should continue unamended, even this again is building up, to punish those that are of such a mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:22
verses.text: For so it is, and he knew it and showed it by his deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:23
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:24
verses.text: "For the rest, brethren, rejoice, be perfected, be comforted, be of the same mind, live in peace, and the God of love and peace shall be with you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:25
verses.text: What means, "for the rest, brethren, rejoice?" Thou hast pained, terrified, thrown them into an agony, made them to tremble and fear, and how biddest thou them rejoice? 'Why, for this very reason I bid them rejoice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:26
verses.text: For,' he says, 'if what is your part follow' upon mine, there will be nothing to prevent that joy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:27
verses.text: For all my part has been done; I have suffered long, I have delayed, I have forborne to cut off, I have besought, I have advised, I have alarmed, I have threatened, so as by every means to gather you in unto the fruit of repentance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:28
verses.text: And now it behoveth that your part be done, and so your joy will be unfading.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:29
verses.text: '  "Be perfected".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:30
verses.text: What is, "be perfected?" 'Be complete, fill up what is deficient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:31
verses.text: '  "Be comforted".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:32
verses.text: For, since their trials were numerous, and their perils great, he says, '"be comforted," both by one another, and by us, and by your change unto the better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:33
verses.text: For if ye should have joy of conscience and become complete, nothing is wanting unto your cheerfulness and comfort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:34
verses.text: For nothing doth so produce comfort as a pure conscience, yea, though innumerable trials surround.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:35
verses.text: '  "Be of the same mind, live in peace".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:36
verses.text: The request he made in the former Epistle also, at the opening.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:37
verses.text: For it is possible to be of one mind, and yet not to live in peace, for instance, when people agree in doctrine, but in their dealings with each other are at variance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:38
verses.text: But Paul requires both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:39
verses.text: "And the God of love and peace shall be with you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:40
verses.text: For truly he not only recommends and advises, but also prays.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:41
verses.text: For either he prays for this, or else foretells what shall happen; or rather, both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:42
verses.text: 'For if ye do these things,' he says, 'for instance, if ye be "of one mind" and "live in peace," God also will be with you, for He is "the God of love and of peace," and in these things He delighteth, He rejoiceth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:43
verses.text: Hence shall peace also be yours from His love; hence shall every evil be removed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:44
verses.text: This saved the world, this ended the long war, this blended together heaven and earth, this made men angels.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:45
verses.text: This then let us also imitate, for love is the mother of countless good things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:46
verses.text: By this we were saved, by this all those unspeakable good things come to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:47
verses.text: '   Then to lead them on unto it, he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:48
verses.text: "Salute one another with a holy kiss".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:49
verses.text: What is "holy?" not hollow, not treacherous, like the kiss which Judas gave to Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:50
verses.text: For therefore is the kiss given, that it may be fuel unto love, that it may kindle the disposition, that we may so love each other, as brothers brothers, as children parents, as parents children; yea, rather even far more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:51
verses.text: For those things are a disposition implanted by nature, but these by spiritual grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:52
verses.text: Thus our souls bound unto each other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:53
verses.text: And therefore when we return after an absence we kiss each other, our souls hastening unto mutual intercourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:54
verses.text: For this is that member which most of all declares to us the workings of the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:55
verses.text: But about this holy kiss somewhat else may yet be said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:56
verses.text: To what effect? We are the temple of Christ; we kiss then the porch and entrance of the temple when we kiss each other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:57
verses.text: See ye not how many kiss even the porch of this temple, some stooping down, others grasping it with their hand, and putting their hand to their mouth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:58
verses.text: And through these gates and doors Christ both had entered into us, and doth enter, whensoever we communicate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:59
verses.text: Ye who partake of the mysteries understand what I say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:60
verses.text: For it is in no common manner that our lips are honored, when they receive the Lord's Body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:61
verses.text: It is for this reason chiefly that we here kiss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:62
verses.text: Let them give ear who speak filthy things, who utter railing, and let them shudder to think what that mouth is they dishonor; let those give ear who kiss obscenely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:63
verses.text: Hear what things God hath proclaimed by thy mouth, and keep it undefiled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:64
verses.text: He hath discoursed of the life to come, of the resurrection, of immortality, that death is not death, of those other innumerable mysteries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:65
verses.text: For he that is about to be initiated comes to the priest's mouth as it were an oracle, to hear things full of awe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:66
verses.text: For he lost his life even from his forefathers, and comes to seek it again, and to ask how he may haply find and get it back.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:67
verses.text: Then God announceth to him how it may be found, and that mouth becomes more awful than the very mercy-seat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:68
verses.text: For that mercy-seat never sent forth a voice like this, but spake much of lesser things, of wars and such peace as is here below: but this speaks all about heaven and the life to come, and things new and that pass understanding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:69
verses.text: And having said,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:70
verses.text: "Salute one another with an holy kiss," he added, "All the saints salute you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:71
verses.text: By this also giving them good hopes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:72
verses.text: He has added this in the place of the kiss, knitting them together by the salutation, for the words also proceed from the same mouth from which the kiss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:73
verses.text: Seest thou how he brings them all together, both those who are widely separated in the body and those who are near, these by the kiss and those by the written message?   Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:74
verses.text: "The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, and the love of God," and the Father, "and the communion of the Holy Ghost, be with you all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:75
verses.text: After having united them to one other by the salutations and the kisses, he again closes his speech with prayer, with much carefulness uniting them unto God also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:76
verses.text: Where now are they who say that because the Holy Spirit is not inserted in the beginnings of the Epistles, He is not of the same substance? For, behold, he hath now enumerated Him with the Father and Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:77
verses.text: And besides this, one may remark, that when writing to the Colossians and saying, "Grace to you, and peace from God our Father," he was silent of the Son, and added not, as in all his Epistles, and from the Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:78
verses.text: Is then the Son not of the same substance either, because of this? Nay, these reasonings are of extreme folly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:79
verses.text: For this very thing especially shows Him to be of the same substance, that Paul useth the expression or not indifferently.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:80
verses.text: And that what is here said is no conjecture, hear how he mentions Son and Spirit, and is quite silent of the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:81
verses.text: For, writing to the Corinthians, he says, "But ye were washed, but ye were sanctified, but ye were justified in the name of the Lord Jesus Christ, and in the Spirit of our God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:82
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:83
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:84
verses.text: ) What then, tell me? were these not baptized into the Father? Then assuredly they were neither washed nor sanctified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:85
verses.text: But did they baptize them? doubtless then just as also they did baptize.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:86
verses.text: How then did he not say, 'Ye are washed in the name of the Father?' Because it was indifferent in his view, at one time to make mention of this, at another of that Person; and you may observe this custom in many places of the Epistles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:87
verses.text: For writing to the Romans he says, "I beseech you therefore by the mercies of God," (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:88
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:89
verses.text: ) although those mercies are of the Son; and, "I beseech you by the love of the Spirit," (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:90
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:91
verses.text: ) although love is of the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:92
verses.text: Wherefore then mentioned he not the Son in "the mercies," nor the Father in "the love?" Because as being things plain and admitted, he was silent about them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:93
verses.text: Moreover, he will be found again, to put the gifts also themselves transposedly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:94
verses.text: For having said here, "The grace of Christ, and the love of God and the Father, and the communion of the Holy Ghost;" he in another place speaks of "the communion of the Son," and of "the love of the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:95
verses.text: For, "I beseech you," he says, "by the love of the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:96
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:97
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:98
verses.text: ) And in his Epistle to the Corinthians, "God is faithful, by Whom ye were called into the communion of His Son".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:99
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:100
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:101
verses.text: ) Thus the things of the Trinity are undivided: and whereas the communion is of the Spirit, it hath been found of the Son; and whereas the grace is of the Son, it is also of the Father and of the Holy Spirit; for we read, "Grace be to you from God the Father".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:102
verses.text: And in another place, having enumerated many forms of it, he added, "But all these worketh the one and the same Spirit, dividing to each one severally as He will".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:103
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:104
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:105
verses.text: ) And I say these things, not confounding the Persons, (away with the thought!) but knowing both the individuality and distinctness of These, and the Unity of the Substance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:106
verses.text: Let us then continue both to hold these doctrines in their strictness, and to draw to us the love of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:107
verses.text: For before indeed He loved us when hating Him, and reconciled us who were His enemies; but henceforth He wishes to love us as loving Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:108
verses.text: Let us then continue to love Him, so that we may be also loved by Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:109
verses.text: For if when beloved by powerful men we are formidable to all, much more when beloved by God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:110
verses.text: And should it be needful to give wealth, or body, or even life itself for this love, let us not grudge them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:111
verses.text: For it is not enough to say in words that we love, but we ought to give also the proof of deeds; for neither did He show love by words only, but by deeds also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:112
verses.text: Do thou then also show this by thy deeds and do those things which please Him, for so shalt thou thyself reap again the advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:113
verses.text: For He needeth nothing that we have to bestow, and this is also a special proof of a sincere love, when one who needeth nothing and is not in any necessity, doth all for the sake of being loved by us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:114
verses.text: Wherefore also Moses said, "For what doth the Lord God require of you, but to love Him, and that thou shouldest be ready to walk after Him?" (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:115
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:116
verses.text: ) So that when He biddeth thee love Him, He then most of all showeth that He loves thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:117
verses.text: For nothing doth so secure our salvation as to love Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:118
verses.text: See then, how that all His commandments even tend together to our repose and salvation and good report.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:119
verses.text: For when he says, "Blessed are the merciful, blessed are the pure in heart, blessed are the meek, blessed are the poor in spirit, blessed are the peacemakers;" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:120
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:122
verses.text: ) He Himself indeed reaps no advantage from these, but he enjoins them for our adorning and attuning; and when He says, "I was an hungred," it is not as needing that ministry from us, but as exciting thee to humanity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:123
verses.text: For He was well able even without thee to feed the poor man; but as bestowing upon thee an exceeding treasure, he laid these commands upon thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:124
verses.text: For if the sun, which is but a creature, needeth not our eyes; for he abideth in his own proper brightness, even though none should look upon him, and we it is who are the gainers when we enjoy his beams; much more is this so with God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:125
verses.text: But that thou mayest learn this in yet another way; how great wilt thou have the distance to be between God and us? as great as between gnats and us, or much greater? Quite plainly it is much greater, yea, infinite.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:126
verses.text: If then we vainglorious creatures need not service nor honor from gnats, much rather the Divine Nature none from us, seeing It is impassible and needing nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:127
verses.text: The measure of that which He enjoyeth by us is but the greatness of our benefit, and the delight He taketh in our salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:128
verses.text: For this reason He also oftentimes relinquisheth His own, and seeketh thine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:129
verses.text: "For if any," he saith," have a wife that believeth not, and she be pleased to dwell with him, let him not put her away;" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:130
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:131
verses.text: ) and, "He that putteth away his wife, saving for the cause of fornication, causeth her to commit adultery".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:132
verses.text: Seest thou what unspeakable goodness? 'If a wife be a harlot,' He says, 'I do not compel the husband to live with her; and if she be an unbeliever, I do not forbid him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:133
verses.text: ' Again, 'if thou be grieved against any one, I command him that hath grieved thee to leave My gift and to run to thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:134
verses.text: ' For He saith, "If thou art offering thy gift, and there remember that thy brother hath aught against thee, leave thy gift before the altar, and go thy way, first be reconciled to thy brother, and then come and offer thy gift".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:135
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:136
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:138
verses.text: ) And what saith the parable of him that had devoured his all? (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:139
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:141
verses.text: ) Doth it not show this? For when he had eaten up those ten thousand talents, He had mercy on him, and let him go; but when he demanded of his fellowservant an hundred pence, he both called him wicked and delivered him over to the punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:142
verses.text: So great account doth He make of thy ease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:143
verses.text: The barbarian was about to sin against the wife of the just man, and He says, "I spared thee from sinning against me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:144
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:145
verses.text: xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:146
verses.text: ) Paul persecuted the Apostles, and He saith to him, "Why persecutest thou Me?" Others are hungry, and He Himself saith He is an hungred, and wanders about naked and a stranger, wishing to shame thee, and so to force thee into the way of almsgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on 2 Corinthians 31:147
verses.text: Reflecting then upon the love, how great He hath shown in all things, and still shows it to be, both having vouchsafed to make Himself known to us, (which is the greatest crown of good things, and light to the understanding and instruction in virtue,) and to lay down laws for the best mode of life, and having done all things for our sakes, having given His Son, and promised a kingdom, and invited us to those unspeakable good things, and prepared for us a most blessed life, let us do and say every thing so as both to appear worthy of His love and to obtain the good things to come; whereunto may we all attain, through the grace and love towards men of our Lord Jesus Christ; with Whom to the Father, with the Holy Spirit, be glory now and ever, and world without end, Amen.
